The following cautionary statements identify important factors that could cause our actual results to differ materially from those projected in the forward-looking statements made in this Offering Memorandum. Any statements about our expectations, beliefs, plans, objectives, assumptions or future events or performance are not historical facts and may be forward looking. These statements are often, but not always, made through the use of words or phrases such as “will likely result,” “are expected to,” “will continue,” “believe,” “anticipated,” “estimated,” “intends,” “expects,” “plans,” “seek,” “projection” and “outlook.” These statements involve estimates, assumptions and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially from those expressed in them. Any forward-looking statements are qualified in their entirety by reference to the factors discussed throughout this Offering Memorandum. Important risks, uncertainties and other factors that could cause such differences between the actual results from those expressed in forward-looking statements include, but are not limited to: - risks related to general economic conditions and economic slowdowns, liquidity pressure, fiscal or political uncertainty and declines in property sales and leasing activities; - adverse impact of COVID-19, including severe disruptions in the global economy and financial markets; - inability to compete with numerous local, regional and national competitors across our businesses and geographies; - negative impact of low demand for housing or lease terminations and/or tenant defaults; - inability to grow our business based on our acquisition strategy with appropriate acquisition opportunities and acceptable terms or the inability to close acquisitions under purchase agreements, exclusivity arrangements or letters of intent; - failure to appropriately address actual or perceived conflicts of interest; - risks related to managing large numbers of residential properties; - inability to effectively manage our growth into new geographies; - risks related to negative marketplace perception of our brands and reputation, which are key assets of our company; - failure to maintain, execute and adapt to our information technology strategies; - failure to successfully execute our strategy for operational efficiency; - risks related to key relationships with third-party providers; - litigation risks may negatively impact our financial liabilities and/or damage our reputation; - negative impact on our business related to adverse developments in the credit markets; - adverse impact of interruption or failure of our information technology, communications systems or data services; - negative impact of a material breach in security relating to our information systems; - the failure to comply with regulations related to a material breach in data security; ----- - the failure to license or enforce our intellectual property rights and risk associated to claims of intellectual property infringement; - risks related to insufficient insurance coverage; - risks related to weaknesses and deficiencies in our internal controls; - the failure to realize estimated cost savings, gains and synergies; - the failure to comply with new laws or regulations or changes in existing laws or regulations or the application thereof; - adverse impact of challenges by tax authorities or changes in tax laws or challenges to our tax position; - adverse impact due to inability to retain our senior management or our inability to attract and retain qualified and experienced employees; - negative impact of increased labor costs and disruption to operations due to labor disputes; - adverse impact of our shareholders’ interests conflicting with your interests as a holder of the Additional Notes; - inability to realize the full value of our goodwill; - risks related to changes to accounting standards; - negative impact of foreign exchange; - negative impact on financial results and liquidity due to our seasonal revenue and cash flow; and - negative impact of higher than expected capital expenditure and other maintenance costs. These and other factors are discussed in “Risk Factors” of this Offering Memorandum. Because the risk factors referred to in this Offering Memorandum could cause actual results or outcomes to differ materially from those expressed in any forward-looking statements made in this Offering Memorandum by us or on our behalf, you should not place undue reliance on any of these forwardlooking statements. Furthermore, any forward-looking statement speaks only as of the date on which it is made, and we undertake no obligation to update any forward-looking statement to reflect events or circumstances after the date on which the statement is made or to reflect the occurrence of unanticipated events. New factors will emerge in the future, and it is not possible for us to predict such factors. In addition, we cannot assess the impact of each factor on our business or the extent to which any factor, or combination of factors, may cause actual results to differ materially from those described in any forward-looking statements. -----

We are the global leader in the residential real estate services (“RRES”) market by dwellings under management, providing services to both individuals (“business-to-consumer” or “B2C”) and businesses (“business-to-business” or “B2B”), and have also entered the commercial real estate services segment for B2B customers. In 2022, we entered the UK market through the acquisition of FirstPort, the UK’s largest joint property manager (based on units under management), as a result of which we became the largest residential property management company in the world. We assist our residential and commercial customers at every stage of their property journey with competitive and comprehensive service offerings. We provide end-to-end assistance, from managing individual apartments and building areas jointly owned by apartment owners through our Lease Management and Letting and Joint Property Management business lines, respectively, to providing brokerage, digital and ancillary other services such as insurance brokerage, technical diagnostic and energy brokerage through our other business lines. Our RRES business is the leader in France, operating under the Foncia brand through a unique network of over 500 branches. We also hold leading positions in Switzerland, Benelux, Germany and the UK where we operate under various brands. We have expanded our size and reach through bolt-on acquisitions and completed over 330 acquisitions since 2016. In addition to our successful M&A track record, our recent performance has been marked by achievements in operations, digitization, and our IT and communications infrastructure. We believe our success is the result of a unique, integrated ecosystem of real estate services, which provides the opportunity for organic growth via cross-selling of additional services with recurring revenues and external growth through bolt-on acquisitions. We operate an integrated business model across a wide range of real estate services and divide our real estate services into the following businesses: - **French Residential Real Estate Services (representing 57.7% of 9M 2022 revenue) consisting of: - **Joint Property Management (representing 28.6% of 9M 2022 revenue) through which we are mandated by landlords to manage jointly owned building areas and equipment. - **Lease Management and Letting (representing 27.0% of 9M 2022 revenue) through which we manage properties on behalf of landlords and assist landlords and tenants throughout their rental process. - **Residential Services (representing 2.1% of 9M 2022 revenue) through which we provide other ancillary real estate services in France, notably via Constatimmo, Optissimmo and Tech-Way. - **French Real Estate Brokerage (representing 13.3% of 9M 2022 revenue) through which we assist property owners and buyers throughout the real estate sales process. ----- - **French Digital Services (representing 9.5% of 9M 2022 revenue) through which we operate services relying on digital platforms such as online real estate valuation and brokerage services. - **French B2B Services (representing 4.7% of 9M 2022 revenue) through which we provide real estate services to our commercial and institutional customers, as well as adjacent real estate services such as insurance and diagnostics services. - **International Services (representing 14.8% of 9M 2022 revenue) through which we provide the full spectrum of real estate services through our international operations in Switzerland, Benelux, Germany and the UK. As a result of the closing of the FirstPort acquisition in August 2022, our international services business will represent a greater portion of our group revenue going forward.

Subsubsection Title: Sector leadership focused on strongest economies in Western Europe providing competitive advantages
Subsubsection Text: We have established ourselves as a leader for residential real estate services in France, Switzerland, Benelux, Germany and the UK by delivering high quality, reliable and innovative services uniquely suited to the needs of our customers. As of August 2019, we were the number one player in the French real estate services market, with approximately 13% market share, according to an international report provider. As of September 30, 2022, we managed approximately 2.1 million dwellings in France, which is approximately two times the number of dwellings managed by our next closest competitor according to publically available information for the year ended 2020. Outside of France, we also hold leading positions in Switzerland, Benelux, Germany and the UK. As of September 30, 2022, we operated over 114 branches in these countries, which collectively accounted for 14.8% of our revenue for the nine months ended September 30, 2022. In 2022, we entered the UK market through the acquisition of FirstPort, one of the UK’s largest property services groups and the UK’s largest joint property manager with approximately 315,000 units under management as of March 2022, and has a market share of approximately 11%, twice the size of its closest competitor in the UK. FirstPort operates primarily in joint property management as well as in the rental management and real estate brokerage markets in England, Scotland and Wales with a strong geographical national coverage, generating revenue of €120 million in 2021 with the support of over 3,800 employees. FirstPort has an in-house built digital platform which enables it to offer a marketleading, fully automated and scalable service proposition which supports its continuous growth alongside a strong organic development, mobilization of a secured order book (recurring revenue streams with high visibility) and accretive acquisitions. Our scale, operations and service offerings provide us with a clear competitive advantage. Our centralized processes result in lower internal costs and enable improved customer service compared to our typically small, individual-owned competitors. Our comprehensive range of innovative services, such as FONCIA 24/7 (our assistance service for our joint property management customers), and Assurimo (our real estate insurance service), differentiate us from competitors. Our comprehensive network of over 500 branches covering all major French cities is one of the largest offerings in the market and results in close proximity to our customers and the dwellings that we manage; unique market positioning in negotiations with third-party repair and maintenance service suppliers resulting in decreased costs; and financial resources that allow us to expand our customer portfolio through acquisitions. We have been able to successfully enter markets through acquisitions and expanded our operating geography, despite the regulatory and technological requirements that create barriers to participation in the real estate services market. Our regional and national regulatory and real estate industry expertise and our leadership team’s extensive experience in the real estate services industry are key to meeting and complying with such requirements. Our strong reputation for quality, service and multi-branded strategy have also supported our ability to grow in existing markets and enter new markets. -----

Subsubsection Title: Loyal and diverse customer base and synergetic business model in an attractive and resilient market
Subsubsection Text: Our large and diversified client base, integrated ecosystem of residential real estate services and high customer retention rates drive a high level of recurring revenues (75% in 2020 and 72% in the nine months ended September 30, 2022). We have grown our diversified customer base to approximately 1.8 million dwellings in our French Joint Property Management business and over 376,000 dwellings in our French Lease Management business as at September 30, 2022. Through our synergetic business model, we are able to cross sell our services to our diverse customer portfolio across our business lines, which in turn leads to further organic growth. For example, our proven ability to cross-sell is highlighted by the high penetration rates of Assurimo, our specialized property insurance brokerage unit (providing property insurance, homeowners’ insurance policies and brokerage services) through which we currently provide building insurance (multi-risque immeubles) contracts to 49.7% and household insurance (multi-risque _habitation) contracts to 34.3% of our French Joint Property Management buildings, respectively._ Similarly, we currently provide technical services to approximately 104,220 contracts which represent 27.7% of our French RRES Lease Management customers through our dedicated business, Constatimmo. We believe that we are well positioned to target new customers, including B2B customers, given our knowledge regarding fulfilling requirements for our B2C customers. The addressable markets in which we operate are characterized by high outsourcing rates, with a high and stable portion of joint property or condominium owners (85% in France) under external management, as of August 2019 using services like our Joint Property Management business. Property owners tend to rely on expert services such as ours due to the volume of work and amount of legal and accounting know-how required to directly interface with tenants and other counterparties. Moreover, landlords rarely switch leasing managers during a tenancy, given the risks and costs involved in switching service providers and the limited potential benefit, resulting in a high customer net retention rate of 95.1% in our Joint Property Management business and 91.2% in our Lease Management business for the nine months ended September 30, 2022. The UK market is also characterized by a loyal customer base, as evidenced by FirstPort with a net retention rate of approximately 98% in the year ended December 31, 2021. We believe that through the integrated ecosystem of high-quality services we consistently provide we have established high customer retention rates, and long lasting customer relationships, certain of which last more than 20 years. Moreover, 36.2% of our customers from our Joint Property Management business in France entered into contracts of three or more years and 23.8% for two to three years for the nine months ended September 30, 2022. Due to our broad and diverse customer base, we are not reliant on any particular customer. According to an international report provider, the French property management market is estimated to be €12.2 billion in August 2019, of which €5.3 billion is captured by property management companies, with the rest serviced in-house. The externally serviced property management market has grown by approximately 2% annually between 2014 and 2019. This stable growth has been driven by population dynamics and the construction of collective units. We continue to capitalize on opportunities to grow through acquisition of customer portfolios, cross-selling of related services to our large client base and the addition of new revenue opportunities for our existing services.

Subsubsection Title: Strong and predictable cash flow generation with an inflation resilient business model
Subsubsection Text: We have a track record of steady cash flow generation, driven by a high level of recurring revenues, which has enabled us to regularly deleverage. Our trend of high EBITDA conversion rates has continued with a Pre-IFRS-16 EBITDA Conversion Rate, of approximately 85.1% for the year ended December 31, 2021, compared to 81.6% for the year ended December 31, 2020. Despite our regular M&A activity, our discretionary spend on acquisitions provides us with flexibility to manage our cash flow and reduce our financial leverage. Further, our business requires limited maintenance capital expenditures (accounting for approximately 4.2% and 4.6% of revenues for the year ended December 31, 2021 and ----- for the nine months ended September 30, 2022, respectively), and is characterized by limited working capital requirements. Our revenue increased by 12.2% to €943.3 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2022, up from €840.9 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2021 and increased by 19.3% to €1,146.8 million for the year ended December 31, 2021, up from €961.5 million for the year ended December 31, 2020. Our margin resilience is supported by an adaptable cost structure for the more cyclical flow Brokerage business, as Brokerage salary costs include a significant variable portion that is indexed on commissions. Our Adjusted EBITDA Margin was 27.7% for the twelve months ended September 30, 2022 and 28.2% and 26.9% for the years ended December 31, 2021 and 2020, respectively. Our recurring, stable revenue is in part due to our complementary business profiles across our branches, experienced management and sales force teams, and fee-based services in connection with our Joint Property Management and Lease Management and Letting businesses which accounted for 65.2% of our revenue in France for the nine months ended September 30, 2022. In addition, our high proportion of recurring revenues (75% in 2020 and 72% in the nine months ended September 30, 2022) and balanced portfolio of services split between stock and flow businesses with limited correlation have supported our resilience during adverse economic conditions, achieving a substantially stable performance in 2020 despite unprecedented government measures taken in response to the COVID-19 pandemic. We believe that our business model is resilient to inflationary pressures, in particular as a result of our ability to pass through a portion of our cost increases and of the limited impact of inflation on our business in general. Most of our contracts are either subject to an annual pricing assessment or contain inflation adjustment mechanisms, which allow us to effectively pass-through inflationary impact to our customers. In addition, our fees are typically derived as a proportion of rent, and we, therefore, benefit from price increases occurring in an inflationary environment. Due to the nature of our business, we have a relatively limited exposure to energy and gas price increases, and the energy saving measures that we have put in place allow us to further mitigate any such impact. We estimate that the negative impact from elevated levels of inflation on EBITDA for our French business in the nine months ended September 30, 2022 was approximately €2.5 million.

Subsubsection Title: Continuous investments in operational improvement through technology reinforces our competitive position and provides sustainable efficiency gains
Subsubsection Text: We continuously invest in cutting edge technology in order to offer the best multi-channel services to our customers. Since 2017, we have upgraded a significant portion of our IT and communication infrastructure including utilizing a mix of integrated and outsourced solutions, transitioning to a single telecom provider, and streamlining our finance and human resources functions with Workday, which enabled us to quickly and effectively transition to a work-from-home environment during the COVID19 pandemic. We have also leveraged our technological know-how combined with our knowledge of the real estate industry to design and launch our new ERP system, Millenium. Millenium integrates all of our IT and resource planning functions into one database to better meet our customers’ needs and address internal business challenges. Millenium increases the digitization of our activities with the aim of helping customers by creating greater transparency and improving our operations with standardized, digital processes to increase efficiency and to improve the speed at which we can serve our customers. We believe our high levels of investment in IT for our corporate platform and customer interface service such as over recent years give us a competitive edge in the current environment. Millenium was piloted at several of our branches in France and launched at all brokerage operations in France in early 2022 prior to the roll-out to our broader network starting in November 2022. Further, we commenced the roll-out of Millenium at our RRES operations which is now in use for 5.6% of our Joint Property Management dwellings and 6.0% of our Lease Management dwellings. We aim to accelerate the rollout of Millenium in the first quarter of 2023. ----- The digitization, standardization and automation offered by Millenium complement our already synergetic business model and will allow us to more quickly leverage our customer database to identify cross-selling opportunities leading to greater operating efficiencies and inter-business synergies. We believe that Millenium’s compatibility with big data, AI and IoT, will allow us to explore new business opportunities and provide access to a number of revenue-enhancing opportunities. For example, we have developed a new operational model called “Agency of the Future” which will utilize Millenium to reorganize the residential real estate services and aims at improving client satisfaction and reducing our customer churn rate, which we believe will, in turn, lead to greater opportunities for organic growth. Furthermore, we also believe that the gains of Millenium and the development of Agency of the Future will positively impact our EBITDA by €25.0 million in the next 24 months. We have invested in, and will continue to invest in, technology to continually improve our internal operations in order to provide our customers with product offerings that meet their needs and make us the number one choice among residential real estate service providers.

Subsubsection Title: Consolidation platform with proven track record of executing value accretive acquisitions to drive incremental EBITDA growth
Subsubsection Text: In addition to our organic growth, we maintain a successful, reduced risk strategy of growth through small, bolt-on acquisitions. We completed over 330 acquisitions since January 2016, which represented €814.1 million of acquired revenues. In the nine months ended September 30, 2022, we entered the UK market with the acquisition of FirstPort and we also completed 54 acquisitions in our primary French market and in other geographies, representing 29,069 new Lease Management dwellings and 553,981 new Joint Property Management dwellings and €261.1 million of acquired revenues. These 55 acquisitions contributed to our Adjusted EBITDA, which reached €409.9 million for the twelve months ended September 30, 2022, as compared to €348.3 million for the year ended December 31, 2021. Consolidation is a natural trend in the highly fragmented markets we operate in, accelerated by increasing regulations, and we play a key role in the market by defining new quality standards and unrivalled execution processes. We have a strong M&A team, with a disciplined approach that is dedicated to identifying, diligencing, completing and integrating opportunistic acquisitions in our five geographical regions, which we plan to expand in the UK. Our long-standing integration experience, including a dedicated post-acquisition integration team, enables us to extract full synergy potential from acquired businesses, with both cross-selling and cost synergies. We have identified a number of potential targets in France, Switzerland, Benelux, Germany and the UK to continue growing and, importantly, reinforcing our leadership in the market.

Subsubsection Title: Highly experienced management team with proven execution capabilities and focus on growth and value creation
Subsubsection Text: Our management team, led by our Chief Executive Officer, Philippe Salle, has significant experience in the industry and proven track record of delivering business and revenue growth, executing investment plans, driving continuous improvement of our European enterprise and generating high returns on capital. Our management team comes from various industries and geographies and is supported by four heads of region in France and four heads of region in international markets, who have extensive experience in real estate and enable us to provide our customers with tailored expertise and service. We believe that the collective industry knowledge and leadership of our management team positions them well to continue our successful organic and external growth and execute our strategies. Further, our management team encourages growth through a focus on operational efficiency and innovation including through the management’s dynamic external growth policy that enabled us to, among others, establish our market leading presence in the UK, Benelux, Switzerland and Germany, successfully divest our non-core businesses to focus on our core, synergetic businesses and more recently, by the ongoing overhaul of our IT infrastructure, including the development and deployment of Millenium and enabling our planned transition to our new operational model, “Agency of the Future.” This is demonstrated by the consistent increase in our revenues which increased by 12.2% to €943.3 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2022, up from €840.9 million for the nine months ended ----- September 30, 2021 and increased by 19.3% to €1,146.8 million for the year ended December 31, 2021, up from €961.5 million for the year ended December 31, 2020.

Subsubsection Title: Industry-leading technology to further reinforce our competitive advantage
Subsubsection Text: We are committed to providing the best real estate services offerings to our customers by investing in industry- leading IT and data platforms, which in turn supports our market share gains. Our most recent digital innovation, Millenium, an in-house developed ERP system that is cloud-based and will allow us to fully digitalize our businesses. We believe that Millenium will allow us to better, more efficiently serve our customers, cross-sell across our services and therefore capture greater market share from existing customers and generate business from new customers. Our IT and data platforms are subject to a process of continuous improvement and innovation, which we support with ongoing investments, such as the team of 68 developers we hired in connection with the development of Millenium. We believe that our robust investments in our IT and data platforms provide us with a significant competitive advantage, particularly during the COVID-19 pandemic when businesses have been required to transition to a work-from-home environment. Additionally, our ongoing and historical use of big data, AI and IoT to create new business opportunities enables us to maintain a cutting edge development program while minimizing the risks traditionally associated with experimentation. For example, we have developed our new operational model, Agency of the Future, which we believe will generate significant savings, mainly related to (i) staff costs synergies from the optimization of the ratios of middle and back-office functions to front-office employees and an increase in productivity and significant reduction of time spent on manual and repetitive processes and (ii) gains resulting from the digitization and automation of certain tasks that were previously done manually, such as reminder fees or the collection of postal charges. Since 2018, we have invested approximately €155.0 million into our IT projects, and we believe that the gains of Millenium and Agency of the Future will positively impact our EBITDA by €25.0 million in the next 24 months. We have developed, and continue to develop, innovative solutions based on emerging trends that are aimed at providing our customers with the highest quality, optimal solutions for their real estate needs. We are constantly looking for ways to improve our offerings and develop new solutions for our customers, which we expect to drive incremental growth and positively impact our revenue.

Subsubsection Title: Continue to drive organic growth and pursue targeted and opportunistic bolt-on acquisitions in our core French market
Subsubsection Text: Our goal is to continue to deliver organic growth in France. We have been successful in achieving incremental organic revenue growth through active cross selling efforts across our ancillary services. We intend to continue to benefit from this growth through expanding our service offerings by introducing new business lines. In addition, we aim to further reduce our customer churn rate in Joint Property Management by improving client satisfaction, including as a result of the overhaul of our IT systems and operating model. In addition, we have made, and intend to continue to make, selected bolt-on acquisitions in our core French market and the other geographies in which we operate to supplement our organic growth, solidify our current market position and expand our presence. We have a strong track record of successfully identifying, completing and integrating opportunistic acquisitions. From January 2016 to September 2022, we completed over 330 acquisitions. We believe that our strong brand, broad platform and our dynamic infrastructure have allowed us to generate growth and operating cash flows through acquisitions. Recent examples of targeted acquisitions in France that have accelerated our growth and have allowed us to better address customer needs include Billon and AGDA, in our RRES business, Humakey in B2B and in Belgium, with Syncura. We intend to continue to further strengthen our strong position in the market by pursuing opportunistic acquisitions in our existing geographies to accelerate our growth, and we aim to do so by leveraging our internal expertise. ----- We have an M&A team that is dedicated to identifying growth opportunities. Our team deploys a disciplined and systematic approach and focuses on opportunities that will enhance the offerings and services we provide in France, Switzerland, Benelux, Germany and the UK.

Subsubsection Title: Continue to develop complementary service offering
Subsubsection Text: We provide alternative services and continue the development and roll-out of complementary solutions to our main business lines based on emerging market trends to capitalize on cross-selling opportunities between our different divisions. During the COVID-19 pandemic, when the concern for health safety greatly increased, we launched Tech-Way, a new business line dedicated to the technical maintenance of housing to help our clients to live and work in secure and healthy environments. Tech-Way provides actionable advice and sustainable solutions for pest control, fire protection, routine maintenance and repair work. We believe that providing complementary solutions to our core services allows us to further extend our market reach by catering to the real estate related needs of both landlords and tenants as well as our professional customers.

We have expanded, and plan to continue to expand, our geographic footprint in Europe, organically and through targeted and opportunistic acquisitions. We intend to leverage our expertise and know-how as well as our highly localized real estate providers to penetrate European markets where there is an unmet demand and an opportunity for further expansion, as evidenced by factors such as population dynamics and the construction of collective units, accompanied by increases in price and service level and a higher degree of outsourcing driven by regulatory changes. We strategically pursue new markets while remaining committed to expanding in France, Switzerland, Benelux, Germany and the UK as these markets offer us proximity to existing customers and expansion opportunities in countries where we have established brand recognition. In 2022, we entered the UK market through the acquisition of FirstPort, one of the UK’s largest property services groups and the UK’s largest joint property manager with approximately 315,000 units under management as of March 2022. With this acquisition, Emeria became the global leader in residential property management as well as the number one player in the largest European markets: the UK, France and Germany. For the year ended December 31, 2021, our strategic focus on the expansion of our geographical footprint in Europe would have allowed us to generate approximately €274 million of International Revenue, taking into account FirstPort as if the acquisition of FirstPort had closed on January 1, 2021 (based on an aggregation of the Group’s International Revenue and FirstPort’s revenues without pro forma adjustments, each for the year ended December 31, 2021). Our expertise and solutions are scalable from region to region, and we believe that as we continue to expand, we can increase market share by deploying practices and strategies that have proven to be successful in other markets.

We are committed to ESG matters and providing a safe and healthy environment for all of our customers and employees. Our corporate social responsibility strategy is based on the following key commitments: supporting sustainable energy in the buildings and dwellings we manage, improving the well-being of our customers and our employees and ensuring fair and non-discriminatory access to housing and assisting local communities. Our ESG initiatives are also focused on protecting the environment while also ensuring that our operations have minimal impact on the environment. We aim to achieve carbon emission neutrality at the Group level by 2040. We also aim to work with our clients, contractors and suppliers to improve efficiency, conserve natural resources and reduce waste and emissions. We focus on energy transition of buildings under management by developing services and solutions to enable our clients to renovate and finance their dwellings. In the third quarter of 2022, we appointed a new Vice President of ESG and Strategy, with an aim to drive the further development of our ESG objectives, action plans and reporting. In 2023, we ----- aim to ensure that all of our building managers are systematically trained to lead such renovation projects, partner with clients and employees who demonstrate a commitment to the environment and reduce our carbon footprint.

On the Issue Date, the Senior Secured Notes Issuer will issue the Additional Notes offered hereby and use the proceeds of the Offering to (i) repay amounts outstanding under the Revolving Credit Facility, (ii) fund cash on balance sheet and (iii) pay fees and expenses in connection with the Transactions. The estimated sources and uses of the proceeds from the Offering are set forth in “Use of Proceeds.” The Offering and the application of the proceeds from the Offering as set forth under “Use of Proceeds,” are collectively referred to in this Offering Memorandum as the “Transactions.”

Founded in 1996, Partners Group is a global private markets investment management firm with USD 131 billion in assets under management in private equity, private real estate, private infrastructure and private debt as at September 30, 2022. The firm manages a broad range of customized portfolios for an international clientele of institutional investors. Partners Group is headquartered in Zug, Switzerland and has offices in Denver, Houston, New York, Toronto, São Paulo, London, Guernsey, Paris, Luxembourg, Milan, Munich, Dubai, Mumbai, Singapore, Manila, Shanghai, Seoul, Tokyo and Sydney. The firm employs around 1,600 professionals and is listed on the SIX Swiss Exchange (symbol: PGHN) with a major ownership by its partners and employees. It had a market capitalization of CHF 21.8 billion as at December 30, 2022. In private equity, Partners Group manages assets of USD 66 billion and has on behalf of its clients directly invested in more than 280 businesses since inception. The investment focus in private equity is on profitable companies with strong growth potential and value-add opportunities in four industry verticals. Partners Group pursues a diversified and global relative value approach across geographic regions and industries. Selected private equity investments include Techem, Rovensa, Ammega, SPi Global, Schleich, Cerba HealthCare, Global Logic and KinderCare Education. CDPQ is a long-term institutional investor that manages funds primarily for public and parapublic pension and insurance plans from the province of Québec, Canada. It receives money on deposit from its clients (known as “depositors”) and manages these funds while seeking optimal return on investment, in accordance with depositors’ investment policies. CDPQ is one of Canada’s largest institutional fund managers, with CAD 392 billion in assets as at June 30, 2022. It invests globally in major financial markets, private equity, infrastructure, real estate and private debt. CDPQ was constituted in 1965 by an act of the Québec National Assembly. Founded in 1968, TA Associates (“TA”) is a leading global growth private equity firm. TA invests in growing companies with opportunities for sustained growth across its five core industries: technology, healthcare, financial services, consumer and business services. An active investor, TA employs a longterm approach, utilizing its global resources and value-add competencies to help management teams build lasting value in great companies. With $48.6 billion raised since inception and over five decades of experience, TA offers its portfolio companies strategic guidance, global insight, strategic acquisition support, recruiting assistance and a significant network of contacts, in addition to sound financial backing. TA’s investment team is based in Boston, Menlo Park, Austin, London, Mumbai, and Hong Kong. -----

Subsubsection Title: Additional Facility B2B and Additional Facility B2C
Subsubsection Text: On January 11, 2023, certain third party lenders provided to the Senior Secured Notes Issuer, (i) a euro denominated senior term loan facility in a principal amount of €35.0 million established under the Senior Credit Facilities Agreement (“Additional Facility B2B”) and (ii) a euro denominated senior term loan facility in a principal amount of €30.0 million established under the Senior Credit Facilities Agreement (“Additional Facility B2C”). The proceeds from Additional Facility B2B and Additional Facility B2C were used to repay certain amounts outstanding under our Revolving Credit Facility and to pay related fees and expenses. See “Description of Other Indebtedness—Senior Credit Facilities _Agreement.”_

Subsubsection Title: Merger between Emeria SASU and Emeria Holding SAS
Subsubsection Text: Effective from January 3, 2023, Emeria Holding SAS (formerly known as Foncia Holding SAS) was merged into the Senior Secured Notes Issuer by way of a transmission universelle de patrimoines. As a result of this merger, Emeria Europe became the direct subsidiary of the Senior Secured Notes Issuer.

Based on our management accounts, we estimate that for the eleven months ended November 30, 2022 compared to the eleven months ended November 30, 2021, our revenue increased by approximately 15.2%, from approximately €1,032.9 million for the eleven months ended November 30, 2021 to approximately €1,190.3 million for the eleven months ended November 30, 2022. We estimate that our reported EBITDA for the eleven months ended November 30, 2022 increased by approximately 13.7% from approximately €278.0 million for the eleven months ended November 30, 2021 to approximately €316.2 million for the eleven months ended November 30, 2022. This increase in revenue and EBITDA was largely driven by strong performance in France and acquisitions undertaken in the UK, Benelux, Switzerland and Germany, and in particular, the acquisition of FirstPort in August 2022. _The information presented above relating to our performance for the eleven months ended November 30, 2022 (including the comparative figures for the eleven months ended November 30, 2021) is derived from internal management accounts. This information has been prepared by management of the Senior Secured Notes Issuer. It has not been audited, reviewed or verified, and it is not subject to any procedures by our auditors, and you should not place undue reliance on it. While we believe this information is preliminary, it is subject to change, and those changes could be material. This information may not be indicative of our performance in the remainder of the financial quarter, the financial year or any future period. See “Forward-looking Statements,” “Risk Factors” and “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations” in this Offering Memorandum for a more complete discussion of certain of the factors that could affect our future performance._ ----- Flamingo Lux II SCA[(2)] (Luxembourg) (“Senior Notes Issuer”) Guarantors and Pledged Opcos[(6)] Emeria SASU[(6)] (France) (“Senior Secured Notes Issuer”) Term Loan Facilities[(4)] Revolving Credit Facility[(4)] Shareholders[(1)] Guarantors and [(6)] Senior Secured Notes Restricted Group Senior Secured Notes Issuer Emeria Europe Guarantors ----- pledge granted by the Senior Notes Issuer in respect of structural intercompany receivables owing to it by the Senior Secured Notes Issuer. (3) The Senior Secured Notes Issuer issued €400 million aggregate principal amount of 3.375% Existing Senior Secured Notes due 2028 on the Original Issue Date. The Existing Senior Secured Notes are senior obligations of the Senior Secured Notes Issuer and (i) rank pari passu in right of payment with all of the Senior Secured Notes Issuer’s existing and future indebtedness that is not subordinated in right of payment to the Existing Senior Secured Notes, including any indebtedness under the Senior Credit Facilities and certain hedging obligations, if any; (ii) rank senior in right of payment to all of the Senior Secured Note Issuer’s existing and future subordinated indebtedness of the Senior Secured Notes Issuer, including the Senior Notes; (iii) are effectively subordinated to any existing and future indebtedness of the Senior Secured Notes Issuer and its subsidiaries and the Guarantors that is secured by property or assets that do not secure the Existing Senior Secured Notes, to the extent of the value of the property or assets securing such indebtedness; and (iv) be structurally subordinated to any existing and future indebtedness of subsidiaries of the Senior Secured Notes Issuer that do not guarantee the Existing Senior Secured Notes, including obligations to trade creditors. (4) We entered into the Senior Credit Facilities Agreement on the Original Issue Date. The Senior Credit Facilities include the Revolving Credit Facility, which provides for up to €437.5 million of senior secured credit borrowings and letters of credit and ancillary facilities, and the Term Loan Facilities in an aggregate principal amount of €1,963.0 million, consisting of the Original Term Facility drawn in 2021, Additional Facility B2A, drawn in December 2022 to repay Additional Facility B2 in full, Additional Facility B2B and Additional Facility B2C, both drawn in January 2023, respectively. The Senior Credit Facilities are guaranteed by all of the Guarantors on a senior basis, pari passu with the Senior Secured Notes Guarantees and senior to the Senior Notes Guarantees. The Senior Credit Facilities are secured by the Senior Secured Notes Collateral on a first-ranking basis, pari passu with the Existing Senior Secured Notes. See “Description of Other Indebtedness—Senior Credit Facilities Agreement” and “Summary Historical Financial Information and Other Data—Summary Financial and Other Information—Summary Other _Financial and Operating Data.”_ (5) The Senior Secured Notes Issuer will issue €400.0 million aggregate principal amount of its % Senior Secured Notes due 2028 (the “Additional Notes”). The Additional Notes will be issued pursuant to the Senior Secured Notes Indenture. The Additional Notes will have substantially the same terms and conditions (except as otherwise set forth herein, including with respect to the issue price, interest rate, issue date, redemption prices, call schedule and the date from which interest shall accrue) as the Existing Senior Secured Notes and will constitute a single class of securities with the Existing Senior Secured Notes for all purposes (unless otherwise indicated) under the Senior Secured Notes Indenture, including, without limitation, waivers, amendments, and offers to purchase. The Additional Notes may be issued with more than de minimis original issue discount (“OID”). Because the terms and conditions of the Additional Notes are not identical to the terms and conditions of the Existing Senior Secured Notes, the Additional Notes will not be fungible with the Existing Senior Secured Notes for U.S. federal income tax purposes, and as a result will be issued with separate common codes and International Securities Identification Numbers from those assigned to the Existing Senior Secured Notes. See “Description of the Senior Secured Notes.” On the Issue Date, the Senior Secured Notes Issuer will use the proceeds from the Offering to (i) repay amounts outstanding under our Revolving Credit Facility, (ii) fund cash on balance sheet and (iii) to pay fees and expenses in connection with the Transactions. See “Use of Proceeds” and “—Transactions.” (6) On the Issue Date and subject to the terms of the Intercreditor Agreement, the Additional Notes will be guaranteed by the Guarantors on a senior basis. On the Issue Date, the Additional Notes will also be secured on a first priority basis by the Senior Secured Notes Collateral. The validity and enforceability of the Senior Secured Notes Guarantees and the security and the liability of each Guarantor and security provider will be subject to certain limitations. See “Certain Insolvency Law Considerations and _Limitations on the Validity and Enforceability of the Senior Secured Notes Guarantees and Security Interests.” The security_ interests in favor of the Additional Notes and the Senior Secured Notes Guarantees may be released under certain circumstances. For the twelve months ended September 30, 2022, the Senior Secured Notes Issuer, the Guarantors and the Pledged Opcos generated 51% of our consolidated EBITDA (and 29% excluding Pledged Opcos). As of September 30, 2022, our subsidiaries that will not guarantee the Additional Notes did not have any material indebtedness. -----

We define Pre-IFRS-16 EBITDA as EBITDA adjusted for the IFRS-16 impact on leases at our French and international premises and includes IAS 17 adjustments for leasing for vehicles, copy machines and laptops. We adopted IFRS 16 on January 1, 2019. We present Pre-IFRS-16 EBITDA as additional information because we believe it is helpful to investors in evaluating the performance of the underlying business. However, Pre-IFRS-16 EBITDA is not a measure of financial performance under IFRS and should not be considered as an alternative to measures of performance derived in accordance with IFRS. (2) Pre-IFRS-16 EBITDA Margin and EBITDA Margin is calculated as Pre-IFRS-16 EBITDA and EBITDA, respectively, divided by revenue for the relevant period. (3) EBITDA and Adjusted EBITDA are non-IFRS measures. We define EBITDA as net profit before Income tax expense, share of profit (loss) of equity-accounted companies, other financial income and expenses, net income from cash and cash equivalents, cost of gross debt, non-recurring operating income (expenses) and elimination of net additions to depreciation, amortization and impairment of assets. We define Adjusted EBITDA as EBITDA as adjusted for completed acquisitions, minority interest and COVID-19 impact. We present EBITDA and Adjusted EBITDA as additional information because we believe they are helpful to investors in highlighting trends and evaluating the performance of the underlying business. However, other companies may present EBITDA or Adjusted EBITDA differently than we do and therefore comparability may be limited. EBITDA and Adjusted EBITDA are not measures of financial performance under IFRS and should not be considered as an alternative to net profit as an indicator of our operating performance, profitability, liquidity or any other measures of performance derived in accordance with IFRS. Subsubsection Text: (a) Represents the estimated pro forma impact of closed acquisitions during each of the years ended December 31, 2021 and 2020 and during each of the nine months ended September 30, 2022 and 2021. This adjustment corresponds to the estimated EBITDA of the target for the next 12 months, without double counting the results already included in the relevant period, based on its historical data. The number reflects the estimated impact of the churn and the full-year impact of the cost synergies linked to the integration in our operational model, which are calculated based on the historical churn and cost savings we have achieved with prior acquisitions. These figures are diligenced in connection with each acquisition and validated by our operational and regional teams who will integrate the target as part of their perimeter and track the performance against budgeted figures. Most of the acquisitions are integrated within three to six months and are then part of the organic perimeter of the Group. The types of synergies that are recognized in the first year following an acquisition, many of which are recognized on day one, typically include target management costs if they do not stay with the business, staff costs related to functions such as headquarters and accounting, advertising costs, non-recurring items such as recruitments fees and subcontracting, and accounting adjustments such as for taxes and leases, which we record below EBITDA. (b) Refers to our 50% owned subsidiary, Foncia Brette SA, which is consolidated in our Financial Statements (without giving effect to intra-group transactions). (c) Our business has been impacted by the COVID-19 pandemic and related lockdowns. While our Joint Property Management and Lease Management businesses have been relatively resilient as our employees were able to service customers from a remote working environment; they did experience a slight fall in revenues due to impacts such as a reduction in transfer fees in Joint Property Management and disruptions with the postal service, which led to delays in sending invoices and receiving fees in Lease Management. We also experienced some offsetting effects such as government programs to supplement salaries for employees who were unable to work as well as a decrease in headquarter costs and performance bonuses. The following table presents the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on EBITDA across our businesses for the years ended December 31, 2021 and 2020 and the twelve months ended September 30, 2022.

Subsection Title: Year ended December 31, Twelve months ended September 30, 2020** **2021** **2022 COVID-19 Impact on Adjusted EBITDA (in millions of euros)

Subsubsection Text: For purposes of determining our Adjusted EBITDA, we have only included the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on our stock (recurring) business lines as those are generally more stable and predictable. We have not adjusted our EBITDA for the impact of ----- the Brokerage and Lettings business lines, which are our primarily non-recurring flow businesses. Our Brokerage business line was particularly impacted by the COVID-19 pandemic during the first lockdown from March to May 2020. During this time, we were not able to recognize revenue due to the cessation of notary services, and the closure of our agencies and the limited ability for people to move led to a reduction in new transactions. As a result of the restrictions imposed during the second lockdown in France lasting approximately two months from October 30, 2020 (the “second lockdown”), the number of new transactions was impacted, but not as significantly, and notaries were allowed to work, which enabled us to recognize revenue during this period. The renting side of our Lease Management and Letting business is a transaction-based business that also experienced a decline in revenue when the French government largely prohibited people from moving to new properties during the initial lockdown and, to a lesser extent, during the second lockdown. Constatimmo, which performs diagnostic and inventory reviews, experienced a similar decrease in revenue as a result of fewer lettings and therefore fewer individuals requiring its services. For a more detailed description of the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on our business, including the breakdown of lost revenue by business line, see “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations—Key factors _affecting results of operations—COVID-19 pandemic impact on our business.”_ The above information and adjustments are based upon available information and assumptions that we believe to be reasonable. This information has not been audited, reviewed or verified by our statutory auditors in accordance with any generally accepted accounting standards and the resulting financial information, including our Adjusted EBITDA, are based on a number of assumptions that are subject to inherent uncertainties and subject to change. In particular, the adjustments take into account our estimated lost revenue as a result of the COVID-19 pandemic based on our internal budgets and historic performance. This information is inherently subject to risks and uncertainties. It may not give an accurate or complete picture of the financial condition or results of operations in the absence of the COVID-19 pandemic for the periods presented, may not be comparable to our consolidated financial statements or the other financial information included in this Offering Memorandum and should not be relied upon when making an investment decision. See “Risk Factors—Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry—We present _information relating to Adjusted EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA Margin, Pro Forma M&A Adjusted EBITDA, Pro Forma Revenues, Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA Margin and other non-IFRS measures in this Offering Memorandum; certain of the data used in calculating this information was unaudited or involved certain estimates and judgments, and accordingly you should not unduly rely on them.”_ (4) Pro Forma M&A Adjusted EBITDA is a non-IFRS measure. We define Pro Forma M&A Adjusted EBITDA as Adjusted EBITDA after giving pro forma effect to the estimated impact of acquisitions with signed share purchase agreement expected to close by the end of the first quarter of 2023, additional synergies from acquisitions (from 12 months and up to 18 months) and Agency of the Future / Millenium cost savings and efficiency gains. We present Pro Forma M&A Adjusted EBITDA as additional information because we believe it is helpful to investors in highlighting trends and evaluating the performance of the underlying business. However, other companies may present Pro Forma M&A Adjusted EBITDA differently than we do and therefore comparability may be limited. This information does not represent the results we would have achieved had each of the acquisitions or other transactions for which an adjustment is made occurred at the dates indicated. There is no assurance that items we have identified for adjustment as nonrecurring will not recur in the future or that similar items will not be incurred in the future. Pro Forma M&A Adjusted EBITDA is not a measure of financial performance under IFRS and should not be considered as an alternative to net profit as an indicator of our operating performance, profitability, liquidity or any other measures of performance derived in accordance with IFRS. (a) Refers to our 50% owned subsidiary, Foncia Brette SA, which is consolidated in our Financial Statements, without giving effect to intra-group transactions. (b) Represents the estimated pro forma EBITDA impact of closed acquisitions during the twelve months ended September 30, 2022, including FirstPort, as if such acquisitions had closed at the beginning of the period. This adjustment corresponds to the estimated EBITDA of the target for the next twelve months, without double counting the results already included in the relevant period, based on its historical data. The number reflects the impact of estimated churn and the full-year impact of the cost synergies linked to each acquired company’s integration in our operational model, which are calculated based on the historical churn and cost savings we have achieved with prior acquisitions. These figures are diligenced in connection with each acquisition and validated by our operational and regional teams who integrate the target as part of their perimeter and track their performance against budgeted figures. Most of the acquisitions are integrated within three to six months and are then part of the organic perimeter of the Group. The types of cost synergies that are recognized in the first year following an acquisition, many of which are recognized on day ----- one, typically include target management costs if they do not stay with the business, staff costs related to functions such as headquarters and accounting, advertising costs, non-recurring items such as recruitment fees and subcontracting and accounting adjustments such as taxes and leases, which we record below EBITDA. (c) Represents the last twelve-month impact from COVID-19 on the EBITDA of our stock (recurring) business lines. See corresponding line item in footnote 3 above for further detail. (d) Represents the pro forma impact of potential acquisitions where we have signed share purchase agreements and expect to close by the end of the first quarter of 2023 (collectively, the “Signed Acquisitions”), as if such acquisitions had closed at the beginning of the period. This adjustment corresponds to the estimated EBITDA of the acquisition for the full year based on its historical data and includes the impact of the estimated churn and the full-year impact of the cost synergies linked to the integration in our operational model. These figures are calculated on the same basis as described in footnote (3)(a) above. (e) Represents additional further synergies and churn from acquisitions (including in respect of Signed Acquisitions) in the 12 months up to 18 months after the closing date, in addition to those already considered in pro forma EBITDA figures in the first 12 months. These synergies include cost synergies related to employee costs, rents, Millenium gains and other costs such as accounting, insurance, IT maintenance and legal costs, travel expenses and bank fees and revenue synergies related to, for example, insurance implementation, the GLI guarantee and cross-selling opportunities between our different divisions. Our synergy estimates are based on a number of assumptions made in reliance on the information available to us relating to each individual acquisition and our judgments based on such information. The assumptions used in estimating synergies are inherently uncertain and are subject to significant business, economic and competitive risks and uncertainties that could cause our actual results to differ materially from those contained in the synergy benefit estimates. (f) Represents the estimated gains from efficiencies from the Agency of the Future and our brokerage management initiatives to increase sales leads coming from our Joint Property Management and Lease Management and Letting portfolios in the next 24 months, following the deployment of our new ERP system, Millenium. We have designed a new organizational model named Agency of the Future, which was implemented following the roll-out of Millenium in France in 2022. As a result, we estimate gains, mainly related to (i) staff costs synergies from the optimization of the ratios of middle and back-office functions to front-office employees, an increase in productivity and reduction of time spent on manual and repetitive processes and (ii) gains resulting from the digitalization and automation of certain tasks previously done manually (such as collection of reminder fees or postal charges). We have quantified the impact of the plan by (i) identifying potential for productivity improvement, such as analyzing time spent by employees for their principal tasks in a select number of agencies and identifying potential for improved processes after implementing these projects, (ii) reinvesting and improving service quality by, for example, defining a goal for the joint property management and lease management business and the principal tasks of managers and assistants and quantifying the reinvestment necessary in specific roles in order to put this target organization in place and (iii) scaling of the network resulting from the options for improvement of processes and required reinvestment. Our savings estimate was updated to take into account initial field observations from the roll-out of Millenium for estimate target times and savings to be expected on each process with the implementation of Millenium and the Agency of the Future. Initial observations in branches using Millenium have confirmed our savings estimates on finalized processes. Following these confirmations, we modelled a productivity gains ramp-up to take into account the roadmap for the delivery of Millenium features. Consequently, the presented adjustment of €25.0 million reflects an update of our initial assessment of an adjustment of €15.0 million which was calculated per the developments up to the second quarter of 2022, plus the latest developments measured on the basis of five Millenium pilots operating since July 2022 as well as our projection of the Millenium roll-out between the fourth quarter of 2022 and the third quarter of 2024. For the year ended December 31, 2021, capital expenditures in connection with Millenium and Agency of the Future were €18.7 million, consisting of €15.4 million for the development and €3.4 million for the deployment of Millenium. We anticipate capital expenditures of €39.3 million in the nine months ended September 30, 2022, consisting of €12.7 million for the development and €3.1 million for the deployment of Millenium. In the next 18 to 24 months, we estimate approximately €5.6 million of revenue gains as a result of efficiencies due to Millenium and Agency of the Future. We believe that, we will experience additional gains in the following years, as a result of these projects. For more information, see “Business—Digital _Transformation and IT Systems.” The above information and adjustments are based upon available information and_ assumptions that we believe to be reasonable. This information has not been audited. Any failure by us to successfully execute on our strategy to achieve for operational efficiency could result in total costs and expenses that are greater than expected. For more information see, “Risk Factors—Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry—Any failure by us to _successfully execute on our strategy to achieve for operational efficiency could result in total costs and expenses that are greater than expected.”_ (g) In evaluating Pro Forma M&A Adjusted EBITDA, you should be aware that, as an analytical tool, it is subject to certain limitations. In particular, run-rate cost savings and synergies are unaudited and based on management estimates and assumptions (including the successful implementation of certain initiatives) and are forward looking in nature. We may not be able to achieve these cost savings and synergies in a timely manner or at all. As such, this information is inherently subject to risks and uncertainties, including a wide variety of significant business, economic, and competitive risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially from those contained in our estimates of cost savings and synergies. It may not give an accurate or complete picture of the financial impact or results of these actions and initiatives for the periods presented and may not be comparable with our consolidated financial statements or the other financial information included in this Offering Memorandum, and should not be relied upon when making an investment decision. If one or more of our underlying assumptions regarding these items proves to have been incorrect, these efforts could lead to substantially higher costs than planned and we may not be able to realize fully, or realize in the anticipated time frame, the estimated benefits from our cost-saving measures. Prior to      , 2025, the Senior Secured Notes Issuer may redeem up to 10% of the original aggregate principal amount of the Additional Notes (including the original principal amount of any additional Additional Notes) originally issued in each calendar year at a redemption price equal to 103% of the principal amount of the Additional Notes so redeemed, plus accrued and unpaid interest and Additional Amounts, if any, to, but excluding, the redemption date. Optional Redemption for Tax Reasons ..............** In the event of certain developments affecting taxation which cause the Senior Secured Notes Issuer to pay additional amounts, the Senior Secured Notes Issuer may redeem the Senior Secured Notes in whole, but not in part, at any time, at a redemption price of 100% of the principal amount, plus accrued and unpaid interest, if any, and additional amounts, if any, to, but excluding, the date of redemption. See “Description of the Senior _Secured Notes—Redemption for Taxation Reasons.”_ Change of Control ...............................................** Upon the occurrence of certain events defined as constituting a change of control, the Senior Secured Notes Issuer may be required to make an offer to repurchase all the outstanding Senior Secured Notes at a purchase price in cash equal to 101% of the principal amount thereof, plus accrued and unpaid interest, to the date of purchase. A change of control will not be ----- deemed to have occurred on one occasion if, pro forma for such change of control, certain consolidated total net leverage ratios calculated in accordance with the “Description of the Senior Secured Notes” are not exceeded as a result of such event. See “Description of _the Senior Secured Notes—Change of Control.”_ Tender Offers .......................................................** In connection with certain tender offers for the Senior Secured Notes for any series, if holders of not less than 90% in aggregate principal amount of the applicable series of outstanding Senior Secured Notes of such series validly tendered and do not withdraw such Senior Secured Notes in such tender offer and the Senior Secured Notes Issuer, or any third party making such a tender offer in lieu of the Senior Secured Notes Issuer, purchases all of the Senior Secured Notes of such series validly tendered and not withdrawn by such holders, the Senior Secured Notes Issuer or such third party will have the right to redeem the Senior Secured Notes of such series that remain outstanding in whole, but not in part, following such purchase at a price equal to the price offered to each other holder of such Senior Secured Notes. See “Description of the Senior Secured _Notes—Optional Redemption.”_ Certain Covenants ...............................................** The Senior Secured Notes Indenture, among other things, will restrict the ability of the Senior Secured Notes Issuer and its restricted subsidiaries, to: - incur or guarantee additional indebtedness and issue certain preferred stock; - create or incur certain liens; - make certain payments, including dividends or other distributions, with respect to the shares of the Senior Secured Notes Issuer; - prepay or redeem subordinated debt or equity; - make certain investments; - create encumbrances or restrictions on the payment of dividends or other distributions, loans or advances to and on the transfer of assets to the Senior Secured Notes Issuer or its restricted subsidiaries; - sell, lease or transfer certain assets, including stock of restricted subsidiaries; - engage in certain transactions with affiliates; - consolidate or merge with other entities; - impair the security interests for the benefit of the holders of the Senior Secured Notes; and - amend certain documents. ----- Each of these covenants is subject to significant exceptions and qualifications. See “Description of the _Senior Secured Notes—Certain Covenants.”_ Original Issue Discount .......................................** The Additional Notes may be issued with OID for U.S. federal income tax purposes if the stated principal amount of the Additional Notes exceeds their issue price by an amount equal to or greater than a statutorily defined de minimis amount, in which case in addition to the stated interest on the Additional Notes, a holder subject to U.S. federal income taxation may be required to include the OID in gross income (as ordinary income), on a constant yield to maturity basis, in advance of the receipt of the cash payment thereof and regardless of such holder’s regular method of accounting for U.S. federal income tax purposes. Because the terms and conditions of the Additional Notes are not identical to the terms and conditions of the Existing Senior Secured Notes, the Additional Notes will not be fungible with the Existing Senior Secured Notes and will have separate ISINs and common codes from the ISINs and common codes assigned to the Existing Senior Secured Notes. See “Certain Tax Considerations—Certain United States _Federal Income Tax Consequences.”_ Transfer Restrictions ...........................................** The Additional Notes and the Senior Secured Notes Guarantees have not been, and will not be, registered under the Securities Act or the securities laws of any other jurisdiction and are subject to restrictions on transferability and resale. See “Transfer Restrictions.” We have not agreed to, or otherwise undertaken to, register the Additional Notes (including by way of an exchange offer) with the US Securities and Exchange Commission. No Prior Market ..................................................** The Additional Notes will be new securities for which there is currently no established trading market. Although the Initial Purchasers have advised us that they intend to make a market in the Additional Notes, they are not obligated to do so, and they may discontinue market making at any time without notice. Accordingly, there can be no assurance that an active trading market will develop for the Additional Notes. Listing ...................................................................** Application will be made to the Authority for the listing of and permission to deal in the Additional Notes on the Official List of the Exchange. There can be no assurance, however, that the Additional Notes will be listed on the Official List of the Exchange, that such permission to deal in the Additional Notes will be granted or that such listing will be maintained.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: The success of our business is significantly related to general economic conditions and, accordingly, our business, operations and financial condition could be adversely affected by economic slowdowns, liquidity pressure, fiscal or political uncertainty and possible subsequent declines in property sales and leasing activities in one or more of the geographies or industry sectors that we serve.
Subsubsection Text: Demand for our residential and commercial real estate services is sensitive to changes in the level of economic activity and economic conditions in the countries, regions and sectors in which we operate. Periods of economic weakness or recession, rising interest rates, fiscal or political uncertainty, market volatility, declining employment levels, declining demand for residential or commercial real estate, falling real estate values, disruption to the global capital or credit markets or the public perception that any of these events may occur, may negatively affect the performance of our business. In addition, any of these events may have a direct impact on our ability to collect payments that we are owed under our rent payment guarantee (“Garantie de loyers impayés”) and occupancy guarantee (“Garantie d’occupation”), which we offer to certain residential landlords and lessors, respectively. See “—Low _demand for housing generally or lease terminations and/or tenant defaults could adversely affect our fees and the income produced by the properties we manage, which may have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition or results of operations.”_ The outbreak of the war in Ukraine in February 2022, global supply chain disruptions and other geopolitical conflicts have caused an immediate impact on global economic conditions. Such conditions have resulted in shortages in materials and services and have led to increased inflationary pressure in 2022, including increases in the price for goods and services, including energy prices. Although we do not have direct economic activities in Russia and Ukraine and currently the conflict has not had any material impact on our overall revenue and EBITDA, it is difficult to predict the scope and extent of any potential impact of the increasing tensions and other geopolitical conflicts could have on our operations. Continuing increases in inflation could also impact the rate of rent payment default in the properties we service or the overall demand for and costs of our services and the margins we are able to realize on our services. For example, we estimate that the negative impact from elevated levels of inflation on EBITDA for our French business in the nine months ended September 30, 2022 was approximately €2.5 million. Additionally, inflationary pressures in the labor markets in which we have operations could cause our personnel costs, which represented 51.4% of our revenues in the nine months ended September 30, 2022, excluding employees in our headquarters, to increase. Although we anticipate that in 2023, our personnel costs should be moderately higher in France and in other countries, we expect that the impact of such increase may be partially offset due to price increases in our stock businesses, which are contractually guaranteed in France and negotiable in other countries. We also expect to benefit from the impact of higher interest rates on some of our clients’ bank deposits as a result of the continuing interest raises, and from inflationary price increases built into our management fees in the UK. However, governments may also cap increases in rent, such as France’s recent decision ----- in August 2022 to cap increases in rent by 3.5%, which may limit our ability to pass through inflationary pressures to our customers. Policy responses to inflation, such as increases to central bank policy rates in respect of the currencies with which we conduct our operations or in which our outstanding debt is denominated, may also impact our business, for example, by causing credit conditions to tighten (and adversely affecting the real estate markets in which we operate) or by increasing the costs of our debt service obligations, to the extent we have outstanding debt with a floating rate of interest. See “—Risks Relating to our Capital Structure— _The Senior Credit Facilities bear interest at floating rates that could rise significantly, thereby increasing our costs and reducing our cash flow.” These inflationary pressures, individually and in_ combination, have had, and are expected to continue to have, a limited impact on our business, financial position, results of operations and cash flows. Our results of operations are also significantly impacted by economic trends, government policies and the real estate markets in the countries in which we operate. These include the following: overall economic activity, changes in interest rates, the impact of tax and regulatory policies, the cost and availability of credit and the geopolitical environment. The performance of our RRES services depends on our ability to collect fixed fees, charge variable fees for ancillary services, find tenants to bill transaction fees and collect rents. Our Joint Property Management business model is composed of fixed fees and variable fees related to additional services that could decline due to adverse economic conditions or administrative restrictions such as pandemic lockdowns. Additionally, the revenue derived from the Lease Management side of our Lease Management and Letting business is generally based on a percentage of rent collections from the properties we manage and, with respect to the renting side of the Lease Management and Letting business, from the one-off fees we receive for each new lease agreement entered into by our customers. The revenue generated by our business can be affected by many factors, including: (i) the magnitude of defaults by tenants under their respective leases, which may increase during distressed economic conditions; (ii) real estate and financial market conditions prevailing generally and regionally; (iii) our ability to attract and retain creditworthy tenants, particularly during economic downturns; (iv) the impact of inflationary pressures and cost of living on our tenants, which could contribute to increasing defaults or could cause tenants to trade down to lower rents; and (v) a decrease in the rate of tenants moving and a corresponding decrease in the one-off fees we receive for new lease agreements entered into by our customers. If tenants are unable to pay their rents, we are unable to collect the fees that are typically directly deducted from these rental payments. Additionally, if the cost of our services increases, customers may switch to other, lower-cost real estate services providers. Adverse economic conditions or political or regulatory uncertainty could also impact our Brokerage business as it may lead to a decline in property sales and/or a reduction in sales prices, which in turn could reduce the commissions and fees that we earn in brokering such transactions. Economic, political and regulatory uncertainty, as well as significant changes and volatility in the financial markets, business environment and the global landscape, make it increasingly difficult for us to predict our future financial performance.
