See “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of _Operations—Key Factors Affecting Results of Operations—Macroeconomic and market conditions.”_ The United Kingdom’s withdrawal from the European Union pursuant to Article 50 of the Treaty on European Union, which occurred on January 31, 2020 following a national referendum in June 2016 (“Brexit”), has created lingering uncertainty about the future relationship among the UK, one of our current markets, and the EU and its remaining member states and may constitute an additional risk for the financial markets and the European economy. While the European Union and the United Kingdom agreed a comprehensive, zero-tariff, zero-quota free trade agreement, which came into force provisionally on January 1, 2021, Brexit has led to increased customs, health and safety checks at the borders of the UK and the EU as well as a lack of haulage and other qualified supply chain and logistics workers, which has delayed and disrupted the movement of goods between the EU and the UK. As a result, Brexit may affect our level of revenues and EBITDA in the United Kingdom, particularly with ----- respect to the FirstPort business. Moreover, fluctuations in the exchange rates used to convert the financial statements of FirstPort denominated in a British pound sterling as part of the consolidation process might significantly affect results of operations, net financial debt, and consolidated net assets in the financial statements. See also “—Risks Related to Our Business and Industry—Fluctuations in _exchange rates may adversely affect our business and results of operations.” Given the lack of_ comparable precedent, it is unclear what long-term financial, trade and legal implications Brexit will have and whether, and to what extent, our business could be affected. In addition, certain political parties in Scotland are currently pushing for a second referendum on Scottish independence from the United Kingdom, which may lead to additional uncertainty and may affect our business activities in Scotland and other parts of the United Kingdom. Any of the foregoing risks, if they were to occur, could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: The COVID-19 pandemic, including the resulting global economic uncertainty and the related lockdown measures, in particular its effects in France, Switzerland, Benelux, Germany and the UK where we have material operations, or other epidemics or pandemics, have had in the past, and could have in the future, a significant adverse impact on our business.
Subsubsection Text: The COVID-19 pandemic, including the emergence of variants such as Delta and Omicron and related sub-variants, and the rapidly evolving reactions of authorities, including those in France, Switzerland, Benelux, Germany and the UK, to contain the spread and address the impact of COVID-19 have had significant direct and indirect effects on businesses and commerce generally, including disruptions to supply chain, workforce, transactional activity, facility operation and production. While restrictions on the conduct of business in many jurisdictions, including the closure of workplaces determined to be non-essential, have eased or been lifted, there remain certain restrictions on the international, national and local movement of people and goods, which continue to disrupt many of our clients’ business operations and their recruitment needs. The extent and scope of such restrictions continue to be highly uncertain and subject to change, and stricter measures could potentially be put in place in the future. A prolonged continuance of this public health crisis could therefore have a material adverse effect, including materially increased volatility in financial markets and significant worsening of the global, European, French, UK, Belgian, German, Dutch, Swiss and Luxembourgish macroeconomic outlooks. Although there was no meaningful impact from the COVID-19 pandemic in the nine months ended September 30, 2022, we cannot predict the impact that any future developments relating to it may have on our business. These developments may include, but are not limited to, the duration and spread of COVID-19, its severity, emergence of new variants and further actions taken to contain the virus or treat its impact, including the rate of deployment of vaccines. A number of measures taken by governments in the early stage of the COVID-19 pandemic intended to mitigate the spread of COVID19 caused significant effects on our business, including decreased demand for our services as a result of the slowdown in the European economies in which we operate and our inability to offer certain services as a result of government lockdown measures. In accordance with the decisions taken by most European governments in order to comply with social distancing recommendations, all premises (branches and head offices) were closed to the public during the lockdown periods in France, Switzerland, Benelux, Germany and the UK in the spring of 2020 (the “first lockdown”), as well as to employees (barring exceptional cases). During that period, real estate agents were barred from traveling to sign mandates or show properties and notaries were closed, which prevented any brokerage transactions from closing. For further discussion on notary execution, see “Regulation—France— _Hoguet.” Moving into new premises during this period was particularly complicated, as only moves_ that could not be postponed could be carried out, which resulted in reduced letting fees for the period. The first lockdown measures imposed on the French, Swiss, German and Belgian population also negatively impacted our fee collection with an increasing number of residential and commercial tenants not being able to pay their rent on time or at all, although the rents remained owed as a matter of law. The lease management market was also affected as we collect a portion of rents via check, and there were disruptions with postal service, which led to delays in sending and receiving invoices and fees. ----- Softer lockdowns were introduced again in the autumn of 2020 and spring 2021 which also led to the closure of all of our branches to the public in France which adversely impacted our ability to deliver our services. In addition, the lockdowns and related restrictions caused us to pause for a short period of time the roll-out of Millenium, our new ERP system, in 2020. However, we were able to subsequently resume the roll-out, which is now proceeding according to schedule. For further discussion on the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on our various businesses, see “Management’s Discussion and _Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations—Key Factors Affecting Results of Operations—COVID-19 pandemic impact on our business.”_

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: We have numerous local, regional and national competitors across all of our businesses and the geographies that we serve, and further industry consolidation, fragmentation or innovation could lead to significant future competition.
Subsubsection Text: We compete across a variety of businesses within the residential and commercial property services industry, including management of jointly owned properties, rental management and lettings, property transaction intermediation, specialized property insurance brokerage, technical due diligence and inventories and consulting services for commercial and office properties, business-specific IT services, marketing of properties by blocks or lots and technical maintenance. Although we are the global leading provider of residential real estate services, our relative competitive position varies significantly across geographies and businesses. Depending on the geography, property type or business, we face competition from other residential or commercial real estate services providers and investment firms, in-house corporate real estate departments, developers, institutional lenders, insurance companies, investment banking firms, investment managers, accounting firms and consulting firms. Some of these firms may have greater financial resources allocated to a particular geography, property type or business than we have allocated to that geography, property type or business. In addition, future changes in laws could lead to the entry of other new competitors or further consolidation of the industry. For example, increased regulation following the implementation of the 2014 French access to housing and urban renovation law, l’accès au logement et un urbanisme rénové (“ALUR law”), and the increasing need to invest in the digitization of services has led to the increased consolidation of a highly fragmented market. For further discussion on the ALUR law, see “Regulation—France—ALUR.” Reaching critical scale is important for the digitization and industrialization of processes in order to reduce costs and improve customer service. Our industry is highly fragmented among regional, local and boutique providers. Although many of our existing competitors are local or regional firms that are smaller than we are, some of these competitors are larger or have a stronger presence on a local or regional basis or in their primary markets. We are further subject to competition from large national and multinational firms that have similar services to our commercial real estate business, and it is possible that further consolidation in the residential and commercial real estate industry could lead to much larger competitors in the geographies, property types and businesses that we serve. In addition, disruptive innovation by existing or new competitors could alter the competitive landscape in the future and require us to accurately identify and assess such changes and make timely and effective changes to our strategies and business model to effectively compete. Further, we also face competition from service providers, who may have greater knowledge of their home markets, a better understanding of the specificities of regulations and local legislation and established reputations in their region. There is no assurance that we will be able to effectively compete, maintain current fee levels or margins, or maintain or increase our market share.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: Low demand for housing generally or lease terminations and/or tenant defaults could adversely affect our fees and the income produced by the properties we manage, which may have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition or results of operations.
Subsubsection Text: Low demand for housing generally, or at a particular location due to economic, social or other conditions, may lead to a lower demand for our services. Moreover, our customers’ tenants could experience a change in their financial situation at any time, including as a result of global economic events, natural disasters and public health or pandemic crises. Our customers’ tenants may delay lease commencements, decline to extend or renew their leases upon expiration, fail to make rental payments ----- when due, or declare bankruptcy. Any of these actions could result in the termination of the tenants’ leases, or expiration of existing leases without renewal, and the loss of rental income attributable to the terminated or expired leases. Although a significant portion of our revenues are derived from “stock” businesses consisting of providing fee-based services to our customer portfolio, the loss of income by our customers could hinder their ability to pay such fees. Moreover, while our fees for our Joint Property Management business are expected to be paid by the landlords whether or not the property is being rented or occupied by the landlord, for our Lease Management and Letting business, our fees are paid only if the properties are being rented and paid for by the tenants. Therefore, lease terminations may result in a decrease in fees that we receive. Additionally, even if the lease continues, but the tenant fails to pay rent, we will not be able to collect our fees because they are automatically deducted from rental payments. We also are prohibited by law in France from evicting tenants in the winter so the effect of non-payment may be greater during that time because we will not be able to evict and re-let the property as quickly as during other times in the year. See “Regulation.” In the event of a tenant default or bankruptcy, we may experience delays in enforcing our rights and may incur substantial costs in protecting our customers and re-letting their property. If commercial leases are terminated or defaulted upon, it may be difficult to find a tenant to whom the property can be re-let. We also offer a rent payment guarantee (“Garantie de loyers impayés”) to certain residential landlords who have entrusted us with the management of their property. Under this guarantee, we bear the cost of any unpaid rent and advance such rent to landlords. These advances are not always recoverable from the lessee and thus represent a risk of non-recovery. We also offer an occupancy guarantee (“Garantie d’occupation”) to a small number of lessors to protect against vacant properties for up to six months if we are unable to find a tenant on selected apartments in new buildings. As a result, we may bear the cost of any unoccupied properties under this guarantee. For example, the quantity of unpaid rent typically increases during the winter months when we are prohibited from evicting people under French law, and thus it is possible that we may experience an increase in loss of revenues if we are unable to rent such properties. In addition, during the COVID-19 pandemic in 2020, our stock increased temporarily as it built up when we were unable to process disputes and evictions as a result of the first lockdown restrictions. In this case, the COVID-19 pandemic did not result in a significant increase in unpaid rent or defaults, however, we cannot ensure that our revenues will not be negatively impacted as a result of future lockdowns or other COVID-19-related disruptions. There is no assurance that we will receive payments that we are owed under our rent payment and occupancy guarantees; therefore, both represent a large source of potential risk. Moreover, the occurrence of any of the situations described above could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition or results of operations. For information about our guarantee programs, see “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations—Key _Factors Affecting Results of Operations—Rent payment and occupancy guarantees” and “Business— Our Businesses—French Residential Real Estate Services—Lease Management and Letting.”_

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: Deterioration in macroeconomic conditions and UK housing market conditions could have a material adverse effect on our operating results, business prospects and financial condition.
Subsubsection Text: Our business and future growth prospects depend in part on the strength and growth of the UK housing market, which we entered in August 2022 through our acquisition of FirstPort. The growth and the strength of the UK housing market is closely linked to macroeconomic conditions in the UK, which are affected by macroeconomic conditions in Europe and worldwide. In the aftermath of the COVID-19 pandemic, global GDP is estimated to have decreased by 2.8% in 2021, with UK GDP declining by 4.0% in the same year. Moreover, the outbreak of the war in Ukraine in February 2022, global supply chain disruptions and other geopolitical conflicts have caused an immediate impact on the UK economy, which is predicted by the IMF to grow more slowly than economies of other developed countries in the near future. Recently, a deterioration in economic conditions in the UK coupled with internal political instability resulted in an increased volatility of the UK mortgage markets, which, in turn, negatively ----- affected the UK real estate sector and contributed to declining real estate valuations in certain areas of the country. Any future deterioration in economic conditions in the UK could lead to increased unemployment rates, loss of earnings, increased short and long-term interest rates, consumer and commercial bankruptcy filings, inflation, increased cost of living, shortages of labor and/or materials and supplies and increased energy prices. All of these factors could negatively impact household and business incomes resulting in decreased demand for new housing, which could materially and adversely affect our profitability and prospects.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: Our ability to grow our business relies significantly upon our acquisition strategy and there can be no guarantee that sufficient or appropriate acquisition opportunities will be available to us, that we will be able to close any or all acquisitions under purchase agreements, exclusivity arrangements or letters of intent, or that financing will be available on acceptable terms.
Subsubsection Text: A significant component of our growth over time has been generated by acquisitions. We routinely explore acquiring other businesses and assets, and in the nine months ended September 30, 2022, we completed 55 acquisitions. We plan to continue to expand our business externally through similar acquisitions depending in part upon the continued availability of suitable acquisition candidates at favorable prices and upon advantageous terms and conditions, which may not be available to us, as well as sufficient funds from our cash on hand, cash flow from operations, existing debt facilities and additional indebtedness to fund these acquisitions. The number of acquisitions we pursue largely depends on the quality of the potential target and a key point of focus during our due diligence on a potential target, and the primary reason we decline to pursue a target after entering into a letter of intent, is the quality of the target’s client accounting. The success of our acquisition strategy depends on the ability of our senior management to identify suitable acquisition candidates, to accurately assess the value, strengths, weaknesses, contingent or other liabilities and potential profitability of such acquisition candidates, to obtain any necessary permits or approvals from regulatory bodies and to integrate the operations of such businesses once they are acquired. Our success in making additional acquisitions depends on the availability of, and competition for, suitable acquisition candidates. Further, we may be unable to identify or complete promising acquisitions for many reasons, including any misjudgment of the key elements of an acquisition, quality of client accounting, competition among buyers, the high valuations of businesses in our industry, the need for regulatory and other approvals, lack of internal resources to actively pursue all attractive opportunities and availability of capital. Even after entering into a share purchase agreement, exclusivity agreement or letter of intent, there can be no assurance that such acquisition will close until such transactions are finalized, which may also impact the Adjusted EBITDA presented in this Offering Memorandum. See also “Risk Factors—Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry—We present _information relating to Adjusted EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA Margin, Pro Forma M&A Adjusted EBITDA, Pro Forma Revenues, Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA Margin and other non-IFRS measures in this Offering Memorandum; certain of the data used in calculating this information was unaudited or involved certain estimates and judgments, and accordingly you should not unduly rely on them.”_ When we do identify and complete acquisitions, we may face financial, managerial and operational challenges, including diversion of management attention and resources needed for existing operations, difficulty with integrating acquired businesses, acquiring businesses that are not consistent with our long-term strategies, integration of different corporate cultures, increased expenses, potential dilution of our brand, assumption of unknown liabilities, indemnities, potential disputes with the sellers and the need to evaluate the financial systems of and establish internal controls for acquired entities. We have historically financed acquisitions through a variety of sources, including our own cash reserves and debt financing. While we intend to continue to finance acquisitions from these sources in the future, we may have insufficient cash reserves to fund acquisitions, and adverse market conditions or other factors may prevent us from obtaining debt finance on acceptable terms or at all. If we are unable to ----- implement our acquisition strategy, obtain sufficient financing or integrate acquired businesses successfully, our business and prospects for growth could be negatively affected. See “Management’s _Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations—Key Factors Affecting the Comparability of Our Results of Operations—Acquisitions and Disposals.”_ Given the various risks to which we are exposed and the uncertainties inherent in our business, we cannot guarantee the successful implementation of our acquisition strategies. Additionally, our strategies may put operational strain on our business and consume management time and focus to the detriment of our existing business operations. If we do not meet our strategic objectives or achieve the results initially expected, we may be unable to recover our investment or this may otherwise have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition or results of operations. We may not realize the expected benefit of our past or future acquisitions or we may face unforeseen costs or liabilities. In the past, we have grown through a combination of organic development and bolt-on acquisitions, and we intend to continue this combination in the future. Growth through acquisitions entails certain risks, including the risk of a failure to realize the expected benefits of the acquisitions and incurrence of unexpected risks and obligations. Our ability to realize the benefits we anticipate from our acquisition activities, including any anticipated cost synergies and other anticipated benefits, will depend in large part upon whether we are able to integrate such businesses efficiently and effectively. Integration is an ongoing process, and we may not be able to fully integrate such businesses smoothly or successfully, and the process may take longer than expected. Successful integration of acquired businesses will also depend on our ability to effect any required changes in operations or personnel and may require capital expenditures or the funding of unforeseen liabilities. The integration and operation of any future acquisitions may expose us to certain risks, including the following: liability related to the mishandling of customer cash accounts; difficulty in integrating the acquired businesses in a cost-effective manner, including the full integration of the acquired business account management into our IT system, management information and financial control systems; unforeseen legal, regulatory, contractual, labor or other issues arising out of the acquisitions; significant unexpected liabilities or contingencies arising from the acquisitions; potential disruptions to our ongoing business caused by our senior management’s focus on the acquired companies; and post-acquisition performance not meeting our expectations or plans. We are required to have separate customer accounts in our Joint Property Management business, and if a target has poor customer accounting policies, it could lead to difficulties collecting customer balances or complying with applicable law. There can be no assurance that our future acquisitions will be made on appropriate terms or at an acceptable cost or can be successfully integrated with the rest of our businesses. A failure to identify appropriate acquisitions could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition or results of operations. Our failure to realize the expected benefits or synergies of past or future acquisitions could result in the lack of implementation and achievement of our growth strategy may prevent us from obtaining the advantages that the acquisitions were intended to create, or could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition or results of operations.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: A failure to appropriately address actual or perceived conflicts of interest could adversely affect our businesses.
Subsubsection Text: Our company has different businesses and a broad customer base and is therefore subject to numerous potential, actual or perceived conflicts of interests in the provision of services to our existing and potential customers. For example, conflicts may arise from our position as broker to both landlords and tenants in residential real estate lease transactions or our Brokerage business could have inside information about a property or the property owner’s circumstances relative to other brokers as a result of our managing that property through our RRES business. In certain cases, we are also subject to fiduciary obligations to our customers. We have adopted various policies, controls and procedures to monitor, address and limit actual or perceived conflicts, such as an officer in charge of our risk ----- management team, anti-bribery software, a whistleblower hotline and data compliance procedures, but these policies and procedures may not be adequate or may not be adhered to by our employees. Appropriately dealing with conflicts of interest is complex and difficult, and our reputation could be damaged and cause us to lose existing customers or fail to gain new customers if we fail, or appear to fail, to identify, disclose and appropriately address potential conflicts of interest or fiduciary obligations, which could have an adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations. In addition, it is possible that in some jurisdictions, regulations could be changed to limit our ability to act for parties where conflicts exist even with informed consent, which could limit our market share in those markets. We cannot guarantee that future conflicts of interest will not cause material harm to us.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: We are subject to various risks related to managing large numbers of residential properties, and our failure to effectively perform property management functions or to effectively manage our portfolio and operations could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition or results of operations.
Subsubsection Text: As of September 30, 2022, we managed approximately 59,040 buildings and approximately 1.8 million dwellings in France under our Joint Property Management business and approximately 376,000 dwellings in France under our Lease Management and Letting business. In addition, following the acquisition of FirstPort in August 2022, as of September 30, 2022, we managed approximately 321,000 units in the UK under our Joint Property Management business. It may be difficult for us or our agents (including real estate brokers and subcontractors hired by other third parties we engage) to regularly inspect such properties and manage the maintenance and upkeep on behalf of our customers and to ensure compliance with regulatory requirements. Additionally, we may find it difficult to manage tenants if they encounter difficulties with the properties they rent. For example, although there are certain basic necessities that must function properly, such as heat or water, we cannot force a landlord to comply with all tenant requests if they are not mandated by law. Therefore, a tenant may have an unfavorable view of us as property manager for unresolved requests that the landlord will not approve or if they are unhappy with the quality of work commissioned by the landlord, which can present a risk to our reputation. The occurrence of any such development could have a material adverse effect on our reputation, business, financial condition or results of operations. Our ability to perform the property management services will be affected by various factors, including, among other things, engaging the appropriate subcontractors, maintaining sufficient personnel and retaining key personnel at the number of our properties that we manage under our Lease Management and Letting and Joint Property Management businesses. No assurance can be made that we will continue to be successful in attracting and retaining skilled personnel, in integrating any new personnel into our organization or in engaging with the appropriate subcontractors at reasonable costs. Our future success will depend, in part, upon our ability to successfully monitor our operations, costs, regulatory compliance and service quality and maintain other necessary internal controls. Our inability to effectively perform the property management services on the properties managed by us as part of our Lease Management and Letting and Joint Property Management businesses, or to effectively manage our portfolio and operations, could materially adversely affect our business, financial condition or results of operations.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: We may not realize any or all of our estimated cost savings, gains and synergies, which would have a negative effect on our results of operations.
Subsubsection Text: In the past, we have grown through a combination of organic development and significant bolt-on acquisitions, and we intend to continue this combination in the future. Any cost savings, gains and synergies that we realize from these bolt-on acquisitions may differ materially from our estimates. The estimates contained herein are our current estimates, but they involve risks, uncertainties, assumptions and other factors that may cause our actual results, performance or achievements to be materially different from any future results, performance or achievements expressed or implied by such estimates. ----- Our ability to realize the expected cost savings, gains and synergies associated with the adjustments included when calculating Adjusted EBITDA, Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA and other non–IFRS financial measures depends on factors beyond our control, such as operating difficulties, increased operating costs, competitors and customers, delays in implementing initiatives and general economic or industry conditions. We may be required to make cash expenditures to achieve such cost savings, gains and synergies, and these costs are not reflected in Adjusted EBITDA or Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA. We cannot assure you that these cash expenditures to achieve such cost savings, gains and synergies will not be higher than we anticipated. In addition, we may not fully realize such cost savings, gains and synergies within 12 months of the completion of the respective acquisitions, and may not do so at all. Further, our churn rate in respect of the bolt-on acquisitions may be higher than expected. Accordingly, you should not view our presentation of this adjustment in our Adjusted EBITDA or Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA as a projection that we will achieve these cost savings or gains. Our ability to realize these anticipated gains and synergies is subject to significant uncertainties and you should not place undue reliance on the adjustments in evaluating our anticipated results. In addition, any cost savings, gains and synergies that we realize may be offset, in whole or in part, by reductions in revenues, or through increases in other expenses, including as a result of the actions we take. For example, reducing sales, marketing and customer support could result in lower revenue and could lead to disruption of our operations, loss of or inability to recruit key personnel, decline in employee productivity, weakening of internal standards, controls or procedures, and impairment of key customer and supplier relationships. Further, no third party, including our independent auditors or any of the initial purchasers, has performed any assurance procedures or expressed an opinion with respect to these estimated cost savings or gains, or their respective achievability. As a result, our future performance may differ significantly from the pro forma financial information set forth herein. See “Summary Historical Financial Information and Other Data—Summary Financial and Other _Information—Summary Other Financial and Operating Data—Other Financial Data.”_

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: We present information relating to Adjusted EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA Margin, Pro Forma M&A Adjusted EBITDA, Pro Forma Revenues, Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA Margin and other non- IFRS measures in this Offering Memorandum; certain of the data used in calculating this information was unaudited or involved certain estimates and judgments, and accordingly you should not unduly rely on them.
Subsubsection Text: The Offering Memorandum includes certain statements and figures relating to Adjusted EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA Margin, Pro Forma M&A Adjusted EBITDA, Pro Forma Revenues, Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA Margin and other non-IFRS measures. Pro Forma M&A Adjusted EBITDA and other metrics calculated using Pro Forma M&A Adjusted EBITDA include estimated results of acquired businesses assuming such acquisitions were made at the beginning of the period presented. We calculated such figures using third-party quality of earnings assessments and the information and records available from the acquired businesses, which in certain instances was based on unaudited financial information or management schedules and therefore required significant assumptions and estimates, may not be up to date or may not be prepared on the same basis on which we prepare our accounts. While these figures are based upon the latest available financial information from the acquired business at the time we built each business case, actual figures may differ. Moreover, we can offer no assurances that any anticipated acquisitions will close or that we will recognized our estimated cost savings or efficiency gains. In addition, Pro Forma Revenues, Adjusted EBITDA and Pro Forma M&A Adjusted EBITDA also gives effect to the impact that the COVID–19 pandemic had on our business in the periods presented in this Offering Memorandum. This adjustment is for illustrative purposes only. While we believe these estimates and assumptions to be reasonable, some or all of this information may prove to be inaccurate or incomplete. As a result, you should not unduly rely on such information in making an investment in the Additional Notes. See also “Risk Factors—Risks Relating to Our Business _and Industry—Our ability to grow our business relies significantly upon our acquisition strategy and there can be no guarantee that sufficient or appropriate acquisition opportunities will be available to us, that we will be able to close any or all acquisitions under purchase agreements, exclusivity arrangements or letters of intent, or that financing will be available on acceptable terms.”_ -----

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: We may be unable to effectively manage our growth into new geographies.
Subsubsection Text: Our growth plan includes expansion into new or recently entered regions, particularly in Europe. For example, we entered the UK market in August, 2022, and we have continued to expand in Germany, Switzerland, Belgium and other countries in recent years. Expanding into these geographies involves significant expenditures, over a period of several years, hiring and training of personnel, and marketing efforts to introduce our brand to the new geography. We may not accurately predict such costs or accurately anticipate operational difficulties caused by local conditions, and therefore may not achieve our financial and strategic objectives for our operations in the new geographies. Additionally, any such operational difficulties may impact our customer service, which may lead to customers switching to competitors, or lead to logistical difficulties such as with the processing of invoices and billing. Accordingly, we may incur losses as we expand our operations. Some examples of the risks encountered in entering new regions include: - increased investment associated with understanding new geographies and following trends in these areas in order to effectively compete; - increased costs associated with adapting our products and services to different requirements in the local markets areas, which may decrease our margins and profitability; - challenges relating to developing and maintaining appropriate understanding and complying with new regulatory schemes; - reduced ability to predict our performance because we will have less experience in the new geographies than in our existing geographies; and - political, regulatory and other local risks. To the extent we are not able to effectively manage our growth into new geographies, our financial results could be adversely impacted.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: Our brands and our reputation are key assets of our company, which will be affected by how we are perceived in the marketplace.
Subsubsection Text: Our brands and their respective attributes are key assets, and we believe our continued success depends on our ability to preserve, grow and leverage the value of our brands. Our ability to attract and retain customers is highly dependent upon the external perceptions of our level of service, trustworthiness, business practices, management, workplace culture, financial condition, our response to unexpected events and other subjective qualities. Negative perceptions or publicity regarding these matters, even if related to seemingly isolated incidents and whether or not factually correct, could erode trust and confidence and damage our reputation among existing and potential customers, which could make it difficult for us to attract new customers and maintain existing ones. Negative public opinion could result from actual or alleged conduct in any number of activities or circumstances, including the personal conduct of individuals associated with our brand, the handling of customer complaints, regulatory compliance, such as compliance with anti-bribery, anti-money laundering and corruption laws, the use and protection of customer and other sensitive information, and actions taken by regulators or others in response to such conduct. Social media channels can also cause rapid, widespread reputational harm to our brand. Our portfolio of brands and our reputation may also be harmed by actions taken by third parties that are outside of our control. For example, any shortcoming of or controversy related to third-party providers, landlords or property owners may be attributed to us, thus damaging our reputation and the value of the affected brand and increasing the attractiveness of our competitors’ services. Also, business decisions or other actions or omissions of our shareholders or management may adversely affect the value of our investments, result in litigation or regulatory action against us, and otherwise damage our reputation ----- and brands. Adverse developments with respect to our industry may also, by association, negatively impact our reputation or result in greater regulatory or legislative scrutiny or litigation against us. The protection of our brand, including related trademarks, may require the expenditure of significant financial and operational resources. Moreover, the steps we take to protect our portfolio of brands may not adequately protect our rights or prevent third parties from infringing or misappropriating our trademarks. Even when we detect infringement or misappropriation of our trademarks, we may not be able to enforce all such trademarks. Any unauthorized use by third parties of any of our brands may adversely affect our brands. Furthermore, as we continue to expand our business, especially internationally, there is a risk we may face claims of infringement or other alleged violations of thirdparty intellectual property rights, which may restrict us from leveraging our brands in a manner consistent with our business goals.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: Failure to maintain and execute information technology strategies and ensure that our employees adapt to changes in technology could materially and adversely affect our ability to remain competitive in the market.
Subsubsection Text: Our business relies heavily on information technology, including on solutions provided by third parties, to deliver services that meet the needs of our customers. If we are unable to effectively execute and maintain our information technology strategies or adopt new technologies and processes relevant to our service platform, our ability to deliver high-quality services may be materially impaired. In addition, we make significant investments in new systems and tools to achieve competitive advantages and efficiencies. For example, we are in the process of rolling out Millenium, our new ERP system designed to digitize many of our services and lead to operational improvements. Implementation of such investments in information technology could exceed estimated budgets, and we may experience challenges that prevent new strategies or technologies from being realized according to anticipated schedules. If we are unable to maintain current information technology and processes, or encounter delays, or fail to exploit new technologies, the execution of our business plans may be disrupted. Similarly, our employees require effective tools and techniques to perform functions integral to our business. Our payroll and compensation technology systems are important to ensuring that key personnel are compensated accurately and on a timely basis. Failure to pay professionals the compensation they are due in a timely manner could result in higher attrition. Failure to successfully provide such tools and systems, or ensure that employees have properly adopted them, could materially and adversely impact our ability to achieve positive business outcomes.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: Any failure by us to successfully execute on our strategy to achieve for operational efficiency could result in total costs and expenses that are greater than expected.
Subsubsection Text: We have an operating framework that includes a disciplined focus on operational efficiency. As part of this framework, we have adopted several initiatives, including the implementation of our operational models such as “Agency of the Future” and Millenium, our new ERP system which we continuously develop, workflow processes and systems to improve client engagement and outcomes across our service lines. Although we have already successfully begun the rollout of Millenium in our French brokerage and more recently our RRES operations, there is no guarantee that our rollout will continue to be successful from an operational perspective, particular as we aim to accelerate adoption in our operations in the near future. Additionally, our ability to continue to achieve the anticipated cost savings, gains and other benefits from these initiatives within the expected time frame is subject to many estimates and assumptions. These estimates and assumptions are subject to significant economic, competitive and other uncertainties, some of which are beyond our control. In addition, we are vulnerable to increased risks associated with implementing changes to our tools, processes and systems given our varied service lines, the geographic regions in which we and our customers operate and the number of acquisitions that we have completed in recent years. If these estimates and assumptions are incorrect, if we are unsuccessful at implementing changes, if we experience delays, or if other unforeseen events occur, we may not achieve or continue to achieve new operational efficiencies and as a result our business and results of operations could be adversely affected. -----

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: We rely on key relationships with third-party providers to conduct our business.
Subsubsection Text: We rely on key relationships with third parties such as law firms, real estate brokers, administrative agencies, notaries, postal services, technical contractors and our customer’s bank branches to conduct our business. If we are unable to find and maintain reliable service providers, any failure by these third parties to adequately perform certain services for us or the loss of these relationships could materially impair our business operations, and reduce our cash flow, income and profitability. For example, the halting of notary activities in connection with the first lockdown directly affected our brokerage activities. While our contracts with certain third parties may provide for indemnification to cover damages resulting from failure to perform their obligations satisfactorily, such indemnification may not fully cover our financial losses in attempting to mitigate their failures or our losses to other parties or may not be received in a timely manner or at all.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: We are subject to various litigation risks and may face financial liabilities and/or damage to our reputation as a result of litigation.
Subsubsection Text: We are exposed to various litigation risks and from time to time are party to various legal proceedings that involve claims for substantial amounts of money. We depend on our business relationships and our reputation to attract and retain customers. As a result, allegations against us, irrespective of the ultimate outcome of such allegations, may harm our professional reputation and as such materially damage our business and its prospects, in addition to any financial impact. As a licensed real estate broker and provider of commercial and residential real estate services, we, and our licensed professionals and independent contractors, are subject to statutory due diligence, disclosure and standard-of-care obligations. Failure to fulfill these obligations could subject us, our sales professionals or independent contractors to litigation from parties who purchased, sold or leased properties that we brokered or managed in the jurisdictions in which we operate. We are subject from time to time to claims by participants in real estate sales and leasing transactions, including associations representing tenants and tenant lobby groups, as well as building owners and companies for whom we provide management services, who claim that we did not fulfill our obligations, or by customers for whom we provided appraisal and valuation services and/or third parties who perceive themselves as having been negatively affected by our appraisals and/or valuations. Additionally, we may be subject to billing-related claims in respect of our RRES business, for example that we have over-billed clients or that we have not been sufficiently transparent in our billing. These consumer organizations representing tenants are able to organize class actions in the real estate services market, which has been introduced by the French Hamon law, and file lawsuits on behalf of tenants. We could be subject to claims following the acquisition of a business or subject to audits and/or fines from various local real estate authorities or regulatory agencies if they determine that we are violating licensing laws or failing to follow certain laws, rules and regulations. In our residential property management business, we hire and supervise third-party contractors to provide services for our managed properties. We may be subject to claims for defects, negligent performance of work or other similar actions or omissions by third parties we do not control. Moreover, our customers may seek to hold us accountable for the actions of contractors because of our role as property or facilities manager or project manager, even if we have technically disclaimed liability as a contractual matter, in which case we may be pressured to participate in a financial settlement for purposes of preserving the customer relationship. We engage with subcontractors to provide a large number of building staff in facilities that we manage, and as a result, we face the risk of potential claims from such staff, such subcontractors. We also face employment-related claims as an employer with respect to our corporate and other employees, for which we would bear ultimate responsibility in the event of an adverse outcome in such ----- matters. We also face claims related to our franchisees, with respect to the termination of our franchise agreements and other claims which may arise related to such agreements. Adverse outcomes of property and facilities management disputes and related or other litigation could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations and prospects, particularly to the extent we may be liable on our contracts, or if our liabilities exceed the amounts of the insurance coverage procured and maintained by us. In addition, we face the risk of claims relating to environmental, health and safety matters relating to properties that we manage. For example, such claims could be based on alleged exposure to asbestos-containing product components and could present potential direct or indirect liabilities to the Group. Further, we face the risk of claims of illness or injury relating to premise liability given that we lease, manage and sell properties to our customers. Some of these litigation risks may be mitigated by the commercial insurance policies we maintain. However, in the event of a substantial loss or certain types of claims, our insurance coverage and/or self-insurance reserve levels might not be sufficient to pay the full damages. Additionally, in the event of grossly negligent or intentionally wrongful conduct, insurance policies that we may have may not cover us at all. Further, the value of otherwise valid claims held under insurance policies could become uncollectible in the event of the covering insurance company’s insolvency, although we seek to limit this risk by placing our commercial insurance only with highly rated companies. Any of these events could materially negatively impact our business, financial condition, results of operations and prospects. Finally, we are also subject, from time to time, to tax audits and challenges from relevant tax authorities. In this respect, two entities of the Group are currently undergoing tax audits run by the French tax authorities in respect of fiscal years 2016 to 2018 and 2016 to 2019, respectively. If any such challenges are made and are not resolved in our favor, they could result in a decrease of our tax losses as well as additional tax liabilities and thus have an adverse effect on our financial condition and results of operations. Based on our oral exchanges with the French tax authorities, we do not anticipate significant adjustments in the context of the aforementioned tax audits.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: Adverse developments in the credit markets may harm our business, results of operations and financial condition.
Subsubsection Text: Our business and our acquisition strategy are sensitive to credit cost and availability as well as marketplace liquidity. Additionally, the revenue in all of our businesses is dependent to some extent on the overall volume of activity and pricing in the residential real estate market. Disruptions in the credit markets may adversely affect our advisory services to investors, owners and tenants of real estate in connection with the leasing, disposition and acquisition of property. If our customers are unable to procure credit on favorable terms, there may be fewer completed leasing transactions, dispositions and acquisitions of property. In addition, if purchasers of commercial real estate are not able to obtain favorable financing, resulting in the lack of disposition and acquisition opportunities for our projects, our business may be unable to generate incentive fees.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: Interruption or failure of our information technology, communications systems or data services could impair our ability to provide our services effectively, which could damage our reputation and materially harm our operating results.
Subsubsection Text: Our business requires the continued operation of information technology and communication systems and network infrastructure. Our ability to conduct our global business may be materially adversely affected by disruptions to these systems or infrastructure. Our information technology and communications systems are vulnerable to damage or disruption from fire, power loss, telecommunications failure, system malfunctions, computer viruses, cyber attacks, natural disasters such as hurricanes, earthquakes and floods, acts of war or terrorism, employee errors or malfeasance, or other events which are beyond our control. With respect to cyberattacks and viruses, these pose growing threats to many companies, and we may be a target of such threats, which could expose us to ----- liability, reputational harm and significant remediation costs and cause material harm to our business and financial results. For example, our Swiss operations were temporarily disrupted by a ransomware attack in December 2021, though we were able to fully resume normal operations shortly afterwards. Such threats may also disrupt our operations, for example interrupting our customer service offerings or impeding our ability to invoice our customers. In addition, the operation and maintenance of our systems and networks is, in some cases, dependent on third-party technologies, systems and services providers for which there is no certainty of uninterrupted availability. Any of these events could cause system interruption, delays and loss, corruption or exposure of critical data or intellectual property or disruption of our ability to provide services to or interact with our customers, contractors and vendors, and we may not be able to successfully implement contingency plans that depend on communication or travel. We could also face difficulties in bringing the IT systems of the companies that we acquire up to the standard of our standard security procedures and protections, which could lead to interruptions or failures of our information systems. Furthermore, any such event could result in substantial recovery and remediation costs and liability to customers, business partners and other third parties. Additionally, we may experience higher than expected capital expenditures related to upgrading our IT systems to deal with unexpected future security risks. We have business continuity and disaster recovery plans and backup systems to reduce the potentially adverse effect of such events, but our disaster recovery planning may not be sufficient and cannot account for all eventualities, and a catastrophic event that results in the destruction or disruption of any of our data centers, our critical business or information technology systems could severely affect our ability to conduct normal business operations, and as a result, our future operating results could be materially adversely affected. Our business relies heavily on the use of software and residential real estate data, some of which is purchased or licensed from third-party providers for which there is no certainty of uninterrupted availability. A disruption of our ability to access such software, including an inability to renew such licenses on the same or similar terms, or provide data to our professionals and/or our customers, contractors and vendors or an inadvertent exposure of proprietary data could damage our reputation and competitive position, and our operating results could be adversely affected.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: A material breach in security relating to our information systems could adversely affect us.
Subsubsection Text: In the ordinary course of our business, we collect and store sensitive data in our data centers and on our networks, including our proprietary business information and intellectual property, our customers’ sensitive data and personally identifiable information of our tenants, employees, contractors and vendors. The secure processing, maintenance and transmission of this information is critical to our operations. Security breaches and other disruptions of our information and technology networks could compromise our information and intellectual property and expose us to liability, reputational harm and significant remediation costs, which could cause material harm to our business and financial results. Unauthorized disclosure, modification or loss of confidential, personally identifiable or sensitive data or other operational failures may occur through a variety of methods. These include, but are not limited to, systems failures, in-house employee negligence, fraud or misappropriation, or unauthorized access to or through our information systems, whether by our in-house employees, vendors or third parties, or a cyber-attack by hackers, members of organized crime and/or state-sponsored organizations. Information security risks have generally increased in recent years, in part because of the proliferation of new technologies and the use of the internet, and the increased sophistication and activity of organized crime, hackers, terrorists, activists, cybercriminals and other external parties, some of which may be linked to terrorist organizations or hostile foreign governments. Cybersecurity attacks are becoming more sophisticated and include malicious software, phishing and spear phishing attacks, wire fraud and payment diversion, account and email takeover attacks, ransomware, attempts to gain unauthorized access to data and other electronic security breaches. Cybersecurity attacks, including attacks that are not ultimately successful, could lead to disruptions in our critical systems, unauthorized release of ----- confidential or otherwise protected information or corruption of our data, and could also substantially damage our reputation. We have experienced cybersecurity attacks in the past, including ransomware attacks by cybercriminals, and we expect we may experience additional attacks in the future. Cybersecurity attacks like the ones we have experienced in the past could have a substantial impact on our reputation with our customers, and stakeholders, and may have a material adverse effect on our business. An incident involving disclosure, data modification, loss or security breach or a significant technical failure could subject us to significant monetary damages or losses, litigation, negative publicity, regulatory enforcement actions, and liability under our contracts, resulting in increased costs or loss of revenue. Any person who circumvents our security measures could steal proprietary or confidential customer information or cause interruptions in our operations that could cause us to be unable to provide our services or operate our business, which could damage our reputation. We incur significant costs to protect against security breaches and other cybersecurity attacks and may incur significant additional costs to address issues caused by any such breaches or cybersecurity attacks. Our failure to prevent future security breaches or cybersecurity attacks, or well- publicized security breaches affecting the internet in general, could significantly harm our reputation and business and financial results.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: Regulations related to a material breach in data security could adversely affect us.
Subsubsection Text: Certain laws, regulations and standards regarding data security affecting our customers impose requirements regarding the security of information maintained by these customers, as well as notifications to persons whose personal information is accessed by an unauthorized third party. Certain laws may also require us to protect the security of our employees’ personal data. In particular, we are subject to the stringent requirements of the EU’s General Data Protection Regulation (“GDPR”), violation of which carries substantial fines and grants individual data subjects the right to claim damages for rights violations. In addition, in connection with the processing of personal data, we are also subject to French law No. 78-17 of January 6, 1978 on information technology, data files and civil liberties as amended, which incorporates the provisions of the GDPR. A public authority, the French Data Protection Authority (Commission Nationale de l’informatique et des Libertés) (“CNIL”), is responsible for ensuring compliance with data protection regulations in France. We cannot ensure that the confidentiality of such data and information will not be breached as a result of cybersecurity attacks or otherwise, or that doubts may not arise regarding the security of the data and information collected and managed by us. As a result of any continuing legislative initiatives and customer demands, we may have to modify our operations with the goal of further improving data security. The cost of compliance with these laws, regulations and standards is high and is likely to increase in the future. Any such modifications may result in increased expenses and operating complexity, and we may be unable to increase the rates we charge for our services sufficiently to offset these increases. Any failure on our part to comply with these laws, regulations and standards can result in negative publicity and diversion of management time and effort and may subject us to significant liabilities and other penalties. If customer confidential information or personal data that we maintain is inappropriately disclosed due to an information security breach, or if any person, including any of our employees, negligently disregards or intentionally breaches our confidentiality policies or other controls or procedures with which we are responsible for complying with respect to such data or otherwise mismanages or misappropriates that data, we may incur substantial liabilities to our customers and be subject to fines or penalties imposed by governmental authorities. Any incidents with respect to the handling of such information could subject us to litigation or indemnification claims with our customers and other parties and harm our reputation. In addition, any breach or alleged breach of our confidentiality agreements with our customers may result in termination of their engagements, resulting in associated loss of revenue and increased costs and have a material adverse effect on our reputation and business. For further discussion on the laws and regulations applicable to our businesses, see “Regulation.” -----

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: Our business may suffer if we cannot continue to license or enforce the intellectual property rights on which our business depends or if we are subject to claims of intellectual property infringement.
Subsubsection Text: Our ability to compete effectively with other companies depends, in part, upon our ability to protect our proprietary methodologies and other intellectual property, including the value of our brands. We rely upon a combination of trade secrets, confidentiality, license and other contractual agreements and patent, copyright, and trademark laws to protect our intellectual property rights. For example, certain of our business units rely on proprietary software that we have developed internally or acquired, such as Millenium, or mobile apps developed as part of our digital initiatives strategy. Our intellectual property rights may not prevent competitors from independently developing services and solutions similar to ours. Further, the steps we take may not be adequate to prevent or deter infringement or other misappropriation of our intellectual property by competitors, former in-house employees or other third parties, which could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition or results of operations. In addition, we cannot be sure that our services and solutions do not infringe on the intellectual property rights of third parties. Third parties, including competitors, may assert intellectual property infringement, misappropriation or invalidity claims against us that could be upheld. Intellectual property litigation, which could result in substantial cost to and diversion of effort by us, may be necessary to protect our intellectual property rights, including trade secrets or proprietary technology or for us to defend against claimed infringement or misappropriation of the rights of others and to determine the scope and validity of our or others’ intellectual property or proprietary rights. We may not prevail in any such litigation, and if we are unsuccessful, we may be subject to monetary liability and injunctive or equitable relief, which may prevent our use of others’ intellectual property or proprietary rights if we are not be able to obtain the necessary licenses on reasonable terms or at all. Any failure by us to protect our trademarks and other intellectual property rights may have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition or results of operations.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: Our insurance coverage may not be sufficient.
Subsubsection Text: We currently have general liability insurance and insurance for certain specific policies, such as cybersecurity-related incidents, in place to cover liability to which we may be exposed from our business activities and certain facilities, in amounts that we consider appropriate. Such policies are subject to certain limits and deductibles and do not include business interruption coverage. We may not be covered by insurance in specific instances, such as fire, explosions, natural disasters, water damage and terror attacks. While we seek to maintain appropriate levels of insurance, not all claims are insurable, and we may experience major incidents of a nature not covered by insurance. Furthermore, our insurance costs may increase over time in response to any negative development in our claims history or due to material price increases in the insurance market in general. Insurance coverage may not be available in the future at current costs or on commercially reasonable terms, and the insurance proceeds received for any loss of, or any damage to, any of our facilities may not be sufficient to restore the loss or damage without negative impact on our results of operations, financial condition and cash flows.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: Our businesses, financial condition, results of operations and prospects could be adversely affected by new laws or regulations or by changes in existing laws or regulations or the application thereof. If we fail to comply with laws and regulations applicable to us, or make incorrect determinations in complex tax regimes, we may incur significant financial penalties.
Subsubsection Text: We are subject to numerous European, national and local laws and regulations specific to the services we perform in our businesses. Brokerage of real estate sales and leasing transactions and the provision of valuation services requires us, and our employees, to maintain applicable licenses in certain countries in which we perform these services. If we, and our employees, fail to maintain our licenses or conduct these activities without a license, or violate any of the regulations regarding our licenses, we may be ----- required to pay fines or return commissions received or have our licenses suspended, cancelled or revoked. In addition, the residential real estate industry and residential tenancies in particular remain heavily regulated and closely monitored by consumer watchdog organizations and associations that can organize class actions and file lawsuits on behalf of tenants. The latest major change came in 2014, with the introduction of the ALUR law, under which the French government introduced, among others, measures to protect individuals considering buying or renting an apartment within a professionally managed co-ownership building. A large amount of extra documentation is now required before the pre-contract (compromis de vente) can be signed, which increases the time between the initial offer and closing. We must comply with law No. 89-462 dated July 6, 1989, which grants residential tenants a statutory right of renewal and caps rents for vacant units and renewed leases at the amount of the last indexed rent paid by the previous tenant and/or of a reference rent determined by the decree. This law also restricts a limited number of landlords a right to recover service charges from tenants and requires residential leases to complete various reports on the environmental status of the property or technical features of the premises. In addition, we are prohibited by law in France from evicting tenants in winter, from November 1 to March 31 each year. We must also comply with articles L.145-1 et seq. of the French Commercial Code, recently modified by law No. 2014-626 dated June 18, 2014 known as the Pinel Law, for premises leased to commercial tenants. The French commercial leases regime establishes various compulsory obligations establishing, amongst others, a minimum term of nine years, a tenant’s statutory right of renewal on lease expiry, a cap on renewed rents and a limitation on service charge recoverable from tenants. We are also subject to laws of broader applicability, such as tax, securities, environmental, employment laws, anti-bribery, anti-money laundering and corruption laws, and occupational health and safety regulations. Failure to comply with these requirements could result in the imposition of significant fines by governmental authorities, awards of damages to private litigants and significant amounts paid in legal fees or settlements of these matters. As the size and scope of our business has increased significantly during the past decade, both the difficulty of ensuring compliance with numerous licensing and other regulatory requirements and the possible loss resulting from non-compliance have increased. The global economic crisis has resulted in increased government and legislative activities, including the introduction of new legislation and changes to rules and regulations, which we expect will continue into the future. New or revised legislation or regulations applicable to our business may have an adverse effect on our business, including increasing the costs of regulatory compliance or preventing us from providing certain types of services in certain jurisdictions or in connection with certain transactions or customers. For example, on May 25, 2018, GDPR became effective with a greater territorial reach than existing laws, and it applies to all of our contracts and agreements throughout Europe. As a result, we updated and continue to update certain agreements and data protection practices, which may take significant time and cost. We are unable to predict how new laws, rules, regulations and proposals will be implemented or in what form, or whether any additional or similar changes to laws or regulations, including the interpretation or implementation thereof, will occur in the future. Any such action could affect us in substantial and unpredictable ways and could have an adverse effect on our businesses, financial condition, results of operations and prospects.

Subsection Title: Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: Examinations and challenges by tax authorities or changes in tax laws or challenges to our tax position could adversely affect our results of operations and financial condition.
Subsubsection Text: We are subject to complex tax laws in each of the jurisdictions in which we operate, as well as international tax laws. Changes in tax laws or regulations or to their interpretations could adversely affect our tax position, including our effective tax rate or tax payments. ----- Our tax returns and the tax treatment of our transactions are prepared in accordance with applicable tax legislation and prevailing case law. Certain tax positions we take are based on industry practice, tax advice we have received in some cases from third parties, and similarities to facts and circumstances described in case law. These positions may relate to tax compliance (especially in the current international tax context tending towards enhanced mandatory disclosure obligations), classification of income, treaty relief, withholding tax, franchise, gross receipts, payroll, property and income tax issues, including tax base. It is possible that the tax authorities will not agree with the views we have taken. From time to time, we are subject to tax audits, and any challenges from relevant tax authorities with respect to our application and interpretation of tax rules may result in adjustments to the timing or amount of taxable income or deductions, and such adjustments may not be favorable to us. If any such challenges are made and are not resolved in our favor, they could result in significant additional tax liabilities and have an adverse effect on our financial condition and results of operations. In particular, European and French tax laws and regulations are extremely complex and are subject to varying interpretations. In this respect, an increase in administrative efforts within our business and an impact on existing structures may occur from the current incorporation into French tax law of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development’s (the “OECD”) principles related to base erosions and profit-shifting (“BEPS”) that were included in the final reports released by the OECD and the Multilateral Convention to Implement Tax Treaty Related Measures to Prevent BEPS signed in Paris on June 7, 2017. The European Union intends to harmonize tax legislation of the Member States. In this respect, the Council of the European Union (the “Council of the European Union”) adopted a directive “laying down rules against tax avoidance practices that directly affect the functioning of the internal market” on July 12, 2016 (Council Directive 2016/1164) (the “ATAD”). The ATAD was later amended on May 29, 2017 by the Council Directive (EU) 2017/952 (the “ATAD 2”), which, inter alia, extends the scope of the ATAD to hybrid mismatches involving third countries and provides that its provisions apply (subject to certain exceptions) from January 1, 2020. Among the set of measures, the ATAD provides for a general interest limitation rule pursuant to which the tax deduction of net financial expenses is limited to 30% of the taxpayer’s earnings before interest, tax, depreciation and amortization (EBITDA) or to a maximum amount of €3 million, whichever is higher (subject to several exceptions). Such rules apply from January 1, 2019 following their transposition into French tax law. The French Finance Law for 2020 (Law 2019-1479 of December 28, 2019) also introduced under French tax law the provisions of the ATAD 2 in the French Code général des impôts (the “French Tax Code”). See “Risk Factors— _Risks Relating to the Senior Secured Notes—French tax legislation may restrict the deductibility, for French tax purposes, of all or a portion of the interest on our indebtedness incurred in France, thus reducing the cash flow available to service our indebtedness” for more details on these rules._ Furthermore, Article 108 of the 2019 French Finance Law introduced, under French tax law, the antiabuse provision provided for by the ATAD with respect to French corporate income tax and aims to address abusive tax practices that are not dealt with by specifically targeted provisions (codified under article 205 A of the French Tax Code). Pursuant to this provision, the French tax authorities may ignore an arrangement or a series of arrangements which are not genuinely taking into account all relevant facts and circumstances, having been put into place for the main purpose, or one of the main purposes of obtaining a tax advantage that defeats the object or purpose of the applicable tax law. The European Commission has also published a corporate reform package proposal on October 25, 2016 including three new proposals that aim at (i) re-launching the Common Consolidated Corporate Tax Base (“CCCTB”) which is a single set of rules to compute companies’ taxable profits in the EU, (ii) avoiding loopholes associated with profit-shifting for tax between EU countries and non-EU countries, and (iii) providing new dispute resolution rules to relieve problems with double taxation for businesses. In a communication to the European Parliament and the Council of May 18, 2021 and denominated “Business Taxation for the 21st Century”, the European Commission announced additional measures in the field of corporate taxation to take into account the evolution of the context of the EU business taxation policy. In particular, the European Commission announced that it will ----- propose a new framework for income taxation for businesses in Europe (“Business in Europe: Framework for Income Taxation” or “BEFIT”) that will replace the pending proposals under the CCCTB. BEFIT will be a single corporate tax rulebook for the EU and will consist in consolidating the profits of the EU members of a multinational group into a single tax base, which will then be allocated to member states using a formula and be taxed at national corporate income tax rates. The preparation for this new proposal will be carried out by the European Commission alongside the member states and the European Parliament. The European Commission has launched a public consultation on BEFIT on 17 October 2022 opened to all stakeholders until early 2023. The European Commission also published (i) a proposal for a directive setting out union rules to neutralize the misuse of shell entities for tax purposes on December 22, 2021 (“ATAD 3”) and (ii) a proposal for a directive creating a Debt Equity Bias Reduction Allowance (“DEBRA”) aiming at encouraging companies to finance their investment through equity contributions rather than through debt financing.
