Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: We are the global leader in the residential real estate services (“RRES”) market by dwellings under management, providing services to both individuals (“business-to-consumer” or “B2C”) and businesses (“business-to-business” or “B2B”), and have also entered the commercial real estate services segment for B2B customers. We assist our residential and commercial customers at every stage of their property journey with competitive and comprehensive service offerings. We provide end-to-end assistance, from managing individual apartment and building areas jointly owned by apartment owners through our Lease Management and Letting and Joint Property Management business lines, respectively, to providing brokerage, digital and other services such as insurance brokerage, technical diagnostic and energy brokerage through our other business lines. Our RRES business is the leader in France, operating under the Foncia brand through a network of approximately 134 and 131 branches dedicated to our RRES and Brokerage businesses, respectively, and 242 branches dedicated to both our RRES and Brokerage businesses, representing 83.4% of our revenue in France for the nine months ended September 30, 2022. For the nine months ended September 30, 2022, our French RRES business, Brokerage business, Digital services, B2B services and international business generated 57.7%, 13.3%, 9.5%, 4.7% and 14.8% of our total revenue, respectively.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Key Factors Affecting Results of Operations
Subsubsection Text: Our results of operations, including the demand for rental properties and our Brokerage businesses, the ability of tenants to pay rent and the level of our costs and expenses, are impacted by economic trends and market conditions such as: - changes in interest and inflation rates, unemployment rates and the level of wages; - economic growth or decline; - demographics (population size, growth and composition of a residential property); - consumer confidence in the economy or the residential property market; ----- - local or regional economic conditions in the markets we serve; - local and regional property inventory levels, the cost of land and land use restrictions; - credit market strength and the cost and availability of mortgage financing; - mortgage underwriting standards or down payment requirements; - levels of foreclosure activity in the French, UK, German, Swiss and Benelux markets, home ownership rates and consumer preferences; - political uncertainty or other geopolitical developments, pandemics or natural disasters; - global pandemics or natural disasters disrupting day-to-day operations and activities; and - man-made disasters that disrupt local or regional markets that we serve. These factors combined with the cyclical nature of the residential property market impact supply and demand, which in turn impact, among other things, residential property prices, Brokerage business commissions and the volume of Brokerage transactions. We believe the diversified nature of our services between recurring and transaction-based activities, our geographic coverage including nationwide presence in France and certain other geographies and the scale of our business have provided some insulation from economic cycles and resiliency to negative market conditions. Nevertheless, recent developments such as central banks’ policies resulting in the tightening of credit conditions, constitute substantial headwinds to the real estate markets in which we operate, which, in turn, may result in adverse impact on our business, financial position, results of operations and cash flows. We classify our revenues as either “stock” (recurring) or “flow” (transaction-tied). Within each business line, there may be stock and flow components based on the various types of revenue streams. Our stock businesses consist of recurring revenues, which by their nature provide better long-term visibility and are less sensitive to the volume of housing transactions and economic cycles. Stock revenue generation is primarily composed of, in both residential and B2B businesses, our Joint Property Management fixed fee, Lease Management fee, including fees on collected rents and insurance broker fees and fees unique to our business such as our rent payment guarantee (“Garantie de loyers impayés” or “rent payment guarantee”) which we offered on approximately 65% of our residential dwellings in France for the nine months ended September 30, 2022. For more information on our rent payment fees, see “—Rent payment and occupancy guarantees.” Our Joint Property Management and Lease Management and Letting businesses are examples of largely stock businesses producing a high share of recurring revenues. Notwithstanding the stability, stock businesses retain some sensitivity to changing economic or market conditions. For example, higher unemployment rates or potential decreases in wages or salaries may affect the average income of tenants or reduce their ability to pay rent and, if tenants do not make rental payments, we are unable to collect our fees which are taken by automatic deduction from rental payments. In addition, if tenants are unable to pay their rent, this could impact the property owner’s (i.e., our customers) ability to pay certain other fees and this non-payment could obligate us to make payments to the property owner under our rent payment guarantees. Where we have offered our rent payment guarantee, we bear the cost if a tenant fails to make a timely rent payment and these advances are not always recoverable. Our business model, however, aims to balance both stock and flow businesses to mitigate the impact of changing market conditions with a stable mix revenue derived from stock and flow businesses. In the nine months ended September 30, 2022, approximately 60% of our revenue derived from stock businesses. Flow activities are those for which we charge transactional fees that are not automatically recurring, and are thus more dependent on the external factors listed above. Our Brokerage business is an example of a largely flow business where we only receive a fee upon the closure of a transaction and, therefore, it faces greater exposure to economic fluctuations than our stock businesses. Brokerage fees are limited to our real estate sales transactions. Other examples of flow activities include revenue generation ----- composed of, for example, letting fees, _Constatimmo (our technical due diligence and inventories services unit) activities related to brokerage and letting, some Joint Property Management variable fees, such as reminder fees and maintenance and repair commissions on third-party invoices. We generated 85.2% of our revenue for the nine months ended September 30, 2022 in France. Although we operate nationwide in France and therefore benefit from diversification across a range of real estate services markets, we are particularly sensitive to the economic conditions and developments in France as well as potential regulatory changes, economic shocks, or social upheaval, which could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition or results of operations. See “—Compliance _with laws and regulations.”_

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Key Factors Affecting Results of Operations
Subsubsection Text: We have historically expanded our operations through prudent, mostly small bolt-on acquisitions of contracts or businesses with properties under management. The real estate services market, particularly in France, is highly fragmented, providing opportunities to add scale, market presence and revenues by acquiring businesses, centralizing costs and operating as part of our diversified portfolio. These acquisitions have been a driver of the growth in our geographic scale, breadth of offerings, revenue and profit margins. In the nine months ended September 30, 2022, we entered the UK market with the acquisition of FirstPort and we also completed 54 acquisitions in our primary French market and in our other geographies, representing 29,069 new Lease Management dwellings (bringing our total to 376,262) and 553,981 new Joint Property Management dwellings (bringing our total to 1,765,964) and €261.1 million of acquired revenues. Following the acquisition of FirstPort in August 2022, as of September 30, 2022, we managed 321,000 units in the UK under our Joint Property Management business and approximately 3,000 lease management units in lettings in the UK In addition, as part of our overall growth strategy, we proactively manage the composition of our portfolio. We take measures to increase efficiencies and profit and cash flows which include focusing on our RRES business offerings and occasionally disposing of certain assets that are less profitable. For more information on our business lines, see “Business—Overview.” Our results of operations are affected by the number of locations where we provide services and the geographies and market conditions in which those sites are located. As a result, our results for future periods may not be directly comparable to past periods because of the large volume of acquisition activity that we have undertaken. The following table reflects the number of properties we managed in our RRES lines for the years ended December 31, 2021 and 2020 and for the nine months ended September 30, 2022:

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Key Factors Affecting Results of Operations
Subsubsection Text: Our performance and results of operations have been, and will continue to be, affected by a number of factors, including external factors. Certain of these key factors that have had, or may have, an effect on our results are set forth below. For further discussion of the factors affecting our results of operations, see “Risk Factors.”

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: We offer rent payment guarantees (“Garantie de loyers impayés” or “rent payment guarantee”) on individual dwellings to certain residential landlords in France for whom we provide property management services. We bear the cost of any unpaid rent and advance such rent to landlords. These advances are not always recoverable from the lessee and therefore represent a risk of non-recovery. However, due to our diligent selection and recovery processes as described below, we believe these rental guarantees offer an attractive business model and by underwriting these guarantees on our balance sheet, we believe we offer a differentiating and competitive service to customers that smaller players would not be able to deliver. Rent payment guarantees are incidental to the property management contracts and, while a tenant remains in the property, we account for the related payments as follows: - the rent guarantee related fees are recorded continuously in income over the period of the mandate, since they are deducted from rents in the same way as basic property management fees; and - when a tenant fails to make their rent payment and after they have vacated the property, we record a provision on our balance sheet that is calculated in accordance with IAS 37 to account for the loss. The amount of the provision we set aside increases in line with the age of the unpaid receivable. Provisions for rent payment guarantees are calculated by reference to late payments relating to current and former lessees, regardless of whether or not lessee statement of accounts (“Arrêtés des Comptes _Locataires” or “ACL”) have been drawn up, taking into account the probability of collection (assessed_ on a statistical basis and regularly updated). From a cash flow perspective, we pay rent to the landlord when rent is due, regardless of whether rent is received from the tenant, and will take remedial measures ----- to try to recover the payment from the tenant. Once a tenant leaves the property, we record for the direct loss. We also offer an occupancy guarantee (“Garantie d’occupation” or “occupancy guarantee”) to a small number of lessors to protect against vacant properties for up to six months if we are unable to find a tenant on selected apartments in new buildings. We typically only offer this occupancy guarantee in limited circumstances for highly desirable properties where we believe there is a low risk of loss. The provision for occupancy guarantees is calculated on a statistical basis by reference to the probable residual vacant period for properties currently vacant and subject to occupancy guarantees. The provision is estimated based on the firm’s average monthly rent. The maximum term of claims is 180 days. In September 2022, on average, 66% of our residential dwellings in France were covered by the rent payment guarantee and 13% of residential dwellings were covered by the occupancy guarantee. We believe we have a strong ability to assess credit risk when offering these guarantees and we undertake a detailed process to select eligible tenants and dwellings. We refer to the new, unpaid rents as a result of defaults under a guarantee each month as our new monthly aggregate of unpaid rent and the total sum of unpaid rents per month as our cumulative aggregate of unpaid rent. In September 2022, €115.9 million of rent revenues were covered by the rent payment guarantee, for which we experienced €3.6 million new unpaid rent (compared to a 2021 monthly average of new unpaid rent of €3.1 million for €108.7 million covered rent revenues) and the cumulative aggregate of unpaid rent was €29.4 million, including outstanding rent payments from previous years. The chart below sets out unpaid rents (in EUR millions) for tenants who remained in their flat versus tenants who moved out of their flat from June 2021 to September 2022, under our rent payment guarantee: We take proactive measures to insulate our business from losses under both the rent payment guarantee and occupancy guarantee including through the stringent credit assessment that we undertake before providing these guarantees and our unpaid rental collection processes. Following an eviction and the transfer of the surrogative discharge from the landlord to us, we have a strong team that seeks to recover the unpaid rent from the defaulting tenant, including by legal means. We have historically recovered approximately 47% of the unpaid rent amount over the last three years, which is added to our statement of profit and loss as revenue. Therefore, given the regulatory regime that restricts when we can evict a tenant and the time it takes to collect unpaid rent, the risk associated with the guarantees has historically been related to the timing of cash flows, rather than lost revenue. However, any unrecoverable payments under these guarantees could result in a significant loss or have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition or results of operations. See “Risk Factors—Risks Relating to Our Business and _Industry—Low demand for housing generally or lease terminations and/or tenant defaults could adversely affect our fees and the income produced by the properties we manage, which may have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition or results of operations.”_

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: COVID-19 pandemic impact on our business
Subsubsection Text: Governmental countermeasures related to the COVID-19 pandemic eased in early 2021, which led to the gradual normalization of economic activities in our primary geographic markets, recovering to preCOVID-19 levels. Nevertheless, we experienced impacts in the year ended December 31, 2021 on revenue, margins and operating cash flow as a result of the COVID-19 pandemic, particularly related to the Brokerage business and, to a lesser extent, to the Joint Property Management and Lease ----- Management and Lettings businesses, and our other businesses as described below. There was no meaningful impact from the COVID-19 pandemic in the nine months ended September 30, 2022. The general lockdown measures imposed by the governments in the jurisdictions in which we operate continued to disrupt the property market in the spring of 2021. In order to protect our workforce and maintain the continuity of our operations, we implemented preventative measures including allowing employees to work from home, permitting short-term working arrangements and providing exceptional travel certificates to certain employees to carry out minimum duties. These costs were all accounted as non-recurring operating income (expenses) due to their exceptional nature. Partially due to the success of the measures we have implemented, we believe we have been able to manage our operations and employee absenteeism, with minimal disruption. In 2022 we saw a gradual normalization of economic activities in our primary geographic markets, recovering to pre-COVID-19 levels. For purposes of determining our Adjusted EBITDA for the years ended December 31, 2020 and 2021, we have included €20.8 million and €7.4 million, respectively, that represent the estimated impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on our stock (recurring) business lines as those are generally more stable and predictable. Similarly, for the purposes of determining our Pro Forma Revenues for the years ended December 31, 2020 and 2021, we have included €32.4 million and €10.1 million, respectively, that represent the estimated impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on our stock (recurring) business lines. See “Summary Historical Financial Information and Other Data—Summary Financial and Other _Information—Summary Other Financial and Operating Data—Other financial data.” For purposes of_ determining our Adjusted EBITDA for the years ended December 31, 2020 and 2021, we have excluded the €10.3 million and €1.4 million, respectively, estimated impact on our Brokerage and Letting business lines, which are primarily non-recurring flow businesses. Similarly, for the purposes of determining our Pro Forma Revenues for the years ended December 31, 2020 and 2021, we have excluded the €18.7 million and €3.1 million, respectively, estimated impact on our Brokerage and Letting business lines. See also “Risk Factors—Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry—We _present information relating to Adjusted EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA Margin, Pro Forma M&A Adjusted EBITDA, Pro Forma Revenues, Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA Margin and other non-IFRS measures in this Offering Memorandum; certain of the data used in calculating this information was unaudited or involved certain estimates and judgments, and accordingly you should not unduly rely on them.” and “Risk Factors—Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry—The COVID-19 pandemic, including the resulting global economic uncertainty and the related lockdown measures, in particular its effects in France, Switzerland, Benelux, Germany and the UK where we have material operations, or other epidemics or pandemics, have had in the past, and could have in the future, a significant adverse impact on our business.”_ The above information and adjustments are based upon available information and assumptions that we believe to be reasonable. This information has not been audited, reviewed or verified by our statutory auditors in accordance with any generally accepted accounting standards and the resulting financial information, including our Adjusted EBITDA, are based on a number of assumptions that are subject to inherent uncertainties and subject to change. In particular, the adjustments take into account our estimated lost revenue as a result of the COVID-19 pandemic based on our internal budgets and historic performance. This information is inherently subject to risks and uncertainties. It may not give an accurate or complete picture of the financial condition or results of operations in the absence of the COVID-19 pandemic for the periods presented, may not be comparable to our consolidated financial statements or the other financial information included in this Offering Memorandum and should not be relied upon when making an investment decision. See “Risk Factors—Risks Relating to Our Business _and Industry—We present information relating to Adjusted EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA Margin, Pro Forma M&A Adjusted EBITDA, Pro Forma Revenues, Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA Margin and other non-IFRS measures in this Offering Memorandum; certain of the data used in calculating this information was unaudited or involved certain estimates and judgments, and accordingly you should not unduly rely on them.”_ -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: As a provider of residential and commercial real estate services, we are subject to a wide range of laws and regulations in each of the countries in which we operate, as well as the regulations of the European Union. We are subject to laws and regulations including those related to rental access and urban planning, rents we can charge, data protection, tax reduction schemes for rental property investors and reforms to housing, planning and digital technology. For example, the French government has introduced measures to protect individuals buying or renting an apartment within a professionally managed co-ownership building. The Access to Housing and Urban Renovation Law (“ALUR”), which was introduced in March 2014, imposed restrictions on the fees agents can charge for selling or letting property and required two dedicated bank accounts for each jointly owned property, thereby resulting in loss of interest income on customer accounts and a large administrative burden. The ALUR law also required a significant amount of extra documentation before the pre-contract (compromis de vente) can be signed, which increased the time between the initial offer and closing and thereby delaying our revenue recognition. In addition, it required publication of commissions when payable by the buyer and any resulting competition from low cost agents. Notwithstanding these requirements, we have experienced certain positive impacts from the imposition of the ALUR law. For example, it required landlords to register their buildings, which became a new fee-based service we began providing. Changes in, and compliance with, such laws and regulations may entail significant costs for us and can have an impact on our results of operations. For a description of certain material regulations applicable to our business, see “Regulation.” Failure to comply with applicable laws, regulations or rules, whether identified as a result of an investigation or otherwise, could lead to adverse publicity, harm our reputation or divert management time and other resources. In addition, non-compliance could result in disciplinary action, imposition of fines, the revocation of a license or authorization or the need to take remedial action. In particular, the loss of a license or authorization could mean that we are no longer able to carry out the business or activity for which we were previously authorized or licensed and any remedial action that may need to be undertaken could result in a significant cost. Finally, such laws, rules and regulations may subject us to more onerous conduct of business and administrative requirements, limit the types of fees or services we can charge and provide or otherwise alter the current regulatory or tax environment, each of which can have a significant impact on the manner in which we conduct our businesses. See “Risk Factors— _Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry—Our businesses, financial condition, results of operations and prospects could be adversely affected by new laws or regulations or by changes in existing laws or regulations or the application thereof. If we fail to comply with laws and regulations applicable to us, or make incorrect determinations in complex tax regimes, we may incur significant financial penalties.”_

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Our ability to actively manage our cost base by cost saving initiatives and enhancing operational efficiencies has been a significant factor affecting our results of operations and financial condition in the period under review. Our principal costs include staff costs and marketing and IT costs. For the nine months ended September 30, 2022, staff costs accounted for 51.4% of revenue. Our business (excluding brokerage activities) has a largely fixed cost base. Our fixed costs, which do not fluctuate with business volumes, consist primarily of salaries and wages (excluding variable commissions, employee profit shares and bonus arrangements), rental costs, most of our information technology (“IT”) costs, as well as other general costs. The management of our cost base is an important factor impacting our results of operations and cash flow. We are able to initiate cost cutting measures when required, such as using temporary employees and limiting travel, entertainment and office expenses and reducing variable compensation. Our Brokerage business, which is more exposed to real estate services market cycles in which our employees are paid based on commission, operates primarily with variable costs, with approximately 24.9% of fixed costs for the nine months ended September 30, 2022. Of a total of €84.3 million of costs for the nine months ended September 30, 2022, our Brokerage business incurred €54.4 million of ----- commissions on sales and €1.2 million of variable operational expenses. Since variable costs tend to fluctuate with business volumes, we will need to react quickly in the future by decreasing such costs if we forecast a potential downturn in business volumes or increase in such costs as the market recovers. In addition, our management team sponsors a number of initiatives to improve efficiency and reduce fixed costs. For example, we launched the broader roll-out of Millenium, our new enterprise resource planning (“ERP”) system, and we plan to accelerate the roll-out across our French network to be completed by the first quarter of 2023. Millenium is already live in all brokerage agencies since January 2022. We have invested significant resources in Millenium including a team currently consisting of 68 developers in order to build this innovative and advanced real estate platform. Our financial condition and results of operations are impacted by our ability to successfully implement Millenium and other initiatives to improve our operational performance. We believe that the improved standardization and digitization Millenium offers, will allow us to reduce administrative inefficiencies and achieve greater productivity. In parallel to the deployment of Millenium, we have designed a new organizational model called Agency of the Future which was implemented following the roll-out of Millenium in France in 2022. Our vision for Agency of the Future sets out four key goals (i) industrialize tasks with low added value; (ii) distinguish ourselves thanks to our expertise in joint property management and rental management; (iii) have close proximity to our clients; (iv) reinforce our attractiveness for staff. As a result of this new organization model, we expect to generate significant cost and efficiency gains mainly related to (i) staff costs synergies from the optimization of the ratios of middle and back-office functions to front-office employees and an increase in productivity and significant reduction of time spent on manual and repetitive processes and (ii) gains resulting from the digitization and automation of certain tasks previously done manually (such as reminder fees or the collection of postal charges). We believe Millenium and Agency of the Future will enable us to achieve greater organization among our businesses allowing our employees to focus on customer satisfaction with the potential to lead to improved customer retention. In the coming years, we plan to fully digitize all business of our businesses, internal processes and our customer relationship management with Millenium. For the year ended December 31, 2021, capital expenditures in connection with Millenium and Agency of the Future were €18.7 million, consisting of €15.4 million for the development and €3.4 million for the deployment of Millenium. We anticipate capital expenditures of €39.3 million in the nine months ended September 30, 2022, consisting of €12.7 million for the development and €3.1 million for the deployment of Millenium. In the next 18 to 24 months, we estimate approximately €5.6 million of revenue gains as a result of efficiencies due to Millenium and Agency of the Future. We also believe that we will experience additional gains in the following years as a result of these projects. For more information, see “Business—Digital Transformation and IT Systems.”

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: RRES Lines Joint Property Management - Dwellings under management (France) .......... 1,712,915 1,463,402 1,765,964 Lease Management - Dwellings under management (France) ....................... 369,044 330,005 376,262 Lettings - Number of lettings (France) .......................................................... 70,510 62,346 52,915 We continually evaluate opportunities for acquisitions to improve market positions within our existing markets or potentially to enter into new markets. We have a strong M&A team, with a disciplined approach that is dedicated to identifying, diligencing, completing and integrating opportunistic acquisitions in our five geographical regions, which we plan to expand into the UK. We are likely to continue to undertake expansion projects in the future to support geographic growth and profitability and improve the breadth and quality of our service offerings. The number of acquisitions we undertake depends on the quality and pricing of potential targets available for purchase at a given time. Additionally, a key point of focus during our due diligence on a potential target, and the primary reason we decline to pursue a target after entering into a letter of intent, is the quality of their customer accounting. By law, we are required to have separate accounts for our Joint Property Management ----- customers and if a target has poor customer accounting policies, it could lead to difficulties collecting customer balances, complying with applicable law or integrating such target’s systems into our own. The price paid for a particular acquisition depends in part on the target entity’s revenues and cost base, along with competition to acquire the business. Our results of operations are therefore impacted by the quality of our due diligence, as well as by our success in integrating any acquired businesses into ours and extracting synergies, gains and cost savings from such acquisitions. Following an acquisition, we integrate the companies into our existing group structure and consolidate all administrative functions, such as payroll, human resources, IT, procurement, sales and marketing, finance and treasury and other support functions, with our central headquarters. Acquisitions we complete may also lead to improved margins and customer retention through, among other measures, the offering of ancillary services to an expanding customer base in a wider geographic network and the leveraging of our scale to procure additional premium partnerships and favorable pricing terms in our utility contracts for our customers. These initiatives have contributed to the successful integration of the acquisitions that we have made and the realization of synergies from such acquisitions. As a result of integrating the acquired business into our existing business, we may also experience an increase in one-off costs such as IT and other integration costs, accounting costs, severance costs, real estate lease agreements termination penalties, potential retention bonuses for key employees, cost related to the rebranding or other expenditures. Therefore our results for the period during which an acquisition takes place may be affected by the inclusion of the results of the acquired business in our consolidated results from the date of their combination or acquisition. We have a track record of implementing a majority of synergies immediately following the acquisition and are able to quickly realize the impact of the synergies, gains and costs savings from the acquisition. However, it may take up to 18 months to realize our expected costs and efficiency gains for an acquired business. See “Summary Historical Financial _Information and Other Data—Summary Financial and Other Information—Summary Other Financial and Operating Data.”_

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Key Factors Affecting the Comparability of Our Results of Operations
Subsubsection Title: Certain changes in accounting standards and accounting policies
Subsubsection Text: _Changes in Presentation and Classifications_ In the Unaudited Consolidated Interim Financial Statements, we restated certain financial data as of and for the nine months ended September 30, 2021. In particular, since 2022 we have changed the allocation of certain business units within our different divisions, with a view to provide a clearer business segmentation. This is a change from the way that the financial data was presented prior to 2022, therefore in order to ensure comparability and accommodate like-for-like comparison between the financial data presented as of and for the nine months ended September 30, 2022 and 2021, we restated certain line items in the table entitled “Revenue” which summarizes our revenue performance per division, as of and for the nine months ended September 30, 2021. For ease of comparative review, we present financial data reflecting the restatements when comparing information as of and for the nine months ended September 30, 2021 with information as of and for the nine months ended September 30, 2022. ----- We have not restated the Audited Consolidated Financial Statements to give effect to the change discussed above. As a result, the revenue breakdown by division in our Audited Consolidated Financial Statements is not directly comparable with the revenue breakdown by division in our Unaudited Consolidated Interim Financial Statements. See “Summary Historical Financial Information and Other _Data—Summary Other Financial Information and Operating Data—Revenue Breakdown by Division.” 2020 Restatement_ In the consolidated financial statements of the Senior Secured Notes Issuer for the year ended December 31, 2020, the consolidated statement of financial position as at December 31, 2020 and the consolidated statement of profit and loss and other comprehensive income, the consolidated statement of cash flows and the consolidated statement of changes in equity for the year ended December 31, 2020 were restated to give effect to application of the definitive decision of the IFRS IC on the attribution of employee benefit to periods of service. In May 2021, the IASB endorsed the conclusions of the IFRS IC dated December 2020 regarding the basis for calculating the period of service to which an entity attributes benefit for a particular defined benefit plan. According to these conclusions, entities should consider periods of benefit entitlement and caps on those periods when recognizing benefit obligations. Whereas the approach most commonly used in France was to recognize benefit obligations on a straight-line basis from the date the employee in question joined the entity to the date of their retirement, the IFRS IC considers that benefit obligations should only be recognized on a straight-line basis over the number of years of employee service immediately before the retirement age, and that said years of service should be capped. The Group took this new approach into account when measuring its employee benefit obligations as at December 31, 2021. In accordance with IAS 8 and in the absence of any transitional provisions to the contrary, any changes resulting from a final agenda decision issued by the IFRS IC are retrospectively applicable. The impact of this change in accounting policy was recognized in the statement of financial position retrospectively as of January 1, 2020, resulting in a €3.5 million decrease in the provision for retirement benefits and a corresponding €2.2 million increase in consolidated equity (net of tax). See note 3.2 to the Audited Consolidated Financial Statements. We refer to the restatements described above as the “2020 Restatement.” For ease of comparative review, we present financial data reflecting the 2020 Restatement when comparing information as of and for the year ended December 31, 2020 with information as of and for the year ended December 31, 2021. _2021 Restatement_ In the Unaudited Consolidated Interim Financial Statements, the consolidated statement of financial position as of December 31, 2021, and the consolidated statement of profit and loss and other comprehensive income, the consolidated statement of cash flows and the consolidated statement of changes in equity for the nine months ended September 30, 2021 were restated to give effect to application of the definitive decision of the IFRS IC on accounting of costs related to SaaS arrangements. In April 2021, the IASB endorsed the conclusions of the IFRS IC dated March 2021 regarding the accounting for configuration or customization costs of a supplier’s application software in a SaaS arrangement. The decision of the IFRS IC confirmed that in most cases, in accordance with IAS 38, such costs shall be recognized as an expense rather than intangible assets since, on the one hand, the customer does not control the software and, on the other hand, the configuration or customization does not generate a resource controlled by the customer that is distinct from the software. These costs shall ----- be accounted for as expenses when (i) such costs are incurred in connection with an in-house software development or a development by a third party provider (not affiliated to the supplier of the SaaS solution) or (ii) such costs are spread for the duration of the SaaS arrangement and the software is developed by the supplier or a sub-contractor. Our review confirmed that costs of configuration and customization of certain SaaS solutions that were historically classified as intangible assets (mainly Workday that is used as an ERP for finance and HR since 2019) did not conform to the criteria outlined by IFRS IC’s position and consequently were required to be classified as expenses. In accordance with IAS 8 and in the absence of any transitional provisions to the contrary, any changes resulting from a final agenda decision issued by the IFRS IC are retrospectively applicable. The impact of this change in accounting policy was recognized in the statement of financial position retrospectively as of January 1, 2021, resulting in a €10.0 million decrease of intangible assets and a corresponding €7.4 million decrease in consolidated equity (net of tax). See note 3.2 to the Unaudited Consolidated Interim Financial Statements. We refer to the restatements described above as the “2021 Restatement.” For ease of comparative review, we present financial data reflecting the 2020 Restatement when comparing information as of and for the year ended December 31, 2020 with information as of and for the year ended December 31, 2021 and when comparing information as of and for the nine months ended September 30, 2021 with information as of and for the nine months ended September 30, 2022.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Key Factors Affecting the Comparability of Our Results of Operations
Subsubsection Text: The timing of acquisitions and disposals may impact the comparability of our results on a year-overyear basis. Our results include incremental revenues and expenses following the completion date of an acquisition. In addition, there is generally an initial adverse impact on net income from an acquisition as a result of preacquisition due diligence expenditures, transaction/deal costs and post-acquisition integration costs, such as fees from third-party advisors engaged to assist with onboarding and process alignment, retention and severance expense, early lease termination costs, and other integration expenses. We have historically used strategic and bolt-on acquisitions to increase our scale within existing capabilities and to expand our presence in new or existing geographic regions globally. We believe that strategic acquisitions will increase revenue, provide cost synergies and generate incremental income in the long term. _Recent Developments_ In 2022, we entered the UK market through the acquisition of FirstPort, one of the UK’s largest property management services groups and the UK’s largest joint property manager with approximately 315,000 units under management as of March 2022. FirstPort operates primarily in joint property management as well as in the rental management and real estate brokerage markets in England, Scotland and Wales with a strong geographical national coverage, generating revenue of €120 million in 2021 with the support of over 3,800 employees. The purchase price for the acquisition was financed by drawings under Additional Facility B1 under the Senior Credit Facilities and an equity contribution of €114.5 million, signaling continued support from the Sponsors. The acquisition was completed in August 2022 and FirstPort has been fully consolidated in our financial results as of and for the nine months ended September 30, 2022 from the date of acquisition.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: We use certain key performance indicators, such as the number of dwellings under management, average revenue per dwelling, average tenant invoice per dwelling, number of lettings, letting fees per ----- letting and number of sales, which in our view provide alternative measures with which to monitor our economic, financial and operating performance. For additional details on our key performance indicators, see “Summary Historical Financial Information and Other Data—Summary Financial and _Other Information—Summary Other Financial and Operating Data.” These measures are not indicative_ of historical operating results, nor are they meant to be predictive of future results. These measures are used to monitor our underlying performance and operations. Not all companies calculate these measures in an identical manner and therefore our presentation may not be consistent with similar measures used by other companies. See “Presentation of Financial _Information and Other Data.”_

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Revenue results from sales of services within the scope of the ordinary operations of consolidated subsidiaries, less revenue from intragroup transactions. Revenue is measured at the fair value of the consideration received or receivable, net of discounts and rebates, VAT and other taxes and duties. In accordance with IFRS 15, we recognize revenue when the amount thereof can be reliably measured, it is probable that future economic benefits will flow to us, and specific criteria are met by each of our businesses, as further described below. _Lease Management and Letting business_ In the lease management line of our Lease Management and Letting business, we act as agent for owners- lessors and fulfil a certain number of contractually defined obligations in this regard. These represent separate service obligations. Accordingly, revenue for each of these obligations is recognized separately. Revenue from services provided over time, such as routine management services and insurance is recognized on a percentage- of-completion basis by reference to the frequency with which expenses are rebilled to the owners. Revenue from one-off services is recognized when those services are provided. In our lettings business, revenue is recognized at the time the inventory of the premises is conducted. We collect fees from owners and from lessees. _Joint Property Management business_ From a contractual and legal perspective, our Joint Property Management business is mostly conducted through mandates, and fees are calculated on a flat-rate basis. In France, this flat rate includes all basic management services provided by the jointly owned property association, and excludes incidental services. All such services are treated as an overall performance obligation satisfied over time. In fact, these different services are associated with a single performance obligation, i.e., management of the jointly owned property association. Annual revenue from basic property management fees is therefore recognized on a percentage-of-completion basis (over time) based on actual amounts billed (costs are in line with the billed amounts). Incidental services may be added to the basic management services and are invoiced based on an agreed rate for each such service, for example, additional meetings and visits, rules and regulations of the jointly owned property, physical and administrative management of claims, technical work and surveys, litigation and disputes. Transfer Fees are also invoiced directly to a landlord selling its property. Since each additional service represents a separate performance obligation, revenue is recognized when the service is performed. ----- _Esset Valorisation_ Esset Valorisation provides investment strategy consulting and arbitrage (appraisals, lending, block/unit property sales) for institutional customers or wealthy families. Its revenue is recognized at the date the notarized final sale agreement is signed and is based on a percentage of the sale price. _Client accounts_ Interest income generated on client funds, limited to rental cash deposits, is booked in revenue. _Constatimmo_ Constatimmo carries out mandatory technical surveys on premises, as well as inventories of premises for lessees. Its revenue is recognized and measured when the related services are performed. _Optissimmo_ Optissimmo is a rental investment expert. _Tech-Way_ Tech-Way is dedicated to the technical maintenance of housing to help our clients to live and work in secure and healthy environments. Tech-Way provides actionable advice and sustainable solutions for pest control, fire protection, routine maintenance and repair work. _Prowen_ Prowen is an energy purchase central providing services to Joint Property Management buildings. _Real Estate Brokerage business_ Revenue in the transactions business is recognized upon signature of the notarized final sale agreement (acte authentique), which is the date on which control is presumed to have been transferred. _Efficity_ Efficity is an online real estate and brokerage business. _Lodgis_ Lodgis is a real estate agency specialized in renting and selling furnished apartments. _Assurimo_ Assurimo provides property insurance brokerage services. Revenue under comprehensive property insurance and comprehensive homeowners’ insurance policies is recognized over the term of the cover, since services in this brokerage business are provided on a straight-line basis. _Seiitra_ Seiitra provides specialist IT property services and developed the Powimo software, which it markets through its software as a service (“SaaS”) solutions model. These property management tools offer the full suite of functionalities needed to keep accounting records for client accounts and to manage suspense accounts, jointly owned properties and rentals, as well as the budget of jointly owned property associations. Maintenance fees are recognized on a straight-line, percentage-of-completion basis, since the corresponding services are provided over time. -----

We also included certain taxes on compensation in taxes other than on income (including transport tax, training levy, apprenticeship tax, tax on wages, payroll taxes and contributions to AGEFIPH (the French association for the employment of disabled people)).

Subsubsection Text: Other operating expenses include directors’ fees, losses on non-recoverable receivables, royalties and other expenses.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Net additions to depreciation, amortization, impairment and provisions
Subsubsection Text: Net additions to depreciation, amortization, impairment and provisions include amortization of intangible assets; depreciation of property, plant and equipment; impairment of receivables; reversals of receivables impairment; impairment of inventories net of reversals; and various additions and reversals to provisions we have taken.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Recurring operating profit (loss) includes all income and expenses directly related to our businesses, with the exception of items classified within “Non-recurring operating income (expenses).” Recurring operating profit (loss) is a performance indicator that may serve as a method for estimating recurring performance. It includes all items included in operating profit (loss), restated for any non-recurring items. Costs relating to business combinations or restructuring are excluded from recurring operating profit (loss).

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Non-recurring operating income (expenses) includes income and expense items that, owing to their nature, amount or frequency, cannot be considered as arising in the ordinary course of our operations and are therefore not reported in recurring operating profit (loss). Non-recurring items are limited, unusual and/or irregular items of a material amount and we classify these items into three main categories: (i) M&A non-recurring integrations charges, (ii) restructuring/transformation non-recurring charges and (iii) corporate non-recurring charges, which include costs of implementation of third party SaaS software (treated as capital expenditures until the financial year ended December 31, 2021). ----- These items include impacts of changes in the scope of consolidation, goodwill impairment, and amortization and impairment charged against trademarks. If material, non-recurring items also include the effects of certain unusual transactions such as capital gains and losses on disposals of non-current assets, restructuring fees, fees relating to major claims and disputes, and any other income or expenses likely to affect the comparability of recurring operating profit (loss) from one period to the next. For transactions directly related to external growth and projects to transform or restructure the business (particularly mergers and reorganizations), a detailed procedure is in place to identify, classify and validate any transactions of a non-recurring nature. This procedure gives a precise indication of transactions that meet the criteria to be recorded in this category.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Operating profit (loss) includes all income and expenses directly related to our businesses, irrespective of whether they are of a recurring nature or whether they result from one-off decisions or transactions.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: The cost of gross debt is equal to all financial expenses on borrowings.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: The cost of net debt is equal to all financial expenses on borrowings, less financial income from cash investments.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Other financial income and expenses includes foreign exchange gains (losses), net interest cost on pension and other employee benefit obligations, capital gains (losses) on financial disposals less costs to sell, net impairment of financial assets, gains (losses) on available-for-sale financial assets, net discounting costs and other miscellaneous costs.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Income tax expense for the year includes current and deferred income tax expense, which are recognized in the statement of profit and loss except when they relate to items recognized in other comprehensive income. We calculate our current taxes in accordance with the tax legislation applicable in the countries in which our earnings are taxable. Current tax expense is calculated on the basis of tax laws enacted or substantively enacted at the reporting date in countries where our subsidiaries operate and generate taxable profit. However, management periodically reviews the positions adopted in tax returns for situations in which tax regulations are subject to interpretation. Where applicable, a provision is set aside based on the amounts payable to the tax authorities. Income tax expense includes the amounts reported by French subsidiaries in respect of the CVAE tax assessed on value added, since we consider this tax meets the definition of income tax set out in IAS 12 – Income Taxes. When they have not been set against income tax, income tax credits that are not included in the calculation of taxable profit and that are always refunded by the government are recorded as subsidies and reduce the expenses to which they relate.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Share of profit (loss) of equity-accounted companies
Subsubsection Text: Associates are entities over which we exercise significant influence. Significant influence is the power to participate in the financial and operating policy decisions of the entity without controlling or jointly controlling those policies. A joint venture is a joint arrangement whereby the parties that have joint ----- control of the arrangement have rights to its net assets. Joint control of an arrangement only exists when decisions about the relevant activities require the unanimous consent of the parties sharing control. Profits, losses, assets and liabilities of associates or joint ventures are accounted for by the equity method in our consolidated financial statements. Under the equity method, the investment in an associate or joint venture is initially recognized at acquisition cost and subsequently adjusted for our interest in the profits, losses and other comprehensive income of the associate or joint venture.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Revenue for the RRES business in France increased by €42.9 million, or 8.5%, from €501.8 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2021, to €544.7 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2022. This increase was primarily driven by a €13.3 million increase in the Lease Management and Letting business, driven by both an increase of dwellings under management and an increase in pricing in our lease management business, which was partially offset by lower volumes in letting due to a softer market as well as a €26.3 million increase in the Joint Property Management business, driven mainly by an increase of dwellings under management. Revenue for the Real Estate Brokerage business in France increased by €8.4 million, or 7.1%, from €117.4 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2021, to €125.8 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2022. This increase was primarily due to the acquisition of AGDA and a positive mix and price effect, partially offset by a decrease of volumes due to a challenging market environment. Revenue for the Digital business in France increased by €9.3 million, or 11.6%, from €80.1 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2021, to €89.4 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2022. This increase was primarily due to the strong performance of Efficity, notably due to the recruitment of new agents. Revenue for the B2B business in France increased by €6.2 million, or 16.5%, from €37.8 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2021, to €44.0 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2022. This increase was primarily driven by recent acquisitions and new contracts. Revenue for our International business increased by €35.7 million, or 34.3%, from €103.8 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2021, to €139.5 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2022. This increase was primarily driven by acquisitions in our international markets, partially offset by reduced brokerage activities due to a challenging market environment, including client churn as a side effect of staff turnover that occurred during the COVID-19 pandemic. In particular, Switzerland presented strong growth, driven by acquisitions in the German-speaking part of the country, and the fact that COVID-19 restrictions occurred in the nine months ended September ----- 30, 2021 and did not recur in the nine months ended September 30, 2022. In addition, Benelux grew by 29.3%, partly driven by the acquisition of Codabel and Cushman & Wakefield Asset Services Belgium. Revenue in Germany grew 33.4% mainly due to acquisitions but was partly offset by some client churn due to side effect of staff turnover following the COVID-19 crisis. The UK performance reflects revenue from completion of the FirstPort acquisition which closed in August 2022. _Other operating income_ Other operating income increased by €1.0 million, or 22.0%, from €4.8 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2021, to €5.8 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2022. This increase was primarily due to gains on client accounts and an indirect impact of the increased activity. _Purchases consumed and external charges_ Purchases consumed and external charges increased by €27.8 million, or 17.0%, from €163.7 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2021, to €191.5 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2022. This increase was primarily due to the growth at Efficity, leading to higher commissions paid to agents. _Taxes other than on income_ Taxes other than on income increased by €1.6 million, from €13.4 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2021, to €15.0 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2022. This increase was primarily due to higher income tax paid as a result of our external growth during the period. _Personnel costs_ Personnel costs increased by €49.1 million, or 11.3%, from €436.1 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2021, to €485.2 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2022. This increase was primarily due to a higher average number of FTEs, notably from acquisitions. _Other operating expenses_ Other operating expenses decreased by €0.5 million, or 10.4%, from €4.6 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2021, to €4.1 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2022. Other operating expenses for the nine months ended September 30, 2022 have, as a percentage of revenue, decreased slightly at 0.4% of revenue, as compared to 0.5% of revenue for the nine months ended September 30, 2021. This decrease was primarily due to a decrease in charges in the France Property Management segment, partially offset by an increase in charges in countries other than France. _Net additions to depreciation, amortization and impairment_ Net additions to depreciation, amortization, impairment and provisions increased by €9.8 million, or 12.2%, from €80.4 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2021, to €90.2 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2022. This increase was primarily due to higher amortization of the IFRS 16 right of use, which was mainly driven by our external growth during the period. _Non-recurring operating income (expenses)_ Non-recurring operating expenses increased by €41.5 million, or 49.8%, from a net expense of €83.4 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2021, to a net expenses of €124.9 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2022. This increase was mainly driven by the net effect of the reversal of the prior shareholder agreement and implementation of a new structure to develop Efficity. ----- The following table sets forth a breakdown of non-recurring operating expenses for the periods indicated.

Subsubsection Text: _Cost of net debt_ Cost of net debt decreased by €12.6 million, or 13.4%, from €93.8 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2021, to €81.2 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2022. The decrease in cost of net debt was mainly attributable to non-recurring costs related to the refinancing completed in March 2021. _Other financial income_ Other financial income increased by €1.9 million, from an income of €0.6 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2021, to an income of €2.5 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2022. This increase was primarily due to the sale of shares, a write back on end of career indemnity provision and an increase of foreign exchange gains. _Other financial expenses_ Other financial expenses increased by €5.0 million, from an expense of €2.7 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2021, to an expense of €7.7 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2022. This increase was primarily due to foreign exchange losses incurred in connection with an intracompany loan granted as part of the FirstPort acquisition. _Income tax expense_ Income tax expense decreased by €5.4 million from an expense of €5.4 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2021, to an income of €0.06 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2022. This decrease was primarily due to higher tax loss activation in France during the period. _Share of profit (loss) of equity-accounted companies_ There was no meaningful impact from the share of profit (loss) of equity-accounted companies.

Subsubsection Text: (a) For ease of comparative review, we present in this Offering Memorandum financial data reflecting the change to the allocation of certain business units within our different divisions when comparing information as of and for the year ended December 31, 2020 with information as of and for the year ended December 31, 2021. See “Presentation of Financial Information and Other Data— _Historical financial information—Comparability of the Financial Statements.”_ Revenue for the RRES business in France increased by €82.1 million, or 13.8%, from €593.2 million for the year ended December 31, 2020, to €675.3 million for the year ended December 31, 2021. This increase was primarily driven by the impact of consolidating companies acquired in 2021, as well as the embedded impact of companies consolidated in 2020. The impact of the COVID-19 pandemic continued to weigh on our rental management business (essentially affecting amounts collected under commercial leases and incidental fees) as well as on letting activities and incidental fees earned on jointly owned properties (fees on transfer duties, reminders, renovation work and vacancies). Revenue for the Real Estate Brokerage business in France increased by €31.6 million, or 25.3%, from €125.0 million for the year ended December 31, 2020, to €156.6 million for the year ended December 31, 2021. This increase was primarily due to the positive effect on the number of sales and pricing terms due to the end of COVID-19 related restrictions. Revenue for the Digital business in France increased by €26.2 million, or 32.6%, from €80.4 million for the year ended December 31, 2020, to €106.6 million for the year ended December 31, 2021. This increase was primarily due to the performance of Efficity. Revenue for the B2B business in France increased by €17.9 million, or 48.4%, from €36.9 million for the year ended December 31, 2020, to €54.8 million for the year ended December 31, 2021. This increase was primarily driven by acquisitions. Revenue for our International business increased by €27.5 million, or 21.8%, from €126.0 million for the year ended December 31, 2020, to €153.6 million for the year ended December 31, 2021. This increase was primarily driven by acquisitions in Germany and Belgium, partially offset by the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic in Switzerland. _Other operating income_ Other operating income increased by €2.2 million, or 41.2%, from €5.4 million for the year ended December 31, 2020, to €7.7 million for the year ended December 31, 2021. This increase was primarily due to gains on certain client accounts, insurance brokerage commissions and other miscellaneous income from our international markets. The following table sets forth a breakdown of other operating income for the periods indicated.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Our primary source of liquidity is cash flow from operations. Our cash needs relate primarily to capital and other expenditures for meeting debt service requirements and funding our working capital requirements, which are primarily costs related to our acquisitions. The components of our working capital are trade receivables and deferred income, trade payables and prepaid expenses, tax and employee related working capital. We believe that, based on our current cash flows, these sources of liquidity, together with existing available borrowings under the Revolving Credit Facility, will be sufficient to fund our operations, capital expenditure and debt service for at least the next 12 months. We are highly leveraged and have significant debt service obligations. As of the Issue Date, after giving effect to the Transactions and to drawings under the Additional Facilities and the use of proceeds therefrom, we expect to have €3,208.4 million of indebtedness, comprising primarily of the Senior Secured Notes, the Senior Notes, the Term Loan Facilities and lease liabilities. We will also be able to borrow up to €437.5 million under our Revolving Credit Facility. The availability of the Revolving Credit Facility is dependent upon certain conditions described further under “Description of Other _Indebtedness—Revolving Credit Facility Agreement.” We may also, from time to time, raise bilateral_ facilities for the purpose of financing future acquisitions. The Senior Secured Notes Indenture, the Senior Notes Indenture and the Senior Credit Facilities Agreement contain, restrictive covenants that may limit our ability to finance our future opportunities and capital needs, or pursue business opportunities and activities. In addition, the Revolving Credit Facility requires us to comply with a leverage ratio, under certain circumstances, in order for us to continue to be able to draw funds under the Revolving Credit Facility. We may from time to time seek to retire or repurchase our outstanding debt through cash purchases, in open market purchases, privately negotiated transactions or otherwise. Such repurchases, if any, will depend on market conditions, our liquidity requirements, contractual restrictions and other factors. Our ability to generate cash depends on our future operating performance, which in turn depends to some extent on general economic, financial, industry and other factors, many of which are beyond our control, such as the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic, as well as the other factors discussed in “—Key _Factors Affecting Results of Operations” and “Risk Factors.” We cannot guarantee that our business_ will generate sufficient cash flows from operations or that future debt and equity financing will be available to us in an amount sufficient to enable us to pay our debts when due, including the Additional Notes, or to fund our other liquidity needs. -----

For additional information, see “Presentation of Financial Information and Other Data—Historical financial _information—Comparability of the Financial Statements—2021 Restatement,” “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations—Key Factors Affecting the Comparability of Our Results of Operations—Certain changes in accounting standards and accounting policies—2021 Restatement” and note 3.2 to the Unaudited Consolidated Interim_ Financial Statements. _Cash flow from operating activities_ Our cash flow from operating activities for the nine months ended September 30, 2022 amounted to an inflow of €101.3 million, primarily due to our EBITDA which amounted to €253.3 million, partially offset by non-recurring operating cost in the amount of €80.0 million, and negative working capital in the amount of €52.0 million. Our cash flow from operating activities for the nine months ended September 30, 2021 amounted to an inflow of €147.9 million, primarily due to our EBITDA which amounted to €230.1 million, partially offset by non-recurring operating cost in the amount of €58.4 million. Our cash flow from operating activities for the year ended December 31, 2021 amounted to an inflow of €221.0 million, primarily due to our EBITDA which amounted to €311.8 million, partially offset by non-recurring operating cost in the amount of €113.4 million and a positive impact of the working capital in the amount of €34.7 million. Our cash flow from operating activities for the year ended December 31, 2020 amounted to an inflow of €171.6 million, primarily due to our EBITDA which amounted to €241.3 million, partially offset by non-recurring operating costs in the amount of €55.4 million primarily driven by the increased number of bolt-on acquisitions, negative change in working capital in the amount of €8.1 million and paid CIT / CVAE in the amount of €10.8 million. ----- _Cash flow from (used in) investing activities_ Our cash flow from (used in) in investing activities principally relates to bolt-on acquisitions of companies operating in our RRES businesses and capital expenditure (such as IT projects). Our cash flow from (used in) investing activities for the nine months ended September 30, 2022 amounted to an outflow of €450.1 million, primarily due to acquisitions of RRES companies in the amount of €398.4 million. Our cash flow from (used in) investing activities for the nine months ended September 30, 2021 amounted to an outflow of €253.0 million, primarily due to acquisitions of companies primarily operating in our RRES businesses in the amount €211.3 million. Our cash flow from (used in) investing activities for the year ended December 31, 2021 amounted to an outflow of €351.2 million, primarily due to acquisitions of companies primarily operating in our RRES businesses in the amount of €314 million. Our cash flow from (used in) investing activities for the year ended December 31, 2020 amounted to an outflow of €211.1 million, primarily due to the intangible and tangible fixed assets expenditure in the amount of €57.6 million, acquisitions of companies primarily operating in our RRES businesses in the amount of €156.1 million. _Cash flow from (used in) financing activities_ Our cash flow from (used in) financing activities for the nine months ended September 30, 2022 amounted to an inflow of €331.6 million, primarily due to additional debt in the amount of €546 million incurred under the Senior Credit Facilities, additional debt incurred under the Revolving Credit Facility (a portion of which was repaid) which netted to additional debt of €50.0 million, repayment of bank loans of companies consolidated in the year in the amount of €243.0 million, repayment of leases in the amount of €46.1 million, payment of financial interests in the amount of €78.5 million and the proceeds from capital increase in an amount €132.4 million. Our cash flow from (used in) financing activities for the nine months ended September 30, 2021 amounted to an inflow of €94.5 million, primarily due to drawings under a syndicated loan in the amount of €221.0 million, partially offset by interest paid in the amount of €56.4 million and €31.0 million of borrowing reimbursement. Our cash flow from (used in) financing activities for the year ended December 31, 2021 amounted to an outflow of €121.3 million, primarily due to drawings under a syndicated loan in the amount of €211.5 million, partially offset by interest paid in the amount of €71.0 million. Our cash flow from (used in) financing activities for the year ended December 31, 2020 amounted to an outflow of €6.7 million, primarily due to the payment of financial interest in the amount of €49.1 million, reimbursement of leases in the amount of €43.2 million and €120.0 million drawn under the then existing revolving credit facility.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Under the provisions of the Hoguet law, property management companies must provide financial guarantees for funds held in client accounts. In accordance with this law, we provide financial guarantees to clients equal to the maximum amount of funds held on their account. These guarantees are presented under commitments given. Commitments given for the years ended December 31, 2021 and 2020 were €2.4 billion and €2.3 billion, respectively, for these Professional Financial Guarantees and total commitments for the same periods were €6.2 billion and €6.1 billion, respectively, including property lease commitments, commitments under financing leases and pledges of certain collateral. Financial guarantees received from guarantors such as guarantee funds, insurance companies and banks are shown under commitments received. Total commitments received for the years ended December 31, 2021 and 2020 were €3.6 billion and €3.0 billion, respectively, including commitments under property lease commitments, commitments under financing leases and pledges of certain collateral. -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: In accordance with the laws and practices in each of the countries in which we operate, we participate in, or operate, benefit plans providing for the payment of post-employment benefits (including retirement benefits) to eligible current and former employees, retirees and their beneficiaries. Virtually all of our employees are entitled to pension benefits. In France, this takes the form of payments by us to the beneficiaries when the rights allotted vest, while in Switzerland, plans are managed by pension funds financed in compliance with the applicable government requirements and regulations. These plans may be funded by investments in various instruments such as insurance policies, equity instruments and bonds.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: We conduct our property management business through mandates signed with customers, under which our companies are responsible for holding client funds. By law, all Joint Property Management accounts are segregated and each individual association must open a current account and a saving account for client funds. These funds consist of guarantee deposits received, rent and expenses and capital and renovation funds. As an agent, we undertake to hold client accounts and to recognize them in our statement of financial position using a specific account for each activity, such as property sales, rentals and management.

Subsection Title: Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosures About Market Risk
Subsubsection Text: Our interest rate risk exposure arises mainly on our borrowings. These borrowings are denominated solely in euros and are managed on a centralized basis. They are mainly indexed to three-month EURIBOR. The risk management policy is set by our management team and the board of directors. Cash flow surpluses and working capital requirements for our companies are centralized under a cash pooling agreement and managed by our treasury department. Our treasury department selects investment vehicles for cash surpluses – either for proprietary cash or client cash (excluding separate accounts) – within the framework set by the management policy, which prioritizes liquidity and security. Interest received is indexed to 3-month EURIBOR or is at fixed rates (term accounts). At September 30, 2022, interest rate risks can be broken down by management outlook as follows, taking into account interest rate maturities applied to the asset/liability financing position:

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosures About Market Risk
Subsubsection Text: We are exposed to various market risks, including interest rate and foreign exchange rate risks. Our treasury department is responsible for managing our exposure to market risk that arises in connection with operations and financial activities, including interest rate, foreign exchange rate, credit and liquidity, and credit risk management. The following sections discuss our significant exposures to market risk. The following discussions do not address other risks that we face in the normal course of business, including country risk and legal risk. -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: We are exposed to two types of foreign exchange risk: - A foreign exchange risk on assets resulting from our shareholdings in our Swiss subsidiaries. Although this risk is measured, it is not subject to specific risk management as the investments are intended to be held over the long term. Our foreign exchange risk exposure on assets is not material. - A foreign exchange trading risk arising on commercial and financial transactions carried out by our companies in currencies other than their local currency. This risk arises on the business of UK and Swiss subsidiaries and concerns the British pound sterling and Swiss Franc, respectively. Since the vast majority of respective local transactions are carried out in British pound sterling and Swiss Francs, as applicable, this risk is not material.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
