Subsubsection Text: The preparation of financial statements requires us to make estimates and assumptions that may affect the measurement and presentation of certain assets and liabilities and any disclosures provided in respect of contingent liabilities at the end of the reporting period, as well as the reported amounts of income and expenses for the period. Estimates and underlying assumptions are determined based on information available at the end of the reporting period and are reviewed on a regular basis in light of past experience and other factors deemed reasonable given the circumstances. These estimates serve as the basis for measuring the carrying amount of assets and liabilities that cannot be obtained directly from other sources. Where applicable, ----- a sensitivity analysis may be performed if the estimates are material. Accordingly, actual results may differ from these estimates. The estimates we make in preparing our consolidated financial statements are based on a going concern assumption and relate primarily to the items described below. _Measurements used in testing goodwill, intangible assets and property, plant and equipment for impairment_ The estimates and assumptions made to determine the recoverable amount of goodwill, intangible assets, and property, plant and equipment relate mainly to the market outlook used to estimate future cash flows and determine the discount rates used. As with any estimate, the assumptions used in these calculations are partly based on uncertain factors and may therefore need to be adjusted in subsequent periods. The notes to the Audited Consolidated Financial Statements included elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum set out the assumptions used to calculate future cash flows and determine the discount rates to be applied in measuring the recoverable amounts of these assets. Sensitivity analyses were also performed and are described in the same notes. _Measurement of leases_ IFRS 16 requires entities to use a significant degree of judgement as well as certain key estimates. These involve determining: - whether an option to extend or terminate a lease is reasonably certain to be exercised; - the lease term; - the appropriate discount rate to be used to calculate future lease payments; and - the specific selling price of any lease components and non-lease components contained in the contract. The main assumptions we use to prepare the audited financial statements are described in the notes to the audited financial statements included elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum. _Measurement of provisions_ We use the best estimate of our commitments and obligations to calculate the corresponding provisions. _Measurement of employee benefits_ We operate both defined contribution and defined benefit plans. Obligations under these plans are calculated using the projected unit credit method, which is based on assumptions regarding the discount rate, future increases in salary, employee turnover, life expectancy and the rate of increase in healthcare costs. The notes to the audited financial statements included elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum set out the assumptions used to measure these obligations. We consider that the actuarial assumptions used are appropriate and justified in the current environment. However, the corresponding obligations may change if these assumptions also change. _Measurement of fair value (Level 1)_ We use fair value on a recurring basis in our statement of financial position to measure unlisted derivative instruments and cash and cash equivalents. ----- _Measurement of recognized deferred tax assets and liabilities and tax expense_ Our tax position is based on our best estimate of future taxable earnings. _Basis for determining the value of identifiable assets acquired and liabilities assumed as part of a business combination_ The estimates and assumptions used to determine the recoverable amount of these identifiable assets and liabilities relate in particular to the market outlook used to estimate future cash flows and determine the discount rates used. Any changes in these assumptions could impact the recoverable amount. _Assessment of criteria for identifying discontinued operations_ In accordance with IFRS 5 – Non-current Assets Held for Sale and Discontinued Operations, we are required to exercise judgement in determining whether an asset or group of assets meets the criteria to be classified as held for sale. IFRS 5 criteria are also used to identify any assets to be classified as discontinued operations. These assessments are reviewed at the end of each reporting period in light of changes in the relevant facts and circumstances. In the absence of IFRS guidance for a specific transaction, event or condition, we use our judgement to define and apply accounting policies that will result in relevant, fair and comparable information to ensure that the financial statements: - present a true and fair view of our financial position, financial performance and cash flows; - reflect the economic substance of transactions; and - are neutral, prudent and comprehensive in all material respects. -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: _The following is a discussion and analysis of the results of operations and financial condition of Emeria for the nine months ended September 30, 2022 and 2021 and for the years ended December 31, 2021 and 2020. See “Presentation of Financial Information and Other Data.” You should read this discussion in conjunction with the consolidated financial statements of Emeria and the accompanying notes included elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum as well as the “Selected Historical Financial Information.” A summary of the critical accounting estimates that have been applied to Emeria’s consolidated financial statements is set forth below in “—Critical Accounting Judgments” This discussion also includes forward-looking statements which, although based on assumptions that we consider reasonable, are subject to risks and uncertainties that could cause actual events or conditions to differ materially from those expressed or implied by the forward-looking statements. See “Forward-Looking Statements.” For a discussion of risks and uncertainties facing us as a result of various factors, see “Risk Factors.”_

Subsubsection Title: Lease management and joint property management
Subsubsection Text: Property management companies’ core offering is composed of lease management services and joint property management services. The lease management business includes i) residential property management (gestion locative), i.e. services for an apartment or a house, and ii) commercial property management, i.e. services for retail buildings, notably shops and restaurants. It refers to the assistance on the day-to-day operations of the property typically related to financial management, legal assistance, conflict handling, etc., for an individual residential unit (which may be a joint property or condominium). On the lease management level, property management companies take care of tenancy agreements, rent collection, account and reporting, tax and insurance claims, maintenance or legal compliance. The property management providers are appointed by the owner of the individual unit(s), typically a private landlord. Joint property management refers to the management of joint property (copropriété), i.e. the management of shared property of joint ownership associations, activities include financial management, structural support and legal assistance. In the joint property management segment, the services provided include organization of general assemblies, a pre-determined number of visits per year for inspection, coordination of maintenance efforts and accounting, bill payment, and building fee collection. The property management provider assumes the role of trustee (syndic) after appointment by the general assembly of joint owners. It is important to note that lease management and joint property management activities can overlap with each other and fall under joint property management for the joint property and lease management for the individual unit. ----- Exhibit 1: property management providers’ types of clients

The property management business in France provides a wide range of services from core property management services (lease management and joint property management) to providing ancillary services to property owners.
(lease management) Source: International report provider Owner occupied apartments Rented apartments Vacant/secondary apartments

Subsection Title: Shared parts of a joined property
Subsubsection Text: (joint property management) Property management companies provide residential real estate services to B2C and B2B clients. The business model has different maturity levels in different geographies, for instance, B2B property management services are far more developed in Germany than in France where this segment is still growing significantly, notably following the COVID-19 pandemic. _Main Customers_ Property management companies address a variety of customers that can be divided into three main groups depending on the type of services provided to them. Typical lease management customers are private landlords and family offices. Private landlords are private individuals with real estate portfolios varying in size. They own the majority of residential units and a very small portion of office and retail buildings. Family offices are individuals who own a real estate portfolio, mainly composed of apartments and to a lesser extent, office and retail buildings. Typical joint property management customers are joint ownership associations or their boards, representing owners of a single property containing multiple units, such as apartments buildings. Typical B2B clients are institutional investors that acquire and manage real estate portfolios such as Axa, Allianz, BNP Paribas or Swiss Life. These portfolios can be composed of apartments, office or retail buildings.

In France, as of August 2019, the total market size for property management was estimated to be €12.2 billion, of which €5.3 billion (44%) was under external management. Exhibit 2: Composition of the French property management market (in 2019, in € billion) 5.3 1.9 3.4 10.3 2.2 8.1 12.2 1.9 6.9 Residential Commercial Total market Unserved market Captured by PM market market size (Done in-house) companies Lease Management Joint Property Management Source: International report provider ----- In 2019, the residential market was the largest segment of the French property management market, estimated to be €10.3 billion (84% of the French property management market), of which the lease management had an estimated market size of €8.1 billion and joint property management had an estimated market size of €2.2 billion. The commercial market, estimated to be €1.9 billion (16% of the French property management market), includes the lease management service for offices and retail. The majority of the French property market is not captured by property management companies, with services instead being managed “in-house.” The market that is captured by property management companies has an estimated total market size of €5.3 billion (44% of the French property management market), and is shared between the lease management providers with an estimated market size of €3.4 billion market, (64% of the captured market) and the condominium management providers with an estimated market size of €1.9 billion (36% of the captured market). Based on penetration rates, property management companies benefit from a strong position in the commercial market, having penetrated 90% of both the market for lease management of office and retail spaces. Their penetration is more balanced in the residential market where it varies widely by the type of customer. The penetration rates for institutional investors is 90% and for condominiums 85%, while private landlords and the secondary and vacant homes are yet to be captured as the penetration rates are low at 30% and 10%, respectively. _Lease management’s market penetration_ Exhibit 3: Penetration of the French residential housing market (in 2019, in million units) 35.8 (100%) Housing units not relevant for external property management Total building stock Owner-occupied Social and free Total addressable Non-penetrated Penetrated units dwellings housing stock units Source: International report provider In 2019, the total residential stock building comprised 35.8 million units. Among these units, roughly two thirds of total dwellings are either owner-occupied (17.0 million units), social housing or “free” housing (5.7 million units) and not addressable for external property management. Therefore, the total addressable residential stock buildings for property management companies is 13.1 million units or 37% of the total residential stock buildings. As of August 2019, property management companies have only captured approximately 2.8 million units or 21% of the residential total addressable market. The majority of the penetrated market are owned by private landlords. _Joint property management’s market penetration_ Exhibit 4: Penetration of the French residential condominium market (in 2019, in million units) 35.8 (100%) Housing units not relevant for condominium management Property management 25.9 done in-house 9.9 8.4 (72%) (28%) (24%) 1.5 Total building Single Total addressable Non-penetrated Penetrated stock ownership stock units units Source: International report provider ----- In 2019, among the 35.8 million units of the French residential market, 25.9 million units were single ownership (72% of the residential total building stock), and not considered relevant for joint property management. The remaining 9.9 million units (28% of the residential total building stock) were condominiums and part of a joint ownership structure (copropriétés). These joint ownership structures include a mix of owned, rented, vacant and secondary dwellings (typically apartments). The vast majority (85%) of these joint ownership associations were managed by external property managers, meaning an estimated 8.4 million condominiums were under external property management, with the remaining 1.5 million units were to be captured by property management companies.

In Switzerland, as of August 2019, the total market size for property management was estimated to be €2.1 billion, of which €1.1 billion (52%) is under external management. Exhibit 5: Composition of the Swiss property management market (in 2019, in € billions) 2.1 0.5 1.0 1.6 1.1 Residential Commercial Total market Unserved market Captured by PM market market size (Done in-house) companies Source: International report provider In 2019, the residential market was the largest segment of the Swiss property management market, estimated to be €1.6 billion (77% of the total Swiss property management market). This segment comprised 4.5 million units owned by condominium owners, private landlords, public sector rental, housing companies, institutional investors and cooperative ownership. Property management companies do not yet hold a strong position in all the segments of the residential and commercial markets based on their penetration rates. In the commercial market, as of August 2019, property management companies have penetrated 80% of retail space and 40% of the office space segment. Similarly, property management companies have varying penetration rates among the various segments of the residential market. Exhibit 6: Penetration of the Swiss residential market (in 2019, in million units) 4.6 (100%) Housing units not relevant for external property management 3.4 (74%) Property management done in-house Total building Single- or two Total addressable Non-penetrated units Penetrated units stock family homes units Source: International report provider In 2019, the total Swiss residential stock building comprised 4.6 million units, of which roughly a quarter of total dwellings were single or two family homes (1.2 million units) and therefore, not addressable for the external property management business. Therefore, the total addressable residential stock amounted to 3.4 million units or 74% of the total residential stock building. Property management companies have captured half of the addressable market with 1.8 million units or 52% of the residential total addressable market. Penetration is the highest among institutional investors as well as construction ----- and real estate companies, and the lowest among housing cooperatives and the public sector, where property management is typically carried out in-house department.

In Germany, as of August 2019, the total market size for property management was estimated to be €10.0 billion in 2019, of which €3.7 billion (37%) under external management. Exhibit 7: Composition of the German property management market (in 2019, in € billion) 10.0 2.0 6.4 8.0 3.7 Residential Commercial Total market Unserved market Captured by PM market market size (Done in-house) companies Source: International report provider In 2019, the residential market was the largest segment of the German property management market, estimated to be €8.0 billion (80% of the German property management market). This segment consisted of estimated 42.4 million units owned by owners associations, housing associations, public sector housing, private landlords and professional companies. The commercial market was estimated to be €2.0 billion (20% of the German property management market) and comprised office properties and retail spaces. Similar to France, the majority of this German property market was not captured by property management companies, with services instead being managed “in-house.” Property management accounted for €3.7 billion (37% of the German property management market) of the total addressable market. Companies benefit from a strong position in the commercial market having penetrated 75% of office space and 75% of the retail space. Penetration by property management companies was lower in the residential market, with penetration rates being equal or below to 50% for all sub-segments. Exhibit 8: Penetration of the German residential market (in 2019, in million units) 42.4 (100%) Housing units not relevant for external property management Property management 21.0                      done in-house (50%) Total building Owner-occupied Houses owned stock houses by private landlords Source: International report provider Owned by housing associations Total addressable units Non-penetrated Penetrated units units In 2019, the total German residential stock building comprised 42.4 million units. Of these 42.4 million units, half of total dwellings were not addressable for external property management, which is comprised of owner-occupied houses (13.7 million), houses owned by private landlords (5.4 million) or houses owned by housing associations (2.2 million). Therefore, the residential total addressable stock amounted to 21.0 million units (50% of the total residential stock building). In 2019, property management companies captured a quarter of the addressable market with an estimated 5.6 million units under management (27% of the residential total addressable market). Penetration was the highest among ownership associations and private landlords as the German Condominium Act applies for WEG management. -----

In the United Kingdom, as of August 2019, the total market size for property management was estimated to be £7.6 billion in 2019, of which £4.0 billion (53%) is under external management. Exhibit 9: Composition of the UK property management market (in 2019, in £ billion) 7.6 Residential block management market Source: International report provider Residential managing agent market Commercial market Total market size Unserved market (Done in-house) Captured by PM companies In 2019, the residential market was the largest segment of the UK property management market, estimated to be £6.6 billion (87% of the UK property management market). It is estimated that this segment consisted of 8.2 million units owned by private landlords, public sector housing and professional companies. The commercial market was estimated to be £1.0 billion (13% of the UK property management market) and comprised office properties and retail spaces. A large share of this UK property market was not captured by property management companies, with services instead being managed “in-house.” The UK market benefits from a high level of penetration in multi-flat buildings with external block management (half of local private landlords in the rental sector use external managing agents), a high level of penetration in office buildings, and a medium level of penetration in retail space. Penetration by property management companies in the residential management segment is relatively high, with sub-segment penetration rates of: 75% for block management, 50% for management agencies, 40% for social housing, and 80% for public sector housing.

The size of the property markets differs depending on the country as well as the size of the addressable markets for property management companies. Property management companies’ penetration rates varies among the markets (residential vs. commercial) and the different types of owners.

Brokerage refers to the management of sale or purchase transaction processes for customers, including property search services, estimations on rental income, advice and assistance with banking and administrative formalities and market analysis, buyer solvency assessments and other services.

In addition to the core offering and brokerage, property management companies also provide other ancillary services that may be broadly categorized as follows: - Rental services: services aimed at minimizing property vacancy rates, such as finding new tenants, renegotiating tenancy agreements as well as property letting, sale of properties or buyer advisory; - Technical building consulting: legal and technical services related to building projects as well as maximizing the property value (for instance through energy optimization), including scrutiny technical advice and building process management, apartment renovations or energy consultancy; - Facility services: facilitation or direct delivery of supporting services for properties and tenants aimed at ensuring stable operations, and gathering different activities such as janitor services, receptionists, canteen operation, cleaning, caretakers or gardeners; ----- - Property asset management: end-to-end assistance with the process of investing in properties including strategy, opportunity assessment, valuation and portfolio development, as well as services such as portfolio strategy and optimization, valuation and risk assessment or portfolio development; and - Insurance advisory: coordination of providers of insurance services such as unpaid rent insurance, property insurance and liability insurance, including services such as offering of unpaid rent insurance, insurance consultancy or preferential supplier offers.

Subsection Title: Key growth drivers in the lease management and joint property management businesses
Subsubsection Text: As of August 2019, the addressable market of our lease management and joint property management businesses in France grew at an estimated 2% per annum between 2014 to 2019. In the UK, Germany and Switzerland, the addressable market for our lease management and joint property management businesses grew at an estimated 1.5% to 3% per annum between 2015 and 2019. The joint property management market is driven by three factors: pricing, building activities and outsourcing penetration for property management.

As of August 2019, prices for residential lease management are expected to grow between 1 to 2% per annum between 2019 and 2024 (excluding the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic and recent inflationary pressures), although impact from recent and future housing reform regulations remains unclear. Pricing for lease management is typically fixed as a percentage of rent (ranging from 2 to 10%, and on average 6 to 8% of annual rent). While prices in terms of percentages have remained stable, rent for residential real estate grew at 0.7% per annum from 2013 to 2019, with a recent trend of increased acceleration (1.7% from 2018 to 2019). Prices for joint property management are expected to grow at 1 to 2% per annum between 2019 and 2024 (excluding the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic and recent inflationary pressures). Prices for joint property management depend on a variety of factors, including the size of the portfolio, the services included, and the location and characteristics of the property. Prices have typically been increasing by 1 to 2% per annum between 2014 and 2019, in line with inflation. This trend is expected to continue on a normalized basis. Prices for Commercial Lease Management are expected to stay flat between 2019 and 2024 (excluding the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic and recent inflationary pressures), reflecting the competitive pressure from tendering processes. Rent levels in the commercial segment vary significantly and pricing tends to be negotiated through a competitive tender process where price points are determined on a global level, based on the characteristics and requirements of the buildings in the portfolio. In general, prices for commercial property management have remained rather stable between 2014 and 2019.

As of August 2019, building activities are expected to account for an estimated growth of 0.5 to 1% per annum between 2019 and 2024. The share of addressable market for property management businesses (excluding social housing and owner occupied units) is expected to remain stable during the same period. Growth for joint properties is expected to be in line with overall residential building stock growth.

Penetration of property management outsourcing is expected to grow for residential lease management, mainly driven by an increase in private landlords engaging management services. The penetration rate (the degree to which property owners outsource property management rather than conduct activities inhouse) for residential lease management varies significantly depending on the type of owners. Penetration within private landlords and secondary and vacant homes is relatively low at approximately 30% and 10%, respectively, as of 2019, whereas for institutional investors and the commercial segment, the penetration rate was approximately 90% as of 2019. As a result of more complex regulations (including PINEL, ALUR, ELAN), there has been a higher tendency among private landlords to outsource property management, as it has become increasingly difficult, time consuming and risky to keep property management in-house. These developments are expected to continue to cause some increases in penetration until 2024, subject to any impact that may stem from general market changes, economic disruption caused by the COVID-19 pandemic, and recent inflationary pressures. Penetration for institutional investors and for the commercial segment is expected to remain stable given already elevated current levels. Secondary and vacant homes are often used for private or short-term purposes, thus penetration is expected to remain low. ----- Exhibit 11: Penetration of property management services (lease management) by types of ownership (2014-2024)

The property management market has seen an estimated annual growth rate of approximately 2%, from €4.82 billion in 2014 to €5.32 billion in 2019. Within the property management market, residential lease management grew at the fastest pace (growing from €1.49 billion in 2014 to €1.71 billion in 2019 with a CAGR of 2.8%), followed by joint property management (growing from €1.71 billion in 2014 to €1.90 billion in 2019 with a CAGR of 2.1%) and commercial lease management (growing from €1.61 billion in 2014 to €1.72 billion in 2019 with a CAGR of 1.3%). Between 2019 and 2024, the property management market in France is expected to grow an estimated rate of approximately 1 to 2% per annum, to reach €5.87 billion in 2024 (excluding the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic and recent inflationary pressures). Continued growth is expected to be driven by the residential lease management segment and joint property management segment, with commercial lease management following historical trends. The growth outlook is expected to be driven by a larger number of addressable units and higher penetration of units owned by private landlords as a result of regulatory changes which have made it more difficult for private landlords to manage properties inhouse. However, certain aspects of this expected growth may be offset by uncertainties regarding the full price effect of recent regulatory changes and new entrants. The private housing market in France has grown steadily since 2000 at a CAGR of 1.2% and as at 2019 had not been affected by the global financial crisis as shown below: Exhibit 10: Evolution of the French private housing between 2000 and 2019 by apartments and rented individual houses (in million units) 9.9 10.0 [10.2 10.3 10.4 10.5 10.7 10.8 10.9 11.0 11.1 11.2 11.3 11.5 11.6 11.7 11.9 12.0 12.2 12.4] 2000 2001 2002 2003 2004 2005 2006 2007 2008 2009 2010 2011 2012 2013 2014 2015 2016 2017 2018 2019 Source: INSEE |9.9 10.0|Col2|Col3|Col4|Col5|Col6|Col7|Col8|Col9|Col10|Col11|Col12|Col13|Col14|Col15|Col16|Col17|Col18|Col19|Col20|Col21|Col22|Col23|Col24|Col25|Col26|Col27| |---|---|---|---|---|---|---|---|---|---|---|---|---|---|---|---|---|---|---|---|---|---|---|---|---|---|---| -----

# of dwellings, 2014–24 Million units, CAGR |Col1|Col2|Col3| |---|---|---| ||~1%|| |||| |Col1|Col2|Col3| |---|---|---| ||~1%|| |||| Houses Apartments Est penetration of PM services, 2014-24 Penetration ~1% ~1% 6.0 6.3 6.7 1.7 1.8 1.9 4.3 4.5 4.8 2014 2019 2024E 28% 30% 32% ~1% ~1% 0.3 0.3 0.3 2014 2019 2024E 90% 90% 90% ~1% ~1% 6.2 6.5 6.8 3.0 3.1 3.3 3.2 3.4 3.6 2014 2019 2024E 10% 10% 10% |Col1|Col2|Col3| |---|---|---| ||~1%|| |||| Source: International report provider As of August 2019, penetration of outsourcing of joint property management for condominiums was estimated to be high at 85%, and is expected to remain stable at the current level until 2024.

Historically, the property management market in Switzerland grew at an estimated 1.5 to 2% per annum, from €1.00 billion in 2015 to €1.07 billion in 2019, and is expected to grow at a similar pace in the near future, reaching €1.17 billion in 2024. This remains subject to any impact that may stem from general market changes, economic disruption caused by the COVID-19 pandemic, and recent inflationary pressures. The main drivers for growth of the sector in Switzerland are expected to be building activity (which is expected to grow at an estimated rate of 1.2% per annum between 2019 and 2024) and to a lesser extent outsourcing penetration (which is expected to grow at an estimated rate of 0.6% per annum between 2019 and 2024). Unlike in France, in Switzerland, the prices have been decreasing slightly between 2014 and 2019, driven by lower percentages charged on the rent, despite increasing rent levels. In the near future, pricing in terms of percentage of rent is not expected to decrease at the same pace given the already low level. An additional upside could potentially be realized through ancillary services. Overall, prices are not expected to have a significant impact on the growth prospects for the property management market in Switzerland. -----

The property management market in Germany grew at an estimated rate of 3% per annum, from €3.24 billion in 2015 to €3.66 billion in 2019. In the near future, the market is expected to grow at approximately 2.5 to 3% per annum between 2019 and 2024, largely in line with historical levels, reaching €4.18 billion in 2024. This remains subject to any impact that may stem from general market changes, economic disruption caused by the COVID-19 pandemic, and recent inflationary pressures. Price increases are expected to be the main growth driver (approximately 1.1% per annum between 2019 and 2024), with some contributions from building activity (approximately 0.7% per annum between 2019 and 2024) and to a lesser extent outsourcing penetration (approximately 0.3% per annum between 2019 and 2024). Prices have increased across residential and commercial segments in the recent past between 2015 and 2019, driven mostly by increasing rent (especially for office spaces, driven by shortage). These trends are expected to continue in the near future. Unlike in France or Switzerland, outsourcing activity in the German market has not followed a clear trend and is not expected to do so in the short term. In Belgium and Luxembourg, the company’s current operations are relatively small compared to other markets limiting the impact of market growth trends on the overall business.

The property management market in the United Kingdom grew at an estimated rate of 2% per annum, from £3.7 billion in 2015 to £4.0 billion in 2019. In the near future, the market is expected to grow at approximately 2% per annum between 2019 and 2024, largely in line with historical levels, reaching £4.5 billion in 2024. The block management segment, similar to the joint property segment in France, is expected to grow at approximately 3% per annum in this period. This remains subject to any impact that may stem from general market changes, economic disruption caused by the COVID-19 pandemic, and recent inflationary pressures. Price increases are expected to be the main growth driver (approximately 2.4% per annum between 2019 and 2024), with some contributions from building activity (approximately 0.6% per annum between 2019 and 2024) while outsourcing penetration is not expected to have a positive impact. Prices have increased across residential and commercial segments in the recent past between 2015 and 2019, driven by increasing rent and increases in the consumer price index.

Emeria has operations in Switzerland, Germany, Belgium, Luxembourg and the United Kingdom. Between 2019 and 2024, the property management market is expected to grow by approximately 1.5 to 2% per annum in Switzerland, approximately 2.5 to 3% per annum in Germany, and by approximately 2% in the United Kingdom (excluding the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic and recent inflationary pressures).

The key metrics that drove growth until 2019 continue to influence the building market favorably. In terms of construction of activity, residential building stock in France consistently grew at approximately 0.9% per annum from 2020 to 2022 and is expected to continue on the same trajectory to 2024. Switzerland which was expected to have the fastest growth in building activity among Emeria’s geographical segments, demonstrated annual growth of approximately 1% from 2020 to 2022 and is expected to continue growing at approximately 1% to 2024. Germany also presented positive growth at approximately 0.7% from 2020 to 2022 and is expected to continue growing at a similar rate. Lastly, the UK has also shown consistent annual growth of approximately 0.5% from 2020 to 2022 and is expected to continue growing at a similar rate to 2024. ----- Exhibit 12: Annual growth in total housing stock (in %) France Switzerland 1.20% 1.10% 1.02% 1.01% 1.00% 2020 2021 2022E 2023E 2024E |France|Swi| |---|---| 0.88% 0.85% 0.96% 0.99% 0.95% 2020 2021 2022E 2023E 2024E Germany United Kingdom 0.66% 0.63% 0.66% 0.66% 0.63% 2020 2021 2022E 2023E 2024E Source: Euroconstruct 0.55% 0.54% 0.55% 0.54% 0.54% 2020 2021 2022E 2023E 2024E Rental growth is a key driver for pricing growth in the external property market. According to Eurostat, from December 2019 to November 2022, across Germany, France and Switzerland, the rental rate grew at CAGR of 0.5% in France, 1.5% in Germany and 1.1% in Switzerland each year. In the United Kingdom, data from the Office of National Statistics shows that annual rental growth ranged between 1.4% and 1.9% between 2019 and 2021 with an acceleration to approximately 4% in November 2022. It is believed that the appeal of third party service providers has also helped play a role in increasing the outsourcing penetration in the market. Overall, the external property management market has benefitted from positive momentum in its key drivers. This is in spite of overall lower levels of economic activity, which were partially offset by the Group’s ability to leverage its leading market position.

_The French lease management and joint property management markets_ The chart below reflects key players in the French market by number of dwellings under management: Exhibit 13: Key players in the French market by number of dwellings under management (in thousands of units) ----- (1) Represents the total units of Square Habitat and Crédit Agricole Immobilier Source: Based on latest figures available from public information and company fillings as of the date of this Offering Memorandum. Note that the figures are provided as of varying dates, based on latest figures available for each company and some key players are excluded due to lack of public information The French real estate services market is highly fragmented, with a few large players and a long tail of independent small and local providers. The increasing barriers to entry with regulations and growing technological requirements make it difficult for small players to remain competitive. _The French brokerage market_ The French brokerage market is highly fragmented, with few large players and a long tail of very small agencies. The main players can be divided into four main categories: - Traditional real estate agency networks (physical) gather a network of several agencies. Most of them opt for franchising that enable them to develop quickly and inexpensively. Only six networks exceed 500 locations in France (Century 21, Emeria, Guy Hoquet’Immobilier, Laforêt Immobilier, Orpi and Stéphane Plaza Immobilier); - Real estate agency networks (online), mainly carry out their activity online, enabling them to propose lower commission rates as they do not operate a network of physical agencies. The seven predominant networks are IAD, Safti, Capifrance, Propriétés-Privées.com, OptimHome, Efficity (a subsidiary of Emeria) and MegAgence; - Independent online agencies which offer fixed commissions and are challenging the codes of the real estate services market. Still few players (a dozen on the French market), these start-ups are essentially present in Île-de-France and in some large cities (Lyon, Bordeaux, etc.); - Specialized agents for the luxury segment coming from dominant specialized agencies distinguished by a significant international presence, such as Barnes and Emile Garcin.

The chart below reflects the key players in the Swiss market as of 2018 by property management per revenue: Exhibit 14: Key players in the Swiss market in 2018 (estimated property management revenue in € millions Market share 10% 6% 6% 4% 3% 2% 2% 2% 1% 1% 1% 14% 48% 100% 510 1070 150 48 25-40 25-40 15-30 15-30 16 10-20 12-16 65 66 100-120 Mid-sized Small Total players players Source: International report provider The Swiss market is relatively fragmented, with a few large players and a long tail of small, local providers. The players can be divided into four main categories: - Independent property management companies, including us, with core offering of property management services for both the commercial and residential segments, without a clear separation. Independent property management companies also provide brokerage and other ----- services such as facility management. Other predominant examples of companies in this category are Privera and Averit; - Institutionally owned property managers are large, nationwide companies, owned by institutional investors or real estate companies such as Swiss Prime Site, SwissLife, and Pensimo. They often offer property management services to third parties, in addition to managing their own portfolios, such as brokerage and other services (commercial letting or technical consulting). Predominant examples are Wincasa, Livit and Regimo; - Local associates of international real estate advisors are originally Swiss property management companies that have partnered with an international real estate advisor, having often two local associates: one for French speaking Switzerland and one for German speaking Switzerland. They usually also offer brokerage services and other services. Predominant examples are Intercity and Real Estate AG; - Small scale property management companies are small and local providers of property management, mainly targeting private investors and offering property management and coownership association services. They are typically family businesses or owner-operated companies with less than 10 employees, with most of the business focused on a single municipality or city. Small scale property management companies represent almost 50% of the market. Predominant examples are Geminwo and Martaler.

The chart below reflects the key players in the German market as of 2017 by estimated residential property management revenue: Exhibit 15: Key players in the German residential property management market (in 2017, estimated residential property management revenue in € millions) Market 0.8% 0.4% 0.4% 0.4% 0.3% 0.2% 0.2% 0.2% 0.2% 0.5% 96% 100% share 2,060 2,150 12 7 7 5 5 4 3 9 9 10 18 Top 10-20 Other Total companies players Source: International report provider There are no actors with significant scale in the German residential property management market as the top 10 players only hold a combined 4% market share. The players can be divided into four main categories: - Property management companies, including us, with core offering of property management. Most of the larger players focus on commercial property management while also holding some residential units. They also provide brokerage and other services such as facility management. Other predominant examples of companies in this category are ECE, DIM, IC Immobilien Gruppe, Treureal and Tectareal; - Full-service real estate advisors operate internationally as “one-stop-shop.” They secure stable income streams. They also provide other services (asset management or facility management). Predominant examples are JLL, BNPP RE, CBRE and Cushman & Wakefield; ----- - Facility management-evolved companies, the core offering of which is facility management, moving gradually more into provision of property management to complement the low-margin facility management business with broader services. Predominant examples are Strabag, Apleona and Property First; - Small-scale property management companies are small companies with “WEG-management” (acting according to the German Condominium Act (“Wohneigentumsgesetz” – WEG), which constitutes the basis for all legal regulations involving individual freehold ownership including the management of condominiums) as core business. Small-scale property management companies also provide property management and gradually move more into property management of commercial space. They are typically owner-operated, with an average of less than 10 employees with most of the business focused around a municipality or a city. They represent more than 80% of the market. Predominant examples are Jürgens Hausverwaltung GmbH and Kaldox Immobilien.

The chart below reflects the key players in the UK market as of 2022 by estimated residential property management units under management. The acquisition of FirstPort in 2022 has established leadership for Emeria in the UK, a market which is mostly made up of small players focused in local areas: Exhibit 16: Key players in the UK residential property management market (in 2022, estimated residential property units under management) -----

We are the global leader in the residential real estate services (“RRES”) market by dwellings under management, providing services to both individuals (“business-to-consumer” or “B2C”) and businesses (“business-to-business” or “B2B”), and have also entered the commercial real estate services segment for B2B customers. We assist our residential and commercial customers at every stage of their property journey with competitive and comprehensive service offerings. We provide end-to-end assistance, from managing individual apartment and building areas jointly owned by apartment owners through our Lease Management and Letting and Joint Property Management business lines, respectively, to providing brokerage, digital and other services such as insurance brokerage, technical diagnostic and energy brokerage through our other business lines. Our RRES business is the leader in France, operating under the Foncia brand through a network of approximately 134 and 131 branches dedicated to our RRES and Brokerage businesses, respectively, and 242 branches dedicated to both our RRES and Brokerage businesses, representing 83.4% of our revenue in France for the nine months ended September 30, 2022. For the nine months ended September 30, 2022, our French RRES business, Brokerage business, Digital services, B2B services and international business generated 57.7%, 13.3%, 9.5%, 4.7% and 14.8% of our total revenue, respectively. Our business lines include: - French Residential Real Estate Services (“RRES”): (a) _Joint property management (our “JPM business”): In our Joint Property Management business, we are mandated by landlords to manage jointly owned building areas and equipment and to ensure compliance with joint ownership regulations. We are the French market leader in Joint Property Management, managing over 1,765,964 dwellings in France for the nine months ended September 30, 2022. We are generally hired by an apartment building homeowners’ board to provide common services to all residents under contracts that are typically one year in length, subject to renewal. Services in our Joint Property Management business include the administrative, financial and technical management of the building, works management, managing security staff and ensuring the maintenance of technical equipment such as elevators, heating and safety systems. We also coordinate the payment of common costs, transfer tasks, help brokers with the management of joint decisions, offer cost management services such as efficiencies with respect to energy, maintenance and heating costs, and provide asset appraisal services, as well as around-the-clock maintenance assistance. These fee-based services in our Joint Property Management business provide recurring and predictable revenue streams with revenue of €269.7 million. Through our growth strategy, which includes both acquisitions and organic growth initiatives, we have gone from managing 1,394,206 dwellings in France in 2019 to 1,765,964 dwellings in France as of September 30, 2022. (b) _Lease management and letting (our “LM&L business”): Through our Lease Management and Letting business, we manage properties on behalf of our ownerlessor customers (the lease management side of the Lease Management and Letting business) and assist landlords and tenants throughout their rental process, including the finding, screening and contracting of new tenants (the “renting” side of the Lease Management and Letting business). In Lease Management, we assist landlords with the day-to-day operations of the property, collect rent, offer financial reporting services and advice and organize necessary maintenance for the properties. We managed over 376, 262 dwellings in France as of September 30, 2022, where we provided recurring services for these landlords under contracts that are typically one year in length. We also offer occupancy guarantee services to certain owner-lessors to provide guaranteed ----- rental income should their lessees fail to make their rental payments or occupy the premise. See “—Lease Management and Letting” and “Management’s Discussion and _Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations—Key Factors Affecting Results of Operations—Rent payment and occupancy guarantees.” Our Lease_ Management and Letting business generated €254.6 million in revenue for the nine months ended September 30, 2022. Through our growth strategy, which includes both acquisitions and organic growth initiatives, we have increased the number of dwellings we manage in France from 330,005 for the year ended December 31, 2020 to 376,262 in France as of September 30, 2022. - French Real Estate Brokerage (our “Brokerage business”): In addition to the recurring activity in our Joint Property Management and Lease Management and Letting businesses, we support our existing customers or other customers with their purchase or sale plans, by offering property search services, estimations on rental income, advice and assistance with banking and administrative formalities and market analysis, buyer solvency assessments and other services. Once a landlord mandates us to sell their apartment, this mandate covers the entire business process from buyer identification to cash collection. We closed over 12,994 transactions in the nine months ended September 30, 2022 and our Brokerage business generated €125.8 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2022. - Our other services include: (a) _French B2B Services: Esset, our B2B business, comprises all lines of business with commercial and institutional customers. Our Esset business line includes Esset Management, our wealth management and consulting services for commercial and office properties firm, and Esset Valorisation, which markets properties by blocks or lots. Our experience and expertise within multiple facets of the real estate services market allows us to provide a broad range of service offerings, including residential, commercial and corporate services, to these B2B customers. For example, we may provide services to an insurance institution, a B2B customer, that owns and rents residential apartments, commercial space and corporate office space and we are able to service their needs in each of these capacities. Our B2B business in France generated €44.0 million in revenue for the nine months ended September 30, 2022. In 2021, we acquired Humakey and Cogeva to strengthen our B2B business and expand our presence in the high-end and bespoke services space. (b) _French Digital Services: Our Digital Services business includes our businesses that rely on a digital platform and is comprised of Efficity, Lodgis, Assurimo and Seiitra. Efficity is an online real estate valuation and brokerage activity operated with a business model based on independent sales agents. Lodgis is a real estate agency specialized in renting and selling furnished units, Assurimo is a specialized property insurance brokerage unit and Seiitra is a business-specific IT services business. Our Digital Services business in France generated €89.4 million in revenue for the nine months ended September 30, 2022. (c) _International Services._ We also offer RRES, Brokerage and other services in our International businesses in Switzerland, Benelux, Germany and the UK For the nine months ended September 30, 2022, 85.2% of our revenues were derived in France, and 5.7%, 2.7%, 5.2% and 1.2% of our revenues were derived in Switzerland, Benelux, Germany and the UK, respectively. We continue to expand our presence in these international geographies through a robust acquisition pipeline. For a further detailed description of our businesses, see “—Our Businesses.” We were founded in 1972 and have since established ourselves as the leading European RRES, with over 16,700 employees across Europe as of September 30, 2022. Our recent growth has been marked by achievements in operations, digitization, our successful M&A track record and our IT and ----- communications infrastructure. We believe our success is the result of a unique integrated ecosystem of real estate services providing the opportunity for cross-selling of recurring and additional services and growth through bolt-on acquisitions. The following diagram provides a breakdown of our revenue by business for the for the nine months ended September 30, 2022: (1) Lease Management and Letting revenues also include revenue generated from interest income on our customer accounts, Foncia Immo Neuf and Holiday Rental. The RRES market in the jurisdictions in which we operate remains largely fragmented. According to a third-party report prepared in 2019 the French property management market was estimated to be worth approximately €12 billion (excluding rental services and brokerage), of which approximately €5.3 billion was under external management, along with an estimated €1.2 billion market for rental services. However, greater regulation in France and the increasing need to invest in the digitization of services has made it more difficult and time consuming for private landlords to keep property management inhouse, leading to the increased outsourcing and penetration rate of properties under external management in the residential property management market. These trends towards increased regulation and digitization have also led to the growing consolidation of the highly fragmented market, enabling us to capitalize on small bolt-on, strategic acquisitions and increase our market positioning and scale. Our size provides us with a competitive advantage against smaller and local competitors as we can industrialize processes to better leverage our cost base, replicate best practices across our network to ensure consistent quality of service and adapt more easily to regulatory changes. As a result, we made 55 acquisitions in the nine months ended September 30, 2022, both in our primary French market and in other geographies, including FirstPort in the UK, representing 29,069 new Lease Management dwellings and 553,981 new Joint Property Management dwellings and €261.1 million of acquired revenues. We have a robust acquisition pipeline in France, Switzerland, Benelux, Germany and the UK and a strong team of approximately 40 employees and five trainees dedicated to post acquisition integration.

Subsubsection Title: Sector leadership focused on strongest economies in Western Europe providing competitive advantages
Subsubsection Text: We have established ourselves as a leader for residential real estate services in France, Switzerland, Benelux, Germany and the UK by delivering high quality, reliable and innovative services uniquely suited to the needs of our customers. As of August 2019, we were the number one player in the French real estate services market, with approximately 13% market share, according to an international report provider. As of September 30, 2022, we managed approximately 2.1 million dwellings in France, which is approximately two times the number of dwellings managed by our next closest competitor according ----- to publically available information for the year ended 2020. Outside of France, we also hold leading positions in Switzerland, Benelux, Germany and the UK. As of September 30, 2022, we operated over 114 branches in these countries, which collectively accounted for 14.8% of our revenue for the nine months ended September 30, 2022. In 2022, we entered the UK market through the acquisition of FirstPort, one of the UK’s largest property services groups and the UK’s largest joint property manager with approximately 315,000 units under management as of March 2022, and has a market share of approximately 11%, twice the size of its closest competitor in the UK. FirstPort operates primarily in joint property management as well as in the rental management and real estate brokerage markets in England, Scotland and Wales with a strong geographical national coverage, generating revenue of €120 million in 2021 with the support of over 3,800 employees. FirstPort has an in-house built digital platform which enables it to offer a marketleading, fully automated and scalable service proposition which supports its continuous growth alongside a strong organic development, mobilization of a secured order book (recurring revenue streams with high visibility) and accretive acquisitions. Our scale, operations and service offerings provide us with a clear competitive advantage. Our centralized processes result in lower internal costs and enable improved customer service compared to our typically small, individual-owned competitors. Our comprehensive range of innovative services, such as FONCIA 24/7 (our assistance service for our joint property management customers), and Assurimo (our real estate insurance service), differentiate us from competitors. Our comprehensive network of over 500 branches covering all major French cities is one of the largest offerings in the market and results in close proximity to our customers and the dwellings that we manage; unique market positioning in negotiations with third-party repair and maintenance service suppliers resulting in decreased costs; and financial resources that allow us to expand our customer portfolio through acquisitions. We have been able to successfully enter markets through acquisitions and expanded our operating geography, despite the regulatory and technological requirements that create barriers to participation in the real estate services market. Our regional and national regulatory and real estate industry expertise and our leadership team’s extensive experience in the real estate services industry are key to meeting and complying with such requirements. Our strong reputation for quality, service and multi-branded strategy have also supported our ability to grow in existing markets and enter new markets.

Subsubsection Title: Loyal and diverse customer base and synergetic business model in an attractive and resilient market
Subsubsection Text: Our large and diversified client base, integrated ecosystem of residential real estate services and high customer retention rates drive a high level of recurring revenues (75% in 2020 and 72% in the nine months ended September 30, 2022). We have grown our diversified customer base to approximately 1.8 million dwellings in our French Joint Property Management business and over 376,000 dwellings in our French Lease Management business as at September 30, 2022. Through our synergetic business model, we are able to cross sell our services to our diverse customer portfolio across our business lines, which in turn leads to further organic growth. For example, our proven ability to cross-sell is highlighted by the high penetration rates of Assurimo, our specialized property insurance brokerage unit (providing property insurance, homeowners’ insurance policies and brokerage services) through which we currently provide building insurance (multi-risque immeubles) contracts to 49.7% and household insurance (multi-risque _habitation) contracts to 34.3% of our French Joint Property Management buildings, respectively._ Similarly, we currently provide technical services to approximately 104,220 contracts which represent 27.7% of our French RRES Lease Management customers through our dedicated business, Constatimmo. We believe that we are well positioned to target new customers, including B2B customers, given our knowledge regarding fulfilling requirements for our B2C customers. The addressable markets in which we operate are characterized by high outsourcing rates, with a high and stable portion of joint property or condominium owners (85% in France) under external ----- management, as of August 2019 using services like our Joint Property Management business. Property owners tend to rely on expert services such as ours due to the volume of work and amount of legal and accounting know-how required to directly interface with tenants and other counterparties. Moreover, landlords rarely switch leasing managers during a tenancy, given the risks and costs involved in switching service providers and the limited potential benefit, resulting in a high customer net retention rate of 95.1% in our Joint Property Management business and 91.2% in our Lease Management business for the nine months ended September 30, 2022. The UK market is also characterized by a loyal customer base, as evidenced by FirstPort with a net retention rate of approximately 98% in the year ended December 31, 2021. We believe that through the integrated ecosystem of high-quality services we consistently provide we have established high customer retention rates, and long lasting customer relationships, certain of which last more than 20 years. Moreover, 36.2% of our customers from our Joint Property Management business in France entered into contracts of three or more years and 23.8% for two to three years for the nine months ended September 30, 2022. Due to our broad and diverse customer base, we are not reliant on any particular customer. According to an international report provider, the French property management market is estimated to be €12.2 billion in August 2019, of which €5.3 billion is captured by property management companies, with the rest serviced in-house. The externally serviced property management market has grown by approximately 2% annually between 2014 and 2019. This stable growth has been driven by population dynamics and the construction of collective units. We continue to capitalize on opportunities to grow through acquisition of customer portfolios, cross-selling of related services to our large client base and the addition of new revenue opportunities for our existing services.

Subsubsection Title: Strong and predictable cash flow generation with an inflation resilient business model
Subsubsection Text: We have a track record of steady cash flow generation, driven by a high level of recurring revenues, which has enabled us to regularly deleverage. Our trend of high EBITDA conversion rates has continued with a Pre-IFRS-16 EBITDA Conversion Rate, of approximately 85.1% for the year ended December 31, 2021, compared to 81.6% for the year ended December 31, 2020. Despite our regular M&A activity, our discretionary spend on acquisitions provides us with flexibility to manage our cash flow and reduce our financial leverage. Further, our business requires limited maintenance capital expenditures (accounting for approximately 4.2% and 4.6% of revenues for the year ended December 31, 2021 and for the nine months ended September 30, 2022, respectively), and is characterized by limited working capital requirements. Our revenue increased by 12.2% to €943.3 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2022, up from €840.9 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2021 and increased by 19.3% to €1,146.8 million for the year ended December 31, 2021, up from €961.5 million for the year ended December 31, 2020. Our margin resilience is supported by an adaptable cost structure for the more cyclical flow Brokerage business, as Brokerage salary costs include a significant variable portion that is indexed on commissions. Our Adjusted EBITDA Margin was 27.7% for the twelve months ended September 30, 2022 and 28.2% and 26.9% for the years ended December 31, 2021 and 2020, respectively. Our recurring, stable revenue is in part due to our complementary business profiles across our branches, experienced management and sales force teams, and fee-based services in connection with our Joint Property Management and Lease Management and Letting businesses which accounted for 65.2% of our revenue in France for the nine months ended September 30, 2022. In addition, our high proportion of recurring revenues (75% in 2020 and 72% in the nine months ended September 30, 2022) and balanced portfolio of services split between stock and flow businesses with limited correlation have supported our resilience during adverse economic conditions, achieving a substantially stable performance in 2020 despite unprecedented government measures taken in response to the COVID-19 pandemic. We believe that our business model is resilient to inflationary pressures, in particular as a result of our ability to pass through a portion of our cost increases and of the limited impact of inflation on our ----- business in general. Most of our contracts are either subject to an annual pricing assessment or contain inflation adjustment mechanisms, which allow us to effectively pass-through inflationary impact to our customers. In addition, our fees are typically derived as a proportion of rent, and we, therefore, benefit from price increases occurring in an inflationary environment. Due to the nature of our business, we have a relatively limited exposure to energy and gas price increases, and the energy saving measures that we have put in place allow us to further mitigate any such impact. We estimate that the negative impact from elevated levels of inflation on EBITDA for our French business in the nine months ended September 30, 2022 was approximately €2.5 million.

Subsubsection Title: Continuous investments in operational improvement through technology reinforces our competitive position and provides sustainable efficiency gains
Subsubsection Text: We continuously invest in cutting edge technology in order to offer the best multi-channel services to our customers. Since 2017, we have upgraded a significant portion of our IT and communication infrastructure including utilizing a mix of integrated and outsourced solutions, transitioning to a single telecom provider, and streamlining our finance and human resources functions with Workday, which enabled us to quickly and effectively transition to a work-from-home environment during the COVID19 pandemic. We have also leveraged our technological know-how combined with our knowledge of the real estate industry to design and launch our new ERP system, Millenium. Millenium integrates all of our IT and resource planning functions into one database to better meet our customers’ needs and address internal business challenges. Millenium increases the digitization of our activities with the aim of helping customers by creating greater transparency and improving our operations with standardized, digital processes to increase efficiency and to improve the speed at which we can serve our customers. We believe our high levels of investment in IT for our corporate platform and customer interface service such as over recent years give us a competitive edge in the current environment. Millenium was piloted at several of our branches in France and launched at all brokerage operations in France in early 2022 prior to the roll-out to our broader network starting in November 2022. Further, we commenced the roll-out of Millenium at our RRES operations which is now in use for 5.6% of our Joint Property Management dwellings and 6.0% of our Lease Management dwellings. We aim to accelerate the rollout of Millenium in the first quarter of 2023. The digitization, standardization and automation offered by Millenium complement our already synergetic business model and will allow us to more quickly leverage our customer database to identify cross-selling opportunities leading to greater operating efficiencies and inter-business synergies. We believe that Millenium’s compatibility with big data, AI and IoT, will allow us to explore new business opportunities and provide access to a number of revenue-enhancing opportunities. For example, we have developed a new operational model called “Agency of the Future” which will utilize Millenium to reorganize the residential real estate services and aims at improving client satisfaction and reducing our customer churn rate, which we believe will, in turn, lead to greater opportunities for organic growth. Furthermore, we also believe that the gains of Millenium and the development of Agency of the Future will positively impact our EBITDA by €25.0 million in the next 24 months. We have invested in, and will continue to invest in, technology to continually improve our internal operations in order to provide our customers with product offerings that meet their needs and make us the number one choice among residential real estate service providers.

Subsubsection Title: Consolidation platform with proven track record of executing value accretive acquisitions to drive incremental EBITDA growth
Subsubsection Text: In addition to our organic growth, we maintain a successful, reduced risk strategy of growth through small, bolt-on acquisitions. We completed over 330 acquisitions since January 2016, which represented €814.1 million of acquired revenues. In the nine months ended September 30, 2022, we entered the UK market with the acquisition of FirstPort and we also completed 54 acquisitions in our primary French market and in other geographies, representing 29,069 new Lease Management dwellings and 553,981 new Joint Property Management dwellings and €261.1 million of acquired revenues. These 55 acquisitions contributed to our Adjusted EBITDA, which reached €409.9 million for the twelve months ----- ended September 30, 2022, as compared to €348.3 million for the year ended December 31, 2021. Consolidation is a natural trend in the highly fragmented markets we operate in, accelerated by increasing regulations, and we play a key role in the market by defining new quality standards and unrivalled execution processes. We have a strong M&A team, with a disciplined approach that is dedicated to identifying, diligencing, completing and integrating opportunistic acquisitions in our five geographical regions, which we plan to expand in the UK. Our long-standing integration experience, including a dedicated post-acquisition integration team, enables us to extract full synergy potential from acquired businesses, with both cross-selling and cost synergies. We have identified a number of potential targets in France, Switzerland, Benelux, Germany and the UK to continue growing and, importantly, reinforcing our leadership in the market.

Subsubsection Title: Highly experienced management team with proven execution capabilities and focus on growth and value creation
Subsubsection Text: Our management team, led by our Chief Executive Officer, Philippe Salle, has significant experience in the industry and proven track record of delivering business and revenue growth, executing investment plans, driving continuous improvement of our European enterprise and generating high returns on capital. Our management team comes from various industries and geographies and is supported by four heads of region in France and four heads of region in international markets, who have extensive experience in real estate and enable us to provide our customers with tailored expertise and service. We believe that the collective industry knowledge and leadership of our management team positions them well to continue our successful organic and external growth and execute our strategies. Further, our management team encourages growth through a focus on operational efficiency and innovation including through the management’s dynamic external growth policy that enabled us to, among others, establish our market leading presence in the UK, Benelux, Switzerland and Germany, successfully divest our non-core businesses to focus on our core, synergetic businesses and more recently, by the ongoing overhaul of our IT infrastructure, including the development and deployment of Millenium and enabling our planned transition to our new operational model, “Agency of the Future.” This is demonstrated by the consistent increase in our revenues which increased by 12.2% to €943.3 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2022, up from €840.9 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2021 and increased by 19.3% to €1,146.8 million for the year ended December 31, 2021, up from €961.5 million for the year ended December 31, 2020.

Subsubsection Title: Industry-leading technology to further reinforce our competitive advantage
Subsubsection Text: We are committed to providing the best real estate services offerings to our customers by investing in industry- leading IT and data platforms, which in turn supports our market share gains. Our most recent digital innovation, Millenium, an in-house developed ERP system that is cloud-based and will allow us to fully digitalize our businesses. We believe that Millenium will allow us to better, more efficiently serve our customers, cross-sell across our services and therefore capture greater market share from existing customers and generate business from new customers. Our IT and data platforms are subject to a process of continuous improvement and innovation, which we support with ongoing investments, such as the team of 68 developers we hired in connection with the development of Millenium. We believe that our robust investments in our IT and data platforms provide us with a significant competitive advantage, particularly during the COVID-19 pandemic when businesses have been required to transition to a work-from-home environment. Additionally, our ongoing and historical use of big data, AI and IoT to create new business opportunities enables us to maintain a cutting edge development program while minimizing the risks traditionally associated with experimentation. For example, we have developed our new operational model, Agency of the Future, which we believe will generate significant savings, mainly related to (i) staff costs synergies from the optimization of the ratios of middle and back-office functions to front-office employees and an increase in productivity and significant reduction of time spent on manual and repetitive processes and (ii) gains ----- resulting from the digitization and automation of certain tasks that were previously done manually, such as reminder fees or the collection of postal charges. Since 2018, we have invested approximately €155.0 million into our IT projects, and we believe that the gains of Millenium and Agency of the Future will positively impact our EBITDA by €25.0 million in the next 24 months. We have developed, and continue to develop, innovative solutions based on emerging trends that are aimed at providing our customers with the highest quality, optimal solutions for their real estate needs. We are constantly looking for ways to improve our offerings and develop new solutions for our customers, which we expect to drive incremental growth and positively impact our revenue.

Subsubsection Title: Continue to drive organic growth and pursue targeted and opportunistic bolt-on acquisitions in our core French market
Subsubsection Text: Our goal is to continue to deliver organic growth in France. We have been successful in achieving incremental organic revenue growth through active cross selling efforts across our ancillary services. We intend to continue to benefit from this growth through expanding our service offerings by introducing new business lines. In addition, we aim to further reduce our customer churn rate in Joint Property Management by improving client satisfaction, including as a result of the overhaul of our IT systems and operating model. In addition, we have made, and intend to continue to make, selected bolt-on acquisitions in our core French market and the other geographies in which we operate to supplement our organic growth, solidify our current market position and expand our presence. We have a strong track record of successfully identifying, completing and integrating opportunistic acquisitions. From January 2016 to September 2022, we completed over 330 acquisitions. We believe that our strong brand, broad platform and our dynamic infrastructure have allowed us to generate growth and operating cash flows through acquisitions. Recent examples of targeted acquisitions in France that have accelerated our growth and have allowed us to better address customer needs include Billon and AGDA, in our RRES business, Humakey in B2B and in Belgium, with Syncura. We intend to continue to further strengthen our strong position in the market by pursuing opportunistic acquisitions in our existing geographies to accelerate our growth, and we aim to do so by leveraging our internal expertise. We have an M&A team that is dedicated to identifying growth opportunities. Our team deploys a disciplined and systematic approach and focuses on opportunities that will enhance the offerings and services we provide in France, Switzerland, Benelux, Germany and the UK.

Subsubsection Title: Continue to develop complementary service offering
Subsubsection Text: We provide alternative services and continue the development and roll-out of complementary solutions to our main business lines based on emerging market trends to capitalize on cross-selling opportunities between our different divisions. During the COVID-19 pandemic, when the concern for health safety greatly increased, we launched Tech-Way, a new business line dedicated to the technical maintenance of housing to help our clients to live and work in secure and healthy environments. Tech-Way provides actionable advice and sustainable solutions for pest control, fire protection, routine maintenance and repair work. We believe that providing complementary solutions to our core services allows us to further extend our market reach by catering to the real estate related needs of both landlords and tenants as well as our professional customers.

We have expanded, and plan to continue to expand, our geographic footprint in Europe, organically and through targeted and opportunistic acquisitions. We intend to leverage our expertise and know-how as well as our highly localized real estate providers to penetrate European markets where there is an unmet demand and an opportunity for further expansion, as evidenced by factors such as population dynamics and the construction of collective units, accompanied by increases in price and service level and a higher degree of outsourcing driven by regulatory changes. We strategically pursue new markets while ----- remaining committed to expanding in France, Switzerland, Benelux, Germany and the UK as these markets offer us proximity to existing customers and expansion opportunities in countries where we have established brand recognition. In 2022, we entered the UK market through the acquisition of FirstPort, one of the UK’s largest property services groups and the UK’s largest joint property manager with approximately 315,000 units under management as of March 2022. With this acquisition, Emeria became the global leader in residential property management as well as the number one player in the largest European markets: the UK, France and Germany. For the year ended December 31, 2021, our strategic focus on the expansion of our geographical footprint in Europe would have allowed us to generate approximately €274 million of International Revenue, taking into account FirstPort as if the acquisition of FirstPort had closed on January 1, 2021 (based on an aggregation of the Group’s International Revenue and FirstPort’s revenues without pro forma adjustments, each for the year ended December 31, 2021). Our expertise and solutions are scalable from region to region, and we believe that as we continue to expand, we can increase market share by deploying practices and strategies that have proven to be successful in other markets.

We are committed to ESG matters and providing a safe and healthy environment for all of our customers and employees.
