Our corporate social responsibility strategy is based on the following key commitments: supporting sustainable energy in the buildings and dwellings we manage, improving the well-being of our customers and our employees and ensuring fair and non-discriminatory access to housing and assisting local communities. Our ESG initiatives are also focused on protecting the environment while also ensuring that our operations have minimal impact on the environment. We aim to achieve carbon emission neutrality at the Group level by 2040. We also aim to work with our clients, contractors and suppliers to improve efficiency, conserve natural resources and reduce waste and emissions. We focus on energy transition of buildings under management by developing services and solutions to enable our clients to renovate and finance their dwellings. In the third quarter of 2022, we appointed a new Vice President of ESG and Strategy, with an aim to drive the further development of our ESG objectives, action plans and reporting. In 2023, we aim to ensure that all of our building managers are systematically trained to lead such renovation projects, partner with clients and employees who demonstrate a commitment to the environment and reduce our carbon footprint.

We were incorporated in 1972 and have since expanded our business with subsequent acquisitions of real estate services businesses in France, Switzerland, Benelux, Germany and the UK and we are focused on improving our technological capabilities in order to optimize our efficiency and overall business offering. From January 2016 to September 2022, we have completed over 330 acquisitions, primarily within Joint Property Management and Lease Management and Letting. Our external growth strategy and development of ancillary service offerings has been a key driver to our historical growth. The following are the key milestones in our corporate history following our foundation: 1973 - 1993 Development of an advanced computerization solution for rental management and lettings and management of jointly owned properties, adapted to the expectations of local real estate agents. Launch of the first bolt-on acquisitions program aiming at expanding Foncia’s presence in France. 2000 - 2006 International development of the group with the acquisitions of residential real estate service companies in Switzerland, Germany and Belgium. ----- 2013 Further development in Belgium with the acquisition of Trevi Group. Acquisition of Tagerim’s property administration division (representing 17 agencies and approximately 500 employees). August 2014 Acquisition of Efficity. July 2016 Funds advised and managed by Partners Group, leading a consortium including Caisse de dépôt et placement du Québec (“CDPQ”) and CIC Capital Corporation, signed a Share Purchase Agreement to acquire 100% of the shares of Foncia from Bridgepoint and Eurazeo. Completion of the sale took place on September 7, 2016. September 2016 Acquisition of Icade Property Management, which was folded into the Esset brand in December 2019. October 2018 Acquisition of Lodgis. October 2018 Strengthening of our position in Germany with the acquisition of Bautra’s Property Management business. September 2019 Organization of the first general meeting of joint property owners online with Fuze. March-May 2020 During the first pandemic lockdown and while the agencies were closed to the public, our teams remained available to assist customers using digital tools and ensuring business continuity. June 2020 Announcement of the beginning of our digital transformation in the management of jointly owned properties and rental management, to strengthen responsiveness, transparency and expertise in the service. September 2020 Creation of Foncia’s RRES premium division, to develop its premium offer for lease management activities in France. December 2020 Acquisition of OP in Belgium and Luxembourg. December 2021 Funds advised and managed by TA acquire an indirect 25% stake in Foncia from Partners Group and funds advised and managed by Partners Group invest into a majority in the new transaction. January 2022 Foncia Management becomes Emeria. January 2022 Emeria enters real estate market in the Netherlands for property management. January 2022 Launch of Millenium, our new enterprise resource planning (“ERP”) system that we developed in-house, for all Brokerage operations in France. July 2022 Five branches use Millenium in select RRES operations in France. August 2022 Emeria enters the UK market through its acquisition of FirstPort. November 2022 Ten branches use Millenium in select RRES operations in France. -----

The residential real estate services in France, operating primarily under the Foncia brand, represented 57.7% of our total revenue for the nine months ended September 30, 2022, and 67.8% of our total revenue generated in France for the nine months ended September 30, 2022. Revenue from this business primarily comprises (i) jointly owned property management fees, (ii) rental management fees (including rent payment and occupancy guarantee fees), and (iii) letting fees, which allow us to maintain stable revenues. _Management of Jointly Owned Properties_ In our Joint Property Management business, we assist our customers in managing common building areas, features and costs in their jointly owned properties by providing technical and accounting management. These management services include (i) providing information and communicating on a regular basis with the joint property owners, (ii) organizing and managing general meetings of joint property owners by preparing the agenda, summons, minutes, etc., (iii) managing the upkeep of the joint property as a whole, (iv) controlling costs by drawing up a budget, (v) obtaining bids from potential suppliers, (vi) providing a breakdown of joint property charges, (vii) collecting funds and amounts due for the joint property accounts, (viii) providing bookkeeping services, (ix) monitoring contract performance, and (x) providing mass procurement offers for joint property owners and leveraging our large purchasing power to offer attractive prices to our customers on expenses such as gas and other utilities. We also provide direct access to all Foncia services on a unique customer portal, MyFoncia, and offer around-the-clock customer service. From a contractual and legal perspective, our Joint Property Management business is conducted primarily through mandates. We take the role of trustee (syndic) after appointment by the homeowners’ board or general assembly of joint owners. We calculate fees on a flat-rate basis, which leads to relatively stable and recurring revenue. In France, this flat rate includes all basic management services provided by the jointly owned property association, including (i) preparing, convening and organizing general meetings, (ii) managing the joint owners’ council or general assembly (iii) managing the financial operations, including bill payments and collection of building fees, (iv) keeping the accounts of the jointly owned property association (v) managing the jointly owned property in compliance with its rules and regulations and (vi) carrying out periodic visits and inspections of the jointly owned property. We also receive additional incidental fees such as transfer fees when a landlord selling a dwelling requires a book balance report called a “transfer report,” reminder fees, fees on insurancerelated claim management services, maintenance and repair commissions on third parties invoices and additional post office charges. These variable fees comprise 24.6% of our total Joint Property Management fees for the nine months ended September 30, 2022. All such services are treated as an overall performance. These different services are associated with a single performance obligation, i.e., the management of the jointly owned property association. Incidental services may be added to the basic management services and are invoiced based on an agreed rate for each such service. As of September 30, 2022, we had 1,765,964 dwellings under our management of jointly owned properties, generating a revenue of €269.7 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2022, representing 28.6% of our total revenue for the same period. ----- _Lease Management and Letting_ Our Lease Management and Letting business is comprised of Lease Management and rental services. On the Lease Management side of the business, we manage an owner’s-lessor’s rented apartment and provide assistance on the day-to-day operations of the property, typically related to financial management, legal assistance and handling conflicts. We are appointed by the owner of the individual unit, typically a private landlord, and we act as agent for owners-lessors to fulfil a number of contractually defined obligations in this regard. These key services primarily include: (i) routine management services such as rent reviews and collection, annual adjustment invoice for expenses, and sending rent receipts and deposits to lessees, (ii) other one-off management services, including preparation of the lease contract, inventory of premises, compilation of documentation, management of claims, administrative filings and requests for subsidies, (iii) technical management services, such as coordinating on-site repairs, mandatory technical surveys and preparation of essential information documents for lessees, (iv) insurance against unpaid rent and (v) other insurance such as for vacant premises or property damage. Lease Management fees are comprised of a base fee for the contracted services described above and, in some instances, other additional fees such as fees in connection with helping file tax forms or fees related to rent payment guarantees. We offer rent payment guarantees (“Garantie de loyers impayés” or “rent payment guarantee”) to certain residential landlords in France for whom we provide property management services and an occupancy guarantee (“Garantie d’occupation” or “occupancy guarantee”) to a small number of lessors to protect against vacant properties for up to six months if we are unable to find a tenant for selected apartments in new dwellings. In September 2022, approximately 66% of residential dwellings in France were covered by the rent payment guarantee, and approximately 13% of rentals are covered by the occupancy guarantee. We believe we have a strong ability to assess credit risk when offering these guarantees and undertake a detailed process to select eligible tenants and dwellings. We refer to the new unpaid rents as a result of defaults under the occupancy guarantee each month as “flow of unpaid rent,” and the total sum of unpaid rents per month as our “stock of unpaid rent.” In September 2022, €115.9 million of rent revenues were covered by the rent payment guarantee, for which we experienced €3.6 million new unpaid rent (compared to a 2021 monthly average of new unpaid rent of €3.1 million for €108.7 million covered rent revenues) and the cumulative aggregate of unpaid rent was €29.4 million, including outstanding rent payments from previous years. Once rent is reported as unpaid, any payments to landlords under these guarantees are recorded in full as a provision on our balance sheet. By underwriting rent payment guarantees and occupancy guarantees on our own balance sheet, we believe we offer a differentiating and competitive service to customers that smaller competitors would not be able to deliver. See “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial _Condition and Results of Operations—Key Factors Affecting Results of Operations—Rent payment and occupancy guarantees” and “Risk Factors—Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry—Low demand for housing generally or lease terminations and/or tenant defaults could adversely affect our fees and the income produced by the properties we manage, which may have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition or results of operations.”_ As of September 30, 2022, we had 376,262 dwellings under management in our Lease Management and Letting business in France, generating a revenue of €254.6 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2022, representing 27.0% of our total revenue for the same period (this includes Foncia Immo Neuf, CAI and Holiday Rental). Revenues are driven by rent evolution, fees as a percent of rent (on units acquired), and add-on services and volumes are driven by apartments under lease management and tenant mobility rates. We operate primarily in the residential real estate services market, but manage certain commercial real estate properties through Esset. See “—French B2B Services.” Through our renting services, we aim to minimize the vacancy rates of the properties by helping landlords find a suitable tenant and helping tenants find a property to rent. For landlords, we manage ----- the sourcing, screening, and contracting of new tenants, and provide services such as posting advertisements on various real estate portals, showcasing their properties in Foncia branches and providing structured feedback on renting efforts. For tenants, we assist lessees with leasing rental properties and we receive one-off placement fees for these services. For the nine months ended September 30, 2022, we assisted with 52,915 rentals in France. Our services include access to a large number of rental home insurance packages and fixture inventory programs offered by professionals who are available on short notice.

We completed over 12,994 transactions across France in the nine months ended September 30, 2022 and support our customers with all aspects of their property sales or purchases. Once we receive a mandate, we follow the sale through to completion. Our services include property viewings and search services, advice and assistance with banking and administrative formalities, property appraisals, buyer solvency assessments, market analysis, assistance complying with regulatory requirements, and drafting sale agreements. Our Brokerage business is conducted primarily through mandates, exclusive or shared, and fees for such mandate in the event of a transaction are calculated on a flat-rate basis. This rate usually comprises an average of 5% of the selling price of the property. Revenue are recognized upon signature of the notarized final sale agreement (acte authentique). For further discussion on notary execution, see “Regulation.” Our Brokerage business provides ample opportunities for cross-selling services, such as property appraisals, brokerage insurance, technical surveys, and inventories services provided by our other businesses. See “—France B2B Services.” Our Brokerage business in France generated a revenue of €125.8 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2022, representing 13.3% of our total revenue for the same period.

We are the global leader in the RRES market, serving customers in France, Switzerland, Benelux, Germany and the UK We maintain an integrated business model with operations across a wide range of businesses, with recognized brand names in the countries in which we operate. Our unique business model provides for cross-selling opportunities, which help us achieve recurring and predictable revenues and strong cash flows.

Efficity Efficity is a national network of independent real estate consultants and is a leader in online real estate valuation. Lodgis Lodgis is a listing service for furnished rentals. Assurimo Assurimo provides property insurance brokerage services. Seiitra Seiitra provides specialist IT property services and develops software, to RRES professionals which it markets through the sale of software licenses.

Since 2003, we have expanded our services outside of France and in the nine months ended September 30, 2022, we generated 14.8% of our revenue in our international operations. We have acquired ----- recognizable brands in Switzerland, Benelux, Germany and the UK, and have reached leading positions in these markets for our real estate services. Our average international headcount for employees in 2021 increased to 1,630, compared to 1,430 in 2020. As a result of the closing of the FirstPort acquisition in August 2022, our international services business will represent a greater portion of our group revenue going forward. The chart below provides a revenue breakdown for the nine months ended September 30, 2022 of our international operations by country: _Switzerland_ We entered the Swiss market in 2004 through the acquisition of the real estate services group, GECO. In 2015, we reinforced our position in the French-speaking region of Switzerland with the acquisition of Domicim, and we entered the German-speaking regions of Switzerland in 2019 through the acquisition of Gribi. We have since strengthened our position in German-speaking Switzerland through our 2021 acquisition of Intercity. As of September 30, 2022, we have 28 branches in Switzerland and all of our operations were managed under DBS Group which includes 11 recognizable brands Domicim, Brolliet, Duc-Sarrasin, Elitim, Batiline, Facilitim, Immosure, Gribi, IntercityGribi, GUINNARD and Bruchez & Gaillard. While we offer all of our primary services in Switzerland, our Brokerage business is characterized by transactions on whole buildings (sales in blocs), rather than individual units. We are also involved in sales of new buildings for promoters. For the nine months ended September 30, 2022, our operations in Switzerland generated €54.2 million in revenue. _Benelux_ We entered the Belgium market under the Trevi brand, which we acquired in May 2013 through a reverse takeover that enabled us to retain a successful local management team. We have 20 branches in Belgium, which are primarily located in the greater Brussels area, as well as in Flanders. In addition, we have 28 Trevi Partner agencies which are operated by independent third parties under the Trevi brand. We believe we are one of the largest residential real estate services group in Belgium and now operate under the OP Brand. In December 2020, we acquired OP to strengthen our service offerings in Belgium and to enter the Luxembourg market through its branches in the country. In January 2022 we acquired Codabel and the property management business of Cushman & Wakefield Asset Services Belgium, which will be combined under the Esset Property Management brand to cover Belgium, the Netherlands and Luxembourg. In the third quarter of 2022, we acquired Syncura, the leading RRES player in Flanders headquartered in Ghent. For the nine months ended September 30, 2022, our operations in Benelux generated €25.5 million in revenue. ----- _UK_ We entered the UK market in August 2022 through the acquisition of FirstPort, one of the UK’s largest property services groups and the UK’s largest joint property manager with approximately 315,000 units under management as of March 2022, an orderbook of approximately 98,000 units and a market share of approximately 11%, twice the size of its closest competitor in the UK The purchase price for the acquisition was financed by drawings under Additional Facility B1 under the Senior Credit Facilities and an equity contribution of €114.5 million, signaling continued support from the Sponsors. FirstPort operates primarily in the joint property management, rental management and real estate brokerage markets in England, Scotland and Wales with a strong geographical coverage in each of these nations. FirstPort generated €120 million in revenue and employed over 3,800 employees in 2021. FirstPort operates an in-house digital platform, which enables it to offer a fully automated and readily scalable service proposition and supports FirstPort’s continuous growth through strong organic development, mobilization of the order book and accretive acquisitions. FirstPort benefits from recurring revenue streams with high visibility, with 92% of its revenues being recurring or re-occurring, consisting of 60% of contracted management fee revenues with in-built inflationary price increases and 32% of annually repeating revenues from ancillary services linked to units under management. In addition, 8% of revenues are linked to property transaction levels which are relatively predictable given the portfolio size. FirstPort demonstrated a strong financial track record with its revenues increasing at a CAGR of 17.16% to £97.3 million for the year ended December 31, 2021, up from £60.5 million for the year ended December 31, 2019, its reported EBITDA increasing at a CAGR of 17.0% to £20.5 million for the twelve months ended September 30, 2021, up from £12.8 million for the year ended December 31, 2019 and its free cash flow, defined as reported EBITDA adjusted for movements in net working capital and maintenance capital expenditure, increasing to £15.1 million for the year ended December 31, 2021, up from £9.3 for the year ended December 31, 2019. For the nine months ended September 30, 2022, our operations in the UK generated €11.0 million in revenue which reflects the revenue generated by FirstPort from the date of completion of the acquisition on August 18, 2022 (when it was first consolidated in our financial results) until September 30, 2022. _Germany_ We entered the German market in 2003 through the acquisition of FONCIA VOW Verwaltungsorganisation für die Wohnungswirtschaft GmbH & Co.KG. Our dynamic external growth policy enabled us to establish our presence in Germany, and our latest acquisitions include Vegis and Prazisa in June and July 2019, Sogertec in October 2020 and Paul Immobilien in September 2020. We operate under several brands in Germany, mainly REANOVO and Optima, with a presence in 60 branches. We are recognized as a leader in Joint Property Management in a highly fragmented German market composed of relatively small local players. For the nine months ended September 30, 2022, our operations in Germany generated €48.8 million in revenue.

Esset Management Esset Management provides property management services (jointly owned property management and rental services) for B2B customers such as national and international insurance, real estate and financial institutions. Our Digital businesses and B2B businesses generated revenues of €89.4 million and €44.0 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2022, respectively.

Digital transformation is at the heart of our operations and we believe it will improve the efficiency of our operations and commercial development, while providing unique and differentiated services to customers. From inception, we have appreciated the importance of creating an efficient platform in order to better serve our customers, and understand the dynamics of our market and improve our employees responsiveness and efficiency. IT systems impact virtually all aspects of our business, including record keeping, customer information processing and storage, data security, marketing and ----- sales, compliance logistics, and practice and performance management. Our IT strategy is driven by the dual goals of promoting growth of our business while ensuring data security. Our most recent digital innovation is Millenium, our new enterprise resource planning (“ERP”) system that we developed in-house, and we launched a go-live version of it in March 2020 at one of our branches in France. We have invested significant resources in Millenium, including a team currently consisting of 68 developers in order to build this innovative and advanced real estate platform. We launched Millenium on all brokerage activities in France in early 2022, and launched the broader rollout of Millenium in our French RRES business in November 2022 (10 Métropoles), initially in operations covering approximately 252,859 Joint Property Management dwellings and 67,701 Lease Management dwellings. We aim to accelerate the roll-out of Millenium across our broader operations in the first quarter of 2023. Millenium includes numerous functionalities and unifies a number of our IT functions at our head office under one centralized database. It is managed by an experienced team of information specialists. Business applications for each of our activities have been developed with Millenium, including our Joint Property Management business, Lease Management and Letting business, and Brokerage Business, as well as our accounting department, support call center and web and mobile applications. Millenium is equipped with an application interface program, which is a technology that allows for a direct access to other software solutions, startups, and business partners. For example, Millenium is connected to Kyriba, an online platform for viewing bank transaction in real time, which we use to manage our Joint Property Management cash transactions involving approximately 120,000 bank accounts. Millenium also functions with Docapost, an online, information technology company, which we utilize to collect and scan checks, and send and receive approximately 3.1 million invoices per year. Millenium provides, among other features, (i) increased digitization of activities, including the ability to use online signatures and receive digital payments, (ii) greater transparency with our customers, as employee progress on customer matters can be seen in real time and customer calls are tracked using tickets, (iii) significant automation of the accounting activities, including automated rent reminders and rent payments (iv) the ability to better leverage our customer database to create inter-business synergies in compliance with European GDPR regulations, and (v) standardized processes across our businesses and substantial efficiencies due to a high degree of automation. Millenium also includes MyFoncia, a web and mobile app platform designed to improve customer experience through automation, digitization, and improved productivity for our customers to use for all of their service needs. In parallel to the deployment of Millenium, we have designed a new operational model called Agency of the Future which was implemented following the roll-out of Millenium in France in 2022. Agency of the Future will utilize Millenium to reorganize the residential real estate services and aims to improve client satisfaction, reducing our customer churn rate and, in turn, leading to greater opportunities for organic growth. See “Summary—Our Strengths—Continuous investments in operational improvement _through our innovative technology platforms reinforces our competitive position and provides sustainable efficiency gains.”_ In the coming years, as part of our Agency of the Future initiatives, we plan to fully digitalize all business lines, internal processes, and our customer relationship management. In addition, we aim to increase our use of big data, artificial intelligence and IoT and continue to further automate our accounting. We believe that the improved standardization and digitization Millenium offers, will allow us to reduce administrative inefficiencies and achieve greater productivity. In addition, we believe that Millenium will enable us to achieve greater organization among our businesses allowing our employees to focus on customer satisfaction with the potential to lead to improved customer retention. It may also lead to new business opportunities, which could include big data or machine learning and licensing opportunities. -----

The real estate sector is responsible for approximately 25% of greenhouse gas emissions in France and plays a decisive role in the fight against climate change. The environmental impact of a building is influenced by three factors, including: (i) the performance of the building itself; (ii) the management and the maintenance of its equipment; and (iii) occupant behaviors. Our objective is to improve our impact on the environment and our commitment is driven by these three factors. We are focused on promoting energy renovation, developing more sustainable building management by measuring the energy consumption of our park and setting targets to improve future performance, raising awareness, and supporting our customers in making better use of resources.

We have over 134 and 131 branches dedicated to our RRES and Brokerage businesses, respectively, and 242 branches dedicated to both businesses throughout France and, by the nature of our activity, we aim to contribute to the economic development of the communities in which we operate. We wish to assume and reaffirm our role as a partner and supporter of our customers and other stakeholders at the local and national levels, and aim to accomplish this through a number of measures. For example, by strengthening and enhancing our territorial anchoring, focusing on our recruitment efforts, concentrating on our choice of and support from our suppliers and reinforcing our commitment as a good corporate citizen. We also seek to develop a dialogue with our stakeholders and improve our communication on topics of interest to our stakeholders.

We service the homes of more than seven million people in France, Switzerland, Benelux, Germany and the UK. As a key local player, we are committed to sustainable housing improved well-being, and better living for our customers, tenants, residents, communities, and other stakeholders in the residential real estate sector. We achieve this through our corporate social responsibility strategy, which is based on three key commitments: supporting sustainable energy in the buildings and dwellings we manage, improving the well- being of our customers in ensuring fair and non-discriminatory access to housing and assisting local communities. From this mission stems the responsibility to provide solutions to environmental and social issues in our sector, and to contribute to more sustainable lifestyles. We have developed a number of ESG initiatives that measure and aim to improve on annual basis. For example, track our carbon footprint and aim to reduce it each year. We also closely consider the impact that our clients, contractors and suppliers have on the environment and we aim to work with those who seek to improve efficiency, conserve natural resources and reduce waste and emissions. In addition, we focus on energy transition of buildings under management by developing services and solutions to enable our clients to renovate and finance their dwellings. In 2021, one of our goals related to corporate social responsibility is to ensure that all of our building managers are systematically trained to lead such renovation projects and partner with clients and employees who demonstrate a commitment to the environment. In the third quarter of 2022, we appointed a new Vice President of ESG and Strategy, with an aim to drive the further development of our ESG objectives, action plans and reporting.

Subsection Title: Well-being of our Customers and Employees
Subsubsection Text: The majority of our business lines have low customer concentration. Our Lease Management and Letting, and Brokerage businesses are focused almost exclusively on serving individual customers. Our Joint Property Management business is focused on serving condominium corporations, which are primarily individual entities, rather than on B2B master agreements with institutional property customers. Of our businesses, Esset has the highest customer concentration. Esset’s largest customer represented 10% of its total revenues for the nine months ended September 30, 2022.

Subsection Title: Well-being of our Customers and Employees
Subsubsection Text: As of September 30, 2022, we employed approximately 11,000 full time employees in our operations in France and approximately 5,700 full time employees outside of France. Despite the macroeconomic impact of the COVID-19 pandemic, we added 884 full-time, permanent employees to our headcount in 2020. The majority of our employees work full-time employees; however, we have increasingly relied on temporary employees, including hourly, part- time, and temporary workers, to better adapt to the seasonality of our business. The following table shows the average number of employees as of December 31, 2020 and 2021 and as of September 30, 2022:

Subsection Title: Well-being of our Customers and Employees
Subsubsection Text: We are aware of the rapid changes in lifestyles and ways of living in Europe, and we aim to actively contribute to the improvement of the quality of life of our customers and our employees. This involves securing not only a healthy living and working environment, but also a better understanding of the societal transformations at work including developments in the digital space, new uses, and the development of associated responses. Finally, we believe a commitment to quality of life also implies implementing concrete actions against discrimination, particularly in terms of access to housing and the fight against absentee landlords. -----

Subsection Title: Nine months ended Year Ended** **September December 31,** **30, 2020** **2021** **2022
Subsubsection Text: Average headcount – France .................................................................. 9,145 10,115 10,935 Average headcount – International ......................................................... 1,430 1,630 5,710 We believe our people are fundamental to our continued success, as their skills and dedication enable us to grow and lead the market. We invest, and will continue to invest, in the development of our employees. For example, we provide training on company policies such as data protection and privacy, health and safety, anti- discrimination, ethics, sustainability and anti-bribery, among others. In addition, we believe the implementation of Millenium will result in productivity and efficiency gains, such as the automation of processes and controls, that will lead to streamlined procedures and settings for our front office and administrative staff. We cooperate with local unions, employee representatives, health, safety and working conditions committee and work councils in France where these representative bodies are active. In these jurisdictions, we normally have framework agreements or other general agreements in place, which are agreed through discussions with the works councils and compliant with local labor laws. These agreements govern, among other things, working conditions, working hours and the definition of tariff groups. These agreements can be negotiated for a limited or unlimited term, and can be cancelled by either party in favor of renegotiation. These bodies have clearly defined powers and we are required to consult and inform their members on a periodic basis about the implementation of projects relating to the situation of our employees. We are also required to consult our work council for the acquisition we are contemplating and for the integration of our acquired businesses. As we typically complete multiple acquisitions every month, we have, therefore, agreed to meet with our work council on a monthly basis to specifically discuss potential acquisitions and the integration of the recently completed acquisitions. We believe we have good relationships with our employees, and open and constructive working relationships with such employee representation bodies across our various regions. -----

We have been, and may from time to time be, a party to legal disputes and administrative proceedings within the scope of our business activities. As of the date of this Offering Memorandum, we are not involved in any material claims, lawsuits, investigations, or proceedings, and there are no such material claims, lawsuits, investigations or proceedings threatened against us. See “Risk Factors—Risks Relating _to Our Business and Industry—We are subject to various litigation risks and may face financial liabilities and/or damage to our reputation as a result of litigation.”_

The French rental market is highly regulated. We are not subject to a specific regulatory framework that governs the operation of our business. However, our primary business offerings require that we comply with regulations affecting the real estate industry and maintain licenses in the various jurisdictions in which we operate and adhere to data protection standards. Like other market participants that operate in numerous jurisdictions and in various businesses, we must comply with a myriad of regulatory regimes. Some of the most significant regulations to which we are subject to include the European GDPR, the ALUR law, the ELAN the PINEL plan and the Hoguet law. For information about these regulations and their impact on our business, please see “Regulation.”

_France_ Our Paris offices serve as our group headquarters. They house our core group-wide and French operational, management and planning functions. We do not own any real estate and all of our properties are leased pursuant to leases on customary terms. In France, we had approximately 939 property leases, of which more than 27% were tacitly renewed, including our 134 and 131 branches dedicated to our RRES and Brokerage businesses, respectively, and our 242 branches dedicated to both businesses, in each case as of the nine months ended September 30, 2022. These contracts are managed using a dynamic approach directly in line with the operating performance of our branch network and real estate strategy. As at September 30, 2022, our key leases in France include the head office at Antony, Rue de Provence, Rue Raymond Losserand and Boulevard de Courcelles premises in Paris and the Esset Management’s premises at Courbevoie. _Switzerland, Benelux, Germany and the UK_ Our headquarters in Switzerland, Benelux, Germany and the UK are located in Lausanne, Brussels, Essen and London, respectively. Each office is responsible for the operations in their respective countries, excluding a few exceptions, such as M&A transactions. We do not own any real estate and all of our properties are leased pursuant to leases on customary terms. In Switzerland, Benelux, Germany and the UK, we had approximately 340 property leases. As at September 30, 2022, our key leases outside of France are the Brolliet premises in Switzerland and the Vegis, Foncia Maiberger, and Foncia Deutschland premises in Germany.

The real estate services market is highly fragmented, however, the industry has recently experienced a period of active consolidation marked by an increase in M&A activity and the emergence of larger companies. We compete for customers on the basis of customer service, service offerings, reputation, and the ability to tailor our services to the specific needs of a customer, and we believe our size and our unique, nationwide network sets us apart from our competitors. See “Risk Factors—Risks Relating to _Our Business and Industry—We have numerous local, regional and national competitors across all of our businesses and the geographies that we serve, and further industry consolidation, fragmentation or innovation could lead to significant future competition.” In France, our main competitors include_ Nexity, Citya, Square Habitat, and Credit Agricole Immobilier in the RRES market, BNP Paribas Real ----- Estate and Nexity in the commercial property management market and Orpi, Century21, Citya, Guy Hoquet, and Laforet in the Brokerage market. In Switzerland, our largest competitors are Wincasa, Livit, and Privera. In Benelux, we believe our largest competitor is Lamy (Nexity). In the UK our main competitors are R&R, HML and Pinnacle in the Joint Property Market. In Germany, the largest market participant is ECE, focusing on the retail segment, followed by Strabag and Apleona with large commercial portfolios, and Capera, Treureal, and DIM on the residential side. For a further description of our industry and the competitive landscape in which we operate, see “Industry.”

We have registered several trademarks in France, Switzerland, Benelux, Germany and the UK, and at the European Union Trademark Database. We regard our trademarks and other intellectual property as valuable assets in the marketing of our services, in particular, our “Foncia” trademark and the rights associated with our new Millenium ERP IP. However, as we operate distinct businesses and brands for our various service offerings and across geographies, we consider all of these core brands to be an integral part of our business, and we take appropriate action when necessary to protect them and, when necessary, enforce them. See “Risk Factors— Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry—Our brands _and our reputation are key assets of our company, which will be affected by how we are perceived in the marketplace.”_

We have a number of insurance policies in place, including in connection with professional and civil responsibilities based on our role as a real estate services provider, premises damages, D&O, cyber, and IT- related insurance. Some of our real estate servicing contracts require that we maintain certain levels of insurance. We believe we have adequate insurance coverage against material risks that are typically insured by similar companies with comparable risk exposure. Insurance coverage is regularly verified and adjusted when necessary; however, our insurance may not cover every potential risk associated with our business. See “Risk Factors—Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry—Our insurance _coverage may not be sufficient.”_ -----

_The market information presented in this section is taken directly or derived from the cited sources and extrapolations from third-party and publicly available data, including an industry report prepared by a leading consulting firm (an “international report provider”). Market data are inherently forward- looking and subject to uncertainty, and do not necessarily reflect actual market conditions. They are based on market research, which itself is based on market data sampling and judgments by the researchers about what types of products and competitors should be included in the relevant market. While we have compiled, extracted and reproduced market or other industry data from external sources, including third party or industry or general publications, the Senior Secured Notes Issuer, the Guarantors or the Initial Purchasers have not independently verified such data. The primary market information derived from an international report provider was prepared in August 2019. Therefore, the market and industry data included below may not accurately reflect certain aspects of the current market and industry and should not be unduly relied upon. See “Industry and Market Data” for further detail. We have provided updates to some of the key metrics that underpin our markets to the extent third party data was available. We do not intend to and do not assume any obligations to further update any data, including industry and market data, set forth in this Offering Memorandum._ We are the global leader in the residential real estate services market, providing services to both individuals (“business-to-consumer” or “B2C”) and businesses (“business-to-business” or “B2B”), and have also entered the commercial real estate services segment for B2B customers. We assist our residential and commercial customers at every stage of their property journey with competitive and comprehensive service offerings.

We are not subject to a specific regulatory framework that governs the operation of our business, although there are a number of regulations we must comply with as we deliver our primary service offerings to our customers. These regulations vary between one jurisdiction to another and also between our businesses. See “Risk Factors—Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry—Our businesses, _financial condition, results of operations and prospects could be adversely affected by new laws or regulations or by changes in existing laws or regulations or the application thereof. If we fail to comply with laws and regulations applicable to us, or make incorrect determinations in complex tax regimes, we may incur significant financial penalties.”_

We acquire and process personal data on customers and customers during the course of our activities and our databases contain personal data of customers and customers. Our ability to obtain, retain and process such personal data is governed by data protection and privacy regulations and guidance issued by, among others, the European Union, national regulators and, where applicable, recommendations and best practices developed by trade associations. The EU General Data Protection Regulation (Regulation (EU) 2016/679 (“GDPR”)) became effective as of May 25, 2018. The GDPR provides a common framework for data protection and privacy and regulates the Processing and transfer of Personal Data in the European Union. In the course of our activities, we may be qualified as “Controllers,” or as “Processor,” as defined and governed by GDPR, depending on the services provided and the service agreement entered into. We established our compliance program with GDPR quite early and we comply with the GDPR obligations, and rights for individuals whose Personal Data we Process (“Data Subjects”), including, among others: - accountability and transparency obligations, requiring us to demonstrate and record compliance with the GDPR, including the maintenance of detailed records of Personal Data Processing activities; - appointment of a data protection officer, subject to the satisfaction of certain criteria; - requirements to Process Personal Data lawfully, fairly, and in a transparent manner, to Process Personal Data only to the extent necessary for the purposes required, maintain the accuracy of Personal Data, limit the retention of Personal Data for no longer than is necessary, and maintain appropriate technical and organizational security measures against unauthorized Processing or accidental loss, destruction or damage to Personal Data; - an obligation to provide clear notice of Personal Data Processing activities to Data Subjects, which must include, among other details: the identity of the Controller and the Processor; the nature and purpose of the Processing activities; the legal basis applicable to each Processing activity; the categories of Personal Data Processed, the recipients to whom the Personal Data ----- are disclosed; the rights of the Data Subjects; and details of any cross-border transfers of Personal Data; - an obligation to include certain mandatory contractual terms in agreements with certain service providers which Process Personal Data on our behalf; - restrictions on the export of Personal Data to recipients located in countries outside of the European Economic Area; - requirements to ensure, for each Processing activity, that either (i) there is a valid legal basis in place; or (ii) an exemption or derogation applies; - obligations to consider data protection issues with respect to the development of any new products or services which involve the Processing of Personal Data (“data protection by design”), and to ensure that by default, the amount of Personal Data Processed is limited to what is necessary in the context of the relevant Processing activity (“data protection by default”); - a requirement to undertake a data protection impact assessment with respect to Processing activities that are likely to result in a high risk to the rights and freedoms of relevant Data Subjects; - obligations to comply with the data protection rights conferred on Data Subjects including, in certain circumstances: a right of access to, and rectification of, Personal Data; a right to obtain restriction of Processing; a right to object to Processing; a right to request that Personal Data be transferred to another Controller; a right not to be subject to certain types of profiling or automated decision-making; and a right to request erasing Personal Data; and - an obligation to notify Personal Data Breaches to Supervisory Authorities without undue delay and no later than 72 hours after detection of the relevant Personal Data Breach, except where the Personal Data Breach is unlikely to result in a risk to the rights and freedoms of individuals, and an obligation to notify affected Data Subjects without undue delay, unless the Personal Data Breach is unlikely to result in a high risk to the rights and freedoms of the affected Data Subjects. The GDPR has therefore strengthened the individual rights of individuals over their personal data and imposes strict requirements on companies processing personal data. In addition, the GDPR introduces fines for serious breaches of up to the higher of 4% of annual worldwide revenue or €20 million. The GDPR identifies a list of points to consider when determining the fine level to impose (including the nature, gravity and duration of the infringement). Data Subjects also have a right to compensation for financial or non-financial losses (e.g., distress) in certain circumstances. Data Subjects may bring complaints via the courts, or via Supervisory Authorities, or both, and in some circumstances may have a choice as to the EU Member State(s) in which they bring such claims. We accomplished a review of our data polices with the aim of minimizing data collection and storage so that only the appropriate amount of personal data required for any particular purpose is processed, and establishing protocols to destroy unnecessary datasets and anonymize data wherever possible. In addition, we have put in place and implemented rules, policies and procedures that we strive to maintain and improve, in order to ensure compliance with GDPR. These rules, policies and procedures are twofold: internal and external. These rules, policies and procedures, implemented at all levels of our business, apply to the processing of personal data, data storage, retention, preservation, maintenance, protection and management of personal data within the course of our business operations, as well as the transfer of personal data. Our legal team was intensely involved in the implementation of such rules, ----- policies and procedures and reviewed our activities and operations to implement a legal framework that complies with the GDPR requirements. We believe that we are compliant in all material respects with applicable data protection regulations and we submitted all the relevant declarations to the national regulators, the CNIL (Commission _Nationale de l’Informatique et des Libertés) in France and the BfDI (Der Bundesbeauftragte für den Datenschutz und die Informationsfreiheit) in Germany and the APD (Autorité de protection des données) in Belgium. We have appointed a Data Protection Officer, who is registered with the relevant_ regulator and who is in charge of all aspects of GDPR for the applicable country and, in particular, maintains data processing registers. As used herein, “Personal Data” has the meaning set out in the GDPR, “Personal Data Breach” has the meaning set out in the GDPR, and “Processing” has the meaning set out in the GDPR, and the terms “Process” and “Processed” shall be construed accordingly.

As part of certain operations, we follow anti-money laundering and counter-terrorist financing standards set forth in the applicable local laws implementing Directive (EU) 2005/60/EC on the prevention of the use of the financial system for the purpose of money laundering and terrorist financing. Our operations are also subject to requirements of local anti-money laundering laws. On May 20, 2015, Directive (EU) 2015/849 on the prevention of the use of the financial system for the purposes of money laundering or terrorist financing, amending Regulation (EU) No 648/2012, and repealing Directive 2005/60/EC (the “4th AML Directive”) was adopted by the European Parliament and the Council. The 4th AML Directive enhances the current customer due diligence requirements and also imposes stricter sanctions with administrative fines of at least €5,000,000 or 10% of total annual turnover. Directive (EU) 2018/843 (the “5th AML Directive”), amending the 4th AML Directive, was adopted by the European Parliament and the Council on May 30, 2018 and since then Directive (EU) 2018/1673 (the “6th AML Directive”) has been introduced and went into effect for EU Member States on December 3, 2020.

The Hoguet law (Loi n°70-9 réglementant les conditions d’exercice des activités relatives à certaines _opérations portant sur les immeubles et les fonds de commerce) was introduced in January 1970 and_ aimed at setting the legal framework for the profession of real estate agents in France and therefore applies to all of our employees who act as real estate agents on our behalf. The Hoguet law requires the execution of specific administrative formalities to be a professional real estate agent including: - holding a professional card (“carte professionnelle”) issued by the president of the territorial chamber of commerce and industry, which is subject to professional aptitude and morality conditions and is renewable every 3 years; - having a financial guarantee from a bank or professional organization for funds held in customer accounts and retaining professional liability insurance. ----- In accordance with this law, we provide financial guarantees to customers equal to the maximum amount of funds held in their account. The customer’s deposit must be held in a third-party account and be guaranteed by a third party financial guarantor, such as Société de caution mutuelle des professions _immobilières et foncières (SOCAF). This body guarantees reimbursement of any funds deposited with_ them for purchase. The name of the financial guarantor must be displayed in the agents office. Professional real estate agents must have a written mandate authorizing them to negotiate or enter into contracts on behalf of the owner or the property lessor. This mandate must therefore be finalized before any act of mediation or negotiation begins. This mandate must indicate the level of the fees or commission (honoraires) that will be payable and just who will pay it, the buyer or the seller. We maintain a register of such agreements with each agreement numbered and recorded in accordance with the Hoguet Law. Once the mandate is signed, the real estate agent is entitled to a commission in the event of the sale or lease of the property, subject to the mandate. The real estate agent’s right to commission is subject to multiple conditions and no sum of money may be demanded or remitted to the real estate agent before the transaction (i.e. sale, rental, etc.) is concluded and recorded in an act containing the commitment of the parties. The collection of a sum of money in violation of the Hoguet law is an offense punishable by up to two years’ imprisonment and a maximum fine of €30,000.

The ALUR law (Loi n°2014-366 pour l’accès au logement et un urbanisme rénové) was introduced in March, 2014 and aimed at improving access to housing and providing increased protection to tenants in the housing market within large cities and urban areas of France. The introduction of the ALUR law has had a number of effects in the way we conduct our operations across our core service offerings, including: - Joint property management: The ALUR law imposes a mandatory obligation on us as joint property managers to register each joint property we manage with the national matriculation register if not yet registered and also requires us to create two dedicated bank accounts for each joint property we manage. The law also introduces model joint property agreements that are applicable in our joint property management service. - Rental management and lettings: The ALUR law regulates which fees can and cannot be charged to tenants and how fees should be shared between tenants and landlords. Depending on the property’s location, it imposes a limit on the renting commission paid by tenants to an amount that must not exceed between €11-€15 per square meter. In addition to this fee cap, tenants can no longer be charged penalties for breaches to rental agreements or for rent payment notices. The law also introduced restrictions on the yearly rental escalations for residential properties in Paris. It also standardized certain administrative requirements for rental contracts through means such as model contracts and rental declaration forms for residential lettings.

The ELAN law (Loi n°2018-1021 portant évolution du logement, de l’aménagement et du numérique) was introduced in November 2018 and aimed to build more housing, simplify standards, protect the most fragile tenants and to introduce digital transitions in the service of tenants. The law created a new lease called a “mobility lease,” which is a non-renewable lease between one to ten months for certain categories of tenants, such as students and trainees, with flexible termination terms that allow the termination of a lease by the tenant upon the provision of only one months’ notice. Within municipalities of more than 50,000 inhabitants, where there is an imbalance between the supply and demand of housing, the law also imposes an obligation on landlords to set their rent within a range defined by the authorities each year. The introduction of the ELAN law has had a number of effects in the way we conduct our operations across our core service offerings, as it created an incentive for short-term rentals which may reduce the predictability of our revenue. -----

The PINEL plan refers to multiple laws introduced since 2014, which aimed to design and promote the construction of new build properties in designated areas. The PINEL plan provided income tax deductions to private individuals who invested in these new build properties, provided the properties were put up for rent for at least six years. This plan has had a direct impact on fees that property managers can charge for their services. For example, it restricts the freedom of the landlord and tenant to contract with regards to expenses which cannot be recovered from tenants. Non-recoverable expenses include structural repairs and repairs under article 606 of the French Civil Code, taxes such as the “Territorial Economic Contribution” where the landlord is personally liable for payment and the management fees of the landlord linked to rents management. As a result, landlords are no longer able to recover fees from tenants for certain expenses for major repairs, regional economic contribution taxes and fees related to rental management. The PINEL plan also introduced rules governing commercial leases including rules limiting the ability of a landlord to impose rental increases and granting tenants a right of first refusal in the event of the sale of leased commercial property. The plan provides for the mandatory use of national indexes provided by the national statistics bureau of France (INSEE) for the calculation of revised rents for commercial activity premises and is applicable during the life of the lease.

Subsubsection Title: Eviction Laws and the Winter Truce
Subsubsection Text: _Eviction Laws_ On July 9, 1991 a new law (Loi n° 91-650 du 9 juillet 1991 portant réforme des procédures civiles _d’exécution) introduced the eviction regime into the law of civil enforcement proceedings. This law_ introduces, in article L411-1 of the Code of Civil Enforcement Procedures (Code de Procédure Civile), the condition that an eviction can only take place by virtue of a court decision where the occupiers were notified. A tenant can be evicted for failure to pay the rent when due and also for breaches of lease agreements. In the event that the tenant fails to pay rent, the landlord is required to follow various mandatory steps, including filing of a payment instruction notice (Commandement de payer). This notice sets a time limit for a tenant to pay the outstanding rental and must delivered by a bailiff (huissier _de justice). The time limits provided by this notice are two months for a residential lease and one month_ for a commercial lease. If the tenant fails to pay the rental arears within the stipulated time, the landlord can apply to the court for the cancellation of the lease. Upon the determination of the court proceedings, the court will often provide for an installment payment of the rent arrears and stipulate that the tenant voluntarily move out within a period of two months. The bailiff and the police will forcibly remove the tenant if the tenant fails to move out within this period. _Winter Truce_ The winter truce is the period during which any tenant eviction measure is suspended. This rule was introduced on July 9, 1991 (Loi n° 91-650 du 9 juillet 1991 portant réforme des procédures civiles _d’exécution). The regime provides that a landlord can begin proceedings during the winter truce to seek_ to evict tenants who do not pay rent, or who refuse to leave after receiving the contractual notice period. However, eviction requires a court order from a judge, which can be appealed by the tenant. Once a final judgment is made, the landlord is able to give an eviction order to the tenant with a minimum notice period of at least two months for the tenant to vacate the leased premises (the length of this period will depend on the court order). Notwithstanding the foregoing, the eviction of the tenant cannot take place during the winter truce, which is in effect between November 1 and March 1 of the following year. In 2014, the ALUR law expanded the winter truce period to five full months, from November 1 to March 31 of the following year. This period was extended to July 10 as an exceptional measure for 2020 only, as part of the emergency measures taken by the French government in response to the COVID-19 pandemic. -----

In France, the parties are free to enter into any agreed terms regarding rental deposits. The terms of the deposit should explain what the deposit is expected to cover. For example, the rental deposit terms can provide that the rent, repairs, service charge, dilapidations and rates are covered. These terms could also be widely drafted to cover any liabilities owed by the tenant at the end of the tenancy. The amount of the deposit is, in part, regulated by the law which provides that the maximum amount of the deposit for unfurnished properties will be one month, with no maximum for furnished properties. The rent deposit paid at the beginning of the tenancy must be refunded at the end of the rental period. The landlord or their representative has one month to refund the security deposit if the final inventory is consistent with the initial inventory and if there is no outstanding rent or tax to be paid. This period may be extended to two months if there are differences between the initial and final inventories. The time frame to refund the deposit begins on the day the tenant returns the keys for the premises (in person or by registered letter with acknowledgement of receipt). In the event the security deposit is not refunded, the outgoing tenant must send a formal demand to the landlord by registered letter with acknowledgement of receipt. If, despite this action being taken, the landlord refuses to refund the security deposit, the tenant can refer the case to the regional mediation commission (Commission Départementale de Conciliation). If this mediation process proves unsuccessful, the tenant can then go before the small-claims court (juge de proximité) if the value of the claim is less than €4,000, or the district court (tribunal d’instance). If the amount of the security deposit exceeds €4,000, the tenant must send an assignation, which will be prepared and delivered by a bailiff to the landlord. -----

As a real estate business operating in France with a primary focus on residential real estate property management and real estate property transaction brokerage, we are subject to the general application of the laws and regulations provided below. See also “Risk Factors—Risks Relating to Our Business and _Industry—Our businesses, financial condition, results of operations and prospects could be adversely affected by new laws or regulations or by changes in existing laws or regulations or the application thereof. If we fail to comply with laws and regulations applicable to us, or make incorrect determinations in complex tax regimes, we may incur significant financial penalties.”_

Subsection Title: MANAGEMENT The Senior Secured Notes Issuer
Subsubsection Text: Emeria is organized as a simplified joint stock company (société par actions simplifiée unipersonnelle) under the laws of France, and is registered in France under the sole identification number 820 204 766 RCS Nanterre. It was incorporated on October 11, 2016. The business address for the Senior Secured Notes Issuer is 13 Avenue Lebrun 92160 Antony, France. Pursuant to French law governing simplified joint stock companies and the Senior Secured Notes Issuer’s articles of association, its affairs are managed by a President (président) assisted by, as the case may be, one or more managing directors _(directeurs généraux). The President is assisted by an Executive Committee (the “Executive_ Committee”). The President of the Senior Secured Notes Issuer is under the control of a supervisory board (conseil de surveillance) (the “Supervisory Board”). For a discussion on the Supervisory Board, see “—Supervisory Board.” As of the date of this Offering Memorandum, Hodpar SAS. (a company directly controlled and managed by Mr. Philippe Salle) serves as President of the Senior Secured Notes Issuer. For a biography of Mr. Philippe Salle, see “President.” Pursuant to the articles of association of the Senior Secured Notes Issuer, when the President or a member of the Supervisory Board is a legal person, then such legal person shall be represented by his legal representative or any other natural person specially authorized to represent it. When a legal person is appointed President, its officers are subject to the same conditions and obligations and incur the same civil and criminal liabilities as if they were President in their own name of the Senior Secured Notes Issuer, without prejudice to the joint and several liability of the legal person they manage. _President_ The President is appointed by the Supervisory Board of the Senior Secured Notes Issuer for an indefinite period. The President of the Senior Secured Notes Issuer is Hodpar SAS. _Hodpar SAS. Established in 2021, Hodpar SAS is a simplified joint stock company managed, wholly_ owned (directly or indirectly) and represented by Philippe Salle. Hodpar SAS has been President of the Senior Secured Notes Issuer since October 2021 and has been represented by Phillippe Salle since its incorporation. Hodpar SAS is also a member of the board of directors of Banque Transatlantique. _Philippe Salle. Mr. Salle has been President and Chief Executive Officer (as permanent representative_ of Finellas SAS and now Hodpar SAS) of the Senior Secured Notes Issuer since December 2017. Mr. Salle is also the Chairman of the Board of Directors of the CGG Group since April 26, 2018. Mr. Salle started his career at Total, in Indonesia, before joining Accenture in 1990. He joined McKinsey in 1995 and became senior manager in 1998. The following year, he joined Vedior group (now known as Randstad) and was appointed Chairman and Chief Executive Officer of Vedior France in 2002. He joined the Management Board of Vedior NV in 2003 and was appointed Chairman of the Southern Europe zone (France, Spain, Italy and Switzerland) in 2006. He was an executive officer of Geoservices Group (sold in 2010 to Schlumberger) from 2007 to 2011, a technology company in the petroleum sector, first as Deputy Chief Executive Officer and then as Chairman and Chief Executive Officer. From 2011 to 2015, he served as Chairman and Chief Executive Officer of the group Altran, a world leader in innovation and engineering consulting firm. Mr. Salle then became Chairman and Chief Executive Officer of Elior Group, a world leader in catering and services, a position he held until October 31, 2017, before joining the Senior Secured Notes Issuer, as President and Chief Executive Officer. Mr. Salle graduated from the Ecole des Mines de Paris (France) and holds an MBA from the Kellogg Graduate School of Management, Northwestern University (Chicago, United States). _Executive Committee_

Philippe Salle ................................................ 57 Chief Executive Officer ----- Antoine Grenier ............................................ 49 Chief Financial Officer Laurence Batlle ............................................. 49 President (Président) of Foncia SAS _Philippe Salle. For a biography of Mr. Philippe Salle, see “President.” above. Antoine Grenier. Mr. Grenier has been the Chief Financial Officer of the Senior Secured Notes Issuer_ since January 2018. He is in charge of the Senior Secured Notes Issuer’s finance, mergers and acquisitions and integration, legal, compliance, procurement and internal audit. Before joining the Management Board of the Senior Secured Notes Issuer, Mr. Grenier worked as a partner at Argon & Co., a management consulting firm. Between October 2011 and May 2015, Mr. Grenier served as deputy group Chief Financial Officer in charge of France, India and the transformation of the finance function and member of the management committee within the group Altran. Before taking on these responsibilities, Mr. Grenier worked for more than 10 years within the Schlumberger group, at the time, a world leader in petroleum services, and exercised a complementary panel of functions such as, internal auditor in Houston, Texas, regional financial director in North Africa, and Corporate Treasurer for Europe, Africa & Russia. His last mandate was as Chief Financial Officer of the Geoservices group acquired by Schlumberger in May 2010. Mr. Grenier graduated from Paris Dauphine University and obtained his MBA within the TRIUM alliance, delivered by the New York Stern Business School, the London School of Economics and HEC Paris. _Laurence Batlle. Laurence Batlle was appointed President of Foncia SAS, in charge of residential real_ estate services, in January 2022. She was previously Chairwoman of the Executive Board of RATP Dev (13 countries, 28,000 employees) and sat on the RATP Group Executive Board since January 1, 2017. She joined RATP Dev in 2007 as Chief Financial Officer. She became a member of the Executive Board in 2011, and was in charge of its Americas-Africa and Sightseeing business units from 2014 to 2016. Prior to joining RATP Dev, Laurence Batlle spent 14 years driving sales growth in major consulting firms, first for PricewaterhouseCoopers where she was made a partner in 2005 and then as VP Global Finance Support at Atos Origin. Laurence Batlle was also an independent Board member of Elior Group from 2014 to 2018, heading its Audit Committee. She has been a member of the Toronto Global Forum (International Economic Forum of the Americas) since 2019 and a member of the Dubai Future Council for Transportation since 2018. In 2021, she became a Non-Executive Director of the Areas group, owned by PAI Partners. A graduate of Harvard Business School and Institut Commercial de Nancy, Laurence Batlle is a Knight of the Legion of Honour and a Knight of the French National Order of Merit. _Supervisory Board Organization_ The Supervisory Board of the Senior Secured Notes Issuer exercises permanent control over the management of the Senior Secured Notes Issuer. The Supervisory Board can provide its observations to the shareholders on the reports provided by the President or the accounts for the closed financial year. At any time, the Supervisory Board can implement controls that it deems appropriate and require documents it deems useful to be communicated to its attention to aid the accomplishment of its objectives. The Supervisory Board is assisted by an Audit Committee, a Nomination and Compensation Committee and an Investment and Acquisition Committee (and any other committee that the Supervisory Board may deem appropriate to establish from time to time subject to the prior consultation of the President). _Members of the Supervisory Board_ The Supervisory Board is established to oversee the management of the Senior Secured Notes Issuer and is appointed by the shareholders of the Senior Secured Notes Issuer for an indefinite term. As of the date of this Offering Memorandum, the Supervisory Board is made up of one Chairman (président _du conseil de surveillance) and four additional members. It is constituted with the following members:_ ----- B. Prot Conseil N/A Chairman Compagnie de Romas N/A Member Kim Nguyen 47 Member Patrick Sader 44 Member Patrick Xin Du 32 Member The following are brief biographical descriptions of the members of the Supervisory Board mentioned above. The Supervisory Board also includes two observers with no voting rights. _B.Prot Conseil. B.Prot Conseil was appointed as Chairman on December 2, 2016. Created in 2015, B._ Prot Conseil is a French simplified joint stock company managed by Mr. Baudouin Prot. Mr. Prot is the former Chairman of the BNP Paribas Group and has been senior advisor to the Boston Consulting Group since July 2015. Within the BNP Paribas Group, Mr. Prot served as Chief Executive Officer from 2003 to 2011, then as Chairman from 2011 to 2014. Mr. Prot is also an independent administrator of Kering and Veolia. Mr. Prot graduated from HEC Paris and from the Ecole Nationale d’administration (ENA). _Compagnie de Romas. Compagnie de Romas was appointed as member of the Supervisory Board on_ September 29, 2016 and serves as a member of the Supervisory Board. Compagnie de Romas is a French simplified joint stock company created in 2005 and managed by Benoit Fournial. Mr. Fournial is also a member of the supervisory board and chairman of the audit committee of Immobilière Dassault SA, member of the supervisory board, chairman of the audit committee and chairman of the board of directors of New Primonial Holding and member of the supervisory board, chairman of the audit committee and chairman of the board of directors of Kereis. Mr. Fournial previously served as a member of the supervisory board and chairman of the audit committee of M1 Vies Habitat (formerly known as Logement Français SA). Mr. Fournial is the former deputy head-finance of Groupe Crédit Lyonnais and former Chief Executive Officer of Axa Immobilier SAS and former Chief Executive Officer of AXA Real Estate Investment Managers SA. Mr. Fournial received an undergraduate degree from ESSEC Business School and from Sciences Po. _Kim Nguyen. Mr. Nguyen was appointed as member of the Supervisory Board on September 29, 2016._ Mr. Nguyen is global co-head of Private Equity Services for Partners Group. Mr. Nguyen is also a member of the global investment committee and the private equity directs investment committee for Partners Group. Mr. Nguyen is also a member of the board of directors of Version 1 and Schleich. Prior to joining Partners Group, Mr. Nguyen worked at Bridgepoint, Nestlé and Bain & Company. Mr. Nguyen holds an MBA from the IMD Business School in Lausanne, Switzerland, and a master’s degree in industrial engineering from the Swiss Federal institute of Technology (ETH) in Zurich, Switzerland. _Patrick Sader. Mr. Sader was appointed as member of the Supervisory Board on December 10, 2021._ Mr. Sader is the co-head Europe Services Group of TA Associates. Mr. Sader holds a BA, Finance and Accounting from ESSEC Business School. _Patrick Xin Du. Mr. Du was appointed as member of the Supervisory Board on December 10, 2021._ Mr. Du has been a board member of Flamingo Lux II GP S.à r.l. since November 19, 2019. In addition, Mr. Du has been a Member of the Management of the Private Equity Services business unit of Partners Group since July 2015. Prior to joining Partners Group, he worked at EY Transaction Services from September 2013 to June 2015. Mr. Du holds an MSc from HEC Paris and a BA from the University of St. Gallen. -----

_The following provides a brief description of the main laws and regulations applicable to our business. Although the following brief description contains selected information concerning laws and regulations that we consider material, it is not an exhaustive account of all applicable laws and regulations. References and discussions to laws, regulations and other administrative and regulatory documents are entirely qualified by the full text thereof._

On December 10, 2021, certain affiliates of Partners Group entered into a shareholders’ agreement (the “Shareholders Agreement”) with, among others, certain affiliates of TA and certain other intermediary holding companies (collectively, the “Minority Co-Investors”). The Shareholders Agreement governs, among other things, the relationship between Partners Group and the Minority Co-Investors with respect to their interests in the parent holding companies of the Group, including the Senior Secured Notes Issuer and its subsidiaries. The Shareholders Agreement provides for certain governance rights and sets forth procedures to follow in connection with the appointment of the President and the Chief Executive Officer of the Senior Secured Notes Issuer as well as the appointment of the members of the Executive Committee and the Supervisory Board, notably the right for Partners Group to have at all times the majority of the voting rights at the Supervisory Board. For additional information on our governance, see “Management.” The Shareholders Agreement also contains provisions concerning, among other things: (i) transfers of shares of the parent holding companies of the Group; (ii) rights of first offer and lock-up periods in respect of such transfers; and (iii) tag-along and drag-along rights applicable in certain conditions. -----

As of the date of this Offering Memorandum, the issued share capital of the Senior Secured Notes Issuer amounted to €726,000,832 represented by 593,688,196 shares, each with a par value of €1. The Senior Secured Notes Issuer is wholly owned by the Senior Notes Issuer. The Senior Notes Issuer is indirectly controlled by funds managed and/or advised by Partners Group and holding together, indirectly, approximately 68.7% of the economic ownership of the Senior Notes Issuer. Through these funds, CDPQ and CIC Capital Corporation each hold a minority interest in the Senior Notes Issuer. Funds managed and/or advised by TA hold together, indirectly, approximately 25.0% of the economic ownership of the Senior Notes Issuer. The remaining 6.3% equity interests are held directly or indirectly by certain directors and members of management and certain directors.

Section Title: CERTAIN RELATIONSHIPS AND RELATED PARTY TRANSACTIONS
Subsubsection Text: The directors of Senior Secured Notes Issuer have received €260,000 in directors’ fees in the year ended December 31, 2021.

Section Title: CERTAIN RELATIONSHIPS AND RELATED PARTY TRANSACTIONS
Subsubsection Text: On December 10, 2021, Partners Group and TA entered into services agreements with the Senior Secured Notes Issuer, (as amended and restated since then, the “Services Agreements”) for the provision of general management and consulting services, strategic advice and analysis, identification of new acquisition and disposition opportunities, support for further financing activities, corporate finance services, marketing advice, advice on human resources issues and other advisory services. Under these Services Agreements, Partners Group and TA are entitled to an annual fee, payable in quarterly installments, as well as reimbursement for reasonable expenses.

Section Title: CERTAIN RELATIONSHIPS AND RELATED PARTY TRANSACTIONS
