Section Title: V** **- NOTES TO THE CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
Subsection Title: NOTE 1. GENERAL PRESENTATION Emeria, the European leader in residential real estate services
Subsubsection Text: As of 3 January 2022, the Group changed its corporate name to Emeria. This new identity is fully in line with the Group’s strategy to cement its position as the European leader in residential real estate services, recognised for its legal and accounting expertise as well as for its quality of service. Foncia Management, now trading as Emeria, continues to be the Group’s lead holding company. The Group changed its corporate name to Emeria, effective 3 January 2022. This new identity is fully in line with the Group’s strategy to cement its position as the European leader in residential real estate services, recognised for its legal and accounting expertise as well as for its quality of service. Foncia Management, now trading as Emeria, continues to be the Group’s lead holding company.

Section Title: V** **- NOTES TO THE CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
Subsubsection Text: Founded in 1972, Emeria is Europe’s leading provider of residential real estate services for both individuals and businesses, with over 17,000 employees in 2022. Emeria’s European banners specialise in the management of jointly owned properties, rentals, transactions and property management, and offer a broad range of real estate services, from surveys and technical diagnostics to insurance brokerage, security, maintenance work for jointly owned properties, and lettings. With approximately €1.1 billion in revenue in 2021, Emeria is the leader in jointly owned property management services, rental management and lettings in Germany, Belgium, France and the United Kingdom, and second in Switzerland. Also present in Luxembourg, the Netherlands and Portugal, Emeria is one of the leading European property management companies in the B2B segment. In 2022, Emeria had more than 700 branches in Europe serving over 3.5 million customers. Today, Emeria is mainly present in Germany under the Reanovo trademark, in Belgium under the OP and Trevi trademarks, in France where it has traded under the Foncia banner for the past 50 years along with the Assurimo, Constatimmo, Efficity, Lodgis, Tech-Way, Seiitra and Stares trademarks, in the UK under the FirstPort trademark, in Portugal under the Efficity trademark, in Switzerland under the Brolliet, DBS Group, Domicim and Gribi banners, and across Europe under the Esset trademark. Founded in 1972, Emeria is Europe’s leading provider of residential real estate services for both individuals and businesses, and had over 12,000 employees at 31 December 2021. Emeria’s European banners specialise in the management of jointly owned properties, rentals, transactions and property management, and offer a broad range of real estate services, from surveys and technical diagnostics to insurance brokerage, security, maintenance work for jointly owned properties, and lettings. With approximately €1.2 billion in revenue in 2021, Emeria is the leader in jointly owned property management services, rental management and lettings in Germany, Belgium and France, and second in Switzerland. Also present in Luxembourg and the Netherlands, Emeria is one of the leading European property management companies in the B2B segment. In 2021, Emeria had more than 600 branches in Europe serving over 3 million customers. Today, Emeria is mainly present in Germany under the Reanovo trademark, in Belgium under the OP and Trevi trademarks, in France where it has traded under the Foncia banner for the past 50 years along with the Assurimo, Constatimmo, Efficity, Lodgis, Tech-Way, Seiitra and Stares trademarks, in Switzerland under the Brolliet, DBS Group, Domicim and Gribi banners, and across Europe under the Esset trademark.

Section Title: V** **- NOTES TO THE CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
Subsection Title: NOTE 2. HIGHLIGHTS OF THE PERIOD Changes in scope of consolidation
Subsubsection Text: External growth investments (acquisitions) The period’s most significant acquisitions are described below. - **Acquisition of FirstPort in the UK On 18 August 2022, the Group completed the acquisition of a 100% stake in the UK’s FirstPort group from the investment fund Equistone, for a total purchase price of GBP 198.4 million (€228 million). With the largest acquisition in its 50-year history, Emeria is continuing to pursue its international growth strategy, adding the UK’s leading residential property services company (jointly owned property management) to its portfolio and becoming the world leader in its sector. FirstPort operates in England, Scotland and Wales. With more than 4,000 people, it had revenue of €130 million in 2021. FirstPort’s main activity is the management of jointly owned properties. At 30 September 2022, costs directly related to the acquisition (mainly due diligence, advisory and legal fees) were recognised in non-recurring operating income and expenses, for a total of GBP 5.4 million (€6.2 million). To finance the acquisition, the Group carried out a cash capital increase for €114.5 million subscribed by its ----- below). It should be noted that FirstPort’s borrowings and debt were repaid by the Group in full on the date of the acquisition, for a total amount of GBP 191.9 million. The unamortised issuance costs relating to the former borrowings and debt were expensed in full in the statement of profit and loss, for a total amount of €3.3 million. The process of identifying the assets acquired and liabilities assumed as part of the acquisition was in progress at 30 September 2022. Based on the figures available at the acquisition date, provisional goodwill recognised in connection with the acquisition amounted to €446.2 million at 30 September 2022. - **Acquisition of Codabel (Benelux) In January 2022, Emeria Benelux completed the acquisition of Codabel and the property management business of Cushman & Wakefield Asset Services Belgium, for a total amount of €19.7 million. With the addition of Trevi Corporate, Esset Benelux will manage a portfolio of 1.6 million square metres. The acquisition propels the Group to the number three spot in Belgium’s professional property management market, behind BNP Paribas and CBRE. The process of identifying the assets acquired and liabilities assumed as part of the acquisition was still in progress at 30 September 2022. Provisional goodwill recognised in connection with the acquisition amounted to €16 million at 30 September 2022. - **Acquisition of Optima (Germany) In March 2022, the Group completed the acquisition of Germany’s Optima group, for €23.6 million. Berlin-based Optima was founded in 1993 and is a major player in the German property management market. With 400 employees, it manages nearly 33,000 residential and commercial units and had €21.8 million in revenue in 2021. This acquisition is one of the biggest transactions in the German property management market in recent years. Postacquisition, Reanovo manages around 150,000 residential units and has almost 1,300 employees. The process of identifying the assets acquired and liabilities assumed as part of the acquisition was still in progress at 30 September 2022. Provisional goodwill recognised in connection with the acquisition amounted to €20.3 million at 30 September 2022. - **Acquisition of Billon (France) On 31 May 2022, the Group completed the acquisition of the real estate division of the Lyon-based Billon group, for a net amount of €109.5 million. Billon, a family-owned group founded in 1870, is active in both property management and transactions. With 230 employees in 14 local offices in and around Lyon, as well as in the Var and Alpes-Maritimes départements, Billon had revenue of €25.8 million in 2021. The acquisition of this key industry player has further reinforced Foncia’s already deep foothold in the region. At 30 September 2022, the Billon group was not included in the scope of consolidation. The Group’s investment is included in other non-current financial assets. ----- Overview of the number of legal structures in the consolidation scope

Subsubsection Text: The Group saw further acquisition-led growth in the nine-month period ended 30 September 2022, with 129 new companies consolidated as a result of its acquisitions (including 83 relating to the FirstPort group alone). This growth was mainly driven by the French and international property administration business (administration de biens, hereafter referred to as property management).

Section Title: V** **- NOTES TO THE CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
Subsubsection Text: In 2022, the Group negotiated agreements with the founders and certain key individuals, replacing the previous agreements signed between Emeria and Foncia Saturne in 2018. - **Description of the transaction As a reminder, to secure the founders’ commitment to Efficity’s future development, in 2018 the Group entered into an agreement using a specific legal structure based on an intermediate holding company (Foncia Saturne) controlling Efficity’s entire share capital. At the time, the founders subscribed to a capital increase carried out by the holding company in an amount of €4 million, with the possibility of realising a potential capital gain on the subsequent resale of their shares to Emeria, depending on trends in the company’s EBITDA. In accordance with the Group’s objective of retaining exclusive control upon completion of the transaction, Efficity continued to be fully consolidated. The estimated cost of purchasing the managers’ shares in Efficity was treated as a profit-sharing arrangement intended as consideration for services rendered. Accordingly, the cost was spread over the term of the transaction, as from 2018. At 31 December 2021, an earn-out liability of €53.9 million was recognised in other current liabilities, with the offsetting entry recognised gradually in non-recurring operating income and expenses. In May 2022, further to a wish to develop its relationship with the founders and key individuals, the Group altered the shareholding structure as described below: - In accordance with the previous agreements, Emeria Europe exercised its call option (valued based on the company’s performance to date) to acquire the remaining Foncia Saturne shares for a total amount of €69.8 million, including: - €4.7 million paid in cash at closing; - €42.6 million paid to the founders in the form of a vendor loan to be settled by the Group by April 2023 (shown as an earn-out liability within other current liabilities); - €22.5 million reinvested by the founders and key individuals (i) in Efficity (€20 million) and (ii) in Efficity International (€2.5 million). |Analysis of scope of consolidation at 30 Sept. 2022|Change (10)| |---|---| |30 Sept. 2022 31 Dec. 2021 Full consolidation 359 369|| |Of which acquisitions Of which newly created companies Of which mergers and asset contributions (“TUP”) Equity method 1 1|27 1 (38)| |Total – France 360 370|(10)| |Full consolidation 180 82|98| |Of which acquisitions Of which newly created companies Of which mergers and asset contributions (“TUP”)|102 4 (8)| |Total – International 180 82|98| |Total – Consolidated entities 540 452|88| ----- - New shareholder agreements were set up with key individuals and the founders at the level of Efficity and Efficity International. They include call and put options on shares with exercise periods between 2025 and 2028. The exercise price is dependent on revenue and EBITDA trends over those periods. - Following the transaction, the shareholding structure (through Foncia Saturne) breaks down as follows: - 88.21% of Efficity’s share capital is held by Emeria and 11.79% by the founders and key individuals; - 51% of Efficity International’s share capital is held by Emeria and 49% by the founders and key individuals. - **Accounting treatment of new shareholder agreements _Consolidation method_ The shareholder agreements signed in 2022 are a continuation of the 2018 transaction. Their provisions are very similar and the changes in the governance requirements confirm the Group’s control over the companies. Furthermore, the Group considers that the exercise price of the options does not deprive it of the returns associated with owning the shares and therefore that a “present ownership interest” exists. Accordingly, the Group has continued to fully consolidate the companies’ shares. As a result, no non-controlling interests in respect of Efficity and Efficity International appear in the statement of financial position (the shares in these companies are shown in liabilities). _Treatment of call and put options on shares_ Since the Group considers that the 2022 agreements were signed as a continuation of the 2018 agreements and that, in substance, they result in a proposal to the founders and key individuals to defer part of the amounts due to them in return for their involvement in the company, with the possibility of being able to benefit from any upside on the option exercise date, the reciprocal calls and puts were not analysed in light of IFRS 3. The amendment to the payment terms does not call into question the nature of the payment, but instead offers the key individuals and founders a profit-sharing mechanism linked to the future growth of the business. The same reasoning applies to the lower value Efficity International options. On this basis, the Group concluded that the payments represented employee benefits as defined by IAS 19, requiring recognition as an expense against an employee-related payable. However, as the exercise of the put options is not strictly contingent on the continuing presence of the founders or key individuals within the Group, Emeria considers that the estimated cost of purchasing the shares cannot be recognised over the term of the transaction. Accordingly, the Group recognised the entire expense in full as soon as the agreements were set up. _Summary of impacts at 30 September 2022_ - Consolidated statement of financial position: - Vendor loan: shown as an employee-related payable within other current liabilities for €42.6 million. - Put option granted to the founders and key individuals: shown as an employee-related payable within other current liabilities for €50 million, calculated on the basis of the best estimates and information available at the date of preparation of the interim financial statements. - Consolidated statement of profit and loss: - Settlement of the 2018 transaction: non-recurring operating expense of €15.8 million corresponding to the difference between the total purchase price of the Foncia Saturne shares (€69.8 million) and the payable provisioned at 31 December 2021 (€53.9 million). - 2022 shareholder agreement: non-recurring operating expense of €27.5 million corresponding to the difference between the estimated overall cost of purchasing Efficity and Efficity International shares (€50 million) and the reinvestment made by the founders and key individuals (€22.5 million). - Consolidated statement of cash flows: €7 million payment to key individuals to purchase their shares in Foncia Saturne, shown on the change in working capital requirement line, net of their €2.3 million reinvestment in Efficity and Efficity International (i.e., a net cash outflow of €4.7 million). -----

Section Title: V** **- NOTES TO THE CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
Subsubsection Text: In order to partially refinance its revolving credit facility (RCF) and help finance acquisition-led growth, in April 2022 the Group drew down a new €200 million tranche of its Senior Facility B, bearing interest at 3-month Euribor + 4.5% and maturing in March 2028. As part of the financing for the FirstPort acquisition, in August 2022 the Group also drew down a new €346 million tranche of its Senior Facility B, bearing interest at 3-month Euribor + 4.5% and maturing in March 2028. The costs associated with the new borrowings totalled €13.2 million and were classified as a reduction in borrowings and debt. They are recognised over the term of the borrowings by adjusting the effective interest rate. The two new lines were re-syndicated on 23 November 2022, as indicated in the subsequent events section.

Section Title: V** **- NOTES TO THE CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
Subsubsection Text: Following the March 2021 refinancing operation, the Group acquired two interest rate cap agreements in January 2022, for a total amount of €4.2 million. The premium paid on the instruments is shown in the consolidated statement of cash flows within other financial items. The instruments protect the Group against an increase in the three-month Euribor rate above 1% on a cumulative nominal amount of €1,148 million until 25 December 2024. In view of the hike in interbank rates begun in January 2022, the fair value of the instruments represented €44.5 million at 30 September 2022. Effectiveness tests confirm the eligibility of the instruments for cash flow hedge (CFH) accounting. Accordingly, the change in the fair value of the instruments was recognised in other comprehensive income for €41.3  million  excluding  deferred  tax  (€30.9  million  including  the  deferred  tax  impact)  at 30 September 2022.

Section Title: V** **- NOTES TO THE CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
Subsection Title: NOTE 3. ACCOUNTING POLICIES AND METHODS Basis of preparation of financial information
Subsubsection Text: Emeria’s condensed interim consolidated financial statements at 30 September 2022 were prepared as part of a planned refinancing operation. They were adopted by the Chairman after being reviewed by the Supervisory Board, by way of unanimous decisions made by private deed dated 18 January 2023. Pursuant to Regulation 1606/2002 of 19 July 2002, as amended by European Regulation 297/2008 of 11 March 2008, the Group’s interim consolidated financial statements at 30 September 2022 have been prepared in accordance with IAS 34 – Interim Financial Reporting. As these are condensed financial statements, they do not include all of the financial information required by international financial reporting standards (IFRS) for annual financial statements, and should be read in conjunction with the Group’s annual financial statements for the year ended 31 December 2021. The accounting policies and methods used to prepare the condensed interim consolidated financial statements comply with IFRS standards and interpretations as adopted by the European Union at 30 September 2022. Accounting policies and methods are described in detail in the consolidated financial statements at 31 December 2021. The interim financial statements have been prepared using the same accounting policies and methods as those used to prepare the 2021 consolidated financial statements, subject to the amendments presented in Note 3.2.1 applicable from 1 January 2022, and the specific requirements set out in IAS 34. -----

Section Title: V** **- NOTES TO THE CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
Subsection Title: Group accounting standards 3.2.1.** **Changes in accounting standards
Subsubsection Text: The Group did not early adopt any standards, amendments or interpretations issued by the IASB that were not mandatorily applicable or were not in force in the European Union at 30 September 2022.

Section Title: V** **- NOTES TO THE CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
Subsection Title: Main IFRS standards, amendments and interpretations in force within the European Union and mandatorily applicable since 1 January 2022
Subsubsection Text: - Amendments to IFRS 3 – Business Combinations – Reference to the Conceptual Framework: these amendments have no impact on the accounting treatment of business combinations. - Amendments to IAS 16 – Property, Plant and Equipment – Proceeds before Intended Use: these amendments prohibit entities from deducting from the cost of an item of property, plant and equipment any proceeds from selling items produced while bringing that asset to the location and condition necessary for it to be capable of operating in the manner intended by management. Any such proceeds are to be recognised in the statement of profit and loss. From 1 January 2022, proceeds from the sale of items generated by an asset not yet in use will no longer be recognised as a deduction from the cost of the asset. These proceeds and the associated costs will have to be recorded in the statement of profit and loss. - Amendments to IAS 37 – Provisions, Contingent Liabilities and Contingent Assets – Onerous Contracts – Cost of Fulfilling a Contract: these amendments specify the costs to be considered in assessing whether a contract is onerous. - Annual Improvements to IFRS (2018-2020 Cycle) – Amendments to IFRS 1, IFRS 9, IAS 41 and IFRS 16. The Group has not identified any significant impacts from its first application of these amendments.

Section Title: V** **- NOTES TO THE CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
Subsection Title: Standards, interpretations and amendments not yet adopted by the European Union
Subsubsection Text: The impacts on the interim financial statements of the texts published by the IASB at 30 September 2022 and not yet in force in the European Union are currently being analysed. They concern: - Amendments to IAS 12 – Income Taxes – Deferred Tax related to Assets and Liabilities arising from a Single Transaction. - Amendments to IAS 1 – Presentation of Financial Statements – Classification of Liabilities as Current or Noncurrent. - Amendments to IFRS 17 – Insurance Contracts – Initial Application of IFRS 17 and IFRS 9 – Comparative Information, published on 9 December 2021. - Amendments to IAS 8 – Definition of an Accounting Estimate: these amendments help entities distinguish between changes in accounting policies and changes in accounting estimates. - Amendments to IFRS 16 – Lease Liability in a Sale and Leaseback: these amendments concern the subsequent measurement of right-of-use assets and lease liabilities arising from a sale and leaseback transaction (especially in the case of variable lease payments not based on an index or rate). -----

Section Title: V** **- NOTES TO THE CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
Subsection Title: IFRS IC agenda decision on accounting for configuration or customisation costs in a cloud computing arrangement (SaaS)
Subsubsection Text: As a reminder, in April 2021 the IASB confirmed the position taken by the IFRS IC concerning the recognition of the costs of configuring or customising a supplier’s application software in a Software as a Service (SaaS) arrangement. The IFRS IC agenda decision confirmed that in most cases, pursuant to IAS 38, these costs should be recognised as an expense and not as an intangible asset, because (i) the entity does not control the software and (ii) the customisation/configuration activities do not create a resource controlled by the customer that is separate from the software. These costs should therefore be expensed: - either when they are incurred if the developments are carried out internally or by a third-party supplier (unrelated to the SaaS solution publisher); - or over the term of the SaaS contract if the developments are carried out by the publisher of the SaaS solution or by its subcontractor. Analyses conducted by the Group confirmed that configuration and customisation costs for certain SaaS software historically carried within assets (mainly in respect of the Workday software used as the Finance and HR ERP since 2019) did not meet the criteria outlined in the IFRS IC’s agenda decision and should, therefore, be expensed. In accordance with IAS 8 and in the absence of any transitional provisions to the contrary, any changes resulting from a final agenda decision issued by the IFRS IC are retrospectively applicable. The impact of this change in accounting policy was recognised in the statement of financial position retrospectively as of 1 January 2021, resulting in a €10 million decrease in non-current assets and a corresponding €7.4 million decrease in consolidated equity (net of tax). The table below shows the resulting impacts on the statement of financial position at 31 December 2021:

Subsection Title: 3.2.2.** **Use of management estimates in applying the Group’s accounting standards
Subsubsection Text: In preparing its financial statements, the Group is required to make estimates and assumptions that may affect the measurement and presentation of certain assets, liabilities or contingent liabilities at the end of the reporting period, as well as the reported amounts of income and expenses for the period. Estimates and underlying assumptions are determined based on information available at the end of the reporting period and are reviewed on a regular basis in light of past experience and other factors deemed reasonable given the current circumstances. These estimates serve as the basis for measuring the carrying amount of assets and liabilities that cannot be obtained directly from other sources. Final amounts may differ from these estimates. Below is a reminder of the items for which management may be required to make estimates and assumptions, as detailed in the specified notes: - measurement of leases; - measurement of assets and liabilities relating to post-employment plans; - basis for determining the value of identifiable assets acquired and liabilities assumed as part of a business combination. The Group continued to pay particular attention to these items in preparing its interim consolidated financial statements at 30 September 2022. In accordance with IAS 34, the tax expense for the period was calculated by applying the estimated effective annual tax rate to the pre-tax profit for the period, adjusted for any one-off items.

Subsection Title: Total acquisitions of intangible assets in the statement of cash flows Of which investments in client relationships shown as a change in scope of consolidation in the statement of cash flows 34,551 (504)
Subsubsection Text: (1) Deployment of the Millénium project: As a reminder, in 2018 the Group launched Millénium, a vast project to develop a new property management tool in connection with the reorganisation of the property management network. With a view to discontinuing the cumbersome and non-scalable Thetrawin software, _Millénium_ was developed to ensure and enrich all critical functionalities for the property management business (accounting records for client accounts; management of suspense accounts, jointly owned properties and rentals; management of jointly owned property association budgets, etc.). The project was led by the teams of Emeria Technologies, the legal entity responsible for the Group’s digital development and innovation. Most of the costs directly related to the project have been capitalised since 2018, with the exception of some overhead and desktop publishing costs which have been expensed. At 31 December 2021, total costs recognised within intangible assets in progress amounted to €51 million. They include two fairly distinct modules: ML Transaction and ML Property Management. Given the structure of the project and its actual deployment, separate go-live dates have been selected by the Group: - from 1 January 2022 for the Transaction module: as from 1 January 2022, the key functionalities of ML Transaction are available (put into production), allowing the module to be used in the conditions initially intended. Amortisation also started on the same date; - from 30 September 2022 for the Property Management module: go-live was assessed based on two objective parameters: (i) the functional coverage rate of Millénium compared to Thetrawin and (ii) the capacity of the infrastructure to support the use of the applications in all branches. The Group considers the two criteria to have been met on 30 September 2022, allowing for the module’s widespread deployment and its amortisation as from that date. The go-live of the modules is presented as a reclassification between intangible assets in progress and software, for a total amount of €66 million, divided between the two modules as follows: - ML Transaction: €14 million; ----- - ML Property Management: €52 million. Both the Transaction and Property Management modules will be amortised over a period of 10 years, as from their respective go-live dates. Amortisation charged against the ML Transaction module in the period amounted to €1.1 million.

Section Title: V** **- NOTES TO THE CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
Subsubsection Text: As described in the highlights section, the Group acquired two interest rate cap agreements in January 2022, for a total amount of €4.2 million. The two instruments have the following characteristics: - Cumulative notional amount: €1,148 million. - Floating rate hedged: 3-month Euribor. - Hedged rate: maximum rate of 1%. - Start: 24 January 2022. - Expiry: 27 December 2024. In view of the hike in interbank rates begun in January 2022, the fair value of the instruments represented €44.5 million at 30 September 2022. Effectiveness tests confirm the eligibility of the instruments for cash flow hedge (CFH) accounting. Accordingly, the change in the fair value of the instruments was recognised in other comprehensive income for €41.3 million excluding deferred tax (€30.9 million including the deferred tax impact), of which a positive €42.6 million in intrinsic value and a negative €1.3 million in time value.

Subsubsection Text: Strong seasonal fluctuations at Assurimo mean that it issues its invoices at the end of the year, which explains its very high trade receivables balance. Invoices are settled during the course of the following year. Note that besides fees recognised in revenue for the period, Assurimo’s trade receivables also include amounts to be recovered on behalf of insurers which are paid over to those insurers upon receipt of the corresponding supplier invoice.

Section Title: V** **- NOTES TO THE CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
Subsubsection Text: As described in the highlights section, in April 2022 the Group drew down a new €200 million tranche of its Senior Facility B, bearing interest at 3-month Euribor + 4.5% and maturing in March 2028. The Group also took out a new €346 million TLB line, bearing interest at 3-month Euribor + 4.5% and maturing in March 2028, as part of the financing for the acquisition of the FirstPort group in the UK. Repayments of other borrowings and debt amounting to €243 million relate mainly to the repayment of bank loans taken out by FirstPort for €221 million and AGDA for €18.4 million.

Subsection Title: Total provisions for retirement benefits and other 30,963** **4,129** **147** **(4,052)** **(12,891)** **608** **18,904 employee benefits

Section Title: V** **- NOTES TO THE CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
Subsubsection Text: As a reminder, neither IAS 19 nor IAS 34 require systematic valuations of pension liabilities at each interim reporting period. However, given the highly volatile economic environment since the beginning of 2022 and, in particular, the hike in interest rates (and hence actuarial rates), the Group decided that it was necessary to recognise all resulting actuarial gains and losses within other comprehensive income (equity). Accordingly, Mercer (France) and eActuary (Switzerland) re-calculated the amounts at 31 December 2021 based on new assumptions, and projected the liability for retirement benefits and long-service awards over nine months. The actuarial gains and losses generated over the period were then calculated as the difference compared to the calculations based on the prior assumptions. Assumptions: - Discount rate: - France: 3.75%, versus 1% at 31 December 2021/Switzerland: 2%, versus 0.3% at 31 December 2021. - Rate of increase in salaries: - France: unchanged at 1%/Switzerland: 1.5%, versus 1% at 31 December 2021. - The other assumptions (employee turnover, payroll taxes, etc.) were not adjusted.

Section Title: V** **- NOTES TO THE CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
Subsubsection Text: Constatimmo Other activities Property Management Optissimmo Digital business Property Management Tech-Way Other activities Property Management Assurimo Other activities Digital business Seiitra Other activities Digital business Prowen Other activities Property Management Comments on business activity during the period: In the first nine months of 2022, the Group’s revenue increased by €102.4 million (or 12.2%) compared to the same period in 2021, attributable mainly to France. Revenue generated in France increased by 9.1% (or €66.7 million), owing primarily to the property management business (up 8.5%, or €42.9 million): - revenue from rental management activities increased by 5.5% (or €13.3 million) due to a positive volume effect (the number of properties managed increased by 3.8%) as well as an increase in prices; - rental income decreased due to lower volumes resulting from a weak market (gradual decline in the turnover rate); - revenue from joint property management increased by 10.8% (or €26.3 million), mainly due to a positive volume effect (the number of units managed increased by 9.1%). The transactions business grew by 7.1% (or €8.4 million), mainly owing to the acquisition of AGDA, the leading player in Grenoble, and a favourable volume/price mix, whereas sales fell by 5.7% in a more downbeat market environment. The digital business grew by 11.6% (or €9.3 million), driven by the good performance of Efficity (up 15.4%), which recruited more than 490 professionals over the last 12 months despite a tougher market environment. Revenue from the B2B business grew by €6.2 million compared to the nine-month period ended 30 September 2021, mainly on account of acquisition-led growth and new contracts signed. In the international business, revenue grew by €35.7 million, with all countries reporting gains, mainly thanks to acquisitions. In Switzerland, business for the first nine months of 2021 had been negatively impacted by restrictions related to the Covid-19 crisis. In Germany, redundancies in 2021 as a result of Covid-19 led to a loss of customers. |Activity|Reclassified from|Reclassified to| |---|---|---| |Constatimmo|Other activities|Property Management| |Optissimmo|Digital business|Property Management| |Tech-Way|Other activities|Property Management| |Assurimo|Other activities|Digital business| |Seiitra|Other activities|Digital business| |Prowen|Other activities|Property Management| -----

Integration costs mainly concern: - HR costs for €25.9 million, chiefly relating to personnel costs in respect of acquired entities (but for positions that already exist within the Group and are therefore redundant) and severance costs for certain employees (agreements, bonuses, negotiated termination benefits and payroll taxes); - other miscellaneous expenses totalling €6.5 million, including costs related to unlocking synergies (duplicate rentals, removal costs, termination costs, IT costs, etc.). Acquisition fees primarily comprise fees paid to sellers or business providers for support services, market research fees and accounting, legal and consulting assistance fees. IT projects include configuration and customisation costs for SaaS software following the IFRS IC’s final agenda decision in April 2021. Restructuring costs in France mainly concern the Métropole project, relating mostly to: - personnel costs including costs incurred in preparing negotiated termination agreements and costs related to new hires for certain specific projects; - IT and consulting costs incurred in respect of the Métropole project; - indemnities for early termination of certain leases along with removal costs; - costs related to the deployment of the Millénium project and non-capitalisable costs of certain SaaS software. The impacts of the Efficity transaction are described in the highlights section.

Subsubsection Text: The list of consolidated companies is presented in Note 12. |Analysis of scope of consolidation at 31 December 2021|Change 76| |---|---| |31 Dec. 2021 31 Dec. 2020 Full consolidation 369 293|| |Of which acquisitions during the period Of which newly created companies during the period Of which disposals during the period Of which mergers and asset contributions (“TUP”) Equity method 1 1|127 6 ( 1) ( 56)| |Total – France 370 294|76| |Full consolidation 82 55 Of which acquisitions during the period 26 Of which newly created companies during the period Of which mergers and asset contributions (“TUP”)|27 26 3 ( 2)| |Total – International 82 55|27| ||| |Total – Consolidated entities 452 349|103| ----- External growth investments (acquisitions) The Group drove a sharp acceleration in its acquisition-led growth during the year, with 153 new companies consolidated as a result of its acquisitions (versus 75 at 31 December 2020). Acquisition-led growth was mainly driven by the property administration (administration de biens, hereafter referred to as property management) business in France, but also by B2B and international operations. The year’s most significant acquisitions are described below (all of which were consolidated during the year): - **Acquisition of the IPF group (Property management, South-East France): On 1 April 2021, the Group acquired the entire share capital of the IPF group for a total amount of €29.9 million. IPF is engaged in rental management, property transactions, lettings and activities relating to jointly owned property associations (its core business) in the Marseille region. The group has 26 subsidiaries and generated revenue of €15.3 million in 2019. Provisional goodwill recognised in connection with this acquisition amounted to €33.5 million at 31 December 2021. - **Acquisition of the Valexim group (Property management, North-East France): On 31 May 2021, the Group acquired the entire share capital of Financière de Maistre Bayard (Valexim) for €43.2 million. Located in the Alps region, this group has 13 subsidiaries and is predominantly engaged in property management activities (2019 revenue: €22.1 million). This acquisition is part of the drive to develop the business in the Savoie and HauteSavoie regions. Together with its other acquisitions, the Group now has a significant market share and is becoming a key player in both regions. Provisional goodwill recognised in connection with this acquisition amounted to €48 million at 31 December 2021. - **Acquisition of the Quenot group (Property management, Ile-de-France region): On 30 June 2021, the Group acquired the entire share capital of the Quenot group for €24 million. This group is located to the east of Paris and had revenue of €7.1 million in 2019, mainly from its property management business. Provisional  goodwill  recognised  in  connection  with  this  acquisition  amounted  to  €19.5 million  at 31 December 2021. - **Acquisition of the Immo de Corse group (Property management, South-East France): On 1 July 2021, the Group acquired the entire share capital of the Immo de Corse group, the leading manager of jointly owned properties on the Corsican market, for €16.8 million. This independent group comprises five entities and had revenue of €6.9 million in 2020. Its innovative organisation (centralised back office) enables it to generate very high FTE/property ratios. Provisional goodwill recognised in connection with this acquisition amounted to €11.5 million at 31 December 2021. - **Acquisition of the Agda group: On 31 December 2021, the Group acquired the entire share capital of the Agda group for a provisional purchase consideration of €67.7 million. Based in Grenoble, Agda comprises 27 companies and is among the 10 leading managers of jointly owned properties in France (€31 million in revenue). Provisional  goodwill  recognised  in  connection  with  this  acquisition  amounted  to  €86.8 million  at 31 December 2021. - **Acquisition of Humakey (B2B): On 31 July 2021, the Group acquired Humakey for €14.4 million. In just a few years, Humakey has succeeded in establishing itself on the B2B market as the premium player in property management. Humakey is currently the only company to offer a truly bespoke service to its clients for strategic real estate assets, in return for high fees. This acquisition allows Esset to round out its range of services with an upscale offer that meets client demands in this niche market. Provisional goodwill recognised in connection with this acquisition amounted to €8.7 million at 31 December 2021. - **Acquisition of Intercity in Switzerland: On 31 May 2021, DBS Holding acquired 50% of the share capital of Zurich- based Intercity Bewirtschaftung AG for a provisional purchase consideration of CHF 6.6 million. The Intercity group operates in five German-speaking Swiss cities and generated sales of CHF 10.3 million in 2019. This acquisition will enable the Group to become the leading property management company in German-speaking Switzerland. ----- As part of this transaction, reciprocal call and put options were set up with the seller on the remaining 50% of the shares: - Call: option for DBS to buy back the remaining 50% of the shares (unconditionally exercisable from 1 January 2023, with early exercise of the option permitted in certain cases). - Put: option for the seller to sell the remaining 50% of the shares to DBS (in principle unconditionally from 1 January 2022, with early exercise of the option permitted in certain cases). At 31 December 2021, these options were valued at €6.4 million and recognised in net debt (see Note 4.11.) against goodwill. Intercity was fully consolidated during the year in light of the degree of control exercised over this entity within the meaning of IFRS 10 and the Group’s ability to contribute in substance to power over this entity. Given the Group has rights to returns under its call option, Intercity was consolidated on the basis of a 100% interest as from the time of its acquisition. Provisional goodwill recognised in connection with this acquisition amounted to €11 million at 31 December 2021. - **Acquisition of the R&M group in Germany: On 31 August 2021, the Group acquired the R&M group through Brillant 3586 GmbH (a subsidiary of Foncia Deutschland GmbH & Co KG) for a provisional purchase consideration of €10.4 million. With offices in Dresden and Leipzig in eastern Germany, R&M employs around 180 people and generated revenue of around €9.5 million in 2020. This acquisition marks a further step in the Group’s acquisition-led growth strategy and its aim to become a leading player on the real estate services market across Europe. Provisional goodwill recognised in connection with this acquisition amounted to €10 million at 31 December 2021. The process of identifying the assets acquired and liabilities assumed as part of all of the above-mentioned acquisitions was still in progress at 31 December 2021. Subsection Title: NOTE 7. FINANCIAL RISK EXPOSURE Interest rate risk
Subsubsection Text: The Group’s interest rate risk exposure arises mainly on its borrowings. These borrowings are denominated solely in euros, and floating-rate loans are mainly indexed to the 3-month Euribor. As the risk management policy is set by management, the borrowings are managed on a centralised basis. Cash flow surpluses and working capital requirements for the Group’s companies are centralised under a cash pooling agreement and managed by the Group’s Treasury department. The Group’s Treasury department selects investment vehicles for cash surpluses – either for proprietary cash or client cash (excluding separate accounts) – within the framework set by the management policy, which prioritises liquidity and security. Interest earned on investments in term accounts is based on fixed rates. In the current context of negative interbank rates, cash at the bank no longer earns interest. At 30 September 2022, interest rate risk only concerns the Group’s bank borrowings indexed to 3-month Euribor. Interest rate risk can therefore be analysed as follows: Credit risk** _(€ thousands) Client accounts 196,856 - Term accounts (client funds) (71,165) + Net cash and cash equivalents 0 The Group’s interest rate risk exposure arises mainly on its borrowings. Interest earned on investments in term accounts is based on fixed rates. In the current context of negative interbank rates, cash at the bank no longer earns interest. At 31 December 2021, interest rate risk only concerns the Group’s bank borrowings indexed to 3-month Euribor. Subsubsection Text: - A foreign exchange trading risk arising on commercial and financial transactions carried out by the Group’s companies in currencies other than their local currency. This risk is not material as the vast majority of local transactions are denominated in Swiss francs for activities carried out in Switzerland, or in pounds sterling for those carried out in the UK. On 29 June 2018, Foncia signed an amendment to the agreement for the loan granted by Foncia Groupe to its subsidiary Foncia Switzerland, eliminating all repayment clauses. Given that no repayments have been made and that no repayment plan has been set for the foreseeable future, this loan is considered as a monetary item and as part of the net investment in Foncia Switzerland as quasi-equity, in accordance with IAS 21 – The Effects of Changes in Foreign Exchange Rates. Pledges of collateral correspond to commitments given in connection with the financing set up with the banking pool. These liabilities were restructured as part of the March 2021 debt refinancing operation. All commitments that had initially been given to the previous beneficiaries were cancelled and new pledges were made in favour of Natixis as senior agent and Elavon Financial Services DAC as senior collateral agent of the lenders, as follows: - pledge of Emeria Holding shares held by Emeria; - pledge of Emeria Europe shares held by Emeria Holding; - pledge of shares in Assurimo and its subsidiary Assurimo Paris, Seiitra Réseau and Foncia held by Emeria Europe; - pledge of Foncia Vallée du Rhône shares held by Emeria Europe and Foncia Lyon; - pledge of shares in certain Foncia subsidiaries: Foncia Ad Immobilier Foncia Alpes Dauphine Foncia Alsace Bourgogne Franche Comté Foncia Armor Foncia Bordeaux Foncia Hauts de France Foncia LCA Foncia Lémanique Foncia Lyon Foncia Montpellier Foncia Normandie Foncia Paris Rive Droite Foncia Paris Rive Gauche Foncia Toulon Foncia Toulouse ----- Foncia Transaction France As part of these same transactions, the following pledges were also made by the Group: - pledge of Emeria bank accounts; - pledge of certain receivables owed by Emeria to Emeria Holding and Emeria Europe (intercompany loan of 5 September 2016, the terms of which were modified on 25 March 2021).

Subsubsection Text: - assess the appropriateness of management’s use of the going concern basis of accounting and, based on the audit evidence obtained, whether a material uncertainty exists related to events or conditions that may cast significant doubt on the Company’s ability to continue as a going concern. This assessment is based on the audit evidence obtained up to the date of the audit report. However, future events or conditions may cause the Company to cease to continue as a going concern. If the Statutory Auditors conclude that a material uncertainty exists, they are required to draw attention in the audit report to the related disclosures in the consolidated financial statements or, if such disclosures are not provided or are inadequate, to issue a qualified opinion or a disclaimer of opinion; - evaluate the overall presentation of the consolidated financial statements and assess whether these statements represent the underlying transactions and events in a manner that achieves fair presentation; - obtain sufficient appropriate audit evidence regarding the financial information of the entities or business activities within the Group to express an opinion on the consolidated financial statements. The Statutory Auditors are responsible for the management, supervision and performance of the audit of the consolidated financial statements and for the opinion expressed thereon. Neuilly-sur-Seine and Paris-La Défense, 25 April 2022 The Statutory Auditors PricewaterhouseCoopers Audit Deloitte & Associés Jean-Baptiste Deschryver Xavier Lefèvre ----- # CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS ### FOR THE YEAR ENDED 31 DECEMBER 2021 -----
13 avenue Lebrun 92160 Antony France To the sole Shareholder,

In compliance with the engagement entrusted to us by the sole shareholder, we have audited the accompanying consolidated financial statements of Emeria (formerly Foncia Management) for the year ended 31 December 2021. In our opinion, the consolidated financial statements give a true and fair view of the assets and liabilities and of the financial position of the Group at 31 December 2021 and of the results of its operations for the year then ended in accordance with International Financial Reporting Standards as adopted by the European Union.

We conducted our audit in accordance with professional standards applicable in France. We believe that the audit evidence we have obtained is sufficient and appropriate to provide a basis for our opinion. Our responsibilities under these standards are further described in the “Responsibilities of the Statutory Auditors relating to the audit of the consolidated financial statements” section of our report. -----

Without qualifying our opinion, we draw your attention to Note 3.2.2 “Changes in accounting standards” to the consolidated financial statements, which describes the retrospective application as of 1 January 2020 of the IFRS IC decision on the attribution of employee benefits to periods of service.

Due to the global crisis related to the Covid-19 pandemic, the financial statements of this period have been prepared and audited under specific conditions. Indeed, this crisis and the exceptional measures taken in the context of the state of sanitary emergency have had numerous consequences for companies, particularly on their operations and their financing, and have led to greater uncertainties on their future prospects. Those measures, such as travel restrictions and remote working, have also had an impact on the companies' internal organisation and the performance of the audits. It is in this complex and evolving context that, in accordance with the requirements of articles L.823-9 and R.823-7 of the French Commercial Code relating to the justification of our assessments, we inform you of the following assessments that, in our professional judgement, were the most significant in our audit of the consolidated financial statements. The Group tests goodwill and assets with indefinite useful lives for impairment on an annual basis, in accordance with the methods presented in Notes 3.4.5. “Impairment of assets” and 4.1.2 “2021impairment tests” to the consolidated financial statements. We examined the methods used by the Group to test for impairment, together with the cash flow forecasts and assumptions relied upon for that purpose. We further verified that the notes provide appropriate disclosures. As part of our assessments, we also ensured that the estimates used were reasonable. These assessments were addressed as part of our audit of the consolidated financial statements as a whole, and therefore contributed to the opinion we formed as expressed above. We do not provide a separate opinion on specific items of the consolidated financial statements.

As required by legal and regulatory provisions and in accordance with professional standards applicable in France, we have also performed the specific verifications on the information presented in the Group management report. We have no matters to report as to its fair presentation and its consistency with the consolidated financial statements. -----

Subsection Title: Responsibilities of management and those charged with governance for the consolidated financial statements
Subsubsection Text: Management is responsible for preparing consolidated financial statements giving a true and fair view in accordance with International Financial Reporting Standards as adopted by the European Union and for implementing the internal control procedures it deems necessary for the preparation of consolidated financial statements that are free of material misstatement, whether due to fraud or error. In preparing the consolidated financial statements, management is responsible for assessing the Company’s ability to continue as a going concern, disclosing, as applicable, matters related to going concern, and using the going concern basis of accounting, unless it expects to liquidate the Company or to cease operations. The consolidated financial statements were approved by the Chairman.

Subsection Title: Responsibilities of the Statutory Auditors relating to the audit of the consolidated financial statements
Subsubsection Text: Our role is to issue a report on the consolidated financial statements. Our objective is to obtain reasonable assurance about whether the consolidated financial statements as a whole are free of material misstatement. Reasonable assurance is a high level of assurance, but is not a guarantee that an audit conducted in accordance with professional standards will always detect a material misstatement when it exists. Misstatements can arise from fraud or error and are considered material if, individually or in the aggregate, they could reasonably be expected to influence the economic decisions taken by users on the basis of these consolidated financial statements. As specified in article L.823-10-1 of the French Commercial Code, our audit does not include assurance on the viability or quality of the Company’s management. As part of an audit conducted in accordance with professional standards applicable in France, the Statutory Auditors exercise professional judgement throughout the audit. They also: - identify and assess the risks of material misstatement in the consolidated financial statements, whether due to fraud or error, design and perform audit procedures in response to those risks, and obtain audit evidence considered to be sufficient and appropriate to provide a basis for their opinion. The risk of not detecting a material misstatement resulting from fraud is higher than for one resulting from error, as fraud may involve collusion, forgery, intentional omissions, misrepresentations, or the override of internal control; - obtain an understanding of the internal control procedures relevant to the audit in order to design audit procedures that are appropriate in the circumstances, but not for the purpose of expressing an opinion on the effectiveness of the internal control; - evaluate the appropriateness of accounting policies used and the reasonableness of accounting estimates made by management and the related disclosures in the notes to the consolidated financial statements; -----

New TLB2A debt In order to repay part of the RCF, in December 2022 the Group drew down a new €73 million tranche of its Senior Facility B, bearing interest at 3-month Euribor + 5.25% and maturing in March 2028. Efficity vendor loan €26 million of the loan granted to the founders and key individuals of Efficity in connection with the renegotiated agreement has been repaid, of which €25 million on 3 January 2023. The remaining balance will be paid in April 2023. Refinancing of the RCF for €550 million As described in the highlights section, in April and August 2022 the Group drew down two new tranches of its Senior Facility B for a total amount of €546 million, bearing interest at 3-month Euribor + 4.5% and maturing in March 2028. The two new lines were re-syndicated at the end of November 2022 for a total amount of €550 million, bearing interest at a new rate of 3-month Euribor + 5.25% (the maturity date remaining unchanged at March 2028). The costs associated with the syndication amounted to €6.5 million (of which €4 million was financed by an increase in the nominal amount subscribed). -----

The impacts of newly consolidated companies on the consolidated statement of profit and loss are not presented as they cannot be reliably identified owing to distortions resulting from the transfer of portfolios taken over from the historic Foncia entities (via the rental management mechanism).

On 30 April 2021, the Group sold its remaining 60% stake in Leemo to the Primonial group, marking its full withdrawal from this low margin activity. By way of reminder, on 30 November 2018 Primonial had acquired a 40% equity interest in Leemo via a partial asset transfer consisting of Primonial’s entire, stand-alone sales brokerage division for new and existing properties. Since Leemo was not considered material, it was deconsolidated as of 1 January 2021. The impact of deconsolidation was a negative €9.7 million, reflecting a sale price of €0.4 million for a €10 million share of consolidated equity as of the date of sale. This loss on deconsolidation is presented in non-recurring operating items (see Note 5.8). The full amount of the €2 million indemnity receivable from Primonial under the rendezvous clause agreed in the context of the joint venture with Primonial was collected at the close of the sale. As a reminder, non-recurring accrued income had been recognised in the 2020 financial statements and recorded under other miscellaneous receivables.

On 25 March 2021, the Group signed a major debt refinancing agreement (term loan B and high-yield bonds) for a total amount of €1,925 million. The refinancing had two objectives: (i) early repayment of the Group’s existing borrowings (including €1,189 million under senior facility B and €120.3 million under the revolving credit facility); |Impact of newly consolidated companies on the consolidated statement of financial position (€ thousands)|31 Dec. 2021| |---|---| |Non-current assets Current assets|35,108 306,719| |TOTAL ASSETS|341,828| |Non-current liabilities Current liabilities|76,330 318,441| |TOTAL LIABILITIES|394,771| ||| |Total net assets acquired|(52,943)| |Of which net assets acquired attributable to owners of the parent Of which net assets attributable to non-controlling interests (Optissimmo)|(53,071) 128| |Acquisition cost of shares|367,613| |Goodwill|420,683| ----- (ii) payment of an exceptional dividend of €478 million to the Group’s shareholders, namely Partners Group and Caisse de Dépôts et Placements du Québec (payment in the form of a reimbursement of the PIK shareholder loan between Flamingo Lux II and Emeria). Besides the payment of the dividend, the new borrowings will be used to finance acquisitions in an amount of €98.2 million. More specifically, the Group arranged a seven-year, €1.275 billion term loan B, with two bond issues completing the transaction: an issue of seven-year senior secured notes for €400 million and an issue of eight-year senior unsecured notes for €250 million. A revolving credit facility (RCF) was also set up for a total amount of €437.5 million. The main financial terms and conditions of these new borrowings are set out in Note 4.11.3. From both a quantitative and qualitative perspective, since this refinancing operation entails substantial modifications to loan terms, the original debt is extinguished and a new liability recognised. The unamortised issuance costs relating to the original debt were expensed in full in the statement of profit and loss at 25 March 2021 for a total amount of €15.3 million (see Note 5.9). Issuance costs on the new borrowings totalled €39.8 million, of which €0.5 million relates to the cost of early repayment of the original debt. These new issuance costs were classified as a reduction in debt in an amount of €39.3 million, and will be recognised over the term of the borrowings by adjusting the effective interest rate. The early repayment costs were recorded in other financial expenses for the year.

Subsection Title: Entry of TA Associates into the Group’s share capital
Subsubsection Text: Partners Group, the Group’s largest shareholder, expanded Foncia’s shareholder base in October in a recapitalisation deal for US investment firm TA Associates, which acquired an indirect 25% stake in the Company. Following the recapitalisation, Partners Group continues to hold a majority stake in the Company and guide the Group’s expansion in Europe. As part of the transaction, the PIK shareholder loan between Flamingo Lux II and Emeria was repaid in full on 16 November 2021 for a total amount of €111.6 million (including accrued interest). This repayment was made (i) in cash for €9.5 million and (ii) by conversion into Emeria capital for the remaining €102.1 million (capital increase by offsetting the amount owed to Flamingo Lux II by Emeria).

Subsection Title: NOTE 3. ACCOUNTING POLICIES AND METHODS General principles used to prepare the financial statements
Subsubsection Text: The accounting policies described in these notes have been applied consistently to all periods presented in the consolidated financial statements, with the exception of the amendments adopted as described in Note 3.2.2, effective as of 1 January 2021. The consolidated financial statements are prepared on a historical cost basis, except for certain financial instruments carried at fair value or amortised cost in accordance with IAS 32 and IFRS 9. The consolidated financial statements of Emeria at 31 December 2021 were adopted by the Supervisory Board at its meeting held on 13 April 2022, and will be submitted to shareholders for approval at the General Meeting on 30 June 2022. ----- They are presented in thousands of euros and amounts are rounded up or down to the nearest thousand unless otherwise specified. Consequently, the sum of these amounts may differ slightly from the total amounts reported.

Subsection Title: Group accounting standards 3.2.1.** **Basis of preparation of financial information
Subsubsection Text: Pursuant to Regulation (EC) No. 1606/2002 of 19 July 2002 as amended by Regulation (EC) No. 297/2008 of 11 March 2008, the 2021 consolidated financial statements have been prepared in accordance with the international financial reporting standards (IFRS) and interpretations issued by the International Accounting Standards Board (IASB) as adopted by the European Union and applicable at the reporting date. Information for the comparative period was prepared in accordance with the same accounting policies. The full text of the standards adopted by the European Union can be consulted on the European Commission’s website: https://ec.europa.eu/info/business-economy-euro/company-reporting-and-auditing/company-reporting_en Where there is no specific guidance from IFRS standards or IFRS IC interpretations, the Group refers to other IFRS standards dealing with similar issues or to the Conceptual Framework, in accordance with IAS 8 – Accounting Policies, Changes in Accounting Estimates and Errors. At the end of the reporting period, there was no difference between the IFRS used to prepare these financial statements and the standards adopted by the IASB and applicable for the period presented. The Group does not apply IFRS standards that had not yet been adopted by the European Union at the reporting date. It chose not to early adopt the standards, amendments and interpretations not mandatorily applicable at the reporting date. The accounting policies and bases of measurement applied to prepare these consolidated financial statements are described in Note 3.3 below. The consolidated financial statements include the financial statements of Emeria and the entities which it controls (subsidiaries). The financial statements of Emeria’s subsidiaries are prepared over the same period as those of the parent company, i.e., 1 January to 31 December 2021, using consistent accounting policies.

Subsection Title: 3.2.2.** **Changes in accounting standards Main IFRS standards, amendments and interpretations in force within the European Union and mandatorily applicable as of 1 January 2021
Subsubsection Text: The accounting policies and bases of measurement used by the Group to prepare its consolidated financial statements for the year ended 31 December 2021 are identical to those used by the Group at 31 December 2020, except for the following standards, interpretations and amendments, which are mandatorily applicable as of 1 January 2021: - Amendments to IFRS 16 – Covid-19-Related Rent Concessions beyond 30 June 2021 The application of the “Covid-19-Related Rent Concessions” amendment was extended by one year (payments due on or before 30 June 2022). The amendment allows lessees granted rent-free periods or rent reductions directly related to the Covid-19 to recognise them directly in the statement of profit and loss. It has no material impact on the Group’s financial statements. - Amendments to IFRS 9, IFRS 16 and IFRS 7 (phase 2) – Interest Rate Benchmark Reform These amendments, adopted on 13 January 2021, are applicable as of 1 January 2021. The reform of interest rate benchmarks led to the elimination of interbank rates, including Eonia and certain LIBOR rates, as of 1 January 2022, and their replacement as of that date. Most of the Group’s debt and derivatives contracts are indexed to 3-month Euribor. Consequently, the reform does not have a material impact on the Group’s financial statements. ----- In the first half of 2021, the IFRS Interpretations Committee (IFRS IC) issued several agenda decisions, including: - Final IFRS IC agenda decision on the attribution of benefit to periods of service In May 2021, the IASB endorsed the conclusions of the IFRS Interpretations Committee (IFRS IC) dated December 2020 regarding the basis for calculating the period of service to which an entity attributes benefit for a particular defined benefit plan. According to these conclusions, entities should consider periods of benefit entitlement and caps on those periods when recognising benefit obligations. Whereas the approach most commonly used in France was to recognise benefit obligations on a straight-line basis from the date the employee in question joined the entity to the date of their retirement, the IFRS IC considers that benefit obligations should only be recognised on a straight-line basis over the number of years of employee service immediately before the retirement age, and that said years of service should be capped. The Group took this  new  approach  into  account  when  measuring  its  employee  benefit  obligations  at 31 December 2021. In accordance with IAS 8 and in the absence of any transitional provisions to the contrary, any changes resulting from a final agenda decision issued by the IFRS IC are retrospectively applicable. The impact of this change in accounting policy was recognised in the statement of financial position retrospectively as of 1 January 2020, resulting in a €3.5 million decrease in the provision for retirement benefits and a corresponding €2.2 million increase in consolidated equity (net of tax). The consolidated financial statements for the year ended 31 December 2020 were also restated retrospectively to reflect the application of this agenda decision. These restatements are referred to throughout this document as “2020 (restated)”. The table below shows the resulting impacts on the statement of financial position at 31 December 2020, as estimated with the assistance of the actuary firm Mercer.
