|Consolidated statement of financial position 31 Dec. 2020 IAS 19 impact (€ thousands) (presented)|31 Dec. 2020 (restated)| |---|---| |Goodwill 1,445,430 (94)|1,445,336| |Non-current assets 2,756,574 (94)|2,756,480| ||| |Current assets 891,026|891,026| |TOTAL ASSETS 3,647,600 (94)|3,647,506| |Share capital 570,542 Consolidated reserves attributable to owners of (120,794) 2,443 the parent Profit (loss) for the period attributable to owners (58,009) 49 of the parent Equity attributable to owners of the parent 391,739 2,492 Non-controlling interests 3,010|570,542 (118,351) (57,960) 394,231 3,010| |Total equity 394,749 2,492|397,240| |Employee benefits 40,268 (3,489) Deferred tax liabilities 163,395 903|36,779 164,299| |Non-current liabilities 2,063,555 (2,586)|2,060,969| ||| |Current liabilities 1,189,296|1,189,296| ||| |TOTAL EQUITY AND LIABILITIES 3,647,600 (94)|3,647,506| ----- - IFRS IC agenda decision on accounting for configuration or customisation costs in a cloud computing arrangement (SaaS) In April 2021, the IASB confirmed the position taken by the IFRS IC in March 2021, following its tentative December 2020 decision on accounting for the cost of configuring or customising a supplier’s application software in a Software as a Service (SaaS arrangement). This question had been raised due to the variety of observed practices. The IFRS IC agenda decision confirms that in most cases, pursuant to IAS 38, these costs should be recognised as an expense and not as an intangible asset, because (i) the entity does not control the software and (ii) the customisation/configuration activities do not create a resource controlled by the customer that is separate from the software. These costs should therefore be expensed: - either when they are incurred if the developments are carried out internally or by a third-party supplier (unrelated to the SaaS solution publisher); - or over the term of the SaaS contract if the developments are carried out by the publisher of the SaaS solution or by its subcontractor. The Group’s review of this agenda decision brought to light various technical issues in terms of the analysis of the possible components of an SaaS project requiring the assistance of the IT department, and certain operational difficulties in collecting data with the necessary level of detail to understand the expenses incurred. Given the complexity of the analyses to be performed, this decision has not been applied in the consolidated financial statements for the year ended 31 December 2021. Similarly, the 2020 consolidated financial statements were not restated for this decision. The Group is currently analysing the contracts that may be affected by the decision.

Subsection Title: Other  standards, interpretations  and amendments  adopted by the European Union and effective as  of 1 January 2022
Subsubsection Text: - Amendments to IAS 16 – Property, Plant and Equipment – Proceeds before Intended Use From 1 January 2022, proceeds from the sale of items generated by an asset not yet in use will no longer be recognised as a deduction from the cost of the asset. These proceeds and the associated costs will have to be recorded in the statement of profit and loss. The Group does not expect the application of these amendments to have a material impact on its financial statements. - IAS 37 – Onerous Contracts – Cost of Fulfilling a Contract These amendments specify the costs to be considered in assessing whether a contract is onerous. The Group does not expect the application of these amendments to have a material impact on its financial statements. - Other standards and amendments: the Group does not expect the following standards and amendments to have a material impact on its financial statements: - Annual Improvements to IFRSs – 2018-2020 Cycle - IFRS 3 – Reference to the Conceptual Framework

Subsection Title: 3.2.3.** **Use of management estimates in applying the Group’s accounting standards
Subsubsection Text: In preparing its financial statements, the Group is required to make estimates and assumptions that may affect the measurement and presentation of certain assets, liabilities or contingent liabilities at the end of the reporting period, as well as the reported amounts of income and expenses for the period. ----- Estimates and underlying assumptions are determined based on information available at the end of the reporting period and are reviewed on a regular basis in light of past experience and other factors deemed reasonable given the current circumstances. These estimates serve as the basis for measuring the carrying amount of assets and liabilities that cannot be obtained directly from other sources. The estimates made by the Group in preparing its consolidated financial statements are based on a going concern assumption and relate primarily to the items described below. - Recoverable amount of goodwill, other intangible assets and property, plant and equipment The estimates and assumptions made to determine the recoverable amount of goodwill, intangible assets, and property, plant and equipment relate mainly to the market outlook used to estimate future cash flows and determine the discount rates used. Note 4.1.2 sets out the assumptions used to calculate future cash flows and determine the discount rates to be applied in measuring the recoverable amounts of these assets. Sensitivity analyses were also performed and are described in the same note. - Measurement of leases IFRS 16 requires entities to use certain key estimates, which include:  whether an option to extend or terminate a lease is reasonably certain to be exercised;  the lease term;  the appropriate discount rate to be used to calculate future lease payments;  the specific selling price of any lease components and non-lease components contained in the contract. The main assumptions used by the Group to prepare its 2021 financial statements are described in Note 4.4.3. - Measurement of assets and liabilities relating to post-employment plans The Group operates both defined contribution and defined benefit plans. Obligations under these plans are calculated using the projected unit credit method, which is based on assumptions regarding the discount rate, future increases in salary, employee turnover, life expectancy and the rate of increase in healthcare costs. Note 4.12 sets out the assumptions used to measure these obligations. The Group considers that the actuarial assumptions used are appropriate and justified in the current environment. However, the corresponding obligations may change if these assumptions also change. - Basis for determining the value of identifiable assets acquired and liabilities assumed as part of a business combination The estimates and assumptions used to determine the recoverable amount of these identifiable assets and liabilities relate in particular to the market outlook used to estimate future cash flows and determine the discount rates used. Any changes in these assumptions could impact the recoverable amount. In the absence of IFRS guidance for a specific transaction, event or condition, the Group uses its judgement to define and apply accounting policies that will result in relevant, fair and comparable information to ensure that the financial statements:  present a true and fair view of the Group’s financial position, financial performance and cash flows;  reflect the economic substance of transactions;  are neutral, prudent and comprehensive in all material respects. Detailed disclosures in this regard are provided in the notes to the consolidated financial statements. -----

Details of the main consolidated companies at 31 December 2021 are provided in Note 12 “Scope of consolidation”. Controlled entities Companies directly or indirectly controlled by the Group are fully consolidated. Control exists when the Group is exposed to risks or is entitled to variable returns from its involvement with the entity in question and has the ability to affect those returns through its power over the entity. Control is analysed whenever facts and circumstances indicate that one or more of the inputs used to assess control has changed. A subsidiary is consolidated as from the date control is acquired, which is usually upon signature of the share transfer and disposal agreements (see “Accounting for ongoing acquisitions” below). Consolidation ceases when control is relinquished. Any interest in the subsidiary that is not directly or indirectly attributable to the Group is recognised within noncontrolling interests. Profits and losses and each component of other comprehensive income relating to subsidiaries are allocated to owners of the parent and non-controlling interests, even if this results in non-controlling interests having a deficit balance. Changes in the percentage interest held in subsidiaries that do not lead to a change in control are treated as equity transactions, since the transactions take place between owners acting in their capacity as owners. The impact of these transactions is shown in equity net of tax and does not therefore impact consolidated profit or loss. These transactions are also shown in the statement of cash flows under cash flows relating to investing activities. Investments in equity-accounted companies (associates and joint ventures) Associates are entities over which the Group exercises significant influence. Significant influence is the power to participate in the financial and operating policy decisions of the entity without controlling or jointly controlling those policies. A joint venture is a joint arrangement whereby the parties that have joint control of the arrangement have rights to its net assets. Joint control of an arrangement only exists when decisions about the relevant activities require the unanimous consent of the parties sharing control. Profits, losses, assets and liabilities of associates or joint ventures are accounted for by the equity method in the Group’s consolidated financial statements. Under the equity method, the investment in an associate or joint venture is initially recognised at acquisition cost and subsequently adjusted for the Group’s interest in the profits, losses and other comprehensive income of the associate or joint venture. IAS 28 – Investments in Associates and Joint Ventures is applied in order to determine whether the Group’s investments in associates and joint ventures need to be tested for impairment. Where necessary, the total carrying amount of the investment (including goodwill) is tested for impairment in accordance with IAS 36 – Impairment of Assets. ----- Acquisitions in progress or carried out late in the year Before acquiring shares in a property management company, the Group agrees to acquire the shares and typically pays 10% of the estimated price to the seller. This part payment is included in “Downpayments on acquisitions of securities” within non-current financial assets (see Note 4.5). The remaining 90% is booked under off-balance sheet commitments (see Note 8). Note that at this point in the transaction, the Group does not yet have control over the entity being acquired. Upon signing the share transfer or disposal agreement, the Group pays an additional 70% of the estimated price to the seller. The provisional purchase price is then included in equity investments, and the part payment already recognised is also reclassified to this caption. The acquired company is then consolidated. Following a review of the acquired company’s financial statements, the Group pays the remaining balance and adjusts the purchase price of the shares. In the case of acquisitions completed late in the year (generally in November or December), even though the acquired companies may be controlled by the Group, they may not be consolidated until the following year, due to insufficient accounting information being available. The investment made is therefore temporarily carried in non-current financial assets at its acquisition cost (i.e., representing the fair value of the investment). The shares are included in “Investments in controlled companies pending consolidation” (see Note 4.5.). No other statement of financial position or profit and loss item is recorded. Non-consolidated investments Companies with the following characteristics are not included in the scope of consolidation: - they are in the process of being wound up or are dormant; - their business is not strategic for the Group. In accordance with IFRS 9, non-consolidated investments are carried at fair value through other comprehensive income. There are no material obligations or liabilities relating to these entities.

All intragroup transactions and balances as well as any income, expenses, gains and losses resulting from intragroup transactions and included in the carrying amount of assets are eliminated on consolidation. When a Group entity carries out a transaction with a joint venture or associate, the related gains and losses are recognised in the Group’s consolidated financial statements only to the extent of the interests held by third parties in the joint venture or associate.

Presentation currency The consolidated financial statements are presented in euros, which is the Group’s presentation currency. Functional currency and translation of the financial statements of foreign companies A consolidated entity’s functional currency is the currency of the primary economic environment in which it operates. In most cases, the functional currency is the local currency. However, certain entities must adopt a functional currency other than their local currency when that currency represents the currency of the major transactions carried out by the entity and accurately reflects its economic environment. The financial statements of foreign entities whose functional currency is different from the presentation currency of the Group’s consolidated financial statements are translated using the “closing rate” method, as follows: - assets and liabilities are translated at the closing exchange rate; ----- - statement of profit and loss and cash flow items are converted at the average exchange rate for the period. The resulting currency translation differences are recognised directly in other comprehensive income within equity under “Translation adjustments”. Goodwill relating to foreign entities whose functional currency is not the euro are treated as assets acquired or liabilities assumed and therefore translated at the exchange rate prevailing at the end of the reporting period. As the Group does most of its business in the eurozone, only its Swiss subsidiaries prepare financial statements in a currency other than the euro. The following exchange rates were used to prepare the consolidated financial statements: 2021 2020 Equivalent to €1 Closing rate Average rate Opening rate Closing rate Average rate Opening rate EUR (Euro) 1.0000 1.0000 1.0000 1.0000 1.0000 1.0000 GBP (Pound sterling) 0.8403 0.8595 N/A N/A N/A N/A CHF (Swiss franc) 1.0331 1.0812 1.0802 1.0802 1.0705 1.0952 The exchange rates used are the rates published by the Banque de France. Foreign currency transactions Foreign currency transactions are translated into euros at the exchange rates prevailing at the transaction date or at the hedged rate. At the end of the reporting period, monetary assets and liabilities denominated in foreign currency are translated at the closing exchange rate, with the resulting gains and losses included in foreign exchange gains and losses under other financial income and expenses in the statement of profit and loss. Non-monetary assets and liabilities denominated in foreign currency that are measured at historical cost are translated at the exchange rate at the transaction date. Non-monetary assets and liabilities denominated in foreign currency that are stated at fair value are translated at the exchange rate at the date on which fair value was determined. Loans granted to a foreign operation for which settlement is neither planned nor likely to occur in the foreseeable future are, in substance, part of the Group’s net investment in that foreign operation. Translation adjustments arising on monetary items that are part of a net investment in a foreign operation are recognised directly in other comprehensive income (equity) under “Foreign currency translation reserves”, and taken to profit or loss when the net investment is sold.

The Group uses the purchase method to account for its acquisitions of subsidiaries. The fair value of the consideration transferred reflects the fair value of the assets given, equity instruments issued and liabilities assumed or incurred by the acquirer at the date of exchange. Costs directly attributable to the business combination are expensed in the period in which they were incurred. On the first-time consolidation of a subsidiary or equity investment, the Group measures all identifiable items acquired at their acquisition-date fair value. The items are measured in the currency of the acquired company. In the event of deferred settlements, the future amounts payable are discounted to present value at the settlement date. The discount rate used is the same as that used to estimate the value of the assets. Fair value adjustments to assets and liabilities resulting from business combinations accounted for on a provisional basis (i.e., because the independent appraisals or ongoing additional analyses are incomplete) are recognised as retrospective adjustments to goodwill if they occur within 12 months of the acquisition (measurement period) and if ----- they result from facts and circumstances existing at the acquisition date. Adjustments made after the measurement period are taken directly to profit or loss, unless they are made to correct an error, including in relation to deferred tax assets which, if recognised more than 12 months after the acquisition date, generate tax income. Goodwill arising on acquisitions of associates and joint ventures is included in the carrying amount of “Investments in equity-accounted companies”. Goodwill The residual difference representing the excess of the fair value of the consideration transferred plus any noncontrolling interests in the acquired company over the acquisition-date fair value of the assets acquired and liabilities assumed is recognised in the consolidated statement of financial position as goodwill. For each business combination, the Group may choose to account for non-controlling interests: - either at acquisition-date fair value, resulting in the recognition of goodwill on the non-controlling interests (“full goodwill” method); - or based on the share of net identifiable assets of the acquired entity measured at fair value, in which case goodwill is only recognised on the portion attributable to owners of the parent (“partial goodwill” method). Goodwill is not amortised but is tested for impairment at least annually, or more frequently if there is evidence that it may be impaired. The impairment testing approach is described in Note 3.4.5 “Impairment of assets” below. Impairment recognised against goodwill may not be reversed. Bargain purchases When the acquisition-date fair value of the assets acquired and liabilities assumed of the acquired company exceeds the purchase price plus the amount of any non-controlling interests in the acquired company, the negative goodwill is taken immediately to profit or loss in the period of the acquisition, after verifying the procedure for identifying and measuring the various items included in its calculation. Transactions involving non-controlling interests Changes in non-controlling interests that do not result in gain or loss of control are recognised in equity. In particular, when additional shares are acquired in an entity already controlled by the Group, the difference between the purchase price of the shares and the additional share of consolidated equity acquired is recognised in equity attributable to owners of the parent. The consolidated carrying amount of the subsidiary’s identifiable assets and liabilities (including goodwill) remains unchanged. Contingent consideration and/or earn-out Contingent consideration or earn-outs relating to a business combination are measured at their acquisition-date fair value, even if it is deemed unlikely they will be paid. After the acquisition date, changes in the estimated fair value of contingent consideration/earn-outs result in an adjustment to goodwill only if they are made within the 12 months following the acquisition date (measurement period) and if they result from facts and circumstances existing at the acquisition date. In all other cases, any such changes are taken to profit or loss, unless the consideration transferred is an equity instrument. The revised IFRS 3 gives certain indications as regards the accounting for contingent payment arrangements with employees or selling shareholders. These arrangements may be part of the business combination or may be considered as separate from the acquisition agreement for the target entity. In certain acquisitions, earn-out payments were considered part of the consideration for post-acquisition services rendered and are therefore expensed in the periods concerned and in future periods. ----- Business combinations achieved in stages (step acquisitions) In a business combination achieved in stages, the Group’s previously-held equity interest in the acquired company is remeasured at fair value through profit or loss on the date control was obtained. Goodwill at the date control is obtained is calculated as the fair value of consideration transferred (i.e., price paid) plus the fair value of the Group’s previously-held equity interest in the acquired company. Put options granted to non-controlling interests As part of certain transactions, the Group may put in place options contracts regarding consolidated investments. These may be call, puts or even reciprocal options, which may or not be contingent on certain conditions. Analysing these options contracts is often complex and requires a good understanding of the economics of the transaction carried out, along with the substance of the commitments binding the different categories of shareholder concerned. Options are therefore accounted for on a case-by-case basis in light of all known facts and circumstances. In granting a put option to non-controlling interests, the Group sells those non-controlling interests an option under which they can sell their shares. The non-controlling interests can exercise their put option, thereby requiring the Group to purchase the underlying shares at a specified exercise price and future date. In the absence of specific guidance from IFRS, these options are accounted for by the Group as follows:  the present value of the commitment at the reporting date is included within “Liabilities relating to put options on non-controlling interests”;  the corresponding non-controlling interests are cancelled. This accounting method does not affect the presentation of non-controlling interests in the statement of profit and loss. Pending completion of the work in progress at the IASB and IFRS IC, and in accordance with the recommendations of the French financial markets authority (Autorité des Marchés Financiers – AMF) for companies preparing 2009 financial statements, subsequent changes in the value of the commitment are recognised in full by means of an adjustment to equity. When the put option is exercised, the Group derecognises the liability in respect of the deferred payment against the amount of cash effectively paid to the non-controlling interests.

Intangible assets are identifiable non-monetary assets with no physical substance. In accordance with IAS 38, intangible assets that are acquired separately are initially measured at cost when the future economic benefits attributable to the asset will flow to the Group and the cost of the asset can be measured reliably. Subsequent expenditure on intangible assets is included as part of the cost of those assets only if it increases the future economic benefits associated with the assets concerned. Other costs are expensed as incurred. Intangible assets acquired as part of a business combination that can be reliably measured, are controlled by the Group, and are separable or arise from legal or contractual rights are recognised at fair value separately from goodwill. Intangible assets are subsequently measured at cost less any accumulated amortisation and impairment losses. Intangible assets with a finite useful life (software and licences) are amortised on a straight-line basis over their expected useful lives: Client relationships: 18-21 years Software programs: 1-10 years Other intangible assets: 5 years Intangible assets with an indefinite useful life are not amortised. They are included with other assets within cashgenerating units (CGUs) and tested for impairment using the discounted cash flow method at least once a year and whenever there is an indication that they may be impaired. ----- When the recoverable amount of these assets calculated based on criteria prevailing at the acquisition date falls below their carrying amount, an impairment provision is recorded.

Identifiable trademarks are measured using a multi-criteria approach that takes into consideration both their reputation and profitability. The Group classified its main “Foncia” trademark, along with the “Lodgis”, “Trevi” and “Office des Propriétaires” trademarks in Belgium and the “Domicim”, “Brolliet” and “Gribi” trademarks in Switzerland, as indefinite-lived intangible assets. Costs incurred in creating a new trademark or developing an existing trademark are expensed.
Software acquired is carried at cost (purchase price plus ancillary expenses). When allocating the purchase price, certain software programs may also be measured using the replacement cost approach.

Client relationships include the list of mandates managed by the Group’s companies. A mandate is an instrument by which a person (the principal) gives another person (the agent) the power to carry out or enter into one or more legal actions or agreements, in the principal’s name. France’s Hoguet law requires professional property agents to hold a written mandate in order to put properties up for sale or to let, and to manage jointly owned property. In the majority of cases, client relationships are acquired separately as part of purchases of business goodwill and are therefore measured at cost. Client relationships can also be identified within the context of major business combinations, when they meet the identification and materiality criteria (in particular, the Group transacts on a recurring basis with the client). In this case, the Group uses the excess earnings method to measure the relationship. It should be noted that given the large number of external growth transactions carried out by the Group, client relationships are only identified and measured for major acquisitions.
Other intangible assets mainly comprise the cost of acquiring new business.

Property, plant and equipment are measured at their historical cost less accumulated depreciation and impairment losses. The cost of an item of property, plant and equipment comprises its purchase price, including customs duties and non-recoverable taxes, and any costs directly incurred to bring the asset to working condition for its intended use. Any trade discounts and rebates are deducted from the purchase price. Subsequent expenditure is included in the carrying amount of property, plant and equipment or is recognised as a separate component where appropriate, if it is probable that the future economic benefits associated with the asset will flow to the Group and the cost of the asset can be measured reliably. All other maintenance and repair costs are expensed as incurred, except for costs incurred to increase productivity or extend the useful life of an asset, which are capitalised. Property, plant and equipment are depreciated using the components approach over their estimated useful lives, taking into account any residual value. Straight-line depreciation is considered the method that best reflects the pattern in which the assets’ economic benefits are consumed by the Group: ----- - Buildings: 20-50 years - Fixtures and fittings: 8-10 years - IT equipment: 4 years - Vehicle fleet: 5 years - Furniture: 10 years - Office equipment: 4 years The residual values and useful lives of property, plant and equipment are reviewed at the end of each reporting period and adjusted where necessary. The carrying amounts of property, plant and equipment are tested for impairment when there is evidence that they may be impaired. Gains and losses on asset disposals are calculated as the difference between the sale proceeds and the carrying amount of the asset concerned.

The Group has many leases in which it acts as lessee across its entire French and international branch network. Its leases are of many different types, but are mainly leases of property or vehicles. Pursuant to IFRS 16 – Leases, on entering into a contract, the Group analyses the contractual provisions to determine whether it has the characteristics of a lease. It verifies whether the lease transfers in substance the right to control the use of an asset for a specified period of time in exchange for consideration. If these characteristics exist, as soon as the asset is made available the Group recognises: - a right-of-use asset, which represents its right to use the leased asset over the lease term; - a lease liability (“IFRS 16 lease liability”), which represents the present value of its obligation to make lease payments. The Group applies the same method to account for all leases in which it acts as lessee, and has chosen not to use the practical expedients set out in IFRS 16 exempting short-term leases (i.e., leases with terms of 12 months or less) or leases of low-value underlying assets from the scope of the standard. The amount of the right-of-use asset comprises: - the amount of the associated lease liability; - plus:  any lease payments made at or before the commencement date,  any initial direct costs incurred to obtain the lease,  any estimated restoration costs to be incurred by the Group; - less any lease incentives received. Right-of-use assets are subsequently measured at cost less any accumulated depreciation and any accumulated impairment losses. They are depreciated over the lease term or the useful life of the leased asset for accounting purposes, whichever is shorter. The lease liability represents the present value of: - fixed lease payments (including in-substance fixed payments), less any lease incentives receivable; ----- variable lease payments that depend on an index or a rate, initially measured using the index or rate at the commencement date; amounts expected to be payable by the Group under residual value guarantees; the exercise price of a purchase option if the Group is reasonably certain to exercise that option; penalties required for terminating the lease. Lease liabilities are subsequently measured by increasing the carrying amount to reflect interest on the lease liability (using the effective interest rate method) and by reducing the carrying amount to reflect the lease payments made. To determine the lease term, the Group analyses the contractual provisions of the lease, as illustrated below: Term The Group remeasures the lease liability (and adjusts the corresponding right-of-use asset accordingly), when: there is a change in the lease term or a change in the assessment of an option to purchase the underlying asset, in which cases the lease liability is remeasured by discounting the revised lease payments using a revised discount rate; there is a change in future lease payments resulting from a change in an index or rate, or a change in the amounts expected to be payable under a residual value guarantee, in which cases the lease liability is remeasured by discounting the revised lease payments using the initial discount rate; there is a change in the lease contract (lease modification) that is not accounted for as a separate lease, in which case the lease liability is remeasured by discounting the revised lease payments using a revised discount rate. When the Group incurs a material obligation to restore the asset to the condition specified in the lease contract, the related costs are included as part of the cost of the right-of-use asset and the corresponding lease liability is increased accordingly.

In certain specific businesses, the Group may enter into lease contracts as the lessor. This is notably the case for German subsidiary Vegis (acquisition carried out in January 2020), which sub-lets – mostly to students – accommodation which the company itself has leased. IFRS 16 first requires the contract to be identified as a sub-letting arrangement in accordance with provisions applicable to lessors, and then to determine whether that arrangement is a finance lease or an operating lease. Classification as a finance lease or an operating lease is based on the right-of-use asset obtained under the initial lease, and not on the underlying asset. To determine whether a lease is a finance lease or an operating lease, the Group performs an broad analysis to determine whether the contract transfers substantially all of the risks and rewards inherent to ownership of the leased asset to its client (the lessee). ----- To perform this analysis, the Group determines whether: (i) the lease transfers ownership of the underlying asset to the client by the end of the lease term, (ii) the lease term is for the major part of the economic life of the underlying asset, and (iii) the present value of the lease payments amounts to substantially all of the fair value of the underlying asset. This will then determine the accounting treatment applicable to the initial lease and to any sub-letting income. The asset recorded in respect of the initial lease is not derecognised and continues to be depreciated. Lease payments collected from the lessee in the sub-letting arrangement are taken to revenue. Based on their contractual characteristics, all of the Group’s sub-letting arrangements meet the definition of an operating lease within the meaning of IFRS 16. The asset recorded in respect of the initial lease is not derecognised and continues to be depreciated. Lease payments collected from the lessee in the sub-letting arrangement are taken to revenue.

Subsection Title: 3.4.5.** **Impairment of assets Impairment of assets with finite useful lives
Subsubsection Text: Property, plant and equipment and intangible assets with finite useful lives are tested for impairment whenever there is evidence that they may be impaired. Impairment recognised in profit or loss against property, plant and equipment and intangible assets may be reversed.

Subsection Title: Impairment of assets with indefinite useful lives
Subsubsection Text: Goodwill and other intangible assets with indefinite useful lives are tested for impairment at least annually, or more frequently if there is evidence that they may be impaired. Cash-generating units For the purposes of these impairment tests, non-current assets that cannot be tested individually for impairment as they do not generate cash inflows that are largely independent of the cash inflows from other assets or groups of assets, are grouped into cash-generating units (CGUs). Impairment tests are carried out on each CGU or group of CGUs at the lowest level at which goodwill is monitored by the Group. A CGU is the smallest identifiable group of assets that generates cash inflows that are largely independent of the cash inflows from other assets or groups of assets for internal management purposes. The CGUs identified by the Group correspond to its major development and investment strategies. The Group has defined the following three cash-generating units: - Property Management France CGU, which includes the management of jointly owned properties, rental management, lettings, the transactions business and client mandates; - Property Management International CGU, which includes the property management and transactions businesses in Germany, Switzerland and Belgium; - Group of Services CGUs, which includes Constatimmo (brokerage for technical surveys), Assurimo (insurance brokerage), Efficity (property appraisals website), FPM and Esset Management (B2B property management), Prowen (brokerage specialised in energy purchases), Seiitra (property management software development), Tech-way (technical maintenance) and Lodgis (furnished rentals). The Group decides whether or not to recognise an impairment loss by comparing the carrying amount of the assets and liabilities in a CGU or group of CGUs with their recoverable amount. ----- Impairment indicators External indicators of impairment include changes in the general economic and financial environment, downtrends in local economic environments and changes in economic performance. These are analysed by the Group to determine whether the assets concerned should be tested for impairment more frequently. Method used to determine the recoverable amount An impairment loss is recognised in the statement of profit and loss when the carrying amount of an asset or CGU exceeds its recoverable amount. The recoverable amount of an asset or CGU is the higher of: - its fair value less the costs of disposal, representing the amount at which the Group could sell the asset (after selling costs) in an arm’s length transaction between market participants at the measurement date; and - its value in use, representing the present value of the future cash flows expected to be derived from the continuing use and ultimate sale of an asset or CGU based on the most probable assumptions adopted by management. Fair value net of the costs of disposal is calculated based on available information used to establish the best estimate of the selling price net of costs to sell in an arm’s length transaction between fully informed, consenting parties. Value in use of CGUs or groups of CGUs is determined based on post-tax cash flows resulting from business plans and a terminal value calculated by extrapolating data for the last year of the business plan. The assumptions used are based on the budgets and business plans prepared by management for each business. These budgets are the latest budgets approved at the date of preparation of the financial statements. Other assumptions affecting the calculation of the recoverable amount include the growth rate, operating margin, the discount rate and the tax rate (see Note 4.1.2). The discount rate used to discount post-tax cash flows to their present value reflects current market assessments of the time value of money and the risks specific to the asset or CGU. Where there is no specific discount rate for the assets tested, the average cost of capital is used. The discount rates are post-tax rates and are applied to post-tax cash flows. The recoverable amount calculated using post-tax discount rates is equal to that which would have been obtained using pre-tax rates applied to pre-tax cash flows, as required by IAS 36.

If the carrying amount of the CGU exceeds its recoverable amount, the related assets are written down to the recoverable amount. The impairment loss is first allocated to goodwill and then to the carrying amount of the other assets of the CGU, in proportion to their carrying amount. This must not result in the carrying amount of an individual asset falling below the higher of its fair value, value in use and zero. Impairment losses are recognised in other nonrecurring operating expenses and may not be reversed.

Impairment losses recognised against goodwill cannot be reversed. Impairment losses recognised against assets other than goodwill may only be reversed if there is evidence that the impairment loss may have decreased or may no longer exist. The amount reversed is then based on revised estimates of the asset’s recoverable amount. The increased carrying amount of an asset attributable to the reversal of an impairment loss should not exceed the carrying amount that would have been determined had no impairment loss been recognised for the asset. -----

Trade and other receivables are carried at amortised cost, corresponding to their face value less any impairment losses recorded in the statement of profit and loss. In view of its business activities, the Group is exposed to limited bad debt risk on its commercial receivables as the risk is concentrated mainly in the B2B business, which accounts for less than 5% of consolidated revenue.
The measurement and recognition of financial assets and liabilities is defined by IFRS 9 – Financial instruments.

Financial assets include financial investments, shares in companies acquired in the process of being consolidated, deposits and guarantees paid, other long-term receivables, derivative instruments with a positive fair value and cash and cash equivalents. IFRS 9 applies a single analytical framework to all financial assets in order to determine the classification and basis of measurement to be used for accounting purposes. More specifically:  **Financial assets at amortised cost Financial assets that will be recovered through repayments of contractual cash flows (i.e., repayments of principal and interest on the principal amount outstanding) are generally carried at amortised cost. Financial assets at amortised cost include operating financial assets, other loans and receivables and trade receivables. They are initially recognised at fair value and subsequently carried at amortised cost calculated using the effective interest rate method. In accordance with IFRS 9, financial assets at amortised cost are written down by the amount of any expected credit losses. Impairment losses relating to commercial receivables are recognised in recurring operating profit items, while those relating to other financial assets are recognised in financial expenses.  **Assets at fair value through other comprehensive income reclassifiable to profit or loss Financial assets that will be recovered both through repayments of contractual cash flows (i.e., repayments of principal and interest on the principal amount outstanding) and through sales of those assets are generally carried at fair value through other comprehensive income. Changes in the fair value of these assets are recognised directly in other comprehensive income, with the exception of interest income and dividends, which are included in other financial income and expenses. Changes in fair value are reclassified to profit or loss when the assets are sold.  **Assets at fair value through other comprehensive income This category includes downpayments to equity investments and investments in non-consolidated companies, and equity instruments that the Group has irrevocably elected to classify in this category. When these investments are sold, the unrealised gains and losses previously carried in other comprehensive income will not be reclassified to profit or loss; only dividends will be taken to profit or loss. Fair value corresponds to the market price for listed securities or to the estimated fair value for unlisted securities, as determined according to the financial criteria most appropriate to the particular situation of each investment. The fair value of equity investments whose price is not quoted on an active market is determined based on the latest known transactions involving these investments.  **Assets at fair value through profit or loss All other debt and equity instruments are carried at fair value through profit or loss. These include marketable securities with an underlying term of more than three months, other financial assets held for trading and purchased for sale in the near term, and financial instruments with a positive fair value that are not eligible for hedge accounting. These assets are measured at fair value, with changes in fair value taken to financial income and expenses. ----- At the acquisition date, the Group determines the classification of financial assets into one of the IFRS 9 categories based on the characteristics of the instrument and the business model for managing the assets. The table below provides an overview of classification by financial asset category, along with the corresponding measurement approach:

Subsection Title: Classification and measurement of financial assets** **Nature of cash flows** **Business model** **Measurement
Subsubsection Text: Financial investments Acquisitions of companies in the process of being consolidated Downpayments on acquisitions of securities Equity instruments **FV through OCI Other long-term investments Equity instruments **FV through OCI Deposits and guarantees paid SPPI Hold-to-collect Amortised cost Other long-term receivables Derivative instruments (positive fair value) NR NR FV through PL
Trade and other receivables SPPI Hold-to-collect Amortised cost Marketable securities Cash SPPI Other FV through PL

Financial liabilities include borrowings and other payables as well as bank overdrafts. With the exception of trading liabilities and derivative instruments representing liabilities carried at fair value, borrowings and other financial liabilities are initially recognised at fair value less transaction costs, and subsequently at amortised cost calculated using the effective interest method. The effective interest rate is the rate that exactly discounts the estimated future cash payments or receipts through the expected life of the financial instrument or, as appropriate, through a shorter period, to the net carrying amount of the financial asset or liability. Trade payables and other liabilities meet the definition of financial liabilities at amortised cost as defined by IFRS 9 – Financial Instruments. These financial liabilities are initially recognised at nominal value, insofar as this represents a reasonable estimate of their fair value given their short-term nature.

The Group uses derivative instruments to hedge interest rate risks on floating-rate borrowings and foreign exchange risks. In accordance with IAS 32 and IFRS 9, derivative instruments are measured on the statement of financial position at fair value. Changes in the fair value of instruments not eligible for hedge accounting are recognised in profit or loss under other financial income and expenses.

Cash and cash equivalents comprise cash at bank and on hand, as well as short-term highly-liquid deposits with an initial maturity of three months or less and subject to an insignificant risk of changes in value. Short-term investments are measured at market value at the end of each reporting period, with any changes in market value taken to financial income and expenses. ----- Investments in listed equities along with investments with an initial maturity of over three months and no early exit option are excluded from cash and cash equivalents and classified as current or non-current financial assets. Bank overdraft facilities are excluded from cash and cash equivalents and included in current borrowings and debit. Changes in the fair value of these instruments are recorded in profit or loss. For the purposes of the consolidated statement of cash flows, net cash and cash equivalents include the items defined above, net of short-term bank overdrafts.

The Group conducts its property management business through mandates signed with clients, under which the companies are responsible for holding client funds. These funds consist of liquid assets received as guarantees, rent and expenses, joint ownership working capital and renovation funds, and funds received in connection with the transactions business. As an agent, the Group undertakes to hold client accounts and to recognise them in its statement of financial position using a specific account for each activity (property sales, rentals and management). The amount shown for client accounts within assets is equivalent to the amount shown for these accounts in liabilities.

A provision is recognised when, at the end of the reporting period, the Group has a legal or constructive obligation to a third party resulting from a past event that is likely to give rise to an outflow of resources embodying economic benefits and can be measured reliably. Provisions may also be recognised for contingent liabilities arising on business combinations. In this case, they are initially recognised at fair value at the acquisition date. When the Group expects partial or full repayment of the provision, for example owing to an insurance policy, the repayment is booked as a separate asset but only if such repayment is virtually certain. When the effect of the time value of money is material, the amount of the provision reflects the present value of the expenditure expected to be required to settle the obligations, as calculated using a pre-tax discount rate reflecting current market assessments of the time value of money and, where applicable, the risks specific to the liability. Since provisions are calculated based on estimated future contingencies and expenses, they are measured taking into account the assumptions deemed most probable at the reporting date. Items giving rise to provisions (trade and employee disputes, etc.) are reviewed regularly to allow for any adjustments. Provisions include amounts accrued in respect of business, employee-related and/or tax (excluding income tax) risks and disputes arising in the ordinary course of operations, as described below:  Employee-related provisions (disputes, lay-offs, etc.) At the end of each reporting period, a provision is recognised and adjusted in line with the risk exposure, as assessed by the Group’s Human Resources department on a case-by-case basis.  Provisions for rent payment guarantees A rent payment guarantee is offered to lessors who have entrusted Emeria with the management of their property. Emeria bears the cost of any unpaid rent and advances to owners. These advances are not always recoverable from the lessee and therefore represent a risk of non-recovery. Rent payment guarantees are incidental to the property management contracts (deriving from the del credere agreement) and are accounted for as follows: - the related fees are recorded continuously in income over the period of the mandate, since they are deducted from rents in the same way as basic fees; - once rent is reported as unpaid, a provision is recorded, calculated in accordance with IAS 37. ----- The amount of the provision set aside by the Group increases in line with the age of the unpaid receivable. Provisions for rent payment guarantees are calculated by reference to late payments relating to current and former lessees, regardless of whether or not lessee statement of accounts (Arrêtés des Comptes Locataires – ACL) have been drawn up, taking into account the probability of collection (assessed on a statistical basis and regularly updated).  Provision for occupancy guarantees An occupancy guarantee is offered to lessors who have entrusted Emeria with the management of their property. The provision for occupancy guarantees is calculated on a statistical basis by reference to the probable residual vacant period for properties currently vacant and subject to occupancy guarantees. The provision is estimated based on the firm’s average monthly rent. The maximum term of claims is 180 days.  Provision for URSSAF social security audits This concerns in-progress and completed URSSAF social security audits. A provision is booked and adjusted at the end of each reporting period in line with the related risk exposure, as assessed by the Group’s Payroll department on a case-by-case basis.  Provisions for risks on client accounts Provisions for risks on client accounts are designed to cover the non-collection risk on lost client accounts in debit, as well as other risks on client accounts. A provision is booked and adjusted at the end of each reporting period in line with the risk exposure on client accounts, as assessed by the Group’s Client Operations department on a case-by-case basis.  Provisions for third party and professional liability These provisions are recorded based on information provided by senior managers in charge of monitoring claims against their firm. The Audit, Legal and Accounting departments have the final decision in terms of whether or not to record a provision. If the claim is reported and covered by the liability insurance, the maximum provision will reflect the amount of the deductible (€15,000 as of 1 January 2014) or the amount of the estimated risk, whichever is lower. If the claim is not reported, the senior manager concerned sets the amount to be provisioned.  Provisions for other disputes These provisions are intended to cover disputes, litigation and other foreseeable contingencies in connection with the Group’s businesses, along with miscellaneous contingencies and expenses.

Subsection Title: 3.4.11.** **Share-based payment and employee benefits Share-based payment
Subsubsection Text: In some circumstances, some of the Group’s employees may receive compensation in an arrangement involving a share-based payment. At 31 December 2021, there were no other stock option or free share plans within the Group. -----

As part of its acquisition-led growth strategy and in order to accelerate its organisational realignment, in 2020 the Group appointed a new management team in Germany. The new management team is responsible for developing the portfolio of mandates managed through selective acquisitions, and for the organisational and operational realignment processes. In connection with this appointment, the Group granted a long-term incentive plan with the following terms and conditions:  Grant date: 1 June 2020.  Reference period: 2 January 2020 to 31 December 2025.  Performance conditions: LTIP = % performance x equity value, with: (i) Equity value = Enterprise value - cash investments made in connection with acquisitions during the reference period. (ii) Enterprise value = 10 x increase in EBITDA during the reference period. (iii) % performance = progressive rate (between 3% and 5%) based on revenue earned in 2025. In accordance with IFRS 2, the service cost is recognised on a straight-line basis over the vesting period against an employee-related payable. The fair value of this liability will be remeasured at each reporting date until the liability is settled, based on assumptions used in the budget. In 2021, the cost of this incentive plan represented €0.9 million, and is shown in non-recurring operating items.

 Short-term benefits Short-term benefits include paid annual leave, paid sick leave, bonuses and other benefits (other than contract termination benefits), expected to be settled wholly before 12 months after the end of the annual reporting period during which the employee services are rendered. Short-term benefits are expensed in the period in which the corresponding services are rendered by the employee. Any amounts not paid at the end of the reporting period are carried in current liabilities.  Post-employment benefits In accordance with the laws and practices in each of the countries in which the Group operates, Emeria participates in, or operates, benefit plans providing for the payment of post-employment benefits (including retirement benefits) to eligible current and former employees, retirees and their beneficiaries. Virtually all of the Group’s employees are entitled to pension benefits. In France, this takes the form of payments by the Emeria Group to the beneficiaries when the rights allotted vest, while in Switzerland, plans are managed by pension funds financed in compliance with the applicable government requirements and regulations. These plans may be funded by investments in various instruments such as insurance policies, equity instruments and bonds. Post-employment benefits are measured and recognised by the Group in accordance with IAS 19 – Employee Benefits, as described below. - Defined contribution plans Defined contribution plans and multi-employer plans are expensed as incurred in the statement of profit and loss based on contributions. - Defined benefit plans The cost of defined benefit plans is measured on an actuarial basis. The related obligations are calculated by independent actuaries using the projected unit credit method, based on the agreements in effect in each company. ----- Obligations are determined by reference to assumptions that are revised each year and relate for example to length of service, life expectancy, salary inflation and employee turnover, and also take into account macroeconomic assumptions for the various countries in which the Group does business (e.g., discount rate and inflation rate). The assumptions used for 2021 are detailed in Note 4.12. A provision is recognised in the statement of financial position for the difference between the related projected benefit obligation (actuarial liability) and any plan assets as measured at fair value, and includes past service costs and actuarial gains and losses. If plan assets exceed the projected benefit obligation recognised, a non-current asset is recorded for the amount of the plans in the consolidated statement of financial position. A funding surplus (net defined benefit asset) is only recognised in the statement of financial position if its represents future economic benefits that will actually be available to the Group. When the calculation of the net benefit obligation gives rise to an asset for the Group, the amount recognised as an asset cannot exceed the present value of any economic benefits available in the form of future refunds from the plan or future reductions in contributions to the plan. Expenses under defined benefit plans comprise three components, accounted for as described below: - Service cost is recognised under personnel costs within operating profit. It includes service cost for the period, past service cost resulting from plan amendments or curtailments, which are recognised in full in profit or loss for the period in which they arose, and gains and losses arising on plan settlements. - Interest cost is recognised in other financial income and expenses and reflects the impact of discounting the obligations, net of the expected return on plan assets as measured using the discount rate applied to calculate those obligations. - Remeasurements of the net liability (or net asset) are included in other comprehensive income not reclassifiable to profit or loss, and do not impact the statement of profit and loss. They essentially comprise actuarial gains and losses, i.e., changes in the benefit obligation and in plan assets attributable to changes in assumptions and experience adjustments. Experience adjustments represent the difference between the expected impact of certain actuarial assumptions applied to previous measurements of the obligation and actual experience.  Other long-term benefits Other long-term benefits are measured in accordance with IAS 19. The estimated cost of these benefits is recognised within non-current liabilities over the employees’ qualifying years of service. Actuarial gains and losses and past service costs attributable to amendments to an existing plan or the introduction of a new plan are taken immediately to profit or loss. In France, the collective bargaining agreement for the real estate industry stipulates that all active employees who so request are entitled to one month’s salary at every anniversary date: after 20, 30, 35 and 40 years of professional experience. Professional experience is considered overall and not as experience solely within the Group. However, the Group is only liable for the amount proportionate to the employee’s seniority in the Group. The Group’s obligation under long-service awards is assessed each year by an independent expert. The assumptions used for 2021 are detailed in Note 4.12. -----

Deferred taxes are recognised on temporary differences between the carrying amount of assets and liabilities and their value for tax purposes, using the tax rates expected to apply in the period in which the asset is realised and the liability settled, on the basis of tax laws that have been enacted or substantively enacted at the reporting date. Deferred tax does not arise on: - the initial recognition of goodwill; - the initial recognition of an asset in a transaction that is not a business combination and affects neither the accounting profit (loss) nor taxable profit (loss); - temporary differences related to investments in subsidiaries, to the extent that it is probable they will not reverse in the foreseeable future. Tax on items recognised directly in equity or in other comprehensive income is recognised in equity or in other comprehensive income, respectively, and not in the statement of profit and loss. Deferred tax assets arising on temporary differences (after offsetting against deferred tax liabilities) or on tax losses and tax credits carried forward are only recognised to the extent that it is probable they will reverse and that the Group will generate future taxable earnings against which they can be utilised pursuant to local tax laws. The following are taken into account when assessing the Group’s ability to recover these assets: - forecasts of future taxable earnings; - taxable earnings in previous years. Deferred tax assets and liabilities are offset if there is a legally enforceable right to offset current tax assets and liabilities, and if they relate to income taxes levied by the same taxation authority on the same taxable entity.

Trade payables and other current liabilities are liabilities to be settled or renegotiated within the ordinary operating cycle or within 12 months following the end of the reporting period. Trade payables and other liabilities meet the definition of financial liabilities at amortised cost as defined by IFRS 9 – Financial Instruments (see Note 3.4.7). These financial liabilities are initially recognised at nominal value, insofar as this represents a reasonable estimate of their fair value given their short-term nature. The value of items that will be paid over the long term is discounted.

Subsection Title: 3.4.14.** **Classification and measurement of financial assets and liabilities at fair value
Subsubsection Text: The fair value of all financial assets and liabilities is determined at the end of the reporting period, either for accounting purposes or for disclosure in the notes to the financial statements. Fair value is the price that would be received to sell an asset or paid to transfer a liability in an orderly transaction between market participants at the measurement date. IFRS 13 sets out a three-level hierarchy for determining fair value: - Level 1: quoted (unadjusted) prices in active markets for identical assets or liabilities. - Level 2: inputs other than quoted market prices included within Level 1 that are observable for the asset or liability, either directly (i.e., prices) or indirectly (i.e., price-based inputs). - Level 3: inputs relating to the asset or liability which are not based on observable market data (unobservable inputs). ----- The Group primarily uses fair value on a recurring basis in its statement of financial position to measure derivative instruments, cash and cash equivalents, available-for-sale financial assets, cash management financial assets and identifiable assets and liabilities acquired as part of a business combination. The fair values of financial assets and liabilities are disclosed in Note 4.18.

Subsection Title: 3.4.15.** **Assets classified as held for sale, businesses sold or in the process of sale and discontinued operations
Subsubsection Text: IFRS 5 – Non-current Assets Held for Sale and Discontinued Operations sets forth the accounting requirements applicable to assets held for sale, along with the presentation and disclosure requirements for discontinued operations. IFRS 5 requires assets held for sale to be presented on a separate line of the consolidated statement of financial position for the lower of their carrying amount and their fair value less costs to sell, provided that they meet the definition of assets held for sale set out in the standard. When the Group is engaged in a sale process resulting in the loss of control of a subsidiary, the entire assets and liabilities of that subsidiary are classified as held for sale when their carrying amount will be principally recovered through a sale transaction rather than through continuing use, regardless of whether or not the Group retains a residual interest in the subsidiary after the sale. For this to be the case, the asset (or disposal group) must be available for immediate sale in its present condition and the sale must be highly probable. The assets and liabilities concerned are reclassified in assets held for sale and liabilities related to assets held for sale, and no offsetting is permitted. Businesses held for sale or discontinued are presented on a separate line in the statement of profit and loss for the periods presented, which shows post-tax profit or loss attributable to discontinued operations and the post-tax gain or loss on the disposal or the measurement to fair value less costs to sell of the assets or disposal groups comprising the business sold or in the process of sale. Operations that are abandoned or discontinued are defined as a component of an entity that represents a separate major line of business and meets the criteria for classification as an asset held for sale or has been sold by the Group. Similarly, cash flows attributable to abandoned or discontinued operations are presented on a separate line of the consolidated statement of cash flows for the periods presented. Under IFRS 5, profits or losses related to discontinued operations are also to be shown on a separate line of the consolidated statement of profit and loss, retrospectively for all periods presented. A discontinued operation can be defined as a component of an entity that either has been disposed of or is classified as held for sale and: - represents a separate major line of business or geographical area of operations; - is part of a single coordinated plan to dispose of a separate major line of business or geographical area of operations; or - is a subsidiary acquired exclusively with a view to resale.

Subsection Title: 3.4.16.** **Presentation of the statement of profit and loss
Subsubsection Text: As permitted under IAS 1 – Presentation of Financial Statements, the Group has chosen to present operating expenses by nature. “Recurring operating profit (loss)”, “Operating profit (loss)”, “Cost of gross debt” and “Cost of net debt” in the statement of profit and loss and gains and losses recognised directly in equity are presented in accordance with the criteria set out in ANC Recommendation No. 2013-03 issued by the French accounting standards-setter (Autorité des _Normes Comptables)._ -----

Revenue for the Group results from sales of services within the scope of the ordinary operations of consolidated subsidiaries, less revenue from intragroup transactions. Revenue is measured at the fair value of the consideration received or receivable, net of discounts and rebates, VAT and other taxes and duties. In accordance with IFRS 15, the Group recognises revenue when the amount thereof can be reliably measured, it is probable that future economic benefits will flow to the Group, and specific criteria are met by each of the Group’s businesses.  **Jointly owned property management business From a contractual and legal perspective, the Group’s jointly owned property management business is mostly conducted through mandates, and fees are calculated on a flat-rate basis. In France, this flat rate includes all basic management services provided by the jointly owned property association, and excludes incidental services such as: - preparing, convening and organising General Meetings; - managing the joint owners’ council; - managing the financial operations and keeping the accounts of the jointly owned property association; - managing the jointly owned property in compliance with its rules and regulations; - carrying out periodic visits and inspections of the jointly owned property. All such services are treated as an overall performance obligation satisfied over time. In fact, these different services are associated with a single performance obligation, i.e., management of the jointly owned property association. Annual revenue from basic property management fees is therefore recognised on a straight-line basis over the period during which the services are provided. Incidental services may be added to the basic management services and are invoiced based on an agreed rate for each such service, for example, additional meetings and visits, rules and regulations of the jointly owned property, physical and administrative management of claims, technical work and surveys, litigation and disputes. Since each additional service represents a separate performance obligation, revenue is recognised when the service is performed.  **Rental management business In its rental management business, the Group acts as agent for owners-lessors and fulfils a certain number of contractually defined obligations in this regard. These mainly concern: - routine management services, for example, rent reviews and collection, annual adjustment invoice for expenses, sending of rent receipts to lessees, and deposits; - other one-off management services, including preparation of the lease contract, inventory of premises, compilation of documentation, management of claims, administrative filings, and requests for subsidies; - technical management services, such as on-site repairs, mandatory technical surveys, and preparation of essential information documents for lessees; - insurance against unpaid rent; - other insurance such as for vacant premises or property damage. These represent separate service obligations. Accordingly, revenue for each of these obligations is recognised separately. Revenue from services provided over time, such as routine management services and insurance (falling outside the scope of IFRS 4) is recognised on a straight-line basis by reference to the frequency with which expenses are rebilled to the owners. Revenue from one-off services is recognised when those services are provided. -----  **Lettings Revenue is recognised at the time the inventory of the premises is conducted. The Group collects fees from owners and from lessees.  **Transactions business/Efficity Revenue on the transactions business is recognised upon signature of the notarised final sale agreement (acte _authentique), which is the date on which control is presumed to have been transferred._  **Client accounts Interest income generated on client funds is booked in revenue.  **Assurimo Assurismo provides property insurance brokerage services. Revenue under comprehensive property insurance and comprehensive homeowners’ insurance policies is recognised over the term of the cover, since services in this brokerage business are provided on a straight-line basis.  **Constatimmo Constatimmo carries out mandatory technical surveys on premises, as well as inventories of premises for lessees. Its revenue is recognised and measured when the related services are performed.  **Seiitra Seiitra provides specialist IT property services and developed the Thetrawin software, which it markets through the sale of software licenses. These property management tools offer the full suite of functionalities needed to keep accounting records for client accounts and to manage suspense accounts, jointly owned properties and rentals, as well as the budget of jointly owned property associations. Maintenance fees are recognised on a straight-line basis, since the corresponding services are provided over time.  **Esset Management Esset Management provides property management services (jointly owned property management and rental services) for institutions. The accounting principles applied are the same as those explained above for the private property management business.  **Foncia Valorisation Foncia Valorisation provides investment strategy consulting and arbitrage (appraisals, lending, block/unit property sales) for institutional clients or wealthy families. Its revenue is recognised upon signature of the notarised final sale agreement and is based on a percentage of the sale price.

Recurring operating profit (loss) includes all income and expenses directly related to the Group’s businesses, with the exception of items classified within “Non-recurring operating income (expenses)”. Recurring operating profit (loss) is a performance indicator that may serve as a method for estimating recurring performance. It includes all items included in operating profit (loss), restated for any non-recurring items. Costs relating to mergers and acquisitions or restructuring are excluded from recurring operating profit. -----

This caption includes non-recurring income and expense items that, owing to their nature, amount or frequency, cannot be considered as arising in the ordinary course of the Group’s operations and are therefore not reported in recurring operating profit (loss). They include impacts of changes in the scope of consolidation, goodwill impairment, and non-recurring amortisation and impairment charged against trademarks and software. If material, non-recurring items also include the effects of certain unusual transactions such as capital gains and losses on disposals of non-current assets, restructuring fees, fees relating to major claims and disputes, and any other non-recurring income or expenses. It should be noted that for transactions directly related to external growth and projects to transform or restructure the business (particularly mergers and reorganisations), a detailed procedure is in place to identify, classify and validate any transactions of a non-recurring nature. This procedure gives a precise indication of transactions that meet the criteria to be recorded in this category.

Operating profit (loss) includes all income and expenses directly related to the Group’s businesses, irrespective of whether they are of a recurring nature or whether they result from one-off decisions or transactions.
The cost of net debt is equal to all financial expenses incurred by the Group on borrowings and lease liabilities pursuant to IFRS 16, less financial income from cash investments.

Income tax expense for the year includes current and deferred income tax expense, which are recognised in the statement of profit and loss except when they relate to items recognised in other comprehensive income. The Group calculates its current taxes in accordance with the tax legislation applicable in the countries in which its earnings are taxable. Current tax expense is calculated on the basis of tax laws enacted or substantively enacted at the reporting date in countries where the Group’s subsidiaries operate and generate taxable profit. However, management periodically reviews the positions adopted in tax returns for situations in which tax regulations are subject to interpretation. Where applicable, a provision is set aside based on the amounts payable to the tax authorities. Income tax expense includes the amounts reported by French subsidiaries in respect of the CVAE tax assessed on value added, since the Group considers this tax meets the definition of income tax set out in IAS 12 – Income Taxes. When they have not been set against income tax, income tax credits that are not included in the calculation of taxable profit and that are always refunded by the State are recorded as subsidies and reduce the expenses to which they relate.

Earnings (loss) per share corresponds to profit (loss) attributable to holders of ordinary shares divided by the weighted average number of ordinary shares outstanding during the reporting period (excluding treasury shares).
The Group is not concerned by IFRS 8 – Operating Segments. Revenue is broken down by business in Note 5.1. -----

Consolidated cash and cash equivalents, changes in which are displayed in the statement of cash flows, are defined as the net balance of cash and cash equivalents, current bank overdraft facilities and bank credit balances repayable on demand that form an integral part of the cash management strategy. Changes in cash from operating activities are calculated based on operating profit (loss) adjusted for transactions with no cash impact.

finalising the purchase price accounting for its most important acquisitions in 2020 and 2021, the Group recognised:  client relationships for a cumulative amount of €84.5 million (see Note 4.2), to
