The process of identifying the assets acquired and liabilities assumed as part of the acquisitions of Agda, Immo de Corse, Intercity in Switzerland and R&M in Germany was still in progress at 31 December 2021. Accordingly, the goodwill currently recognised is provisional.

The assumptions used in the tests and the approach applied are described below. Calculation of the carrying amount of CGUs at 31 December 2021 Estimating the carrying amount of each CGU includes determining the value of the assets that may be directly attributed or reasonably allocated to the CGU and that will generate cash flows included in the calculation of value in use. However, the carrying amount does not include that of identified liabilities. In 2018, goodwill of €1,094.9 million arising on the acquisition of a controlling interest in Emeria Holding (formerly Foncia Holding) in September 2016 was allocated pro rata to the enterprise value of each CGU, as estimated based on the acquisition business plans for each CGU used within the scope of the purchase price accounting. Following the Group’s various acquisitions, goodwill allocated to each CGU can be analysed as follows:

Subsection Title: Goodwill Property Holding Management company** **Services CGU** **International CGU** **Group CGU
Subsubsection Text: Statement of financial position at 30 Sept. 2021 859 616 77 99 1,651 Allocation of holding company goodwill 620 223 15

For intangible assets identified during the purchase price accounting for Foncia Holding and subsequent material acquisitions, the allocation at 30 September 2021 is as follows (based on the carrying amount):  **Property Management France CGU: €354.7 million to the Foncia trademark and €321.6 million to client relationships;  **Property Management International CGU: €24.5 million to the Brolliet, Domicim, Trevi and Gribi trademarks and €9 million to client relationships;  **Services CGU: €43.9 million to the Foncia and Lodgis trademarks, €1 million to the Lodgis software and €42.8 million to client relationships. The holding company’s residual economic assets following the asset allocation shown above were allocated in full to the Property Management France CGU to reflect the cost allocation of the holding company used to draw up the business plans. The inputs used to estimate the carrying amount of the economic assets to be tested for impairment are shown below for each of the three CGUs. This estimate is based on the Group’s consolidated statement of financial position at a date close to the reporting date, showing: (i) the allocation of goodwill among the three CGUs, as presented above, and (ii) the allocation of the residual economic assets. |Goodwill|Col2| |---|---| |Property Holding Management company Services CGU International CGU Group CGU|| |Statement of financial position at 30 Sept. 2021 859 616 77 99 Allocation of holding company goodwill 620 223 15|1,651| |Goodwill by CGU 1,237 300 114|1,651| -----

Calculation of the recoverable amount of CGUs at 31 December 2021 In accordance with the Group’s impairment testing approach, and in the absence of observable fair values in an organised market, the recoverable amount of CGUs corresponds to their value in use, which is defined as the sum of their net cash flows based on the latest forecasts for each CGU, determined using: - a business plan prepared by management based on growth and profitability assumptions, taking into account past performance, forecast changes in the economic environment, and expected market trends; - a terminal value calculated by capitalising normative cash flows obtained by extrapolating cash flows from the final year of the business plan, with a stable growth rate or a growth rate increasing steadily over the long term; - expected cash flows discounted at a rate determined by reference to the weighted average cost of capital (WACC). The financial forecasts used in the impairment tests carried out at 31 December 2021 were prepared by management and cover a period of five years. They provide a consolidated view as well as a breakdown by CGU. It should be noted that all holding company expenses not allocated in the consolidated business plan were allocated in full to the Property Management France CGU. Corporate functions are managed at individual country-level for the Property Management International CGU and are considered not material for the Services CGU. The discount rate used is the weighted average cost of capital (WACC), calculated based on a sample of comparable European companies. A WACC was estimated for each foreign country and then calculated for the Emeria Group as a whole by weighting the cash flows of the French (Property Management France and Services CGUs) and ###### international (Property Management International CGU) operations. On this basis, a single post-IFRS 16 weighted discount rate of 7.1% was used for all of the Group’s CGUs. By way of reminder, a single pre-IFRS 16 weighted discount rate of 8% had been used for all of the Group’s CGUs in 2020.

As a reminder, the long-term growth rate used for the 2020 tests was also 2%. Finally, in order to take into account the impact of IFRS 16 on flows forecasts in the business plan and in particular estimate the future renewal of leases, the average age of the leases at 30 September 2021 and their useful life by asset class were used. A normative age per asset class was then determined in order to calculate a normative right-ofuse asset level. Renewal expenses relating to right-of-use assets in the business plan flows have therefore been captured in order to converge to the normative right-of-use asset level. Results of impairment tests Based on the impairment tests carried out, the value in use of each CGU exceeds the CGU’s carrying amount and as a result, no impairment needed to be recognised against the Group’s assets at 31 December 2021. Subsubsection Text: Trademarks **6,134** At the date on which Emeria (formerly Foncia Management) acquired a controlling interest in Emeria Holding (formerly Foncia Holding) (September 2016), the Foncia Group and Domicim trademarks were recognised at an amount of €405.7 million based on their valuations. The Group also estimated the value of the Brolliet trademark at CHF 13.7 million (i.e., €13.3 million at 31 December 2021), as well as the Lodgis, Gribi and Office des Propriétaires trademarks, at €2.3 million, €2.9 million and €1.9 million, respectively. Concessions, patents and software Concessions, patents and software mainly relate to IT investments made by the Group. At 31 December 2021, the carrying amount of this caption represents €33.4 million and the main contributors are Seiitra for €16 million, Emeria Europe for €11.4 million and Switzerland for €2.6 million. The investments made during the period (€4.7 million) mainly concern Seiitra (€3.2 million) for the upgraded Thetrawin modules (Powimo project), Switzerland (€0.9 million) and Germany (€0.4 million). Other changes amounting to €13.8 million chiefly concern the capitalisation of assets in progress by Emeria Europe (ongoing IT projects) and Seiitra (Powimo project). Client relationships Client relationships include the fair value of the mandates held by Group companies, initially valued during the September 2016 purchase price accounting (PPA) process and then during the PPAs for significant acquisitions made since that date. These client relationships had a total carrying amount of €444.7 million at 31 December 2021, following the valuation over the period of client relationships taken on as a result of the significant acquisitions made in 2020 and 2021 for a total of €84.4 million (including those relating to the IPF group for €12.8 million, Gérance de Passy for €12.1 million, Loft One for €11.4 million and Quenot for €8.3 million). Client relationships also include portfolios acquired since September 2016 as part of the Group’s acquisition-led growth strategy (jointly owned properties and managed rental properties), representing a total amount of €17.1 million. Investments in the period amounting to €6.1 million mainly concern the Gerancimmo portfolio for €2.1 million and Quenot (brokerage) for €1.2 million. ----- ###### Other intangible assets Other intangible assets essentially comprise the cost of acquiring new business. The €5.3 million increase in this item during the period reflects the capitalisation of the costs of acquiring new mandates, rebilled to other firms in the network. Decreases totalling €1.5 million relate to the retirement of these costs for lots that were not secured in the period. Intangible assets in progress Intangible assets in progress include various Group projects that can be capitalised. At 31 December 2021, the main contributors are Emeria Technologies for €52 million, Emeria Europe for €23.2 million and Seiitra for €4.2 million. Investments made during the period for a total amount of €37.8 million mainly concern Emeria Technologies for €18.7 million (Millénium), Emeria Europe for €13.1 million (mainly IT investments) and Seiitra for €2.8 million.

Most leases relate to Group business premises. These contracts are managed using a dynamic approach directly in line with the operating performance of the Group’s branch network and its real estate strategy. In France, around 998 property leases were included in this caption at 31 December 2021 (789 property leases at 31 December 2020), of which around 47% are automatically renewable. The main leases (in terms of rent) relate to the head office at Antony, Foncia Paris Rive Droite at 27 rue de Provence in Paris, Esset Management in Aubervilliers, Foncia Paris Rive Gauche at rue Raymond Losserand and Boulevard de Courcelles in Paris. Changes in the period can be explained as follows: ➢ new leases in France for €14.3 million, concerning a total of 133 new contracts; ➢ changes in the scope of consolidation, concerning 122 property leases taken on from the various companies acquired in the period, notably Loft One (€5.4 million) and the OP group in Belgium (€1.1 million). As a reminder, in May 2020 the Group signed a framework agreement with BNP Paribas for the lease of Apple equipment. In 2021, this agreement resulted in a €3 million increase in right-of-use assets. The project will be gradually rolled out over the next few years, with the roll-out slated for completion by the end of 2025. Finally, it should be noted that the renewal of the Arval car fleet has been pushed back to the first half of 2022. At 31 December 2021, the vehicles fleet consisted of 1,221 vehicles on the road. (1,338)| |Total lease liabilities|174,351|51,385 95,790 27,176| ----- is based on the prevailing operating and strategic environment at the reporting date and is reviewed each year by the Group’s Property division.  In the particular case of automatically renewable property leases in France, the Group now analyses the broader economics of a lease in determining its enforceable period pursuant to the IFRS IC’s 2020 agenda decision. A single reasonably certain term of three years is used to measure these leases. This estimate takes into account (i) the need for the business to continue operating which acts as an incentive to continue the initial lease, but also (ii) the Group’s strongly proactive and opportunistic real estate strategy in streamlining its property portfolio (notably during restructuring operations resulting from its acquisitions).  Under IFRS 16, the discount rate for each lease is to be determined by reference to the lessee’s incremental borrowing rate. In practice, given how the Group is organised financially, i.e., held or guaranteed almost exclusively by the three French holding companies, the Group adopted an incremental borrowing rate for all of its lease contracts (excluding vehicle leases), reflecting the Group’s own borrowing rate. Initially set at 3.25%, this rate was raised to 3.55% on 25 March 2021 following the Group’s debt refinancing operation. This new rate is therefore taken into account in valuing all leases from this date. The incremental borrowing rate corresponds to the sum of the risk-free rate and the Group’s credit spread over the life of the syndicated loan, without considering the term. The value of the vehicle fleet in France is estimated based on the interest rate implicit in the leases, as supplied by Arval, i.e., 2.56%. With regard to the other main assumptions and practical expedients: ######  The practical expedient exempting low-value or short-term leases has not been adopted by the Group.  Leases previously classified as finance leases under IAS 17 were classified as finance leases at 1 January 2019. To simplify, the residual useful life of these leases is calculated in the same way as under IAS 17. At 31 December 2021, there are no more IAS 17 leases.  Restoration costs: - Property leases: restoration costs are only calculated for major new leases, since it is difficult to reliably estimate such costs for all of the Group’s leases, as they are frequently negotiated with the lessor at the end of the lease. - Vehicle fleet: In France, the Group adopted an average cost of €700 per vehicle (cost plus 20% for private vehicles on which VAT cannot be recovered) in measuring the right-of-use asset corresponding to the residual value guarantee. This average cost was calculated based on a market estimate and taking into account the historical cost actually incurred when changing the automotive fleet at the beginning of 2019.  Deferred tax is recognised on the difference between the right-of-use asset and the lease liability falling within the scope of IFRS 16, in a similar way to that previously recognised for finance leases.  Services provided in relation to the lease are included in the calculation of right-of-use assets and lease liabilities on a case-by-case basis and by category of underlying asset. In particular, for the lease contract with BNP Paribas concerning Apple IT equipment, the Group has chosen not to separate the lease components from the service components, and therefore to consider all payments as relating to the lease. Right-of-use assets and lease liabilities must be calculated for both leases of equipment and for any services component. It should be noted that the Group was not concerned by any lease concessions in the period. -----

(40,412) 16,122 (90) 264 (170)|114,002| ----- The amounts of output and therefore input VAT (see Note 4.15) are significant, but decreased over the year following intra-group payment. As a reminder, the significant increase in other current receivables in 2020 was due to outstanding intra-group transactions. Thanks to the resolution of the technical difficulties encountered in Workday, intra-group settlements could be processed as from the second half of 2021. The change in CICE tax receivables (€8 million decrease) is mainly attributable to the partial reconstitution of the 2017 CICE tax receivable for €2 million due to due to it being over-used to pay 2020 income tax, and to the subsequent collection of the full amount for €9.5 million. This change also includes the partial use of the 2018 CICE tax receivable for €0.8 million to pay the four 2021 income tax instalments for the tax consolidation group. Note also that a 2018 CICE tax receivable was taken on from Loft One. Current accounts receivable at 31 December 2021 relate mainly to financing granted by the Group to companies in the process of being acquired and therefore not consolidated. In 2020, the outstanding amount included €12.6 million in current account advances granted to Loft One for the repayment of its bank debt. Other miscellaneous receivables include outstanding purchase consideration for €7.8 million. This item also includes receivables relating to the Assurance Privilège product for €2 million, and advances linked to client accounting (jointly owned properties and managed properties) for €1.4 million.

Deferred tax assets 51,710 7,412 (588) 158 1,684 (70,404) 42,189 32,161 Deferred tax liabilities 164,299 (4,034) 0 1,327 (166) 22,190 42,271 225,888 Revision of deferred tax positions During the year, the Group completed a review of the deferred tax bases presented in its financial statements. This exercise highlighted the need to revise the historical deferred tax assets recognised, in particular the tax assets generated in connection with cancellations in the statutory financial statements of goodwill (fonds de commerce) arising from acquisitions. The Group’s historical practice was to record a deferred tax asset on consolidation entries in connection with business combinations, in order to neutralise the goodwill recognised in the statutory financial statements. At 31 December 2020, the Group recognised €70.4 million of deferred tax assets on its statement of financial position linked to the neutralisation of goodwill, of which €5.5 million related to goodwill acquired between 2011 and 2016. For tax purposes, these items of goodwill are deductible if they are part of a divestment strategy pursued by the Group. As the Group does not intend to make similar divestments in the near future, the question is whether it is appropriate to maintain these deferred tax assets on the statement of financial position at their historical value. |Adjustment of Changes Changes recognised deferred taxes Deferred taxes 31 Dec. 2020 recognised through other Translation Change in scope Allocation of arising on the Other changes (€ thousands) (restated) through profit or comprehensive adjustments of consolidation goodwill neutralisation of loss income goodwill On temporary differences 5,633 794 (1,468) On tax and harmonisation adjustments (3,581) (537) (1,064) ( 54) 5,480 On elimination of intra-group gains and losses (605) (156) 1 (41) On restatement of employee benefit obligations 5,651 427 (588) 99 292 27 Capitalisation of tax loss carryforwards 5,376 (737) 28 Capitalisation of financial expenses 7,881 4,170 carried forward On IFRS fair value adjustments 154 329 On effective interest rate adjustments ( 65) (71) On remeasurement adjustments (100%) ( 158,466) 8,305 (212) (22,190) (48,858) On other adjustments 25,432 (1,079) 7 1,583 (70,404) 44,779 Net deferred tax position (112,589) 11,446 (588) (1,169) 1,850 (70,404) (22,190) (82) Deferred tax assets 51,710 7,412 (588) 158 1,684 (70,404) 42,189 Deferred tax liabilities 164,299 (4,034) 0 1,327 (166) 22,190 42,271|31 Dec. 2021| |---|---| ||4,959 246 (801) 5,908 4,667 12,051 483 (136) (221,420) 317 (193,726) 32,161 225,888| |Net deferred tax position (112,589) 11,446 (588) (1,169) 1,850 (70,404) (22,190) (82)|(193,726)| ----- Since these tax assets were recognised as part of business combinations within the meaning of IFRS 3, they were recorded against a reduction in goodwill. As a result, the assets were written down against a revaluation of the goodwill amounts calculated and recognised in the context of these acquisitions. The write-down of these tax assets in 2021 therefore resulted in: - a decrease of €70.4 million in deferred taxes; - an increase of €6.9 million in equity, reflecting the adjustment of the impact of the change in tax rate in 2018 and recognised at that time through the statement of profit and loss; - a resulting €77.3 million increase in goodwill (see Note 4.1). Several other presentation adjustments were also made during the year, the details of which are shown below: Cancellation of Offset of deferred Offset of offset of deferred

Deferred tax assets (4,012) (1,469) 47,406 244 42,169 Deferred tax liabilities (4,012) (1,469) 47,406 327 42,252 The adjustments mainly concern: - A deferred tax asset/liability offset on the acquisition fees of Emeria Europe (formerly Foncia Groupe) shares incurred in 2011 by Emeria Holding (formerly Foncia Holding) for a total amount of €15.5 million. From an accounting and tax perspective, these fees had been included in the value of Emeria Europe shares at Emeria Holding and deducted over a period of five years through the recognition of a tax-regulated provision. The fees in question had been reclassified to profit and loss in consolidation in accordance with IFRS 3, and a deferred tax asset recognised. This reclassification is designed to offset this deferred tax asset against the deferred tax liability arising on the neutralisation of the tax-regulated provision. - Deferred tax assets recognised in the statement of financial position up to 31 December 2020 in respect of the neutralisation of goodwill acquired as a result of external growth transactions. These deferred tax assets had been partly offset against deferred tax liabilities arising on remeasurement adjustments. Accordingly, they were reclassified in deferred taxes arising on other adjustments before being adjusted for a total amount of €70.4 million, mainly against goodwill (see above). Deferred tax on temporary differences This caption mainly concerns deferred tax on provisions for employee profit-sharing (€2.6 million) and paid leave (€1.1 million), and the tax treatment of share acquisition fees (€0.7 million). Deferred tax on tax adjustments This caption mainly relates to the tax on the restatement of IFRS 16 leases, and the cancellation of set-up costs and tax-regulated provisions. |Cancellation of Offset of deferred Offset of offset of deferred Deferred taxes tax on Emeria deferred tax on Other tax arising on (€ thousands) Holding acquisition exchange reclassifications neutralisation of fees differences goodwill|Breakdown of other changes| |---|---| |On temporary differences (1,469) 1 On tax and harmonisation adjustments 4,012 1,469 (21) On elimination of intra-group gains and losses (41) On restatement of employee benefit obligations 27 On remeasurement adjustments (100%) (48,859) 1 On other adjustments (4,012) 48,859 (49)|(1,468) 5,460 (41) 27 (48,858) 44,798| |Net deferred tax position (83)|(83)| |Deferred tax assets (4,012) (1,469) 47,406 244 Deferred tax liabilities (4,012) (1,469) 47,406 327|42,169 42,252| |Net deferred tax position (83)|(83)| ----- Capitalisation of tax loss carry-forwards Tax loss carry-forwards within the tax consolidation group at 31 December 2021 are as follows (after utilisation in the current period): - Loss arising on tax consolidation: €11.7 million. This tax loss has been recognised in full in view of the high probability that sufficient future taxable profit will exist against which it can be utilised. - Proprietary tax losses of consolidated companies (arising prior to joining the tax consolidation group): €30.3 million, of which €28.8 million not recognised due to the improbability that sufficient future taxable earnings will be available against which the losses could be utilised (of which Emeria Holding for €8.9 million, IDHA for €4.8 million, Syndic for €2.8 million, Bourgeois Immobilier for €2.7 million and Axium Développement et Participations for €1.8 million). At 31 December 2021, deferred tax assets recognised in respect of tax loss carry-forwards concern tax consolidation arrangements (€3 million), proprietary tax losses of companies in the tax consolidation group (€0.4 million), Yxime (€1.1 million) and Efficity (€0.3 million). Capitalisation of non-deducted financial expenses Additional deferred tax assets of €4.2 million were recognised during the year in respect of the tax consolidation interest carried forward for 2021 under ATAD I tax rules. As in 2019 and 2020, these deferred taxes were charged against the taxable temporary difference arising from the indefinite-lived Foncia trademark. Deferred taxes on remeasurement adjustments Deferred tax liabilities on remeasurement adjustments relate to the deferred tax on the Emeria (formerly Foncia Management) purchase price accounting (PPA) process in September 2016, as well as on trademarks and client relationships recognised since that date on significant acquisitions carried out by the Group. The €22.2 million change in the final allocation of goodwill corresponds to deferred tax recognised during the period following the valuation of the OP trademark in Belgium and of client relationships resulting from major acquisitions carried out in 2020 and 2021 (notably the IPF group, GDP, Loft One, Quenot, Valexim, Humakey and Yxime in the B2B segment). Deferred tax on other adjustments Changes in deferred taxes on other adjustments mainly concern the taxation of contingency provisions (provisions for third party/professional liability and for risks on client accounts), and deferred tax on the Worna LTIP and on adjustments to variables recognised in consolidation. -----

Dividends paid in the period amounting to €704,000 mainly concern profits paid out to non-controlling shareholders of Foncia Brette.

Subsection Title: Equity 4.10.1.** **Equity attributable to owners of the parent
Subsubsection Text: As described in the highlights section, on 16 November 2021 Emeria’s share capital was increased by converting into capital the PIK shareholder loan granted to it in September 2016 by Flamingo Lux II. Based on a value of €4.41 per share (after rounding), and with a par value of €1 per share, the associated amounts are as follows: - Number of new shares issued and subscribed by Flamingo Lux II: 23,146,682. - Share capital increase for a nominal amount of €23,146,682. - Total additional paid-in capital of €78,930,185.62. At 31 December 2021, Emeria SAS’ share capital therefore amounted to €593,688,196, comprising 593,688,196 shares, each with a par value of €1.

Details of the refinancing operation on 25 March 2021 are provided in the highlights section. As part of this operation, senior facility B was repaid in full for €1.2 billion, as well as the former revolving credit facility (RCF) for €120 million. An amount of €200 million was drawn on the new €437.5 million revolving credit facility at 31 December 2021 to finance the Group’s external growth investments. The PIK shareholder loan between Flamingo Lux II and Emeria was also repaid in full during the year: - in the context of the Group’s refinancing operation for €478 million; - in the context of TA Associates’ entry into the Group’s share capital in November 2021 for €111.6 million (including accrued interest), of which €9.5 million in cash and €102.1 million through conversion into Emeria’s share capital. Repayments of other borrowings and debt for €36 million correspond mainly to the repayment of bank loans of companies consolidated in the year, in particular IPF (€12.5 million), Valexim (€10.4 million), GDP (€3.2 million) and IAG (€1.4 million). Liabilities relating to put options on non-controlling interests Reciprocal put and call options were set up by the Group on Intercity in Switzerland (50% of the outstanding shares) and on Optissimmo (30% of the outstanding shares) in the context of these external growth transactions. Subsection Title: Total provisions for retirement benefits and other 30,052** **5,000** **81** **(3,213)** **(3,497)** **662** **1,880** **30,963 employee benefits

Subsubsection Text: The actuarial estimate of provisions for retirement benefits and long-service awards was based on the report drawn up by Mercer and Eactuary, the firms mandated to estimate post-employment benefit obligations for the entire Group. A provision is set aside for all outstanding obligations, estimated based on rights accrued and salary projections, taking into account mortality rates, employee turnover and a discount. As a reminder, in estimating its retirement benefit obligations for 2021, the Group has taken into account the new basis for attributing benefits prescribed by the IFRS IC in its May 2021 agenda decision. For France, the increase in provisions for retirement benefits is mainly attributable to the service cost totalling €1.6 million, reflecting the increase in the net obligation resulting from the contributions of Foncia personnel in 2021. The net actuarial gain of €0.6 million mainly consists of an actuarial gain of €1 million resulting from the increase in the discount rate over the period, and an actuarial loss of €0.4 million due to experience adjustments. These actuarial gains and losses are recognised in other comprehensive income within consolidated equity net of tax. The increase in long-service awards essentially results from €0.6 million in the service cost for 2021. As a reminder, obligations in respect of long-service awards are included within other long-term benefits in accordance with IAS 19. Any related actuarial gains and losses are taken to profit or loss in the period. Note that the take-up rate for longservice awards was maintained at 100%. In Switzerland, the increase in the net benefit obligation over the period is mainly due to: - a service cost representing CHF 3.7 million (€3.4 million); - a net actuarial gain of CHF 3.1 million, reflecting: - an actuarial gain of CHF 1.9 million owing to the increase in the discount rate from 0.14% to 0.30%, - a loss of CHF 4.8 million owing to lower-than-expected returns on plan assets, - a gain of CHF 2.4 million arising on experience adjustments, - a gain of CHF 3.6 million arising on demographic assumptions due to the significant reduction in the number of employees at DBS and Gribi (591 versus 635 in 2020); - a scope impact with regard to the obligations arising from acquisitions carried out in Switzerland, namely €1.1 million for Intercity, €0.4 million for Contrust, and €0.2 million for BG SA. |Interest cost net of Employee benefits 31 Dec. 2020 Contributions paid Actuarial gains and Exchange Change in scope Service cost the return on plan (€ thousands) (restated) in the period losses differences of consolidation assets France 14,506 1,561 57 (442) (607) 131 Belgium 33 Switzerland 14,413 3,439 23 (2,752) (2,890) 662 1,749 Germany 1,100 (19) Total provisions for retirement benefits and other 30,052 5,000 81 (3,213) (3,497) 662 1,880 employee benefits France 6,727 640 25 (297) 134 (7) Total provisions for long-service awards 6,727 640 25 (297) 134 (7) Total employee benefits 36,779 5,639 106 (3,510) (3,363) 662 1,873|31 Dec. 2021| |---|---| ||15,206 33 14,643 1,081| ||30,963| ||7,221| ||7,221| ||38,184| ----- Calculation assumptions used Actuarial calculations are based on a number of long-term assumptions that are reviewed on an annual basis.

Provisions for risks on client accounts Main changes during the year: - reclassification of a third party and professional liability dispute at Axium Immodonia for €0.9 million (presented in other changes); - risks assumed as a result of acquisitions in 2020 and 2021 for a total provisioned amount of €3.6 million, of which €3.2 million represents identified contingent risks estimated in consolidation only. The main risks assumed relate to GDP for €0.9 million, La Régionale Immobilière for €0.4 million, Foncia Saint-Louis for €0.4 million and SGIA for €0.2 million. It should also be noted that at 31 December 2020, this item included €0.3 million in contingency provisions booked at the time of the Esset Management acquisition in 2016. Following an analysis of client accounts, these provisions were written back in full during the year, with the resulting net €0.3 million impact recognised within non-recurring items. Provisions for third party and professional liability Taking into account the reclassification of the provision at Axium for €0.9 million (presented in other changes), the balance of this item is €0.8 million lower at 31 December 2021 versus end-2020, due mainly to the net reversals recorded during the period. The main reversals concern Axium for €0.3 million and Esset Management for the |Provisions|Col2| |---|---| |Additions Reversals Provisions Translation Change in scope Other 31 Dec. 2020 (€ thousands) adjustments of consolidation changes Current Non-current Current Non-current|31 Dec. 2021| |Provisions for risks on client accounts 6,429 250 1,293 (494) (2,009) 3,632 (855) Provisions for third party and professional 5,161 1,098 112 (1,679) (535) 149 874 liability Provisions for URSSAF social security audits 319 181 (106) Provisions for other disputes 3,889 487 274 (760) (398) 64 893 (120) Provisions for occupancy guarantees 1,041 142 30 (257) (30) 2 Provisions for tax contingencies 372 (22) (350) Other provisions for expenses 2,080 666 1,545 (529) (852) (1)|8,246 5,180 394 4,328 928 2,909| |Non-current provisions 19,298 2,643 3,435 (3,741) (4,280) 64 4,674 (100)|21,991| |Provisions for rent payment guarantees 4,582 692 104 (1,087) (99) 12 32 134 Provisions for employee disputes 4,653 616 714 (1,880) (579) 624 (13)|4,371 4,135| |Current provisions 9,235 1,308 818 (2,967) (678) 12 656 121|8,506| |Total provisions 28,533 3,951 4,253 (6,708) (4,958) 76 5,330 21|30,497| ----- CDC VAT dispute, the provision for which was written back in full at 31 December 2021 (€0.3 million written back during the year). Provisions for other disputes In France, this item mainly includes the provision for the Corum dispute for €0.6 million (unchanged over the year) as well as the provision for disputes with franchisees for €0.1 million (€0.4 million written back over the period). Note that the Group took on certain risks representing €0.8 million as a result of acquisitions, mainly concerning IPF for €0.5 million and risks in progress at Foncia Méditerranée for €0.2 million. Outside France, this item chiefly concerns Switzerland for €1.5 million, where the miscellaneous long-standing risks are monitored by the local management team. A net reversal of €0.2 million was recorded during the period. - Update on the dispute with franchisees By way of a reminder, in 2014 franchisees had brought proceedings against the Group after receiving notice that their contracts would not be renewed. They accused the Group of wrongful termination and various breaches of the franchise agreements. Of the 21 initial lawsuits, the Group either settled (most sensitive disputes), or won (before the lower court, on appeal or before the French Supreme Court [Cour de cassation]) the cases. Today, only two disputes are still outstanding, as the franchisees have appealed to the Supreme Court. These disputes concern an amount of €937,000. - Update on the Corum dispute After having terminated its distribution agreement with Primaliance, Corum, a property manager, brought proceedings against Primaliance for trademark infringement for continuing to list the real estate investment trust (SCPI) Corum Origin on its website, www.primaliance.com. The dispute is in progress before the courts. The Group maintained its €0.6 million provision in this respect and did not transfer it to Primaliance when the latter was sold to Bienprévoir.fr. Oral arguments were heard before the court on 21 October 2021. Provisions for other contingencies and expenses These provisions mainly concern: - risks related to commercial leases in France regarding the retroactive removal of rent caps (€0.4 million at 31 December 2021). Note that a net amount of €0.4 million was written back from this provision over the year, mainly in relation to the lease at 7 Rue des Belges in Cannes held by Foncia AD Immobilier, for which the risk of rent cap removal is no longer relevant; - a €0.4 million provision for losses arising on the 2020 Yxime acquisition and relating to outstanding expenses on the Tour Ciel lease at La Défense, which management decided to terminate early at the time of the acquisition. A net reversal of €0.4 million was booked during the year; - a provision for accrued expenses recognised for €0.7 million during the year in respect of AGEFIPH expenses that will actually be incurred in 2022. Provisions for rent payment guarantees The provision for rent payment guarantees remained broadly stable between 2021 and 2020, reflecting (i) a growth effect, driving an upward trend in the provision, and (ii) a post-Covid effect, with the end of the “winter truce” (tenant protection period during winter months applicable in France) as of 31 March 2021. It should be recalled that the amount of the provision set aside by the Group increases in line with the age of the unpaid receivable. Provisions for rent payment guarantees are calculated by reference to late payments relating to current and former lessees, regardless of whether or not lessee statement of accounts (Arrêtés des Comptes _Locataires – ACL) have been drawn up, taking into account the probability of collection (assessed on a statistical basis_ and regularly updated). ----- Provisions for employee disputes In France, the provision remained stable in 2021 at €3.7 million, and concerned 128 lawsuits at end-December compared to 101 at 31 December 2020. Out of the 128 lawsuits in progress, 26 relate to amounts in excess of €0.1 million. The decrease over the period is mainly due to Germany where, as a reminder, provisions had been booked in 2020 for ongoing restructuring for a total amount of €1 million, of which €0.7 million was reversed over the period.

Earn-out liabilities An earn-out clause was set up in first-half 2018 with the founders and key managers of Efficity. The additional consideration payable is calculated based on the value creation generated by the business (EBITDA multiple). At 31 December 2021, Efficity’s earn-out liability amounted  to  €54 million  (compared  with  €28.1 million  at 31 December 2020). Profit-sharing This item includes the provision for LBO bonuses (see Note 2.4). Profit-sharing liabilities in France also increased by €1 million due to the impact of acquisitions. VAT In France, the VAT item remains significant at €80.2 million, but is still down by €20.6 million compared to end-2020, mainly due to the intra-group payments made during the year. As a reminder, this item had significantly increased in 2020 due to outstanding intra-group transactions which automatically inflated the output (and therefore input) VAT positions. Other miscellaneous payables Other miscellaneous payables include €18.7 million in outstanding purchase consideration payable (the net balance represents a liability of €10.8 million), €2.5 million in payables in respect of client accounting in France  and €1.5 million in miscellaneous payables due to various firms. Accounting for client accounts is a separate and autonomous form of accounting. At 31 December 2021, the balance of client accounts and “Article 55” transaction accounts therefore represents all of the transactions carried out for each client account. This balance totalled €572 million, reported under assets and liabilities in the statement of financial position at 31 December 2021. France’s ALUR law requires the use of separate accounts (opened in the name of the joint owners) for jointly owned properties comprising more than 15 main lots as from 1 April 2015. Accordingly, these separate accounts are not reflected in the statement of financial position. The ordinance dated 31 October 2019 now requires separate accounts to be established for all jointly owned properties by 31 December 2021 at the latest. Accordingly, client funds held in respect of jointly owned properties will gradually disappear as these separate joint ownership and individual accounts are closed. All accounts have been opened, including some just before the end of the year. Consequently, the transfers to certain accounts have not yet been made. In accordance with IAS 32 and IFRS 9, which set out the rules for measuring and recognising financial instruments, instruments with a positive fair value are recognised in assets and those with a negative fair value are recognised in liabilities. Fair values of financial instruments are provided by the financial institutions with which the transactions are carried out.

At 31 December 2021, the Group was no longer hedged on its debt as the cap put in place on 3 September 2020 setting the maximum 3-month Euribor rate at 1% expired in September 2021. The unwinding of this hedge has no impact on the 2021 financial statements as its fair value was zero at the date that it expired given the negative interest rate environment.
As from 29 June 2018, the Group no longer has any financial instruments hedging its foreign exchange risk.

In 2021, the Property Management business in France represents 57% of the Group’s total revenue. This reflects a net increase of €77.3 million (13.3%) over the period, mainly due to the impact of consolidating companies acquired in 2021, as well as the embedded impact of companies consolidated in 2020. The Covid-19 health crisis continued to weigh on the rental management business (essentially affecting amounts collected under commercial leases and incidental fees) as well as on letting activities and incidental fees earned on jointly owned properties (fees on transfer duties, reminders, renovation work and vacancies). Revenue for the Transactions business grew by €31.6 million, or 25.3%, compared to 2020. After a sluggish market in 2020, the business saw a record number of sales in France in 2021. |Revenue 2021 2020 (€ thousands) Property Management 657,098 579,833 % total revenue 57% 60% Of which rental management and 318,002 283,579 lettings Of which joint property 332,740 290,441 management Of which Foncia Croissance 2,539 1,912 Of which client accounts 3,817 3,901 Transactions (French network) 156,608 125,015 % total revenue 14% 13% Digital business 65,129 42,838 % total revenue 6% 4% Of which Efficity 58,737 37,125 Of which Lodgis 5,285 4,754 Of which Leemo 959 Of which Optissimmo 1,107 Other activities 114,445 87,812 % total revenue 10% 9% Of which B2B 51,559 34,471 Of which Assurimo 27,504 24,588 Of which Constatimmo 13,431 11,902 Of which Seiitra 15,045 12,945 Of which Foncia Valorisation 3,267 2,478 Of which Prowen 478 556 Of which Htm28 214 Of which Tech-way 2,865 746 Of which other 82 126 Total – France 993,280 835,498 % total revenue 87% 87%|Change| |---|---| ||77,265 34,423 42,299 627 (84) 31,593 22,291 21,612 531 (959) 1,107 26,633 17,088 2,916 1,529 2,100 789 (78) 214 2,119 (44)| ||157,782| ||| |Of which Switzerland 73,105 67,293 Of which Benelux 26,223 14,766 Of which Germany 54,224 43,986|5,812 11,457 10,238| |Total – International 153,552 126,045|27,507| |% total revenue 13% 13%|| ||| |Total revenue 1,146,832 961,543|185,289| ----- Buoyed by an upbeat Transactions market, the Digital business posted significant net revenue growth of €22.3 million on the back of a good performance from Efficity (€21.6 million). The €26.7 million increase in revenue from the “Other activities” segment in France is mainly attributable to the B2B business following the acquisitions of Cogeva and Humakey in 2021 (representing €13.8 million in revenue) and to good business momentum at Assurimo, driven by the growth in the number of comprehensive homeowners’ insurance policies. Revenue for the International business grew by €27.5 million and mainly derives from acquisitions carried out by the Group in Germany and Belgium. Operations in Switzerland was affected by the health crisis, particularly in the Transactions business.

Subsubsection Text: It should be recalled that following the acquisition of Emeria Holding (formerly Foncia Holding) by Emeria (formerly Foncia Management) on 7 September 2016, a new tax group was formed, effective as of 1 January 2017. The new group opted for a tax loss carry-forward system along the lines of the former tax consolidation group, but with a broader scope. The current tax expense for the tax consolidation group for 2021 amounts to €0.5 million (versus a €0.2 million tax saving in 2020 corresponding to philanthropy tax credits provisioned by Emeria Europe and Emeria Technologies). Current income tax expense excluding the tax consolidation group essentially concerns companies acquired in 2021 for €2.3 million, Efficity for €1.5 million and Foncia Brette for €0.3 million. Current income tax expense for foreign companies relates to Belgium for €0.9 million and Switzerland for €0.6 million. The decrease in the CVAE tax on value added in 2021 is mainly due to the reduction in the tax rate (50%). Net deferred tax income in the period mainly results from the decrease in deferred tax liabilities relating to the amortisation of remeasurement adjustments, along with the capitalisation of tax on non-deducted financial expenses within the scope of the Anti-Tax Avoidance Directive (ATAD I). |Of which other Of which other non- Other financial income and expenses 2020 2021 monetary financial monetary financial (€ thousands) (restated) income (expenses) income (expenses)|Change| |---|---| |Foreign exchange gains (losses) 301 301 28 Net interest cost on pension and other employee benefit 148 148 (272) obligations Capital gains (losses) on financial disposals less costs 6 ( 13) 19 (10) to sell Net impairment of financial assets 517 517 (920) Gains (losses) on available-for-sale financial assets 60 60 105 Discounting cost, net (1,274) (1,274) 326 Other financial income and expenses (1,485) ( 1,414) (71) (351)|272 420 16 1,437 (45) (1,600) (1,135)| |Other financial income and expenses (1,728) (1,066) (662) (1,093)|(635)| |Of which other financial income 6,781 5,801 1,048 808 Of which other financial expenses (8,509) (6,867) (1,709) (1,901)|5,973 (6,608)| |Income tax benefit (expense) 2020 2021 (€ thousands) (restated)|Change| |---|---| |Current tax expense excluding CVAE tax on value added (6,031) (2,352) Of which income tax expense relating to the tax consolidation (503) 207 group Of which reclassification of provision for Esset Management tax 43 Of which income tax expense excluding the tax consolidation group (4,149) (1,097) Of which income tax expense relating to foreign companies (1,379) (1,505) Of which CVAE tax on value added in France (6,312) (10,397) Deferred taxes 11,446 10,027|405 (710) (43) (3,052) 125 4,085 1,420| |Income tax benefit (expense) (897) (2,722)|1,825| -----

It should be recalled that since non-deducted financial expenses within the scope of ATAD I may be carried forward indefinitely, they were capitalised in the year (see Note 4.8 on deferred taxes). Only non-deducted financial expenses falling within the scope of the new Anti-Tax Avoidance Directive (ATAD II) are classified as permanent differences. These tax rules came into force on 1 January 2020 (transposition of ATAD II into French law) and concern “hybrid”type arrangements that generate mismatches in tax treatments between two jurisdictions. As the shareholder loan between Flamingo Lux and Emeria falls within the scope of this Directive, 26.25% of interest expenses paid by Emeria were added back to profit for tax purposes during the year, i.e., €6.2 million in respect of 2021.

Update on the UFC-Que Choisir (UFC) dispute On 1 October 2014, UFC-Que Choisir (UFC) brought proceedings against Foncia Groupe before the Nanterre Tribunal _de Grande Instance (regional court) seeking damages for losses allegedly suffered by lessees of Foncia-managed_ properties who were unduly charged for receiving notices to pay (avis d’échéance). More specifically, UFC is seeking payment from Foncia Groupe of an amount of €2.30 per month and per lessee over a period of five years and estimates the number of lessees concerned at 318,400, bringing the total damages to €44 million. In its defence, the Group argues that the French law of 6 July 1989 on residential lease agreements, upon which basis UFC filed its claim, made no provision for class actions at the time of the alleged offence; that no law existed preventing lessees being charged for receiving notices to pay; and that this was therefore a lawful practice. Oral arguments were exchanged before the Nanterre _Tribunal de Grande Instance in March 2018. The decision handed down in May 2018 dismissed UFC’s claims on the grounds that they fell outside the scope of a class action. UFC appealed this decision. In its ruling of 20 May 2021, the court of appeal dismissed all of UFC’s claims and ordered it to pay the Group €10,000 under Article 700 of the French Code of Civil Procedure (Code de procédure civil). UFC has appealed the decision before the French Supreme Court. The brief for UFC before the French Supreme Court was filed on 26 November 2021. The Group considers that no provision needs to be accrued in this respect in its financial statements at 31 December 2021. -----

Emeria Group enters the UK market Emeria’s March 2022 acquisition of FirstPort, the UK’s leading residential property services company, marks a further stage in its international development strategy. FirstPort operates in England, Scotland and Wales, employing more than 4,000 people and with €120 million in revenue. FirstPort specialises in the jointly owned property management business, and is also present in the rental management and transactions markets. The acquisition of FirstPort marks an important milestone in Emeria’s value creation journey, and will help the Group become the world’s leading residential real estate services company. The aim in entering the UK is to become the leader in the three biggest European markets of the UK, France and Germany. Emeria share capital increase On 14 March 2022, Emeria carried out a share capital increase in cash for a total nominal amount of €17,810,645.88 in favour of its sole shareholder, Flamingo Lux II SCA. This capital increase was carried out with no issue premium by increasing the par value of each of its 593,688,196 existing ordinary shares from €1 to €1.03. The cash payment by Flamingo Lux II SCA was made on the same day. New interest rate hedge Following the March 2021 refinancing operation, the Group acquired two interest rate cap agreements in January 2022 for a total amount of €4.2 million. These two instruments have the following characteristics: - Cumulative notional amount: €1,148 million. - Floating rate hedged: 3-month Euribor. - Hedged rate: maximum rate of 1%. - Start: 24 January 2022. - Expiry: 27 December 2024. These two caps allow the Group to protect itself against the risk of a rise in the 3-month Euribor on the equivalent of half of its refinanced debt. The fair value of these caps represented €14.7 million at 31 March 2022. Ukraine crisis Russia’s invasion of Ukraine in February 2022 has important ramifications for financial markets and the price of certain commodities, and will impact the entire global economy. Although the Group has no direct exposure to the Ukraine or Russian markets, it continues to closely monitor the conflict’s development. The indirect consequences of the crisis on the Group’s activities (and its clients) remain difficult to assess at this stage. -----
